HEADLINE: Greenspan's Remarks Send Stocks Higher

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Despite a report that the nation's confidence in the economy had fallen this month, stock and bond traders had their ears cocked for only one man's opinion yesterday, and Alan Greenspan did not disappoint.
When Mr. Greenspan told Congress he saw an economy with inflation at 3 percent or less, low long-term interest rates, as well as steady expansion, all the leading stock markets and the bond market rallied. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 24.20 points yesterday, to 3,911.66, and the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index was up 3.77 points, to 471.46. The smaller-stock Nasdaq composite index rose 2.30 points, to 791.15.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite index rose 1.61 points, to 261.48, on volume of 270.9 million shares. Advancing stocks outnumbered declining stocks by 1,139 to 1,003. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.43 points, to 472.38.
 
Economically Sensitive Stocks
 The rally benefited economically sensitive stocks like Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing and Caterpillar; interest-sensitive stocks like Pacific Gas and Electric and the Texas Utilities Company, as well as high-technology stocks like Intel and Apple Computer.
The price of gold, a familiar inflation indicator, declined and the dollar, a more recent inflation gauge, fell, too. Currency traders slowed their buying of dollars when Mr. Greenspan seemed to indicate that he planned no immediate increases in interest rates, diminishing the dollar's appeal.
Yet traders ignored the flip side of Mr. Greenspan's remarks: short-term rates are more likely to rise than fall. And the Fed will not announce its next move, as it did when it increased short-term rates on Feb. 4, rattling the bond and stock markets.
Traders also ignored an indicator that is designed to speak for millions more people than Mr. Greenspan. The Conference Board, a private business-research group, said yesterday that consumer confidence in the economy in February had fallen for the first time in three months, based on a survey of 5,000 households.
But traders apparently heard what they wanted to hear in Mr. Greenspan's testimony, analysts said. "The markets are in a spook mode," said Michael G. McGlone, a bond options trader at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company. "He didn't say anything new, so he didn't spook the markets."
Alfred E. Goldman, director of stock market analysis at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis, said, "What Greenspan said was very good for interest-sensitive stocks, the best of all possible worlds, in fact." "If the market had plunged further," he said, referring to the 96-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average on Feb. 4, "then the rally would have been even stronger."
The Dow industrials, the most scrutinized stock indicator, is still nearly 67 points below its peak of 3,978.36, reached on Jan. 31, and 56 points below 3,967.66, its Feb. 3 peak just before the Fed's quarter-point increase in short-term rates.
 
Dow Industrial Issues
 Seventeen of the 30 component stocks of the Dow industrials rose in price, with three stocks contributing as much as 15 points to the rise. Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing rose 2 3/4, to 107 3/4. Caterpillar rose 2 1/2, to 110 5/8, and Procter & Gamble rose 1 1/2, to 58 7/8.
The most actively traded stock yesterday was the American depository receipts of British Petroleum, which rose 3/4, to 64. 5/8. A British Petroleum A.D.R. equals 12 ordinary B.P. shares. Chevron, the operator of a project of which British Petroleum is a major partner, said yesterday that a Papua New Guinea, site showed signs of oil and gas. Some 18.8 million A.D.R.'s of British Petroleum were traded yesterday.
The second-most-active stock, at 7.5 million shares, was Novell, a computer-networking company. It rose 5/8, to 24 1/2, in part because of an inexpensive $300 computer networking kit that might expand Novell's market.

HEADLINE: Fund for Neediest Lags; Forgotten by Delayers?

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
As The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund enters its last week, dozens of readers have suddenly begun to heed the gnomic six-word warning, "To delay may mean to forget," that has served as the fund's unofficial motto for decades.
The maxim is usually included in small lettering at the end of articles about contributors to the fund or about the assistance the fund gives to hundreds of thousands of indigent New Yorkers every year. 
 While it may seem inconspicuous, it has registered in the minds of many contributors, who quote it in their letters as if it were an 11th commandment, against procrastination.
" 'To delay may mean to forget,' and I nearly did," wrote Janet L. Schultz, who was raised in Los Angeles but spent seven years in New York City as a graduate student at Columbia University.
Ms. Schultz, now a post-graduate fellow in genetics at the University of Oregon in Eugene, sent $50 to do her part. "I get such hope for humanity reading the articles about how people are helped by this fund," she wrote.
She added yesterday that she has contributed for several years but forgot to give last year in what she called "a classic case of procrastination."
"I had a baby in October, and the time got away from me," she said. "But this year, I told myself that I wouldn't let it get by."
Some late givers have gotten an early start learning about timeliness: "I'm Alessandro Presti, I'm 8 years old and I live in Brooklyn," wrote one recent contributor. "I'm sorry I'm sending this 50 dollars late, but I haven't forgotten. For Christmas my grandmother sent me 100 dollars, and I would like to share it with a person who needs it."
 
The Times Pays Expenses
 As in the past, The Times is paying the campaign's overhead so that every dollar collected can be passed on directly to seven social-service agencies. The money finances many forms of relief, including food for the hungry and shelter for the homeless. The charities also use the money to provide medical care to poor children, pregnancy-prevention workshops for teen-agers and home helpers that enable the disabled and elderly to remain in their homes.
Already during this campaign, three men who were unemployed for several months found jobs shortly after their stories were included in The Times.
But the fund, now in its 82d year, remains about $90,000 behind where it was last year at this time, endangering its ability to help the charities to maintain even their current services. With the continued generosity of donors from around the country, the gap can still be bridged before the campaign ends on Sunday.
It will, however, take realizations like the one that occurred to Matthew H. Klein of Monmouth Beach, N.J., early this month when he sent $25 to the fund and wrote: "You're right. I've put it off too long."
Or the one that occurred to Anne Jackson, the actress, when she read a story about a contributor who, to spur giving, quoted Samuel Johnson: "Let him that desires to see others happy make haste to give while his gift can be enjoyed, and remember that every moment of delay takes away something from the value of his benefaction."
In appreciation, Ms. Jackson matched the contributor's gift of $75.

HEADLINE: Albert T. Sommers, 74, Analyst Of Shifts in American Economy

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Albert T. Sommers, an analyst of national economic trends, died on Sunday in Boca Raton, Fla., where he was vacationing. He was 74 and lived in Manhasset, L.I.
He suffered a heart attack on a tennis court on Feb. 7, his family said. 
 Mr. Sommers strove to explain the mysteries of business cycles, statistics and the volatile changes at work in vital economic forces. He took a historical perspective, set the American economy into a worldwide context and explored the the social, political and ethical pressures that influence -- and inhibit -- economic performance.
Since 1950 he was associated with the Conference Board, a nonprofit business research organization supported mostly by American corporations and trade associations. He started as a senior economist, was director of economic research from 1961 until 1972, and was senior vice president and chief economist from then until 1985. Since then he was senior fellow and economic counselor to the Board.
 
Published The Sommers Letter
 One of Mr. Sommers's principal vehicles was The Sommers Letter, which he started in 1981 to present the outlook on financial, industrial and policy matters.
Mr. Sommers wrote many books and articles published by the Conference Board and elsewhere. His book "The U.S. Economy Demystified," written with Lucie R. Blau, was issued by Macmillan in 1992 and went into a third updated edition last year.
Albert Trumbull Sommers was born in Milford, Conn., graduated from Columbia University and served with the United States Army in World War II. He earned a master's degree at New York University in 1949.
In his years with the Conference Board, he advised hundreds of companies on economic conditions and what was ahead for them and the United States economy. Along the way he won top professional honors in his field.
He served on numerous panels and advisory boards and as an economic adviser to the Ford Foundation, the American Express Company and Bankers Trust Company, among others. In 1979 and 1980 he was chairman of the price advisory committee to the Carter Administration's Council on Wage and Price Stability. At the time of his death he was the president of Albert T. Sommers & Company, a business consulting firm he founded in 1980.
He was a director of several industrial and financial institutions and of the National Bureau of Economic Research, a fellow of the National Association of Business Economists and a former member of the Columbia University economics faculty.
Among the publications he wrote or edited were: "Reconstructing the Federal Budget: A Trillion-Dollar Quandary" (1984), "Understanding the GNP: Keeping Track of the U.S. Economy" (1983), "U.S. Economic Policy Issues in the 1980's" (1981), "A Collision of Ethics and Economics" (1978) and "The Balanced Federal Budget: An Orthodoxy in Trouble" (1978).
Mr. Sommers is survived by his wife of 47 years, Jean Marvin Sommers; a daughter, Elizabeth Sommers Strevey of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and a son, John, of Oakland, Calif.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher In Carry-Over From Holiday

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against most foreign currencies, but the gains in the United States reflected those made overseas on Monday, when the New York financial markets were closed in observance of Washington's Birthday.
Moreover, the American currency failed to gain any additional strength from yesterday's Congressional testimony by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. 
 Mr. Greenspan said real short-term interest rates were more likely to rise than to fall in the period ahead. He also said evidence was mounting that the economic recovery was well entrenched.
 In his testimony, Mr. Greenspan gave no hint of when another interest rate increase was coming. The dollar rose three weeks ago when the Fed nudged up rates. Higher rates make the dollar more attractive relative to other currencies.
 "The dollar picked up overnight, but we've been slowly selling off ever since," said Bruce English, head of institutional sales at ABN-AMRO.
 The report of a drop in the consumer confidence index, to 80.8 in February from 82.6 in January, also put a lid on dollar buying yesterday.
 The dollar posted strong gains against the German mark and the Japanese yen overnight and in early United States trading amid reports that the Bank of Japan bought dollars overseas. The dollar retreated, however, on sales by Japanese exporters.
 Dealers also cited talk that European central banks were selling the dollar at about 1.7300 marks in afternoon trading in the United States.
 In late New York trading, the dollar was at 106.65 yen, up from 104.61 on Friday. It rose to 1.7255 marks, from 1.7133 marks Friday.
 Gold prices slipped from Friday's levels. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for April delivery fell $2.40, to $379.20 an ounce.
Also in New York, the British pound was quoted at $1.4785, down from $1.4825 on Friday.
Other late dollar rates, compared with Friday's quotes, included: 1.4495 Swiss francs, up from 1.4425; 5.8625 French francs, up from 5.8238; 1.3383 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3427, and 1,677 Italian lire, up from 1,666.

HEADLINE: In Hell's Kitchen, Savory Temptations

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL 

 BODY:
The temperature is rising in Hell's Kitchen. After nearly a decade, its main thoroughfare, the stretch of Ninth Avenue between 35th and 55th Streets, is emerging from the gray chrysalis of economic woe to beckon diners and shoppers back to its crumbling sidewalks, its venerable groceries and a new generation of restaurants.
Former hardware stores have been reincarnated as fancy bakeries, former smoke shops have become Afghan and Caribbean restaurants, and mom-and-pop cafes have been reborn as -- is it possible? -- trendy restaurants. 
 In the last two years, nearly 30 restaurants have opened in the area. The catalysts for the changes are low rents, easy access to Broadway and Off Broadway theaters and a flood of new businesses like film editing studios, publishing and advertising concerns and architectural, design and photography studios. In addition, blocks of brownstones have been gentrified and acres of former garment factories have been converted to residential lofts. In a decade, four high-rises have been built in the area as housing for some 20,000 well-educated professionals.
"There's a lot of energy, and you can feel a change," said Joan McNaughton, who has lived in the neighborhood for three years and is one of the four partners who opened the restaurant Revolution in November. "We chose the name because it's a borderline neighborhood, with a past, and there is a definite circular motion: it's revolving back to being vital and lively."
Sidewalk traffic is heavier, restaurants are more crowded and in early evening brings delivery bicycle gridlock. Relative newcomers fear the kind of nonstop chic that conquered Columbus Avenue. But longtime residents are unfazed. Hell's Kitchen is eternal, they say.
"Call it Clinton, the Lower West Side, Ninth Avenue, Paddy's Market," said Lili Fable, whose husband's family has owned the Poseidon Bakery on Ninth Avenue for 50 years, referring to the names of different parts of the area from 34th to 57th Streets, between Ninth and 12th Avenues. "It's all Hell's Kitchen. Like I told the guy who tried to open the pornography shop next door to the bakery, 'We serve food, not filth, in Hell's Kitchen.' "
By any name, Ninth Avenue has been to New York what Les Halles was to Paris: a breadbasket, an international bazaar and a seedy stretch. The neighborhood still has a lot of traffic, which means a lot of potential customers, as well as a large and mostly unskilled immigrant population eager to work, said Sal Dell'Orto, whose father opened Manganaro Groceria, an Italian grocery and restaurant on Ninth Avenue, almost a century ago.
And Hell's Kitchen is still an intimate neighborhood. "If I need to borrow a bottle of this or that, I run across the street," said Richard Gusoff, who opened Pietrasanta six years ago and Rachel's, a French bistro, last fall. "If the guys at the Japanese restaurant need a couple extra chairs, they run down and borrow them from me. There's more camaraderie than competition."
Recently opened food stores -- including African Imports, which sells books, crafts and specialty food products, and the Halal Meat Market, with meat that satisfies Islamic dietary law in the cases up front and prayer rooms in back -- reflect an eternal fact of Ninth Avenue: it is a major thoroughfare, running through a United Nations of a neighborhood.
Other new groceries and specialty stores suggest that the hardscrabble neighborhood is becoming better-heeled. Natura, a grocery that opened two years ago, has a cheese section to rival that of Fairway Market on the Upper West Side. Two recently opened bakeries, St. Famous and Amy's, turn out the crusty rolls and seeded buns, breadsticks and focaccia that nouveaux epicureans crave.
The Hell's Kitchen restaurant boom also reflects the old and the new. In lower Hell's Kitchen, Philippine Fast Food serves hefty portions of kare-kare, a meat and vegetable stew with peanut sauce and thick rice soup as solid and old-fashioned as the Italian food across the avenue at Supreme Macaroni. Around the corner on 39th, Rinconcito Mexicano, a cafeteria, serves authentic Mexican peasant food to crowds of Mexicans who do piecework in the garment district.
Up the avenue, Marta Lemos, a Brazilian cook with an Italian flair, has set up shop under an awning that reads "Rice and Beans Restaurant." At lunch, her black bean soup, beef stew and country chicken lure cabdrivers, neighbors and a "nanny brigade" pushing strollers.
In addition to the authentic flavors and humble prices, the restaurants have an intriguing only-in-New York clientele. The casts and crews from nearby theaters and local residents (some retired, some very young) turn the better dining rooms into a demographer's dream. "Where else in New York are you going to get Chita Rivera at one table, MacNeil of 'MacNeil/Lehrer' at another, and the solid middle-class people who live here at another?" asked Antonios Manatakis, who opened Uncle Nick's, a Greek restaurant, four months ago on 51st Street near Ninth Avenue.
A similar crowd packs the Afghan restaurants that have sprouted along the avenue. Of them, the oldest, Afghan Kebab House, which opened four years ago, continues to turn out the most succulent chicken and lamb kebabs. But a newcomer, Ariana Afghan Kebab, is vying for best Afghan in Hell's Kitchen with delicious appetizers like leeks and lamb, mashed potato and pumpkin turnovers with yogurt sauce and spicy dumplings with yogurt and lamb sauce.
Appetizers are the mainstay of a spate of Middle Eastern restaurants that have claimed former shoe repair, smoke and news shops. Of these, the Lemon Tree Cafe is one of the best, with toothsome falafel and good hummus and baba gannouj, stuffed grape leaves, kibbe and tabbouleh. Turkish Cuisine is sensational, offering sweet, crisp fried calamari, tender potato croquettes and wonderful zucchini and parsley cakes. The grilled chopped lamb patties and lamb simmered with fresh cheese are as sprightly as the belly dancer who performs on weekend nights.
A handful of storefronts have begun sounding the curry bugle. The two best are Bengal Express Indian Restaurant, whose curries and tandoori dishes are fine and inexpensive, and Banjara, a larger, fancier restaurant that makes wonderful vegetable and keema samosa and rich soups.
The Asian restaurants are probably the most certain harbinger of things to come: they are a far cry from tiny holes in the wall with Cantonese cliches. For instance, Mee Noodle Shop, with big bowls of Suzhou-style soups, is modern and airy and designed for a clientele as occupied with dietary concerns as it is smitten with Asian flavors. The neighborhood also supports the Little Saigon Cafe, which serves wonderful Vietnamese specialties at its four tables. Bali Burma, a fanciful storefront, serves the sweet and sometimes peppery dishes of Myanmar; the coconut milk and chicken soup with noodles, thousand-layer bread with potatoes and red-curry fried rice are the stars of the show.
Many restaurants are emblems of a changing population. "The people who move here now come because they want to, not because they have to," said Mrs. Fable, noting that well-educated, relatively affluent people with expensive tastes are as much a part of Hell's Kitchen as first generation immigrants once were.
Mangia e Bevi, a warm and campy reincarnation of Little Italy with unobjectionable, old-fashioned Italian food, has become an everyday restaurant for new Hell's Kitchenites. The tidy storefront known as 44 Southwest has done the same; it features decent versions of food from the southwests of Italy, France and America.
"There are actually two Hell's Kitchens now," said Mr. Gusoff of Pietrasanta and Rachel's, who has worked in restaurants in the area for more than a decade. "There's the solid, workaday, family-oriented Hell's Kitchen and the sort of hip, younger, artistic Hell's Kitchen."
His restaurants serve both. The crowd at Pietrasanta, his Italian trattoria with big plates of garlicky pastas, thick-crusted pizzas and huge salads, looks like Rotary Club meets SoHo. A similarly bifurcated crowd has found common ground at Rachel's, Mr. Gusoff's snug bistro, with unremarkable, although entirely acceptable French food.
Revolution, with its disco music and softly psychedelic murals, is bidding to become the P. J. Clarke's of Hell's Kitchen, an end-of-the-day watering hole. But the food is better than in most saloons, with meaty crab cakes, a tasting of pan-Asian egg rolls and a small menu of carefully prepared pastas, chicken and fish.
"We just wanted to open a bar for all the artists and theater people," Ms. McNaughton said. "But along with people like Petula Clark and the cast from 'Tommy' who stopped in for drinks, we got just as many locals who wanted dinner, too."
But while some restaurants spring from the fertile ethnic mix of Hell's Kitchen, and some reach beyond it with trendy menus and affect, three newcomers strain the traditional blue-collar image of the neighborhood with bids to become "destination" restaurants, like the better pretheater places along Restaurant Row on West 46th Street.
Uncle Nick's is an irrepressible Greek taverna with big cases of fresh fish in the front and a cubbyhole of a back room with red walls and rickety tables and delicious food: spinach pie, moussaka, pastichio, taramosalata and tiny meatballs. The fish is so fresh and carefully grilled that, especially at the price -- about $20 for a three-course meal with wine -- it is worth traveling for.
Upscale vegetarians have traveled to Zen Palate, a food shop and dining room with artful vegetarian cooking. The restaurant uses soy products to confect faux meats. More interesting are the stuffed eggplant, mushroom caps smothered with garlic and delectable Vietnamese-style spring rolls.
In keeping with the Italian roots of Hell's Kitchen, Avanti is turning out stylish, contemporary renditions of traditional Italian food from four different regions. The focaccia is rich with olive oil, the shrimp has a heady blast of fresh rosemary and the homemade mozzarella is some of the best, even in a neighborhood long known for its fresh cheeses. The pastas -- tender gnocchi with fresh tomato sauce; linguine blackened with squid ink and tossed with garlic and clams; spinach parpardelle with smoked tomatoes and porcini mushrooms -- are delectable. Already, the restaurant is pulling in pretheater crowds and local residents.
Even with artful, forward-looking menus and an increasingly cosmopolitan clientele, despite more and more business meals and the pretheater crowd, there is something enduring and very intimate about Hell's Kitchen restaurants. Mr. Manatakis of Uncle Nick's said the feel of the dining rooms mirrors the neighborhood.
"It's a real neighborhood," he said. "By that I mean your people have good hearts and high hopes. They don't spend a lot of money; they spend time with each other. It's not a normal New York."
 
That's Not the Aroma of Brimstone
 THESE are among the new (and old) restaurants and food shops along Ninth Avenue in Hell's Kitchen:

SECTION: Section A; Page 19; Column 5; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 700 words

HEADLINE: In America;
Counting the Jobless

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The Government has changed the way it determines the national unemployment rate, which has resulted in a number that is marginally higher. But the new and supposedly improved methodology does not provide anything close to an accurate picture of a devastating jobs crisis that is becoming ever more entrenched.
Legions of Americans who once felt secure in the workplace are now stunned to find themselves caught in the hideous undertow of long-term unemployment. You don't hear much from them after that. The jobless tend to go quietly. One day they're at their work station, the next day they're not. When enough time passes, they're no longer even counted as unemployed. 
 If you take this group, which increasingly includes middle-class and middle-aged men and women, and link it up with the people who have been forced into part-time or temporary work, and with people who are calling themselves self-employed but who are really making little or no money, and with the underclass of inner-city Americans who have long been among the permanently unemployed, you have a problem with frightening implications.
You cannot deal effectively with public safety, health care reform and welfare reform without engaging the employment crisis.
In November 1991, when President Bush signed a bill extending jobless benefits, there were 1.3 million Americans officially designated as long-term unemployed, meaning they had been out of work for six months or longer. Those benefits have been cut back, but last month the number of long-term unemployed was 1.7 million.
Inevitably the official rates of unemployment are much lower than the true rates. The Government is not concealing the real numbers. In fact, the Bureau of Labor Statistics does a remarkable job of documenting those who are working and those who are not. But the raw numbers get whittled down by the complex procedures and definitions used to arrive at the official statistics.
For example, discouraged workers -- people who have given up looking for a job -- are not counted as unemployed. The bureau will readily tell you how many people fall into the discouraged category, but that number will not be factored into the official unemployment rate.
And even the discouraged category is being shrunk by the bureaucracy. Under the bureau's new rules, a discouraged worker who has not looked for a job for a year is no longer considered discouraged. That worker falls off the statistical charts. Actually, there were a lot of them. Before the change, the bureau counted 1.1 million discouraged workers. After the change, 600,000.
There are endless examples of people who are out of work but not counted as unemployed. Laid-off workers have traditionally been considered unemployed, even though there was a time when they could reasonably expect their jobs to return. Now laid off pretty much means fired. But during the survey that is used to determine the unemployment rate, laid-off workers are asked how active they have been in looking for a new job. If the answer is that they have simply been checking the want ads, they are not counted as unemployed. They sure are out of work, but officially they're not unemployed.
The jobs crisis is not limited to the unemployed. Recent statistics show that college-educated men in their 40's and 50's -- ordinarily considered an elite group at the peak of their earning powers -- are experiencing a sharp decline in wages.
Katherine Newman, a social anthropologist at Columbia University, was quoted in The New York Times as saying: "This was the first generation to be widely educated in college. They followed the recommended path, but their education has failed to insulate them."
The official unemployment rate for January was 6.7 percent. The more we focus on it, the less we understand the extent of the problem. A better indicator of prevailing conditions would be a statistic that showed the number of people who wanted a job but could not find one. That number would be astonishingly high.
Keith Brooks, director of the New York Unemployed Committee, made the essential point: "Does our Government recognize the depth of the jobs crisis in this country? I think not."

HEADLINE: Off the Menu

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant 

 BODY:

Flatiron Italian
Mark Strausman, the chef at Coco Pazzo on the Upper East Side until last spring, has signed a lease for his own restaurant, Campagna, at 24 East 21st Street. The space formerly housed the restaurant Luxe. Since leaving Coco Pazzo, Mr. Strausman has been doing consulting work and most recently has been cooking at Tavola, at 1481 York Avenue (78th Street).
With his new venture, he will be adding his brand of lusty, Italian peasant cooking to the Flatiron district, where a number of young chefs have recently opened their own places. Mr. Strausman, backed by a group of silent partners, said he plans only slight changes in the decor of the 130-seat dining room. 
 Reflecting an increasing trend among chefs, he said he plans to do as much of his own smoking, pickling, brining and curing of ingredients as possible. He also plans to start an off-premises catering company.
 
New but Familiar Faces
 When La Colombe d'Or opened on East 26th Street in 1976, it was a pioneer among French bistros. Now, after nearly two decades of dining-room and kitchen watch, Helen and George Studley, the owners, are beginning to let go. They have arranged for the management to be assumed by Wayne Nish and Joseph Scalice, the owners of March on East 58th Street.
"We want to be less tied down to the restaurant," Mrs. Studley said. "And if this works out it may lead to an eventual sale of the restaurant."
Mr. Nish is no stranger to La Colombe d'Or. During his tenure as chef there from 1988 to 1990, it was awarded three stars by Bryan Miller of The New York Times. Mr. Nish left the restaurant with Mr. Scalice, who was the manager, to open March. Naj Zougari, the chef of La Colombe d'Or, is staying on.
 
Importing the Stars
 To celebrate its 40th anniversary tomorrow, Relais et Chateaux, an association of luxury hotels and restaurants, is importing chefs from France to cook at its American properties.
In France, it hasn't been easy to sell expensive dinners in the countryside on weekday evenings, even with Michelin-starred chefs at the stove. Many are not sold out. In the current economy, some French chefs aren't even able to fill their own restaurants night after night.
At the Old Drovers Inn, in Dover Plains, N.Y., Robert Lalleman from the one-star Auberge de Noves in Provence will cook a five-course meal for $125 tomorrow through Monday; wines will be from Chateau Cordeillan-Bages near Bordeaux. For reservations, call (914) 832-9311. At the Inn at Sawmill Farm, in West Dover, Vt., Andre Daguin, from the two-star Hotel de France in Auch, will prepare a six-course dinner tomorrow night for $135; (802) 464-8131.
At The Point in Upper Saranac Lake, N.Y., the star will be Michel Lorain, a three-star chef from La Cote St.-Jacques in Joigny.Only a couple of places remain for tomorrow night's dinner. No wonder. Half the rooms at the inn were taken by invited press; (800) 255-3530.
 
A Training Program

Last Thursday, Ellyn Rosenthal, the executive director of the Food and Hunger Hot Line, a nonprofit organization that provides meals for homeless people, signed a lease for the space previously occupied by Fourteen and, before that, Quatorze, at 240 West 14th Street. By the fall, she said, the organization hopes to open One City Cafe, a restaurant with a training program for homeless people who live in shelters.
One City Cafe will be open to the public, serving what Ms. Rosenthal calls "cross-cultural comfort food," like meatloaf and mashed potatoes and rice and beans, at low prices.
The training program will accept 24 people a year and will be conducted by the hotel management school of New York University. The group is now seeking corporate sponsors to subsidize the students, to the tune of $15,000 a year.
 
A Taste of Piedmont
 Two visitors from Italy, Tonino and Claudia Verro, the owner and chef of La Contea in Neive, one of the best restaurants in Piedmont, will be preparing a five-course dinner Sunday at 6 P.M. at Tommaso's Restaurant, 1464 86th Street, in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. The food will be paired with the wines of Bruno Giacosa, a premier wine producer of that region, which is in northwest Italy.
The cost of dinner, including wines, is $55. Reservations can be made by calling (718) 236-9883.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 25, 1994, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Off the Menu column in The Living Section on Wednesday included an erroneous description of the status of the restaurant La Colombe d'Or, provided by an owner, Helen Studley. The restaurant is to be sold on Monday to the owners of March, Wayne Nish and Joseph Scalice, not merely to be managed by them.

HEADLINE: Big Board and Amex Uncovered Short Sales Rise

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Short-selling activity, usually done as a bet that stock prices will fall, rose significantly earlier this month, evidently as a result of the sharp fall in stock prices that followed the Federal Reserve's move to raise the Federal funds rate on Feb. 4.
The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the total short position in its stocks -- the number of shares borrowed and sold short, but not yet covered by repurchasing the shares -- rose 3.7 percent in the month that ended Feb. 8, to a record 1.32 billion shares. That was the largest increase in five months, perhaps reflecting renewed confidence among bears. At the American Stock Exchange, the short interest position rose 3.5 percent, to a record 104.9 million shares. It was the largest rise in three months on that exchange. 
 The three largest short positions -- in RJR Nabisco, the Walt Disney Company and the Chrysler Corporation -- all rose as shorts increased their bets. Of the three, only Chrysler has moved significantly since Feb. 8, falling more than $4 a share.
During the month the shorts cut back on bets against United States Surgical, with the number of shares shorted falling by 1.7 million, to 12.4 million. That may have been prompted by the stock's rising amid talk by analysts and company officials that it was likely to benefit when a jury issued a verdict in a patent-infringement case against Johnson & Johnson. Instead, the jury ruled in favor of Johnson & Johnson and the shares have plunged. They closed yesterday at $18.25, down $9.625 since Feb. 8.
Not all rises in short positions are related to negative opinions. For example, the short position in Stone Container leaped 4.1 million shares, to 9.4 million. In part, that may have been related to the company's sale of 16.5 million shares, at $15.25, on Feb. 3. To the extent the shorting was a forecast of lower prices, it has not worked out. The price has climbed back to $16.50 a share.
The sharp reduction in the short position in Columbia Health Care, to 17.7 million shares, a drop of 4.6 million, was related to the fact that its big merger with HCA was about to close. Traders betting on the deal going through had bought HCA and shorted Columbia. The profit from closing out that position became attractive as regulatory hurdles were cleared.

Short Sales Tables Explained
 These tables show issues with a short interest position in the current month of at least 350,000 shares or a change up or down from the previous month of at least 164,947 shares.
 Cover ratio represents the number of days, at average volume level, that it would take to purchase the number of shares sold short.
 A -- American Stock Exchange.
 N -- New York Stock Exchange.
 N.L. -- Not listed.
 + -- Stock split.
 * (American Stock Exchange only.) May have been affected by arbitrage transactions resulting from any one or more of the following: proposed or pending acquisitions; convertible securities of the same company; rights offerings; stock splits or distributions; tenders; other special situations.
 Short interest may also be affected by options positions.
 # indicates a change of 75 percent or more from the previous month.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
Bell Atlantic and Tele-Communications called off their merger. A decline in the value of Bell Atlantic's stock and the potential impact of cable television rate cuts on Tele-Communications apparently led to the decision to end the $33 billion deal. [Page A1.] Raymond W. Smith and John C. Malone once seemed to be the shapers of a new information age. Today, they are two tired executives who could not meet their own deadlines for completing the deal.[D6.] The collapse of the merger was not a complete surprise to analysts who had wondered how the conflicting styles and goals of the two companies could be resolved. [D6.]
Microsoft was ordered to pay $120 million in damages to Stac Electronics Inc. The judgment came in the first patent infringement suit against Microsoft ever to reach a trial. [D1.] 
 The Winter Olympics telecasts have been a hit for CBS, producing the highest-rated week in its history. The network's success has also been a boon to advertisers. [D1.]
Kiwi, a fledgling Newark-based airline, is a prime example of how employee-ownership can break down the us-versus-them mentality of labor-management relations. Many corporations are now trying to copy the success of Kiwi and other employee-owned companies in creating an entrepreneurial culture. [D1.]
Documents detailing how B.C.C.I. diverted billions of dollars from the ruling family of Abu Dhabi were made public. [D2.]
Federal prosecutors are preparing to charge more than a dozen current and former American Honda executives with accepting bribes from dealers in exchange for franchises or cars. [D4.]
Macy's creditors were examining where they stood after Cyrus R. Vance was appointed mediator in the bankruptcy. [D4.]
Spectrum Information Technologies posted a loss of $12.1 million for the third quarter. The loss included a $4.7 million charge to cover an expected settlement of a shareholder suit. [D4.]
Chrysler will sell a large portion of its Acustar parts-making subsidiary to Yazaki of Japan, a maker of wiring systems. [D4.]
McDonald's banned smoking in all of its 1,400 wholly owned restaurants. And a trade group representing McDonald's and other chains backed a law to end smoking in all restaurants. [A16.]

International
U.S. trade policy with Japan was sharply criticized by Senator Bill Bradley. He accused the President of putting the United States' long-term interests at risk for the sake of "Japan-bashing." [D1.]
The Japanese Government partly retracted statements suggesting it would abandon its high-definition television system after the nation's big electronics companies protested. [D1.]
Markets Blue-chips stocks retreated after short-term interest rates rose sharply. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 19.98 points. [D8.]
Treasury prices declined after short-term rates jumped. The yield on the long bond rose to a seven-month high. [D16.]
Platinum prices continued to slide as traders turned to prospects for Russian sales of the metal. [D15.] The dollar edged up against most currencies in narrow trading. [D15.]

Today's Columns
The U.S.-Japan trade dispute may leave scars that will not easily heal. Ideas on a way for the interdependent economies to get back to business are scarce. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
First Chicago's star rose on Wall Street after a longtime banking rival was acquired. The deal for Continental Bank has focused attention on First Chicago's recovery. Market Place. [D8.]
While Madison Avenue often puts a premium on youth, one 53-year-old creative director has begun a campaign that says there is no substitute for experience. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D18.]

HEADLINE: South Korean Expects Atomic Backdown by North

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 23

 BODY:
In South Korea's most optimistic assessment yet of the tense standoff on the Korean Peninsula, President Kim Young Sam said today that he had become "very sure that in the end North Korea will accept the nuclear inspections" that the United States and its allies have demanded for more than a year.
That upbeat view, expressed by Mr. Kim in an interview at the presidential mansion in Seoul, was a sharp turnaround from his tone just eight months ago. At that time he warned the United States against being "led on" by North Korea and suggested that "time is running out" because North Korea would be able to produce plutonium by early 1994 in large enough quantities to make nuclear weapons. 
 But over the last few weeks, he said, after "receiving a lot of information about the nuclear issue," he has concluded that there is "no clear evidence of North Korea's possession of nuclear weapons yet."
This time the 66-year old former dissident politician, who took office a year ago this week as South Korea's first civilian President in more than three decades, talked only of the carrots he was prepared to offer his Communist rivals in the north. He declined to mention any sticks, for fear of angering the North Korean Government "at a sensitive time."
 
Keeping Up the Pressure
 President Kim's comments, and those of several of his aides in recent weeks, make clear that South Korea is far less worried about what kind of nuclear weapons North Korea may already have than it is about keeping up the pressure to bring its development program to a slow halt.
A week ago, after bitterly resisting renewed inspections, the North said it would allow the International Atomic Energy Agency to conduct limited inspections -- not including two suspected nuclear waste dumps. Mr. Kim seems to be betting that his best strategy is to reward the North for the first glimmerings of flexibility rather than immediately press for better access.
Today, for example, Mr. Kim said that it would be "a wise opinion" for the United States to delay the deployment of Patriot missiles to defend the 35,000 American troops here. He was speaking of testimony in Congress on Tuesday by Gen. John Shalikashvili, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, that the deployment was likely to be held up because "we do not want to give some excuse to the North Koreans to derail a process."
South Korean officials concede that they have often switched from sounding hawkish to sounding dovish about the North, usually to provide a counterweight to the prevailing mood in Washington. It is a shift that has often frustrated the Clinton Administration, which South Korea has variously accused of being manipulated by the North or of jeopardizing the talks by taking a hard line.
"I think it is not accurate to describe it as inconsistency," Mr. Kim said. He called it "tactical flexibility," saying that the basic strategy being pursued by Washington and Seoul -- to convince the North that there are economic and political advantages to abandoning the nuclear weapons effort -- "is proving quite effective."
 
A Cautionary Word
 "This is only the beginning of the solution of the problem," he said, cautioning that talks between the two Koreas and additional inspections would be necessary before aid and investment in the North began.
North Korea has demanded that, before it allows the nuclear agency to begin its inspection, the United States give it a written commitment making explicit a long-understood deal: Once inspections begin, Washington will announce the cancellation of the the annnual "Team Spirit" military exercise with South Korea and set a date for high-level talks with Washington. Meanwhile, the North will appoint envoys to restart talks with South Korea.
At the next stage of talks, probably next month, there will be discussion of a new deal. That would trade far more intrusive inspections, something the North still says it will never allow, for political and economic benefits.
Mr. Kim talked expansively about the reforms his Government has initiated to cure what he called "Korean disease," the corruption and loss of direction that afflicted his country's economy in the late 1980's and early 1990's. His most striking action was a purge of more than a third of the top military leadership, which he said had become a "hotbed of corruption."
"The presidents who came to power through coups," he said, talking of most of his predecessors, "were worried that the same could happen to them. So their only solution was to give the military great power."
Now, he said, using the legitimacy gained with 42 percent of the vote in a three-way election, he has returned the military to its defense mission and removed it from politics. "Morale in the military is high now," he added.
The bureaucracy has also been through a shake-up, with more than 200 senior officials forced out of their posts because of what the Government calls "financial irregularities." Mr. Kim's critics, and there are not many, say that his biggest failing is that his reform effort has yet to trickle through most layers of Korean society.
"It is too much to think you can change the habits of a society in just one year," he said.

 VIENNA, Feb. 23 (Reuters) -- North Korea refused to bow to mounting international pressure today for rapid inspection of its suspect nuclear sites, and the International Atomic Energy Agency, meeting in Vienna, could only appeal again to Pyongyang to open its sites to examination without further delay, a spokesman said.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Wants More Spending Control

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Hoping to wield greater control over New York City's finances, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would seek new powers to oversee budgets of independent authorities or agencies receiving money from the city, including the Health and Hospitals Corporation, Board of Education and Transit Authority.
Neither the Mayor nor his senior aides gave details of how they hoped to do so, but changes in the structure or fiscal management of such agencies would require approval of the Legislature and the Governor. 
And that remains far from certain. For example, Assemblyman Albert Vann, chairman of the Assembly's Committee on Corporations, Authorities and Commissions, said yesterday that he would not support turning over fiscal control of the Transit Authority to the Mayor. "I don't think it would make any sense," he said.
Still, Mr. Giuliani's remarks reflected a desire, expressed by mayors in the past, to have more say over the spending of agencies that get money from the city but whose budgets are adopted by boards with a degree of independence. His comments could also serve as a reminder that the Mayor himself now has little control over what those agencies spend.
He argued that while those agencies were created to run independently, they lacked "political accountability" and had grown fatter and more wasteful than agencies directly controlled by the Mayor's office.
"Some of it has to do with the fact that although originally envisioned and put together for very good purposes, being independent, they are now politically unaccountable," Mr. Giuliani said. "I'm accountable. If I don't reduce the expenses of the city, then three and a half years from now, people can throw me out of office."
In his State of the City Address earlier this month, Mr. Giuliani proposed the creation of an independent fiscal monitor to oversee spending at the Board of Education. The proposal followed several days of public clashes with the Schools Chancellor, Ramon C. Cortines, over how best to cut the board's budget, with the Mayor demanding cuts of 2,500 administrators at the central headquarters.
Yesterday Mr. Giuliani said such a monitor would be one approach to gaining greater control over the budgets of the independent agencies.
 
A Different Approach
 Another approach, according to Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers, would be to give the Mayor's four appointees on the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority control over the city's contribution to the Transit Authority, which operates the city's subways and buses. In 1993 the city contributed $634 million of the authority's $3.6 billion operating budget, as well as $105 million of its capital budget.
Mr. Powers said the administration would focus initially on wresting more control over the spending at the authority, the Board of Education and the Health and Hospitals Corporation because they are the largest, accounting for about $4.5 billion of the city's $31.2 billion budget.
In the future, he added, the Mayor would also consider greater oversight of the smaller agencies -- from the Economic Development Corporation to the Water Board.
"We have to be able to approve how the money is spent," said Mr. Powers, who first disclosed the policy when he appeared yesterday at a breakfast forum sponsored by the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry and Crain's New York Business. "If we can't get the ability to monitor it, then we're just writing checks, without accountability."
In recent years, the city has taken some steps to put the "off budget" agencies under greater mayoral control. Two years ago, for example, Mayor David N. Dinkins created a task force to monitor the Board of Education's budget. He also sought unsuccessfully to expand the board from 7, to 11 members, with 6 appointed by the Mayor.
Allen J. Proctor, the executive director of the state's Financial Control Board, which monitors the city's finances, expressed tentative support for such approaches.
"Most of these agencies were moved off budget so mayors would not have to make decisions," he said. The new Mayor's desire "really shows a change in time."
 
Depth of Opposition
 An indication of the depth of opposition such proposals are certain to encounter came from Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the City Council. While expressing support for fiscal oversight, he said he did not believe the oversight should rest solely in the hands of the Mayor. He called for passage of legislation now before the State Senate and the Assembly that would force the agencies to submit their budgets to the City Council for review.
Raymond D. Horton of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit organization, said the real value of considering such an idea, even if never enacted, would be the message. "To the extent the Mayor pushes an idea like this," he said, "maybe the heads of those quasi-independent agencies will cut him some slack."

HEADLINE: Tight Logging Limit Set in Northwest

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Feb. 23

 BODY:
In what is likely to be the final blueprint for managing 24 million acres of public forests in the Pacific Northwest, the Clinton Administration today announced a plan to protect a host of endangered species by significantly reducing logging from the high levels of the 1980's.
The new policy, which came in one of the most extensive environmental impact statements ever done by the Government, is largely similar to a draft that President Clinton presented last summer. The final plan further reduces logging and nearly doubles estimates of the number of jobs that will be lost, to 9,500 from 5,500 in the draft. 
 Under the Clinton plan, which was put together after the President held a conference last spring among the warring factions in one of the nation's major environmental disputes, logging would be reduced to levels that are 20 percent of those in the peak years of the mid-1980's.
About 5 billion board feet of timber used to be cut every year in national forests in Washington, Oregon, and Northern California. Now, the plan calls for cutting slightly more than 1 billion board feet a year. It takes about 10,000 board feet to build the average house.
 
Criticism on Both Sides
 While the plan drew harsh and immediate criticism from both sides in the debate, it is a major reversal of policy from the last three decades. In large part, the report shows scientific acceptance of years of criticism from environmentalists. They have long said excessive logging in national forests was a violation of environmental law and could not be sustained without wreaking havoc.
With this plan, which is intended to protect endangered species like spotted owls, more than 1,000 plant and animal species that depend on old growth forests will also be helped. The Clinton Administration hopes the policy will help it avoid future legal disputes over species like salmon, which are now in decline.
"This is an attempt to get ahead of the endangered-species-of-the-month club," said Tom Tuchmann, director of the Federal Office of Forestry and Economic Development, one of more than a half-dozen agencies that put together the new policy.
Logging would be permitted on about 4 million acres, most of it in areas that are sliced up by roads or were first cut long ago and now have new growth.
The Government estimates that there are 5.3 million acres of old growth forest left in the Northwest, with about 1.5 million of that protected in national parks or wilderness areas. The Administration would allow logging on 693,000 acres but keep most of the remaining old-growth forests off limits.
 
Report Goes to Judge
 The remaining old growth areas would not be given formal wilderness protection, a designation that usually requires an act of Congress.
The report, which could be altered in the next 30 days, will be submitted to Judge William L. Dwyer of Federal District Court in Seattle. Judge Dwyer issued an injunction halting logging in Federal forests here three years ago, saying it violated the law.
If Judge Dwyer accepts the plan and lifts his injunction on logging, a much smaller timber-sale program could resume in national forests in the region.
But some environmental groups are already raising objections to the plan, saying it still leaves some species in jeopardy. And the timber industry has filed a lawsuit charging that open meeting laws were violated in developing the plan.
Among the major changes in this plan from the earlier draft were these:
*Estimates of job losses increased, with up to about 9,500 expected with this plan, leaving about 115,000 timber workers in the Northwest. The higher estimate came because of a change in the model that was used to predict economic consequences.
*No-logging zones around streams increased. The old plan required a 50-foot strip of trees to be left standing on either side of some streams, but the new plan doubles that to 100 feet.
*Slightly more logging would be allowed in Northern California than earlier estimated.
Timber industry officials say President Clinton broke his promise to present a plan that would balance the need for jobs with conservation concerns. Last July, when the President first announced the forestry plan, Administration officials said they hoped to speed up logging on about 1 billion board feet of timber not covered by court orders.
But last year, less than a third of the promised amount was cut, leaving some timber mills short of logs.
"They have been making promises since last year, and they have broken every one of them," said Chris West, a vice president of the Northwest Forestry Association, an industry group based in Portland, Ore.
In the meantime, large private timber holders, who are not affected by these environmental restrictions, have reported record earnings, and continue to send logs overseas in a booming export market.
"We don't need to liquidate the public's last remaining ancient forest treasures in order to provide enough wood for our domestic mills," said Jim Pissot, an official with the Audubon Society.
The timber industry leaders have said they hope that Congress will override the Clinton Administration and propose higher logging levels, even if they violate environmental laws. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, a strong ally of the timber industry, had called the earlier Clinton plan unacceptable. But he is not likely to support overturning the new policy, said Jeff Biggs, a spokesman for Mr. Foley.

HEADLINE: Republicans Say Congress Could Balk on Bosnia Force

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23

 BODY:
As the United States begins pressing the Bosnian Government to make peace, key Republican Senators questioned today whether Congress would approve the Administration's plan to send American troops there if a settlement is reached.
At a hearing of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Secretary of State Warren Christopher warned that Bosnia's Muslim-led Government would not sign a peace treaty without an American pledge to send troops to take part in peacekeeping in Bosnia. 
 Mr. Christopher also confirmed that the United States had decided against imposing tighter sanctions on Haiti, at least for the moment, and announced that he would make his first trip to China as Secretary of State early next month and demand that Beijing improve its human rights record.
But much of the hearing today centered on developments in Bosnia, where a NATO threat of air strikes this week obtained a partial withdrawal of Serbian guns around Sarajevo.
 
A New Urgency to Issue
 Until two weeks ago, the Administration's pledge to send American troops to enforce a durable settlement in Bosnia seemed largely theoretical. Now that the United States has abandoned its hands-off policy toward the Bosnian talks, and the Americans, the Russians, and the Western Europeans are all actively pressing for a settlement, the question of how to enforce any accord has taken on new urgency.
Mr. Christopher emphasized that Congress would be fully consulted and its approval sought before United States forces were sent into Bosnia.
But in a reflection of the anxiety in Congress over American involvement, Senator Richard G. Lugar, the Indiana Republican, asked how Mr. Christopher could be involved in negotiating a peace that would require American troops "without your being able to give that assurance" in advance.
And Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, the Kansas Republican, warned that the Administration was putting itself into "sort of a Catch-22" situation by making promises that it might not be able to keep and urged Mr. Christopher to consider consultations with the Congress even before Bosnia's warring Muslims, Serbs and Croats negotiated in earnest.
 
U.S. Force 'Fundamental'
 Mr. Christopher said that the Administration did not know how many troops would be necessary to enforce a settlement, but that they would not constitute more than half of a special peacekeeping force. But he emphasized that American participation would be "a fundamental building block" in enforcing peace.
Other American officials have said recently that the United States would support deployment of about one-third of an anticipated force of 50,000 soldiers, not one-half, as the United States initially suggested.
"Talk to the leaders of Bosnia," Mr. Christopher told the committee. "The only way they would enter into a settlement is if the United States is involved in the implementation."
Bosnia's Prime Minister, Haris Silajdzic, made a similar point after meeting with members of Congress today. "Bosnia could not be solved without American engagement," he said. "You have to have force to make peace."
 
Advantages of Reconciliation
 The stalled peace negotiations among the Serbs, Muslims and Croats have centered in recent months on a proposal to divide Bosnia into three ethnically based provinces. In recent days diplomats have focused on improving the relations between Bosnia's Croats and Muslims in the hope they will form a political alliance.
Mr. Christopher did not refer directly to the cease-fire agreement signed today by Bosnia's Muslim Government and the Bosnian Croats, but he said a rapprochement between the two factions, which were allies early in the war, would have "many, many advantages."
"If they could get together, it would make for a more viable state," Mr. Christopher said. Such a rapprochement would not only make an accord easier to enforce, he said, but "solve a number of problems" like guaranteeing the Muslims "access to the sea."
After Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Senate Armed Services Committee, said that the Administration would have to prove it had an exit strategy before deploying troops, President Clinton laid down a list of conditions last September for doing so.
He said the United States would commit troops only if a NATO commander was in charge of the operation, if there was a clear timetable for withdrawing the force, if the financial burden on the United States was acceptable and there was clear support from the Congress.
Since then, there has been a growing sense within the Administration and among the allies that the United States will have to send troops if a fragile peace is to take hold in Bosnia.
Senior State Department officials told the French, British and German Governments two weeks ago that the United States was prepared to send one-third of the troops that might be needed to enforce a peace accord. And in a meeting on Monday at the State Department with Mr. Silajdzic, Mr. Christopher pledged American troops as a condition of peace, Mr. Silajdzic said in an interview afterward.
Mr. Christopher's testimony today contrasted sharply with his remarks before the same committee in November, when he dismissed the crises in Bosnia, Somalia and Haiti as "difficult situations" that had not gone exactly as the United States had planned.
Today he said that the United States had important strategic, political and humanitarian interests in bringing peace to Bosnia. His speech reflects the shift in public statements by the Administration on Bosnia as it begins to prepare the public for the deployment of American troops there.
Today Russia's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, proposed a one-day summit meeting with four Western powers to end the war in Bosnia. But the Clinton Administration reacted coolly to the idea, saying that such a meeting "would require a lot of preparation" and that it was devoting its efforts to more basic "groundwork" on a negotiated settlement.
 On the issue of Haiti, Mr. Christopher said that the United States had decided not to press for further economic sanctions to step up pressure on Haiti's military because "there is no plan that we can be promoting effectively with the sanctions."
Mr. Christopher did not directly criticize Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, for resisting an American-backed plan that would restore democracy and return him to power at an unspecified date.
But he said the Administration was urging Father Aristide to appoint a new Prime Minister and to meet with a "centrist" group in Haiti, something that he has so far refused to do.

HEADLINE: Rise in Interest Rates Sends Stocks Lower

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stock prices slumped yesterday after short-term interest rates rose sharply.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 19.98 points, to 3,891.68. Telephone, household product, electric utility, chemical and drug stocks were among the session's biggest decliners. 
 The market slid after a Federal Reserve governor, Lawrence B. Lindsey, said yesterday that the Fed would raise rates again if either inflation or expectations of inflation picked up. On Tuesday, the chairman of the Fed, Alan Greenspan, told Congress that short-term rates were more likely to rise than fall.
"The signal from the Fed is that short rates are going up, and bonds are going down in price," Michael Metz, the chief market strategist at Oppenheimer & Company, said.
As long-term interest rates move to 7 percent, "that's not a real negative for the economy, but it could cause a cessation of funds into mutual funds," prompting a 15 to 20 percent decline in stocks, Mr. Metz said.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 0.77 point, to 470.69. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 2.04 points, to 789.11, hurt by weak technology stocks including Novell, Oracle Systems, Intel and Cisco Systems.
Declining stocks led advancers, 1,177 to 948, on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume advanced to 309.9 million shares, from 270.9 million Tuesday.
Investors "realize the Fed is still in a tightening mode, and for right now, it's probably putting a lid on the market," David Butler, head of equity trading at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago, said. "I think you're looking at higher rates."
 
Retailers See Gains
 Retailers were among the best-performing stocks yesterday. Home Depot Inc., which yesterday reported a 16 percent increase in fourth-quarter earnings, climbed 2 1/4, to 42 3/8; Lowe's Companies gained 1 1/8, to 62 3/8,and Wal-Mart Stores added 3/4, to 29.
Nordstrom Inc. rose 2 7/8, to 39 3/4. The Seattle-based retailer said fourth-quarter earnings rose to 74 cents a share from 61 cents in the prior year. The results exceeded analyst expectations of 69 cents.
Novell fell 7/8, to 23 5/8. After the market closed, the maker of computer networking software said net income in the fiscal first quarter ended Jan. 31 was unchanged at 23 cents a share, a penny ahead of forecasts.
Deere & Company rose 1 1/2, to 84. An analyst at S. G. Warburg raised his rating on the company because of better-than-expected first-quarter earnings.
The Dell Computer Corporation jumped 1 3/8, to 24 1/8. The computer maker's stock rose for a second consecutive day after Dell added five Intel 486-based notebook computers to its direct mail pipeline.
American depository receipts of National Westminster Bank P.L.C. dropped 2 3/4, to 45 3/4. Each A.D.R. represents six common shares. National Westminster, Britain's second-biggest bank, is suffering from weak loan demand, analysts said.
American depository receipts of the Sony Corporation, each representing one common share, rose 1 1/4, to 59 1/8. The Japanese consumer electronics company is said to have hired Furman Selz Inc. to sell part of its United States movie studio operations.
The Hershey Foods Corporation fell 1 3/4, to 51 3/4. Janney Montgomery Scott lowered its rating on the company to "hold" from "buy."

HEADLINE: Goals for Recycling May Change

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
A day after New York State's highest court ordered New York City to comply with its own 1989 recycling law, a senior official in the Giuliani administration said the Mayor might seek to renegotiate the law's timetables with the City Council because of the costs of complying with the statute.
Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers suggested that the recycling goals set forth in the law were no longer affordable given the fact that the law was passed "when the finances of the city were nicer." 
 He said the administration wanted to talk to Council leaders to see if it were possible to change the law, which originally called for the city to be collecting 4,250 tons of recyclable material a day by this April, or about 25 percent of the city's total waste. The city currently is collecting about 15 percent, said Sanitation Commissioner Emily Lloyd.
 
'Got to Get Realistic'
 "We've got to get realistic about things," Mr. Powers said at a breakfast forum with business executives. "We set goals with certain economics in mind. We no longer have those economics. So we've got to revisit those goals. The Mayor's in favor of recycling. He wants to achieve it. He wants to achieve it as fast as we can. But he also has to put a lot of services out there for the people of the city with not enough money to do it."
But City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone yesterday hailed the ruling by the State Court of Appeals and said the money could be found for recycling. "The job of the executive branch now is to comply with the recycling law," he said. "If it can't comply with the law, it has to come back and tell us why."
The 1989 law, signed by Mayor Edward I. Koch, requires the city gradually to increase the amount of residential garbage that is recycled. But as the recession took hold, Mayor David N. Dinkins imposed budget cuts that delayed the expansion of the recycling program.
The Court of Appeals found in a ruling on Tuesday that the recycling measures in the law are mandatory and not goals that could be delayed by fiscal constraints as the Dinkins administration had argued. The ruling sent the Giuliani administration and the plainfiffs -- the Natural Resources Defense Council and two City Council members -- back to court to draw up a new schedule for meeting the recycling requirements.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Short- and Medium-Term Rates Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Short- and intermediate-term interest rates rose sharply yesterday, one day after the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, tried to reassure bond traders and investors not to be concerned about inflation in the near term.
Traders said there were two reasons for the jump in short-term rates, which took the yield on the three-year note to 5 percent, its highest level since January 1993, when it was 5.08 percent. 
 One reason was that Mr. Greenspan made it clear Tuesday, when he testified before a House Banking subcommittee, that the central bank would have to raise short-term interests in the near future. The only uncertainity is the timing. The Fed raised its target for short-term interest a quarter of a percentage point, to 3.25 percent, Feb. 4. It was the first increase in five years.
Traders said concern over the impending rate rise seemed to dampen investor demand at yesterday's auction of two-year notes. The yield at auction was 4.66 percent, up from 4.11 percent in January and the highest since December 1992, when the yield was 4.71 percent.
 
A Big Leap in Yields
 It appeared that this leap in yields also weighed on the market. By late in trading in the when-issued market, the yield on the new two-year note had inched up to 4.67 percent, as the price slipped.
In addition, the poor results in the $17 billion auction of two-year notesraised concern among dealers and traders that today's sale of five-year Treasury notes could also do poorly.
And even though long-term interest rates did not jump as much as short-term rates yesterday, the yield on the 30-year bond by late in the day was 6.64 percent, the highest in seven months. The price, which moves in the opposite direction, fell 19 32 .
Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Federal Reserve governor, added his voice yesterday to the chorus of officials warning of higher short-term interest rates. He said that the central bank would raise short rates again if the rate of inflation picked up. Mr. Greenspan said Tuesday that real short-term rates, which are adjusted for inflation, were more likely to rise than fall.
Talk among traders ahead of the two-year auction indicated that they did not expect great demand. One trader said, "This is not the issue you want to buy if short-term interest rates are going up."
Analysts at MMS International said rumors and speculation about the Fed tightening kept short maturities under selling pressure for the whole session.
The analysts said there was some talk about a Fed increase coming sooner if today's durable orders report for January was strong. But the analysts doubted the Fed was ready to pull the trigger this soon, speculating that it more than likely would come late March.
Alan Kral, a portfolio manager for Trevor, Stewart, Burton & Jacobsen Inc., an investment management firm, said: "Most everyone expects rates will increase. If short-term interest rates are not increased, there is the risk that inflation expectations, and possibly inflation itself, would rise."
Among the new municipal issues priced yesterday was a $125 million revenue bond sale by the Ohio Turnpike Commission through an underwriting group led by Paine Webber Inc., which was initially priced to yield a maximum 5.65 percent for a bond due in 2024. Serial bonds with shorter maturities were priced to yield from 3.10 percent for an issue due in 1995 to 4.50 percent in 2000, 5.05 percent in 2005, 5.45 percent in 2010, and 5.55 percent in 2014
Underwriters said the deal was rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by Standard & Poor's.

HEADLINE: B.C.C.I. Details Misuse Of Arab Ruler's Funds

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
In 32 pages of handwritten and typed notes, Swaleh Naqvi, chief executive of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International, outlined to the bank's majority shareholders the parameters of the financial crisis the institution faced in April 1990, but chose not to admit that more than $2.6 billion invested by the shareholders had been used to conceal B.C.C.I's huge losses.
Copies of Mr. Naqvi's explanation to the ruling family of the Persian Gulf sheikdom of Abu Dhabi were made public for the first time yesterday. That document was accompanied by hundreds of pages of documents detailing the manner in which B.C.C.I. diverted billions from the investment account of Sheik Zayed bin Sultan al-Nahayan. 
 The supporting documents show the extremes to which Mr. Naqvi and a handful of the bank's executives went to deceive those who handled Sheik Zayed's account. Among other things, B.C.C.I. kept two sets of records on Sheik Zayed's assets. Reports sent to his advisers showed the funds invested in a wide range of conservative financial instruments, from certificates of deposits to Treasury bonds, as well as stock in B.C.C.I.
 
Diversion of Funds
 An internal set of books, however, showed that funds had been diverted to cover up losses by the bank's Treasury division and through bad shipping loans.
"There was never, and has not been, any element of conspiracy or collusion," Mr. Naqvi wrote at one point in explaining what went wrong at the bank. Rather, he said, "it was a matter of confidentiality for the sake of the bank and not myself."
Details of the manner in which Sheik Zayed and his associates had been deceived by B.C.C.I. were released outside the United States in December, when Abu Dhabi's ruling family and the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority filed a $7 billion civil suit in Abu Dhabi against Mr. Naqvi; B.C.C.I.'s founder, Agha Hassan Abedi, and 11 other bank executives for mismanaged and stolen funds.
Those bringing the suit said $7 billion was what their $2.6 billion investment, made between 1981 and 1990, would have been worth today, had it been conservatively invested.
Documents relating to Sheik Zayed's investment portfolio came from B.C.C.I. (Overseas) Ltd., an affiliate incorporated in the Cayman Islands. The documents were not released in the United States in December because Sheik Zayed was then the defendant in a $1.5 billion civil suit filed by the trustees of First American Bankshares, the bank B.C.C.I. secretly and illegally controlled.
 
Comprehensive Deal
 The charges against Sheik Zayed were dropped in January as part of a broad-based agreement by Abu Dhabi, the United States Justice Department, the Federal Reserve Board and the Manhattan District Attorney's office.
In exchange for dismissing all charges against Sheik Zayed, the agreement requires Abu Dhabi to furnish a staggering quantity of B.C.C.I. documents, including 6,000 of Mr. Naqvi's files. In addition, it stipulates that Mr. Naqvi, who is currently on trial in Abu Dhabi, and faces Federal and state charges here, be brought to the United States in May.
The first shipment of B.C.C.I. documents, a load totaling 310,000 pages, was delivered to Federal Reserve offices on Tuesday. A team of 15 to 20 investigators from the Justice Department, the Fed and the District Attorney's office are expected to go to Abu Dhabi next week to review documents and interview former B.C.C.I. officials.
B.C.C.I. was closed by bank regulators around the world in July 1991 amid charges of wide-ranging fraud.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Makes Slight Gains On Rise of Short-Term Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar finished somewhat higher against most other currencies yesterday after spending most of the day trading in a narrow range influenced mainly by technical factors.
Traders said the dollar gained support late in the day after short-term interest rates rose on the Treasury securities market. Higher rates tend to increase the popularity and price of the dollar because investors earn higher returns on dollar-denominated investments. 
 During the day, the market's attention was mainly focused on the Japanese yen, which strengthened after falling early in Tokyo. In New York, the dollar ended at 105.65 yen, unchanged from Tuesday.
"People are still very, very nervous in that market," said Ken Gettinger, head of foreign exchange at Union Bank of Switzerland in New York.
The yen swung during the day on unconfirmed reports of large moves by investment funds and an intervention by the Bank of England, which was rumored to be acting on behalf of the Japanese central bank to support the dollar. But traders said they believed the rumors about the British central bank were untrue.
 
Ministers' Meeting Awaited
 Traders were also wary of statements that may emerge this weekend from a meeting of the finance ministers of the Group of Seven industrialized countries.
The yen has risen sharply against the dollar in the last two weeks after the breakdown of bilateral trade talks between the United States and Japan on opening Japan's markets.
The dollar posted gains against the German mark, ending in New York at 1.7290 marks, up from 1.7245 marks on Tuesday. And the pound finished at $1.4780, down from $1.4790 on Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those late Tuesday, included: 1.4545 Swiss francs, up from 1.4495; 5.8750 French francs, up from 5.8620; 1,682 Italian lire, up from 1,676, and 1.3380 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3367.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Platinum Continues to Slide On Concerns Over Supplies

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Platinum futures prices steepened their slide from a six-month high yesterday as traders turned their attention from possible South African supply disruptions to prospects for Russian sales of the metal.
Gold futures also retreated, while silver posted slight gains. 
 Platinum for April delivery fell $5.90 on the New York Mercantile Exchange to settle at $391.20 an ounce. It was the fourth consecutive daily drop for platinum, which hit a six-month high of $406.50 on Feb. 16.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, April gold, the most active contract, slipped 30 cents, to $378.90 an ounce. But March silver rose 1.5 cents, to $5.23 an ounce.
Talk circulated that Russia, a leading platinum producer, may sell some stocks to raise hard currency to trim the Government budget deficit, according to William O'Neill, senior strategist for Merrill Lynch Futures.
The possibility of Russian sales diverted attention from political developments in South Africa, another big platinum producer, he said. South Africa will have its first multirace election in April, and there are fears that racial strife could lead to platinum supply disruptions.
"I think the justification for the rally was not there to start with," Mr. O'Neill said. "Platinum is just getting back down to earth here."
Ian MacDonald, manager of precious metal trading for Credit Suisse in New York, agreed that platinum "was starting to do too much too soon."
"It looks to me that it just ran out of steam," he said.
Mr. MacDonald said platinum was also under pressure as a result of comments this week by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, that short-term interest rates may have to rise to help stave off inflation. Investors often buy precious metals as a hedge against inflation.
Elsewhere, in energy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil for April delivery rose 2 cents, to $14.41 a barrel; March heating oil rose 0.39 cent, to 47.22 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline sank 0.28 cent, to 43.32 cents a gallon, and April natural gas fell 6.4 cents, to $2.232 for 1,000 cubic feet.
