HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
After tough talk, can the U.S. and Japan get back to business?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
THE President's line on trade with Japan apparently played well with corporate America -- and for that matter, with the public. Typical of the reaction was the comment from Kenneth Kay, spokesman for a trade association of computer makers: President Clinton was "smart to let the Japanese Government know in no uncertain terms that the lack of progress is unacceptable," he cheered.
But now that the adrenaline rush is winding down, a lot of people are wondering how the interdependent economies are going to get back to the all-important business of business. For unlike earlier trade disputes, this one does not offer an obvious way out. 
 In their meeting in Washington, President Clinton and Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa agreed to disagree -- and then sent aides scurrying to control the damage. Senior White House officials volunteered soothing words to a group of visiting Japanese executives. And Tokyo is reportedly busy drafting a plan to show this Saturday to finance ministers meeting in Germany.
But ideas for a fix are scarce, and optimism that the scars from the confrontation will soon disappear is even scarcer. "One reason we can't solve this problem is that we don't seem to know what the problem is," said Robert Z. Lawrence of Harvard's Kennedy School of Government.
Under Mr. Hosokawa's predecessor, the issue was access to the Japanese market. Now the Administration is making no effort to correct the impression that the problem is the ballooning bilateral trade deficit -- a deficit that has little to do with trade barriers and much to do with the fact that the American economy is growing while Japan remains hubcap-deep in recession.
Another reason this wound is likely to fester, argues Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, is the inconvenient loss of a mutual enemy. Trade relations could become quite bitter in an era when the American-Japanese alliance was seen as the first line of defense against Communism in Asia. But in the end, geopoliticians in both countries would always reassert cold war priorities. "Japanese prime ministers were judged at home by how well they got along with the Americans," Mr. Hormats recalled, with just a trace of nostalgia.
Last, though hardly least, is the emotional subtext of the seemingly technical debate over "numerical indicators." Unhappy with earlier trade deals that never seemed to bear fruit, the Administration wants "targets" for market share. The Japanese argue that would amount to a big step down the road to "managed trade" in which world markets would be carved up by cartels.
For what it is worth, even most economists who believe the Japanese market is difficult to crack sympathize with the Japanese: As a comparable 1986 deal on semiconductors suggests, trade targets have a way of metamorphosing into entitlements. But Mr. Hormats thinks the point is beside the point. "The real issue is trust," he says: If policy makers in the two countries were sure their counterparts could be held to explicit commitments, there would be less haggling over semantics and more discussion of how to use numbers as benign indicators of market opening.
What, then, is to be done? Diplomats, like physicians, are inclined to temporize on the theory that problems often solve themselves. And there is certainly something to be said for allowing Mr. Hosokawa some room to patch his perilously weak political coalition.
But delay here is full of peril, if only because the Clinton Administration raised expectations that tough deeds would follow tough talk. Mr. Clinton is under pressure to invoke his broad powers to punish alleged Japanese trade perfidy. And even if he resists, Congress probably will not. That, among other reasons, is why many experts would like to see a fresh initiative from the American side.
"We already have an agreement on objective indicators," Mr. Lawrence noted. The trick now, he says, is to be creative in reassuring the Japanese that the numbers would only be used to level the playing field.
Fred Bergsten, the head of the Institute for International Economics, would like to "recover the high moral ground" by using very different policy weapons to force market access. In the case of auto parts, for example, he would like to see an antitrust suit charging collusion in restraint of trade. And in other products, he would like America to take the Japanese to a GATT dispute panel for a ruling.
But Job One, almost everyone agrees, is getting the Japanese to spend their way out of their own recession, thereby increasing demand for imports and sucking potential exports back into the Japanese market. "The big money is in macro-stimulus," Mr. Bergsten said.
Indeed, the big hope is that the very same action that would diffuse trade tensions would also shore up the Japanese Government's standing among recession-weary voters. "If we have the wits, we could still be allies with Hosokawa," Mr. Bergsten concluded.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
With a rival falling to a suitor, First Chicago gets Wall St.'s eye.

BYLINE: By Barnaby J. Feder 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
LAST month's surprising announcement that Bank of America planned to pay nearly $2 billion in stock and cash to acquire Continental Bank was taken as good news by investors in the First Chicago Corporation, Continental's longtime rival for banking pre-eminence here.
First Chicago had already gone a long way toward repairing the damage to its reputation created by a series of misguided strategic moves and bad investments in the 1980's. Earnings reports have come in above Wall Street's consensus estimates for the last six quarters. 
 Now the Continental deal has focused new attention on First Chicago's recovery, including the overhaul of corporate banking operations and the value of a strong position in credit cards and local consumer banking.
First Chicago's common shares reached $49.375 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Feb. 2, up more than 15 percent in the two weeks during which the bank released its fourth-quarter earnings and the Continental deal was announced. After being caught with other banks in a selloff related to fears of rising interest rates, the shares have begun to edge up again, closing yesterday at $47.625 a share, down 37.5 cents.
"We saw it as extensively undervalued for a long time and it is still undervalued at current prices," Diane Glossman, who follows banks for Salomon Brothers in New York, said.
Almost half of the 25 analysts who have recommendations about First Chicago's stock rate it as a buy or strong buy, and the rest have it as a hold, according to Zacks Investment Research Inc., a Chicago-based firm. The consensus earnings estimate for 1994 is $5.94 a share, and among those recently changing their projections the average is $6.07, according to Zacks.
"The management team isn't distracted by major problems," said Henry C. Dickson, a Smith Barney Shearson analyst who projects the stock will reach $60 in 12 months and who recently lowered his risk rating from high to medium. "That's a relatively new experience for them."
Analysts who are less enthusiastic say the proliferation of low-interest cards is putting pressure on the credit card business, which has been First Chicago's crown jewel. They also cite the dangers of counting too much on earnings in activities like trading and venture capital investments, both of which surged last year.
"We don't see any particular down side but I'd be surprised to see the stock up 15 percent," said Lawrence Cohn, who follows banks for Paine Webber and is neutral on First Chicago. "It's still a wholesale bank with a decent regional component that is in transition toward being more of a regional. Regionals like Norwest, Banc One and NBD still have a competitive advantage."
Analysts say that First Chicago is an unlikely takeover target given its size and the likelihood that its board would fight hard to keep Chicago's biggest and most influential bank locally based.
Still, it has not yet rebounded far enough to be able to expand easily through acquisitions of its own. That may be a problem as numerous other domestic and foreign banks angle to strengthen their presence in the Midwest and especially in the Chicago region, which is one of the most fragmented metropolitan areas in the country for banking.
Some analysts are afraid such pressures may push First Chicago to overspend on growth, a fear heightened by its decision to pay $323 million, or 2.5 times book value, for Lake Shore Bancorp Inc. in November.
"That deal undercut the reputation they had been building for discipline," Judah Kraushaar, who follows banks for Merrill Lynch, said.
Doubts may grow if First Chicago follows the Lake Shore deal with other high-priced takeovers. But that seems unlikely. Indeed, some analysts say the next significant news is likely to be a comforting dividend increase this spring.

HEADLINE: Imperfect Spies, Imperfect World

 BODY:
When James Jesus Angleton died in 1987, he was regarded with justification as brilliant but unbalanced. In his long career as chief of the C.I.A.'s counterintelligence operations, Mr. Angleton was so suspicious of Soviet trickery that he even dismissed as a charade Moscow's break with Chinese Communists. He seemed to see potential "moles" everywhere and talked continually of "dangles," "false flags" and "disinformation."
Yet there was also method in Mr. Angleton's view of "the wilderness of mirrors," his term for the duel between Soviet and American intelligence agencies. He would not have been surprised by the allegations that Moscow paid more than $1.5 million since 1985 to Aldrich Ames, who once headed the agency's Soviet counterintelligence bureau. 
 "Think of an espionage service as a highly specialized employment service," Mr. Angleton told a sympathetic chronicler, Edward Jay Epstein. He compared rival services to corporate "headhunters" -- which is evidently how Mr. Ames, in trying to recruit Soviet assets, was ensnared himself. The only way that an espionage service can safely steal documents, Mr. Angleton said, is to recruit an agent with legitimate access to secret data.
As he put it in Mr. Epstein's 1989 book, "Deception," the potential mole can be incrementally drawn into an "a subtle web of irresistible compromises." That is what Federal prosecutors say happened to Mr. Ames and his wife. To foil such penetration, Mr. Angleton instituted lie detector tests and other security measures. But his methods and suspicions got so out of hand that in 1974 he was forced to resign. But as the Ames affair suggests, the agency appears to have paid too little heed to what was valid in his warnings -- and to the potentially fatal consequences for undercover agents in the former Soviet Union.
President Clinton is right to express outrage, and he needs to grill the C.I.A. about why Mr. Ames's betrayal went undetected for so long. But the scandal should not be permitted to derail U.S.-Russian relations. Spying is an unfriendly act, but it is not an uncommon one nor an exclusively Russian activity. Does anyone seriously doubt that the C.I.A. was busily recruiting K.G.B. employees from the rubble of the Soviet empire? In the game of nations, there are no friends, only provisional allies, and even they spy on one another.
In any event, it does not take spies to know the deeper truths that shape U.S.-Russian relations. Espionage and military competition are not the keys to the two nations' future. It is fine to let Boris Yeltsin know that he has stuck his thumb in the eye of a potential ally. But neither Washington nor Moscow can let the Cold War game of spy vs. spy throw them off the path of economic and political cooperation.

HEADLINE: Virginia, Say No to the Mouse

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company excels at creating artificial wonderlands aimed at 10-year-old, television-nurtured sensibilities. Nothing wrong with that, in Anaheim or Orlando. Neither place was ever known for its cultural or natural treasures.
Prince William County, Va., is another matter entirely. It is a region of natural beauty and historical importance, flanked by the Blue Ridge Mountains and the Civil War shrines of Manassas. Its rolling farmland preserves a piece of rural America, with roots in the country's earliest settlement. 
 In its midst the Walt Disney Company now proposes to erect something called Disney's America -- an amusement park with American history as its theme. The people from Anaheim say they have something valuable to add to 3,000 rural acres as yet untouched by suburban mallification, next to the site of the two battles of Bull Run at Manassas, where almost 20,000 Union and Confederate soldiers lost their lives in 1861 and 1862.
The nearest town to the proposed park is Haymarket, population 375. To this bit of earth Disney would bring a new city of 7,000 and 30,000 visitors a day. The usual Mickey Mouse fantasy stuff would be supplemented with a roller coaster ride through a reproduction of an early steelworks, a depiction of plantation life (complete with slaves), whizzbang "Audio-Animatronics" images of dead Presidents, and other history-related entertainments.
The Disney Company is hoping to capitalize on the flow of tourists to the Washington area, and to sell its idea with ersatz history. Make no mistake: What the kids would remember about such an experience would be the technology and the thrills, not the history. This is not an educational undertaking; it is a business venture.
Disney wants Virginia taxpayers to cough up more than $150 million to build roads and other infrastructure. Virginia's new Governor, George Allen, says the project is the keystone in the state's "economic renaissance." Members of the Democratic-controlled state Legislature are not so sure. But even the skeptics seem about to bow to the pressure of Disney lobbying in Richmond. The debate in Virginia's House and Senate is not whether they should spend money but how much.
Have these politicians forgotten who they are? Virginia is not an Alabama or a South Carolina that must pay investors to settle there. Virginia is one of the jewels of the Eastern Seaboard, home to Jamestown and colonial Williamsburg. It is a state with a relatively low unemployment rate; the northern counties where Disney wants to build have low unemployment even by Virginia standards.
Taxpayers would have no guarantee of a return on their investment. And Disney doesn't need the money. The company is merely hoping Virginia will come up with the cash under the threat that The Mouse -- as locals have begun calling it -- will scamper home. That is precisely what Virginians should let it do.
Fortunately, the House has attached a rider to its bill requiring a second look at the proposal and a second vote before adjournment this spring. That should give legislators time to come to their senses, and opponents more time to bring reason to bear on the Governor's cries of economic emergency.
Boosters will no doubt protest "outsiders" taking an interest in a "local" issue. But the proposed Disneyfication of this unique countryside raises questions of national importance. Haymarket is not 42d street or Florida piney woods. Putting a theme park there degrades a scenic and historic resource for a project that can be built elsewhere. This is precisely the sort of exurban zoning issue that will proliferate in a 21st-century America with more people and fewer well-preserved natural areas.
If Disney walks away, Virginia's economy will still be sound, and its role as a custodian of important national resources will be stronger. As for parents who want to give their children history, let them -- like generations before them -- make the trip to Prince William County. Let them sit still at Manassas, and listen for the presence of the dead.

HEADLINE: Officials Say 'Cut!' to Subway Violence on Film

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
The New York City subway system, the setting of the chaotic chase in "The French Connection," the train hijacking in "The Taking of Pelham One-Two-Three" and countless other cinematic scenes of crime, is seeking a more pristine image by refusing to allow producers to film scenes in the subway that officials think are too violent.
Transit Authority officials say such scenes are at odds with a reduction in subway crime in recent years and create an impression of a dangerous system that could threaten ridership. But representatives of the film industry in New York say restrictions by the Transit Authority smack of censorship and could harm the health of the city's film industry, which spent $1.3 billion in the five boroughs in 1992.
 
Contrary to Reality?
 "We've been very successful in the last two or three years in reducing violence and increasing ridership." said Jared Lebow, a Transit Authority spokesman. "We want to protect our investment and increase ridership. We don't look fondly on projects that depict the system as being out of control." 
 Although Mr. Lebow and other transit officials say there is no written policy covering what kind of scenes they will allow to be filmed, he said: "We don't want bullets whizzing around subway cars. We don't want bloody bodies strewn all over the subway cars."
Al Gallardo, the agency's director of government and community relations, said officials were particularly concerned with protecting ridership, which has finally begun to recover after years of decline. "We don't want to create this image that the subways are not safe," he said. "You don't want to have senseless violence -- shootings, bombings in the subway system. That affects ridership."
Jeffrey Hayes, producer of the television series "Law and Order" which is filmed in New York, called the Transit Authority's move curious. "What else are you going to film there, a love story in the subway?" he said.
Many movies and television shows use scenes of characters riding the subway as a way of evoking the city's atmosphere. But its dark, ominous tunnels are still a draw to producers who want to portray the underbelly of city life, as was done in "Carlito's Way" and "King of New York."
Mr. Lebow said transit officials recently declined to cooperate in a film about a mob chief who, unbeknownst to the authorities, is headquartered in the subway system. "We said no," Mr. Lebow said. "It's such a fantasy. It suggests we don't know what's going on in the subway system."
Mr. Lebow said the agency has been trying to restrict scenes of violence over the last year or so. The move comes amid an increase in the number of movie projects since the end of a boycott of the city by major film producers caused by contract disputes with movie unions.
 
Claims of Censorship
 Richard Brick, a film producer who until last month was the commissioner of the mayor's Office of Film, Theatre and Broadcasting, said the agency should not be making judgments based on script content. "They should only be concerned with issues of safety as a condition of their cooperation," he said.
"The subway and buses of New York are characters as much as the Empire State Building and the Brooklyn Bridge, and film makers are drawn here in part to portray those icons," Mr. Brick said. "I hope they would be permitted to portray realistically the conditions in the subway system or on the buses."
Bruce Feinberg, the director of the Governor's Office for Motion Picture and Television Development, who met with the authority president, Alan F. Kiepper, because of concerns that the Transit Authority was being too restrictive, said yesterday that he was told that the authority had no "hard and fast policy" but that "they are concerned about violence, about how the system is portrayed."
"I know he would love to see a love story, a warm and fuzzy love story that takes place in the subway," Mr. Feinberg said of Mr. Kiepper. He said Mr. Kiepper pledged cooperation on films about darker subjects as well.
 
Exploding Stations
 Mr. Feinberg said Mr. Kiepper agreed to work with city officials and officials at Columbia Pictures who are developing a movie called "The Money Train," about police officers' hijacking of a subway train that collects tokens from stations.
Mr. Feinberg said "The Money Train" was expected to have a $45 million budget. He said he told Mr. Kiepper that if films set in New York were not able to be made in the city, producers would simply make a new location look like New York.
Robert Curran, the director of the Pittsburgh Film Office, said yesterday that his office was contacted by people involved with "Die Hard 3" interested in getting information on the city's subway system. He said he understood they were looking at subway systems across the country.
A spokesman for the movie's producer, Cinergi, which is based in Santa Monica, Calif., said it was too soon to talk about plans for the movie.
Charles Darby, deputy commissioner for the city's film office, said the movie was tentatively planned as a violent action film staring Bruce Willis set in the New York City subway system, complete with exploding subway stations.
Mr. Curran said any limits placed on the content of films shot in the New York City subways would help other cities win movie business. "I think the more important message it would send, that would ultimately benefit Pittsburgh and other cities trying to take business from New York, is New York is not a cooperative place to work," he said.
Mr. Lebow said while officials were sensitive to the economic concerns of the city, "we feel we have a responsibility to preserve a realistic portrait of the system."
Mr. Lebow said proposed scripts were reviewed for issues of safety and feasibility as well as content. If the authority agrees to cooperate, producers are required to pay any costs incurred by the subway system.
Mr. Darby said the Transit Authority historically is not enthusiastic about having film makers in the subway system. In fact since its anti-graffiti campaign of the 1980's the authority has forbidden film makers to depict graffiti in the system.

HEADLINE: Bradley Rebukes Clinton on Japan

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23

 BODY:
In an unusually pointed rebuke of his own party's leader, Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey charged today that President Clinton's hard line on Japan trade policy was "gratuitous brinkmanship" that puts the United States' long-term economic and strategic interests at risk in pursuit of domestic political gain.
"I mean, it's kind of Japan-bashing for domestic constituency, without regard to the long-term strategic interests of the country, not even achieving the short-term objective, which is getting the bilateral trade deficit down," the Senator said in an interview in his office that he solicited to talk about Japanese trade. 
 Mr. Bradley, an outspoken advocate of free trade, has occasionally weighed in with a dissenting Democratic voice on a range of policy issues. However, he is one of the Administration's most reliable backers in the Senate and has rarely so sharply criticized Mr. Clinton, a fellow Rhodes Scholar whom he declined to challenge for the Presidential nomination two years ago.
 
 
Risk Cited
 He said that by allowing trade talks with Japan to collapse two weeks ago and threatening retaliation, the United States risked undermining Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's nascent efforts at internal reforms that could open markets and strengthen the Japanese economy.
Indeed, by insisting on specific numerical benchmarks to show whether Japan was opening various markets to goods from the United States and other countries, the White House could force Mr. Hosokawa, he said, into greater reliance on the labyrinthine Japanese bureaucracy, which has resisted change.
At the same time, Mr. Bradley said, the Administration had left Mr. Hosokawa -- and not Washington -- looking like the advocate of free trade in the developing economies of Southeast Asia, which would be a major target of future American exports.
"This opens it up for the Japanese to become the champions of free trade, and for us to become the country pushing for that which is clearly seen as not in the interests of some of these other Asian countries, which is where most of the growth, most of the investment, most of the exports and most of the jobs in this country are going to be created in exporting," he said.
The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, the Administration's top trade negotiator, responded tonight: "The Japanese have had a sanctuary market, which they have protected for decades. It has resulted in a failure to open markets not only to the U.S. but for other countries, which has created economic and political problems in the world trading system."
Mr. Kantor said the Administration respected Mr. Bradley as a friend but could not understand his comments.
"When the Senate Finance Committee was briefed on this, he could not attend," Mr. Kantor said, "and I think part of it may be a misunderstanding of what we are attempting to achieve. Part of it may be the frustration that we all feel that these markets remain closed and have such a pernicious effect on world trade."
Since the talks collapsed, some Democratic politicians have quietly worried that taking too hard a stance could prompt an all-out trade war. But Mr. Bradley, a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's panel on international trade, was the first to voice his concerns so publicly.
 
 
Dispute Resolution 'Mechanism'
 He said today that he favored a dispute resolution "mechanism" to end arguments over access to market sectors that American companies cannot penetrate -- like pulp and paper and telecommunications -- because of Japanese restrictions.
But he left unclear precisely how such disputes would be arbitrated, saying, "I don't have all the details worked out, but the idea is if you have a problem in the flat-glass sector, you have a procedure set out where, publicly, you lay out what all the facts are, and then you kind of have a way of determining is that correct or not."
Mr. Bradley also said the two countries were dependent on each other to confront the nuclear threat in North Korea, and to deal with Russia and China, and should not risk impairing cooperation.
 
 
'We're in Control'
 Asked what political constituency Mr. Clinton was playing to, Mr. Bradley said, "You'd have to talk to the pollster. I don't know." But he said of the public debate, "I think that people want to believe that somehow or other we're not in control of our destiny, that somebody is victimizing us. I mean, we're in control of our destiny." He added: "It's easy to say it's their fault. It's harder to say, O.K., well, let's think a little more strategically here than some sector-specific number."
The Senator also said he believed the debate was tinged with decades of anti-Japanese sentiment, noting that early Japanese immigrants had sought to assimilate into American life, joining political groups and serving in the military, "right up until they were interned" during World War II. "At the same time this was happening," he said, "American officials were saying, 'Oh, you can't trust the Japanese.' So now when you hear the words, 'Trust, but quantify,' there's a historical resonance that goes back to the early period of Japanese immigration."
Noting that some of the architects of the Clinton trade policy had dealt firsthand with Japanese barriers as private investment bankers, Mr. Bradley said: "When you are representing a client, your objective is to get the client into the market. When you are leading a country, your objective is to further the strategic interests of the country, which are geopolitical, political and economic, in the broadest sense of the words, particularly at a time of significant transition in the world."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 26, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Thursday, about Senator Bill Bradley's criticism of the Clinton Administration's trade policy with Japan, misidentified one committee on which Mr. Bradley sits. It is the Senate Finance subcommittee on international trade, not the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on international trade.

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeking to Ease Restrictions On Export of High-Tech Products

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today proposed the first major overhaul of American export controls since the cold war, aiming to ease the sale abroad of machine tools, telecommunications equipment and other devices that had been restricted because they could be used to make sophisticated weapons of mass destruction.
Clinton Administration officials said the legislation to rewrite the 1979 Export Administration Act, which expires in June, is intended to balance the Administration's commitment to nonproliferation with its desire to promote and increase American exports, a driving force in the economic recovery. 
 But the proposed legislation satisfied neither the business community, which found it still too restrictive compared with other countries' export laws, nor the arms control community, which said it would open the floodgates for rogue regimes to acquire advanced weapons-making technology. Leading business groups said they would continue to support competing proposals.
The introduction of the export-control legislation was coupled with a Commerce Department announcement that it was further relaxing restrictions on the sale abroad of powerful computers, making high-speed mainframe computers widely available for export to all but a few outlaw countries. This fulfills part of the President's commitment last September to reform outdated export controls on computers.
The Commerce Department maintains rigorous safeguards on the export of all supercomputers. But today it revised its definition of a supercomputer from a machine that can perform 195 million theoretical operations per second, or mtops, to one that can perform 1,500. Mtops is a measure of computer performance created by the Government. Any computer under 1,500 mtops -- which is most high-performance computers -- can now be more easily sold abroad.
Administration officials said the easing of restrictions on computer exports alone had the potential to unleash some $30 billion in computer sales abroad. The rewriting of the overall export-control law, if passed, would add to that figure, by opening the way for more American exports of certain advanced machine tools, telecommunications equipment, chemicals and other high-tech equipment that had been banned for export because of their weapons potential.
The Administration said that many of these high-tech electronic devices or chemicals were already widely available on the world market and that only the United States was holding back its exporters.
Officials acknowledged that some of the equipment that will now be released for export could be helpful to weapons manufacturers. But they said the new legislation, which Congress began debating today, would continue to control exports of the most advanced technologies that could be used to develop nuclear, chemical or biological weapons and the ballistic missile systems to deliver them.
Introducing the Administration's legislation, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said, "We feel it strikes the critical balance between nonproliferation concerns and economic interests."
 
 
'Christmas Tree' of Exports
 But the arms control organizations disputed that assessment.
"Rather than a balanced law, Clinton has created a Christmas tree for American exporters, with presents beyond their wildest dreams," said Gary Milhollin, director of the Wisconsin Project on Nuclear Arms Control. "As with Iraq, we will have to send U.S. pilots again to bomb things our industry has exported.
"The basic problem with this law is that it sacrifices U.S. national security to a misguided quest for quick export dollars. This bill pays Clinton's debt to Silicon Valley, which backed him early and backed him big."
Moreover, critics say that at a time when Russia's future direction seems increasingly cloudy, and when it is no longer certain whether Moscow is friend or foe, the changes will also make it easier for Russia to upgrade its military industries and quickly ship more exports abroad to the likes of Iran or Libya.
The export controls were originally imposed during the cold war to keep sensitive computer, composite materials and telecommunications technology out of the hands of Communist countries. There was much interagency squabbling over how far the bill should lift unilateral American controls on sensitive technology exports, with the Commerce Department pushing for the cold war lid to come off as far as possible and the Defense and State departments trying to hold it down a little more. The interagency tussle forced the Administration to delay the introduction of its proposal twice.
These are among the highlights of the revised bill:
*It would give individual American companies broader new rights to petition for the elimination of export controls when they have an unfair business impact -- usually meaning that the proposed export is widely available from other countries.
*It would set much tighter restrictions on the United States Government's ability to impose or renew export controls on products that other nations are already widely selling on the world market.
*It would require that all licensing decisions be made, or referred to the President, within no more than 90 days, with the vast majority of decisions made at lower levels. If no decision was made, the exporter would be allowed to go ahead by default.
*It would provide for an interagency dispute mechanism, so that if the Commerce and State departments disagreed about a proposed sale, cases could be quickly shifted to the highest levels for a decision.
*It would require clearer and more complete statements as to why any controls were being maintained.
 
 
Focus on Military Uses
 The legislation is based on the principle that when the Government tries to control everything, it controls nothing well. Therefore, having stripped out many of the outdated controls, the bill tries to focus on technologies with dangerous military applications that would directly threaten the United States or its allies. For instance, the bill would maintain tight controls on the export of any American stealth technology that could be used to conceal aircraft from advanced radar.
The bill eliminates controls for technologies that are already widely available, but it maintains certain restrictions on exports to unfriendly regimes like those in Iran or North Korea, no matter how available the goods may be from exporters in other countries. "We're not going to sell cattle prods to Iran, no matter who else is selling them," one senior official said.
Nevertheless, groups representing manufacturers of computers, telecommunications equipment and chemical products denounced the Administration's bill for not going far enough and said they would continue to support a less restrictive package put together by business interests and sponsored by Representative Toby Roth, Republican of Wisconsin, and and Senator Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington.
 
 
Competitive Concerns
 Business groups complained that the new law would still leave them at a competitive disadvantage against big European exporters, whose governments put few restrictions, if any, on where businesses from their nations can conduct business.
Howard Lewis, vice president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said, "As an initiative to reform the export-control system, the Administration's proposal just doesn't measure up."
He and others argued that too many unilateral American controls would persist on high-technology products that are easy to buy elsewhere in the world. They also asserted that the law would not clearly establish who was authorized to make decisions and accountable for making them, and that the law would not clearly tell American companies what not to export, or to whom.

HEADLINE: Homeless Seeing Less Apathy, More Anger

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

 BODY:
The old man stands so still against a wall at Grand Central Terminal that he seems part of it, a rundown monument to homelessness rising from the cigarette butts. Charlie Buchanan never begs, he watches, and what he sees is the end of an era.
New York was never a gentle city, but for years it let him drift along the currents of its sidewalks. Now he says police officers treat him like a trespasser. People who used to smile or nod do not even look at him, as if they left their heart in their other suit. 
 "It's not that people are meaner," Mr. Buchanan said. "It's that they're weary."
He glimpsed it first in 1988 or '89, the start of what would be a growing national impatience with the ever-increasing presence of dirty and desperate people. Over time that frustration turned to apathy and then anger, not just here but in Baltimore, Philadelphia, and other cities where ideology has given way to an uncomfortable reality.
 
Indifferent Passers-By
 In Seattle, the homeless are fined if they sit on sidewalks during business hours. In San Francisco, where the sheer number of homeless was strangling the downtown, even liberals agreed to push them out of sight and mind. In Miami, a homeless enclave burned its bayside shantytown rather than watch the police rip it down.
The homeless and their advocates fight back with the usual lawsuits, but the clear consensus, at street level, is that they have lost the crusade for the public conscience.
Many passers-by seem to have become numb. As the homeless crisis moves through a second decade, New York has tens of thousands of street people and legions of beggars in midtown and lower Manhattan.
"The sight of them generates a sense of the future very much at odds with the American dream," said William Erlbaum, a New York criminal courts judge who teaches on the homeless at York College, the City University of New York. "People, in this case, turned their anger on the victim."
Not all signs are bleak. The number of volunteers to help the homeless has never been higher, said Mary Brosnahan, executive director of the Coalition for the Homeless in New York. And, as Mr. Buchanan acknowledged, the really good-hearted people, the ones who are not afraid to touch him, are still good.
"The ones we're losing are the ones in the middle, the ones on the fence," said Wayne Elliott, echoing other homeless people. "They're the ones that are changing."
The evidence of the shifting attitude is not hard to find. Three weeks ago in Little Italy, two well-dressed men stood over an older homeless man, cursing him as two police officers stood by laughing. In Times Square two weeks ago, a man shoved a homeless man to the sidewalk because he approached his date for money. Last week in the East Village, five teen-agers shouted curses at a crippled homeless man. They used to give him cigarettes.
Jozel Williams, who walks with a limp and lives in a box in front of an old warehouse in the meatpacking district, said he does not know why people who used to be nice to him now either ignore him or try to abuse him, but it happens almost every day. People tell him to get a job, or to take a bath.
"It's like they got to rub your face in it," he said, warming his feet by a fire in a garbage can.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who said he would prosecute homeless people for assault if they intimidate people by begging too aggressively, who has granted the police more latitude in dealing with the homeless, has been blamed by some homeless people for creating the mean atmosphere. But the longtime homeless say the Mayor is just a product of the times.
"City Hall, the cops, they're only mean when they know the people are on their side," said Mr. Elliott, who sells Street News, a newspaper that the homeless peddle to make money.
Subway signs ban panhandlers. For Roger Robertson, homeless for four years, unemployed forever, the signs are insults, like the old "NO COLORED ALLOWED" signs. The subway signs should read, "NO HOMELESS," he said.
"Because that's what they're really saying," he said.
 
Looking for Peace But Finding Abuse
 In a city filled with beggars, the 61-year-old Mr. Buchanan never asks for one thin dime.
"It's not that I think this city owes me a living, because I don't," he said three weeks ago, pressed up against the wall at Grand Central Terminal.
He just wants to lie down at night and not feel the dehumanizing tap of a nightstick, telling him to move on. He wants to enjoy the warmth of a fourth blanket, and the flavor of a free sandwich. Because when everything else has fallen through, the sidewalk is solid ground.
But it is harder to live peacefully now; more and more police officers force him to keep walking. "I ain't mad, not at them," he said. "They're just doing it because they're told to keep people moving. People like me."
A laid-off packing house worker from Attleboro, Mass., Mr. Buchanan looks 20 years older than he is, his face half hidden by a gray beard that, because he eats most meals on the move, often has soup in it. "I don't bother nobody," he said, but that hasn't saved him.
One night recently, as he lay in an alcove on Madison Avenue, a car came screeching to a stop at the curb and several young men jumped out.
The first thing he thought was that they were going to burn him.
All they did was throw eggs at him.
"I just covered up my head," he said.
Mr. Buchanan can live with a certain amount of cruelty. The thing he hates about the hardening attitude is that it gives people the excuse to ignore him. In a world where the daily pain of living tugs people off into madness, he is anchored by the occasional kind word.
To have them look but not see him does something to him inside. It may not seem too important, in a city where people do not even look at one another in elevators, but the way people ignore the homeless is different.
"It is the worst thing," Mr. Buchanan said.
 
Counting on Coins In Others' Pockets

It has happened before, in the late 1800's, during the Great Depression, when the presence of the homeless intruded too far into the mainstream, Judge Erlbaum said.
Roger Robertson may be the greatest intruder of all.
He is certain that, deep in some pocket, there is money for him. One night in late January he tracked five teen-agers four blocks on 51st Street, followed them to a delicatessen, and waited outside till they came out with some change. It took 20 minutes and he made 17 cents.
Life is changing.
"They'll walk out in traffic now, to keep from walking close to you," he said.
The city seems smaller now. Businesses that would let him stand inside and get warm shut him out. The free coffee no longer flows. Day-old pastries, the little delicacies that he could always count on, he finds in the garbage bags now.
He used to like to sleep on the trains. It was warm, and as long as he paid his token he had a right. But now transit officers shake him awake and order him off the train if he rides it too far or too long.
"The truth is they don't want me on it," he said. "The people don't like to sit by me."
When the police see him working the corners near the hotels in midtown, they tell him to leave, Mr. Robertson said. He is 28, and says he has not had a real home since he was 18. This, is home.
"They're telling me I don't have the right to stand on the sidewalk," he said. "They're telling me I have no right to stick my hand out. Everybody's got their hand out in New York City."
Farther down 51st Street, a homeless man waits until people refuse him, then shoves the stump of his left hand in their face so they can get a good look.
Around the corner at Rockefeller Center, a cold-looking, ghostly pale young woman drifts out of the dark and begs for her children.
Mr. Robertson has news for New York. People like him have always been here, and always will be.
 
Growing Impatience From Working Poor
 Devon Service rides by them in his taxi, and any pity he used to feel is gone.
" 'Give me a quarter, give me a quarter,' that's what they say to me," he said. "I have to drive four blocks to make a quarter."
He is Jamaican. He understands poverty. He does not understand people who beg, who go dirty. If it was up to him, people who make homelessness a life style would be shot.
"I guess I don't have a soft heart," Mr. Service said.
Rosalee Curcio works in a restaurant for minimum wage and tips. She puts her change in a jar, the only savings account she has. She wants to buy a stereo.
For a long time, she would drop a nickel, never more, into the cup of a man who worked the corner near her house. But it has been months now, he is still begging and she is still hoarding her fortune in a jar and dancing to a cheap radio.
Now she keeps her money. Recently a different panhandler followed her for several blocks until she screamed at him, begging him to leave her alone.
"The cops have to do something," she said, "or we won't be able to go outside."
Advocates for the homeless say the impatience is citywide.
"As we entered the second decade of this crisis, we stopped seeing them as people in pain," Ms. Brosnahan said. "We started seeing them as fixtures, like mailboxes and lamp posts. After 12 years there are more homeless than ever out there.
"People started to think there is no solution."
Judge Erlbaum said many people have tried to redefine homelessness, to remove people in genuine need from the genre. It makes it easier for conservative politicians to pass laws that restrict their very presence, he said.
"How can it be a crime," he asked, "to give alms to the mendicant?"
 
Finding at City Hall, A Get-Tough Policy
 To the homeless, he is the personification of the public attitude, a man who rode fear and prejudice into the Mayor's office, blaming them for adding to the sense of chaos in the city.
Mr. Giuliani said he has been misunderstood. Homeless people who break no laws have no reason to be afraid of him.
"The people engaged in aggressive or criminal behavior, those people have found there is a difference now in the enforcement of the law," Mr. Giuliani said.
"They do have more latitude and discretion," he said of the beat officers. "We want them to have more discretion to solve problems on the street, to tell someone to move on, tell people to stop aggressive activity. The reason why they are there is to prevent crime. If they are going to do that, we have to empower them."
Mr. Giuliani said those changes must be accomplished without brutality.
But several police officers, who did not want their names used because they fear retribution in the department, said officers now feel free to use their nightsticks on belligerent homeless people, because of Mr. Giuliani's get-tough attitude, and because they believe the public is behind them.
This comes at a time when the Federal Government, for the first time in 12 years, has called the homeless crisis a full-scale national problem.
Mr. Elliott, the homeless vendor, has it figured out.
"There's too many of us."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Fights Restriction on Filming in Subways

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday criticized the Transit Authority for restricting the filming of violent movie and television sequences in the subway system, saying attempts to screen the content of films raised freedom-of-speech questions and gave the mistaken impression that the city did not welcome movie producers and their big budgets.
"I don't think you get the choice, if you want movies made in your city, to say, 'Well, the movie has to be favorable with regard to the subways,' or 'The movie has to be favorable with regard to the city,' " Mr. Giuliani said. He said that by seeking to do that, "you're getting into pretty dangerous grounds with regard to the First Amendment." 
 He said that other than determining if a proposed film project poses logistical or safety problems, ruling on the content of a script "is an area where government doesn't really have a role."
 
A Decrease in Crime
 Transit Authority officials said they were refusing to allow the filming of violent scenes because they do not accurately portray the system, which has shown a decrease in crime in the last three years, and because they feel it threatens its ridership. Jared Lebow, an authority spokesman, said yesterday that since the authority was a creation of the city and state governments, it would "not turn a deaf ear" to suggestions by the Mayor or by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo that its position on movies was losing business for the region.
The director of the Governor's Office for Motion Picture and Television Development, Bruce Feinberg, met with Transit Authority officials on Wednesday to discuss the policy and said he was satisfied that despite their concern over the image of the subway, they would not be overly restrictive.
Mr. Giuliani also said that the city was actively trying to attract producers of feature films, commercials and television shows to work in the city and that "I wish the M.T.A. would be a little more sensitive here." The Transit Authority is part of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
A recent city study said film work added about $1.3 billion to the city's economy in 1992. "We want people to come to New York and make movies," Mr. Giuliani said. "We want them to do it in a way that enhances this city ecnomically."
He noted that "Serpico" was made in New York with the cooperation of the city even though it portrayed corruption in the Police Department. He said movies advertise the city and "you have to take some that give us advertising that we don't want in return for the ones that give us very, very good advertising and gives us a really good impression of the city."

HEADLINE: Option May Doom Budget Amendment (for Now)

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Democratic opponents of the proposed constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget offered a counterproposal today that seemed likely to lead to the defeat of all versions of the plan.
The substitute version was intended to serve as a political fig leaf that would allow some Senators to vote for the measure and then, after its near-certain defeat, vote against the original version and still tell constituents they had supported a balanced budget amendment. 
 The strategy would divide the Senate and probably insure that opponents would have the 34 votes needed to block adoption of any constitutional amendment.
The substitute, offered by Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, would open several additional loopholes in the basic amendment, which has already been frequently attacked as ineffective and no more than a political smoke screen.
 
Gimmickry Is Charged
 Each side denounced the other's proposal as a political gimmick.
Senator Paul E. Simon, the Illinois Democrat who has pushed the basic balanced budget amendment for years, called the substitute version "political gamesmanship." He said it was "cover for those who want to go back home and say, 'I voted for a balanced budget amendment' " and then "vote against the real thing."
But Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, scoffed at the Simon forces for inserting provisions that would delay the amendment's taking effect until 2001 and would prohibit the courts from acting on it. He said the pair of provisions "pushes it off into the next century and makes it certain that it can never be enforced."
The basic amendment says that "total outlays for any fiscal year cannot exceed total receipts" unless Congress agrees to a deficit by a three-fifths vote in both houses. It would require separate three-fifths votes to add to the national debt.
The Simon amendment does not say how the deficit is to be eliminated, leaving Congress to choose among the full range of increased taxes and cuts in discretionary spending and entitlements like Social Security.
Opponents have repeatedly called the proposed amendment sloganeering instead of action. Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, said, "The promise it makes today is that tough decisions will be made tomorrow."
Senator Reid's substitute would free Social Security spending from any risk of cuts, would allow the Government to establish a separate budget for capital spending outside the deficit rules, without defining what a capital expenditure was and would remove the ban on deficit financing during a recession. Like the Simon proposal, it would also declare that the courts could not enforce the amendment.
Senator Reid was the only supporter of his amendment to declare tonight that he would vote against the Simon amendment if his proposal failed.
But foes of the Simon proposal thought the chance to vote for the alternative would make it easier for them to get others to vote against Mr. Simon's version. Several singled out Senator Wendell H. Ford of Kentucky, Senator Mitchell's deputy leader, as a senator who might vote for the substitute and then against the Simon amendment. Mr. Ford said tonight that it was too early to say what he might do.
Twenty-six senators have publicly declared their opposition to the Simon amendment. Six others are seen by their staffs or their colleagues as almost certain to vote against it.
So to get the 34 needed to reject the Simon plan, opponents would have to find two votes from among another six senators, including Mr. Ford, who have either voted for the proposal before or have expressed some sympathy for it this year. Some, like Mr. Ford, have even been one of its sponsors.
 
A Vow to Continue
 Tuesday's votes in the Senate will not end this year's battles over the issue. In the House, 218 supporters of the basic amendment announced plans today to force a vote late next month. Even if the Senate defeats the proposal first, a successful two-thirds vote in the 435-member House would set the stage for a renewed effort, though probably not until next year.
Senator Simon's chief Republican ally, Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, warned: "This pressure is not going to go away. If we fail to do it this year, we'll be back again."
The Reid amendment would also take effect in 2001, and would require a three-fifths vote for deficit financing, except in wartime, or during a recession, as determined by the Congressional Budget Office. It would not require three-fifth majorities to raise the national debt.
Mr. Hatch called the Reid substitute "a sham." He said that its undefined exclusion of capital investments demonstrated it was phony.
"Why, it could cover everything from education to transportation," he said. "Virtually anything could be excluded from being covered by a balanced budget amendment."

HEADLINE: Bosnia Muslims and Croats To Discuss Proposal in U.S.

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
The Administration said today that it would play host to talks in Washington this weekend on an American-backed peace plan for Bosnia that would unite those parts of the country held by Muslims with those held by Croats, a senior State Department official said today.
The goal of the plan, which is only beginning to take shape but has the backing of Secretary of State Warren Christopher, is to avoid a three-way partition of Bosnia and Herzegovina along ethnic and religious lines. 
 Rather, it is intended to create an independent state of at least the Muslims and Croats, who were allies against Bosnian Serb nationalists in the first stage of the civil war that began nearly two years ago.
The obvious gap in the plan is that it does not deal concretely with the Serbs, who control more than 70 percent of Bosnia's territory and would not have much reason to accept such a proposal without some inducement.
Under the plan, the Muslim-led Bosnian Government and the Bosnian Croats could unite territory under their control into a number of municipalities defined as Muslim or as Croat depending on who forms a majority.
 
Talks to Last Several Days
 The talks, which could begin as early as Saturday and are expected to last two or three days, are another sign that the Administration is moving rapidly to seek a diplomatic settlement in Bosnia after abandoning its hands-off policy two weeks ago.
Charles E. Redman, the United States envoy to the former Yugoslavia, plans to bring together Bosnia's Prime Minister, Haris Silajdzic; the political leader of the Bosnian Croats, Kresimir Zubak, and Croatia's Foreign Minister, Mate Granic. Mr. Christopher is also expected to meet with the officials at some point, said the senior State Department official who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Mr. Silajdzic, who is in Washington meeting with senior Administration officials and key members of Congress, welcomed the development and Washington's expanded role.
"The Administration is being helpful," the Prime Minister told reporters as he met with Mr. Christopher. "We are focusing on the possibility of a rapprochement with the Croats. We believe it to be the first step toward peace in Bosnia."
 
Last Year's Plan Revived
 The plan, which grew out of talks last year between Bosnia's President, Alija Izetbegovic, and Croatia's President, Franjo Tudjman, was revived two weeks ago by the Bosnian Government.
In a suggestion of how ambitious, and perhaps remote, the plan's goals may be when compared with the situation in Bosnia, the official even said it called for unifying the military forces of the Bosnian Croats and Muslims.
The two sides, which have been fighting in central and southwest Bosnia for more than 10 months, signed a cease-fire agreement only on Wednesday.
The Administration's strategy is to help work out a joint Muslim-Croatian entity in Bosnia that would then join in a financial and economic confederation with the Croatian Republic, the official said. That relationship could include freedom of travel and goods, a common currency and cooperation on issues like the environment.
 
Call for 'Greater Croatia'
 Some of the Bosnian Croat leaders have called in recent months for creating a "Greater Croatia" by joining Bosnian territory they hold to the Croatian Republic. Asked if the Administration's plan would put the Muslims at risk of being swallowed up by Croatia, which has several thousand troops fighting in Bosnia, the State Department official dismissed that danger.
In theory the Muslim-Croatian entity would then ask the Bosnian Serbs to join it. The Administration's notion is that the Serbs will somehow prefer to be aligned with what the United States envisions as a democratic, economically vibrant entity, rather than try to secede from Bosnia and link their territory to a "Greater Serbia."
Senior Administration officials stressed today that the Muslim-Croat initiative still requires the Bosnian Serbs to make territorial concessions. The United States has been pressing Bosnia's Government to define its exact territorial requirements.
The idea is to build on a plan in principle endorsed by the three factions last August for a loose Bosnian union of three republics. Under that agreement, 33.3 percent of the territory would go to the Bosnian Government, 17.5 percent to the Croats and the rest, almost 50 percent, to the Serbs.
 
Carrots for Croatia
 As an inducement to the Bosnian Croats and the Croatian Government, the United States plan holds out economic and political incentives.
Croatia would no longer be threatened by economic sanctions because of its military and financial backing for the Bosnian Croats. Both the Bosnian Government and the Croatian Government could be given access to Western European economic organizations and would be invited to take part in a NATO offer of a loose security alliance (but not NATO membership).
The Muslims have dismissed earlier proposals that envisioned the union of two Muslim and Croatian pieces of territory, rather than a federated state, because they feared that the Croatian fraction of Bosnia would be annexed by Zagreb or secede to it.
At the moment, the Bosnian Croats are resisting the idea of creating "ethnic" municipalities, fearing that they will be dominated by the Muslims, who outnumber them. Senior Administration officials said the Bosnian Croats are seeking guarantees that their interests will be protected in areas where a Muslim population is predominant.
Muslims made up 44 percent of Bosnia's prewar population of 2.2 million, while the Serbs made up 31 percent and the Croats 17 percent. Vast shifts of refugees during the 22 months of fighting have made it difficult to update those estimates.
In some respects, Washington's plan resembles the now-defunct Vance-Owen plan, which sought to preserve the ethnic mix of the Bosnian state by dividing the country into 10 ethnically based provinces.
One idea under discussion is that the Muslim- and Croat-controlled territory be governed in a complex, three-layered arrangement. Each of the ethnic municipalities would have a local government; two higher governing bodies would represent all of the Muslim and all of the Croatian regions, and a unified federal government in Sarajevo.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Tudjman Seems Supportive
 ZAGREB, Croatia, Feb. 24 (AP) -- President Franjo Tudjman seemed to bow to international pressure this evening and to accept the idea of a Croat-Muslim state within Bosnia.
Embracing such an idea marks a sharp shift for Mr. Tudjman, who has long flirted with the idea of dividing Bosnia between Croats and Serbs without yielding Muslims any land.
He appeared to indicate in his speech that a Muslim-Croat federation in Bosnia would join in some way with Croatia. But a senior official in Washington said that an entire two-republic Bosnia, with separate Muslim-Croat and Serb areas, would have some sort of federation with Croatia.
"The international community is persuading us that the Croatian people in Bosnia and Herzegovina should live together with the Muslims," Mr. Tudjman said. "The outcome of this could be federation of Muslims and Croats within Bosnia and federation with Croatia. This is acceptable to us."

GRAPHIC: Maps: "Visions of Peace vs. Bosnia's Reality" shows the following geographical representations of Bosnia and Herzegovina:
 
The Vance-Owen Plan
January to May 1993
 The first plan, drafted by the United Nations and the European Community, called for dividing of Bosnia into 10 semiautonomous provinces with a shared zone and weak central government in Sarajevo. It ultimately rejected by the Serbs.
 
The European Plan
July 1993 to February 1994
 The European Community proposed that Bosnia be divided into three republics along ethnic lines. The Muslim-led Government has rejected several drafts, demanding more land, several strategic towns and better access to ports on the Sava River and the Adriatic Sea.
 
Who Holds What Now
 Serbian forces have kept mainly Muslim towns in eastern, central and northwestern Bosnia under siege in recent months, while Muslims and Croats battle in the central and southwestern regions.

HEADLINE: For Lease: A Sweet Suite

BYLINE: By MARGOT SLADE 

 BODY:
The body is not quite cold yet, but already people are carefully examining the carcass of Shea & Gould, the large and influential New York law firm that announced last month that it was dissolving.
And what a carcass: nearly 220,000 square feet of custom-built space -- including conference center, law library, computer room, kitchens, mahogany work stations, custom lighting and 180 offices with a view -- spread over floors 42 through 46 at a prestigious Manhattan address, the former Exxon Building, 1251 Avenue of the Americas, between 49th and 50th Streets. 
 "We have had more than 40 law firms and financial institutions looking at it as their potential home," said Barry Gosin, chief executive officer of Newmark & Company Real Estate Inc., the leasing agent for the building, which is owned by Mitsui Fudosan (New York).
Wendeen Eolis, chairwoman of Eolis International, a legal consulting firm, said: "Most law firms don't want to move right now; it's an expensive proposition, and they are only just recovering from a complex recession. But we've told any that do want to move that this space shouldn't be missed."
Thus far, Mr. Gosin said, seven law firms and three financial institutions have submitted bids for all or some of the space, which is leasing for "the low $40's" a square foot, a competitive price for that location. That would be about $10 million a year for the entire space, although it will probably be subdivided.
Mr. Gosin declined to name the bidders, saying only that they were "serious contenders" and not the "curiosity seekers who simply wanted to see how the space looked."

HEADLINE: Welfare Plan May Require New Taxes

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Finding it difficult to produce a welfare plan that could be financed through spending cuts alone, the Administration is contemplating tax increases, with gambling establishments among the targets, officials said today.
No decisions have been made on whether to propose the taxes. But the talk of taxes contradicts the Administration's previous contention that President Clinton can pay for his ambitious plan to change the welfare system simply by cutting other programs for low-income people. 
 The White House budget director, Leon E. Panetta, acknowledged today that a gambling tax was among the possibilities to supplement cuts in programs. "We're looking at 40 or 50 options and that's one of them," he said in an interview.
The search for possible tax increases is the latest turn in a scavenger hunt for money that has left Mr. Clinton with few happy alternatives. Democrats have denounced suggested program cuts as Draconian, while Republicans are quick to threaten a revolt over any tax increase.
 
Searching for Money
 "We haven't done a good job analyzing the political impact of any of these," said Mr. Panetta, speaking of potential taxes and program cuts.
As they search for money, officials also say they may take as long as a decade to phase in a new welfare program. This latest strategy is intended to avoid overburdening administrators, to reduce costs and to concentrate at first on the youngest mothers, who are at greatest risk of longterm dependency on welfare.
State officials have applauded the idea because they say they cannot instantly run a new program for millions of people.
But Mr. Panetta said the phase-in schedule was one of many important decisions that remain. "I don't think, frankly, right now we have a very good handle on the policy," he said.
Mr. Clinton's pledge to drastically change the welfare system was one of his most popular themes in the 1992 campaign, and he has vowed to send Congress a bill this spring. He said it would expand training opportunities for the five million families receiving welfare and then force those who were unemployed after two years on welfare to join a work program.
 
Rethinking the Financing
 The Administration has been drafting its welfare plan for almost a year, but a serious discussion of financing has begun just in the past month.
While officials did not previously rule out a tax, they did leave the impression that new taxes were not on the table. As recently as Friday, Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, said that "welfare reform would be paid for by offsetting cuts in other programs."
Budget laws require any new spending to be offset with tax increases or corresponding cuts in entitlement programs. But the search for those cuts has proved difficult and put a group of Democrats in the unusual position of scouring the antipoverty programs they have spent the past decade defending.
The idea of supplementing program cuts with tax increases is being quietly encouraged by welfare officials who fear that cuts alone may go too deep.
 
$7 Billion in Possible Cuts
 In late January, the Department of Health and Human Services presented the White House with a list of six possible cuts, totaling about $7 billion.
Some of those remain under consideration, including reductions in a program aimed at preventing homelessness and cuts in benefits for legal immigrants. But others, like taxing welfare and food stamps, were publicly discarded after they drew fire from both Democrats and Republicans.
The talk of taxes is very sensitive, since Republicans in Congress are already threatening to block any such proposal and Mr. Clinton does not like to be reminded of his 1992 campaign pledge not to increase the tax burden on the middle class.
House Republicans have put forward their own plan to put welfare recipients in a work program after two years. But they would finance that plan by eliminating virtually all assistance to legal immigrants, a move the Democrats have called Draconian.
 
Gambling Tax
 Several of the tax measures that the Administration is considered involve gambling. One option is to place a new excise tax on some gambling establishments, like casinos and racetracks.
Administration officials said such a tax would probably exempt state lotteries and small charities, like church bingo games, and gambling operations on Native American reservations. They would not say how much money such a tax might raise.
A second gambling measure focuses on the enforcement of existing taxes, rather than on raising new ones. It would increase the amount of the tax, to 36 percent from 28 percent, that is automatically withheld when gamblers win more than $50,000. By withholding more money up front, the Administration hopes to reduce tax evasion.
Administration officials also acknowledged that the lists compiled by the Treasury Department included new taxes on alcoholic beverages, but they would not elaborate or say how likely they were to propose them. The Treasury Department also has a task force examining the earned-income tax credit, to see if savings are available from reducing fraud or abuse.
Bruce Reed, a co-chairman of the task force drafting Mr. Clinton's plan, said the likeliest option for phasing in changes would apply the time limit on welfare receipt only to mothers born after 1969, or perhaps 1972. That would target the youngest mothers, who are considered most likely to benefit from the training and work programs.
Under this scenario, about 1.3 million of the 5.4 million families expected to be on welfare in 1997 would be subject to the work requirements, with more being added each year.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Collapse of a Giant Deal
Profit, not the vision of a new information age, drove the talks for a combination of Bell Atlantic and Tele-Communications. The deal ultimately collapsed because the dollars and cents no longer appeared to add up. With the merger shelved, progress toward new information technologies may well be slowed and may not be led by telephone-cable combinations. News Analysis. [Page A1.] 
 The would-be partners said the issue that broke apart their $33 billion deal was the F.C.C.'s move to cut cable television rates by 7 percent. But industry experts said regulatory issues need not have been a deal breaker. [D4.]
Investors took another look at cable television stocks, and the shares fell further. Wall Street had hoped that the giant merger would provoke a wave of takeovers. [D4.]
 
International
 The Administration plans to rewrite export-control laws. The proposed overhaul, which would be the first since the cold war, is aimed at easing the sale abroad of machine tools, telecommunications equipment and other products that had been restricted because of their potential use in weapons. [A1.]
A code of conduct for business in South Africa has drawn interest from seven big U.S. multinational companies. [A2.]
 
Companies
 Tenneco's chief executive stepped down to devote himself to battling the effects of a brain tumor. [D1.]
Barneys New York released sales and earnings figures and balance-sheet information to quell speculation about its financial stability. [D1.]
Southwestern Bell will acquire the U.S. cellular operations of Associated Communications for $680 million. [D3.]
RJR Nabisco plans a $2 billion offering of preferred stock. The issue is seen as a way to spin off its tobacco operations. [D3.]
Shares of Stac Electronics jumped a day after it won a judgment in a patent-infringement suit against Microsoft. [D3.]
Metallgesellschaft blamed its former chairman for losses that nearly put the German conglomerate in bankruptcy. [D3.]
 
Markets
 Interest rates surged on new fears about inflation and the pace of the nation's economic growth. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond climbed to 6.73 percent. But the Federal Reserve tried to reassure investors. [D1.]
Stocks fell sharply in the United States and Europe. Investors worried that a continued rise in American interest rates would draw money out of stock markets. [D1.]
The dollar dropped against the yen, the mark and the pound. Gold prices also slipped. [D13.] Crude oil prices soared after a report showed lower U.S. supplies of gasoline and other refined products than traders had expected. [D13.]
 
The Economy
 Orders for durable goods increased 3.7 percent in January, the biggest of six consecutive increases. But analysts noted that most of the gain was in civilian and military aircraft. [D2.]
Brokers and mutual funds will be discouraged from using misleading advertisements and sales practices in a new campaign by the National Association of Securities Dealers. [D6.]
The Surgeon General called for a ban on cigarette ads aimed at young people as part of an effort to combat smoking. [A12.]
