HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Like Old Times: A Hoffa Amid Top Labor Chiefs

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 24

 BODY:
No one wears or solicits credentials, so almost anyone can hang around the annual gatherings of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s executive council, organized labor's 35-member ruling hierarchy, and bend the ears of the presidents of the nation's leading unions.
At this week's events, which end today, one visitor had gall enough to roam around the council's immense meeting room one day in the half- hour before the doors closed and business began. 
 The man was James P. Hoffa, a staff member of the Michigan teamsters's joint council who also happens to be the son of the late James R. Hoffa, one of a string of presidents of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to be imprisoned on corruption charges. Mob infiltration of the union, which flourished in the Hoffa era, was such that the federation ousted its biggest member union in 1957 and waited 30 years to re-admit it.
Today, the president of the teamsters is Ron Carey of Queens, who won the presidency three years ago after promising to rid the union of abuses. And it is Mr. Carey, not scions of the former leadership, who occupies the seat at the council table. So why was James P. here, natty in a green polo shirt and a blue blazer, stalking the halls of the Sheraton Bal Harbour?
"I'm down here to meet with all the delegates, especially the Michigan delegation," he said.
When told of Mr. Hoffa's explanation, Vincent R. Sombrotto, president of the letter carriers union, said: "What delegation? There is no Michigan delegation."
In the way of an explanation, Mr. Sombrotto noted, "It's rumored he's positioning himself to run" for Mr. Carey's job in the 1996 union election.
"It's a possibility," Mr. Hoffa said. "I've not made any announcements."
For campaign positioning, however, this place would seem a barren venue. The only vote around was that of Mr. Carey.
 
Taking No Chances

In many ways, Mr. Carey cuts a very different figure among the 35 council members here. He never sheds his suit and tie, much less appears in a bathing suit, even though he was a star high school swimmer. He also refuses, unlike his peers, to take an ocean-front suite. Instead, he stays with friends in the area or at cheaper hotels nearby.
And he is the only council member who rarely takes a step without a companion. Mr. Carey's sidekick is Rick Blaylock, an amiable former coal miner and organizer, whose titles and functions include special assistant, field coordinator, driver, alter-ego and bodyguard.
Mr. Blaylock has the girth to stop a truck. Mr. Carey, who has had difficulty in fulfilling his promises to tame an entrenched stratum of mostly unelected old-guard regional officers, receives periodic death threats. "I'd say about two a month," he said.
Mr. Carey brought his two biggest current causes to the meeting to curry support of other unions and to draw news attention.
One was his complaint over the United Parcel Service's attempt to raise the weight limit of packages that workers had to lift, to 150 pounds from 70 pounds, resulting in a one-day strike earlier this month; the other, his long strike against Diamond Walnut, a growers cooperative in Stockton, Calif., where management has permanently replaced the strikers. The strike started in 1991 and continues today.
In the first case, he flew in 2 of 10 U.P.S. workers who had injured themselves lifting the bigger packages. And to put pressure on Diamond Walnut, he enlisted union leaders here to join a demonstration at an Entenmann's Bakery plant in Miami to persuade it to stop buying Diamond's walnuts.
As planned, he got himself arrested for trespassing, along with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, Lane Kirkland; the president of the Bakery and Confectionary Workers union, Frank L. Hurt, and a striker from Stockton, Frances Hatilano.
 
Renewal of Relevance

Of big American institutions, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s leadership is among the thinner skinned. Its members bristle over comments on the sex and age of the council members, nearly all male, white and past 60. They are even more annoyed by the drumbeat of reports of declining membership. Unions represent just 11.2 percent of the private sector work force and 15.8 percent of all workers.
For this week, however, the gloom dissipated, thanks partly to six sunny days as well as an unexpected deluge of Democrats seeking campaign support. If unions have lost some relevance in the economy, they retain it within the Democratic Party.
No one knew exactly how many came courting, but at least 30 or 40 -- and far more than veterans of these affairs could recall. Among them were Senators Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey and Bob Graham of Florida; Kathleen Brown, the California treasurer who is running for governor, and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, who is seeking re-election.
The only Republican sighting was that of Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, who has a condominium nearby and was walking on the beach.
 
A Healthy Alliance

Organized labor and the Clinton Administration helped set this tranquil tone because they believe they really need each other in overhauling the health care system. "They're essential," Vice President Al Gore said of the unions during his stop here. "Organized labor are our key allies in this fight."
The struggle over health care has drowned out most of labor's rancor over the Administration's victory in the fight for passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement. But it is wrong to assume, some union leaders here said, that Democrats who voted for the agreement are home free.
The union's prime target appears to be Representative Jim Cooper, the Tennessee Democrat who has drawn up the leading alternative to President Clinton's health care proposal. He also was a supporter of Nafta. Unions think the Cooper proposal undermines the notion of universal coverage, a principal feature of the Clinton plan.
Gerald W. McEntee, president of the 1.2-million-member union of state, county and municipal employees, said he expected the members of his Memphis local to go after Mr. Cooper. "We've got some juice down there," he said, "and his record is very, very bad."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In a symbolic show of support for striking teamsters union members in California, Lane Kirkland, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. was arrested in Miami on Wednesterday. Mr. Kirkland was among a group of labor leaders who were taken into custody on charges of trespassing as part of a demonstration at an Entenmann's Bakery plant. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Law Firms Begin Reining In Sex-Harassing Partners

BYLINE: By MARGOT SLADE 

 BODY:
Fourteen years ago the Federal Government adopted guidelines that encouraged employers to eliminate sexual harassment on the job. The guidelines promoted the ideal of a workplace free of hostility, and subsequent Supreme Court interpretations of them enhanced sex harassment suits' chances of success if defendant employers had no effective anti-harassment policy.
It was Government lawyers who wrote the guidelines, and it is private lawyers who have been advising employers on the implications ever since. But with a myopia variously attributed to arrogance, ignorance or innocence, most law firms themselves long declined, or simply neglected, to police sexual harassment in their own offices. Many simply had no written policy against it. 
 That has begun to change.
To be sure, it is still easy to find law firms whose female associates will speak -- not for attribution -- about the straying hand or the lewd aside of a male superior, and of fearing to turn in the offender.
 
Rainmakers Lose Immunity
 But specialists who track the progress of women in the profession agree that at a growing number of firms, the atmosphere of fear is receding. Even "rainmakers" -- those partners with a knack for luring lucrative clients -- are no longer necessarily immune from discipline for lavishing unwanted sexual attention on the women in the office.
"Law firms' policies used to be a one-paragraph boilerplate statement in a handbook no one read saying that 'sexual harassment won't be tolerated at this firm,' " said Freada Klein, president of Klein Associates, a Boston-based consulting company that helps employers deal with workplace bias. "That is starting to give way to detailed statements, offering examples of what constitutes sexual harassment and many options for dealing with it."
Although there are no comprehensive national statistics illustrating the trend, what numbers there are tend to confirm it.
Two months ago, for example, 73 percent of the lawyers responding to a survey by The National Law Journal said the firms where they worked had adopted detailed sexual harassment policies, almost double the 38 percent who so reported in a survey by the publication four years earlier.
The later survey, which drew responses from nearly 800 lawyers, both men and women, at more than 70 firms in 14 cities, also found that in most instances where a policy had been adopted, someone in the office had been specially designated to oversee it.
 
Costly Battlefield
 While there are a number of reasons for the change in environment, one overriding theme is firms' own self-interest.
First, events of the last few years, from the Clarence Thomas confirmation hearings to a number of highly publicized suits against partners of leading law firms, have underscored the costliness, whether political or financial, of the sex harassment battlefield.
Lawyers who have defended firms or their partners against harassment suits say the cost of litigating, win or lose, easily exceeds half a million dollars. In the event of defeat, tack on a jury award that will amount to many thousands more. Last August, for instance, a Philadelphia jury found that Richard Glanton, a top rainmaker at Reed, Smith, Shaw & McClay, had "engaged in pervasive and regular sexually discriminatory conduct toward" a female associate, who as a result was awarded $125,000 in damages for defamation.
Negotiations now under way in one of two sex harassment suits against the venerable Chicago firm of Baker & McKenzie could make the Glanton verdict look like so much spare change. Those cases involve Martin Greenstein, a premier rainmaker at the firm's office in Palo Alto, Calif., who is accused of harassing a former associate there, Mary Rossman, as well as a former secretary, Rena Weeks. Mr. Greenstein has left the firm, and lawyers for all sides confirm that talks aimed at reaching a settlement in the Weeks case involve sums that are "substantial."
 
Women's Ranks Expand
 If firms needed yet further incentive for subduing harassment, they have found it: the evolving look within their own offices.
Fully a quarter of the nation's lawyers are now women, up from just 3 percent only two decades ago. More striking still, women will account for almost half of this year's law school graduates. And the best of them, eagerly recruited by leading firms, are not too shy to ask how they will be treated if they sign on.
The change of environment at law firms took its time in arriving. Indeed, with the steps that are only now becoming commonplace, the profession has generally lagged behind big employers as a whole by a decade or so.
"In a strange way, many lawyers saw themselves as above the law; these policies were for the hoi polloi, not for professionals like us," said Drucilla Ramey, executive director and general counsel of the Bar Association of San Francisco. "So they handled sexual harassment problems in a peculiarly poor way," which often meant not at all.
"It was like the cobbler's children who have no shoes," said Ron M. Green, a labor and employment lawyer at Epstein, Becker & Green in New York. "What lawyers forgot is that as partners in a law firm, they are regulated employers, not just owners of a business who can do what they want."
 
'Dead in the Water'
 Even now, few would contend that the profession is anywhere close to being harassment-free.
"At most small firms and a hefty number of mid-size ones, complaining about sexual harassment is not exactly a career-enhancing move," said another New York labor and employment lawyer, Rachel J. Minter. Many small firms have no sexual harassment policies at all, she said, and a medium-size firm may well depend on a large revenue earner or two and therefore feel compelled to protect them.
"These firms think that by having a policy, that will insulate them from liability," Ms. Minter said. "The reality is that you're generally dead in the water if you make a claim against a powerful partner at these places."
Several female associates at medium-size Manhattan firms, speaking on condition of anonymity, agreed.
"I don't care what our sexual harassment policy says," said one such woman, who described how her supervisor, a senior partner, had touched her, subjected her to sexual jokes and made comments about her body. "It may protect me if I want to complain about an unimportant or unpopular partner, someone the firm would like to jettison anyway. But by attacking this firm's money earner, I would be jeopardizing the livelihood of everyone here. I'd never get away with it.
"And if I left, who would hire me? I'd be considered a troublemaker, and the job market out there still isn't that hospitable to troublemakers."
Further, lawyers who counsel victims of harassment say the increasing presence of women within firms' senior ranks does not always offer protection: some female partners have little sympathy for young associates, whom they perceive as either competitors or, in the event of a harassment complaint, predators -- a threat to the firm that feeds all of them.
 
One Risk, and Another
 Still, experts on women in the profession say that at most medium-size firms and particularly at larger ones, where the partners are many and their power more diffuse, harassed women now feel freer to complain. Ms. Klein, the Boston anti-bias consultant, said, "The risks to a firm's reputation of allowing a rainmaker to continue his harassing behavior are fast approaching the risks to the firm's finances of stopping him, including forcing an unrepentant harasser to resign."
Palmer & Dodge, a 160-lawyer firm in Boston, has even created the position of ombudsman to resolve sexual harassment complaints, the only law firm in the country to have done so.
The ombudsman, Elizabeth Walsh Pino, says that in the two years since her post was established, she has handled accusations against three partners, all by associates, and that the complaints have been handled firmly, quietly and to the satisfaction of all parties.
Sometimes the matter is resolved more firmly still. Although declining to name names, Mr. Green, the New York employment lawyer, says that with growing frequency he has seen partners -- even major billers -- suffer financial consequences for acting in inappropriate ways with young female associates: either their end-of-year compensation is reduced, or they must contribute to a settlement with the aggrieved woman. Occasionally the offender leaves the firm; many times he undergoes counseling as a requisite for staying.
 
Compelling Demographics
 "I'd love to say that we would discipline a partner because we want to do the right thing, and there is an element of that here," said Jane L. MacLennan, managing director of professional development at Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy in New York. "But there are also business and economic interests at stake. Certainly our law school recruitment levels would be affected, especially given the demographics of law school graduates."
Those demographics are compelling. Forty-four percent of this year's law graduates will be women, as against 4 percent in 1970, said Cory M. Amron, chairwoman of the American Bar Association's Commission on Women in the Profession. And Colleen McMahon, a partner at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison in New York, noted that even in the worst of economic times, leading firms compete for the best graduates from the best law schools.
"If almost half of those graduates are women, and the word gets out -- and it will get out -- that your firm is inhospitable to women, well, your recruitment efforts will be dead," said Ms. McMahon, who is also chairwoman of the New York City bar association's Committee on Women in the Profession.
One other place where women are becoming more populous is at the American corporation, as general counsel. Ms. Klein says that any number of these women were driven from law firms years ago by harassment or bias, and the significance of that is not lost on her. "Guess," she said, "who is hiring the outside counsel for their corporations."

HEADLINE: City Hall's Job Targets Center on Agency for Poor

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration has identified many of the city jobs it hopes to eliminate by offering an ambitious severance package to employees beginning next month, and almost half of them would come out of the agency that serves New York City's poor, officials said yesterday.
About 3,600 of the jobs the administration plans to cut would fall in the Department of Social Services, the officials said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Those cuts would come on top of the 1,000 positions that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed eliminating when he unveiled his preliminary budget at the beginning of this month. Before the cuts the department had a total of 23,700 positions. 
 The administration also hopes to cut another 250 jobs from the Department of Parks and Recreation and about 700 more from the Department of Transportation, the officials said. In all, the Mayor plans to eliminate 7,600 municipal jobs under the severance package, a linchpin of his plan to close a $2.3 billion gap in the city's budget for the fiscal year that begins in July.
 
Goal of 15,000 Jobs
 Mr. Giuliani has vowed more than once that he would reduce the city's municipal work force by 15,000 jobs in all without causing a drastic impact on essential services. But officials said yesterday that the depth of the cuts raised questions about how that was possible.
"In some places agencies are already operating so close to the line that it makes it impossible not to have a significant impact on services," one agency official said, speaking on condition of anonymity.
The details also emerged as other officials and independent budget monitors have increasingly criticized the Mayor for exempting the Police Department, the Fire Department and teachers -- more than 110,000 employees in all -- from job cuts. Mr. Giuliani has insisted that his electoral mandate was to spare those employees.
Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, who presented a highly critical response to the Mayor's preliminary budget yesterday, said the Mayor's plan was "a municipal version of trickle-down economics" and "inequitably targeted" city agencies.
"It's ridiculous to say the people who voted for him wanted fewer maintenance workers in their parks," Ms. Messinger said.
The Mayor's aides are still cobbling together the details of administration's severance proposal, including how large a payment the administration will offer to entice workers off the payroll, the budget director, Abraham M. Lackman, said yesterday. Top administration officials have said that if the severance package does not reduce the municipal work force enough, layoffs would be necessary.
 
Plan Could Collapse
 The administration has also not yet received the agreement of the Municipal Assistance Corporation to use a $200 million surplus to pay for the severance packages. Without that money, the plan would collapse.
Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers said on Wednesday that the severance packages would include health benefits in addition to cash payments. Speaking at a breakfast forum, he said that extending benefits, possibly for as long as a year, was one of the "creative ideas" the administration learned after consulting with private companies that have used severance offers to cut jobs.
"Some people find that's a very good inducement," Mr. Powers said. "A lot of people would rather get less money and have their benefits extended over a period of time."
Randy Levine, the Commissioner of Labor, who will lead the administration's negotiations with the city's labor unions, said that the Mayor and his top aides would prepare an initial offer to present to the unions by next week. The administration plans to offer the severance packages during a three- or four-week period beginning in March.
One administration official, who spoke only on condition of anonymity, said the administration wanted a concession from the unions that would allow more transfers of municipal employees from agency to agency. That, the official said, would allow the administration to fill positions considered essential that are vacated by workers who accept the severance package, thus easing the potential impact on services.
The roughly 7,500 jobs targeted for elimination in the severance plan would be in addition to the 4,089 the Mayor identified in his preliminary budget plan. Most of those would be eliminated by not filling existing vacancies. The remainder of the 15,000 jobs are expected to come from the Board of Education, which has been told to reduce administrators at its headquarters by 2,500, and by attrition.
 
Extended Deadlines
 The Mayor's budget officials required the city's agencies to submit their targets by yesterday. Some agencies, however, have had problems identifying expendable jobs, officials said, and have been given an extension until Monday, including the Department of Homeless Services, which has a total of 3,200 jobs in the city's shelters.
In addition to the targeted cuts of 3,600 jobs at the Department of Social Services, the administration wants to remove 275 jobs from the Department of Health, 191 from the Department of Environmental Protection, 258 from the Department of Santitation and 331 from the Department of Corrections.
Raymond D. Horton of the Citizens' Budget Commission, a nonprofit fiscal monitor whose proposals have received support from Mr. Giuliani, said yesterday that the administration could ease the potential impact of the job cuts by spreading them across a wider pool.
Mr. Giuliani has remained steadfast, however.
"I ran for Mayor with the clear understanding that the priority would be public safety," Mr. Giuliani said this week. "It would be crazy for me to cut the Police Department."

HEADLINE: 7 Companies May Back A South African Code

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Seven major American multinational companies, uncertain what will be expected of them after the South African elections this spring, are considering support for a new code of corporate conduct being developed by South African churches.
The seven -- Borden, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Colgate-Palmolive, Ingersoll-Rand, International Paper, Kimberly-Clark and Pfizer -- all indicated a willingness to talk with the South Africans about how they could help put the code into practice, according to the Interfaith Council on Corporate Responsibility, a New York-based organization that coordinates stockholder activities by church groups. 
 In return, the Interfaith Council, which had placed shareholder resolutions concerning South Africa on the agendas of the companies' annual meetings this year, said yesterday that it was withdrawing those resolutions.
The 10-point code contains broadly worded provisions on equal opportunity and affirmative action programs, training and education, labor union rights, community relations, consumer protection, environmental practices and support for local black-owned businesses. It also assumes, but does not spell out, a system to monitor each company's adherence to the code.
"At this point, several different models are being discussed and no one has been asked to endorse a monitoring system or to pay anything to develop one," said Donna Katzin, director of the Interfaith Council's South Africa program.
 
Reasons for Corporate Support
 One reason the companies are showing interest in the code is their belief that it will have wide backing in South Africa and may serve as an alternative to harsher legislation.
In addition, many of them believe that a code developed by South Africans would be applied to all multinational companies, creating a more level playing field than existed in the 1980's, when they were under greater pressure from advocacy groups and politicians in the United States to actively fight apartheid than were their European and Japanese competitors.
Monitoring is the major point of contention. Church groups and some other investors eager to support South Africa's move to majority rule want a system that will allow them to grade corporate behavior. The companies endorse the goals in the South African churches' code and similar codes developed by South African unions and the African National Congress, saying their own performance in recent years has exemplified what the codes call for.
But they want to be free of reporting responsibilities that they feel will add unnecessary costs to their operations, and some companies have come out against the codes.
"It's another layer of costly reporting that would be superfluous," said Richard Kryzanowski, general counsel of the Crown Cork and Seal Company, which along with the United Technologies Corporation has decided to oppose shareholder resolutions calling for support of the code.
 
A Cost of Doing Business
 Most multinational companies that stayed in South Africa have contended with performance ratings, which they considered burdensome and hoped to see disappear after the elections on April 27. The ratings began in 1977 when 12 American companies embraced a code of conduct developed by the Rev. Leon H. Sullivan, who believed that American companies could undermine the apartheid system by supporting economic and educational opportunities for blacks.
Eventually, more than 190 companies endorsed the Sullivan Principles. The endorsers submitted annual data on their treatment of ethnic and racial minorities, community investment and other matters to Arthur D. Little Inc., which was retained to rate them. Starting in 1985, those that did not submit the data and had more than 25 employees were required by a Presidential order to make similar reports to the State Department.
In 1987, Mr. Sullivan moved away from his earlier set of principles, advocating corporate divestiture to fight apartheid. An Industrial Support Unit, set up by companies determined to keep the Sullivan Principles alive, now has just 55 members and is scheduled to dissolve after April 27.
The State Department program could also be dismantled if President Clinton determines that the election was free and fair.

HEADLINE: Beyond Budget Debate Hyperbole

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
Balancing the Federal budget by the beginning of the 21st century, as the Constitutional amendment now before the Senate would require, would not be easy.
It could not be accomplished, as some conservative advocates of the amendment seem to believe, simply by eliminating wasteful programs, by placing a cap on Government benefits and by cracking down on welfare cheats. And it could not be done, as some liberal supporters seem to think, just by raising taxes on the wealthy and slashing spending at the Pentagon. 
 Balancing the budget would probably take all those steps and much, much more. The amendment would not say how the goal should be accomplished.
Presidents and Congresses could resort to accounting devices to ease the pain. The basic balanced budget amendment before the Senate would preclude exempting certain programs like Social Security or the military or establishing a separate capital budget. Yet other creative methods could probably be found to make the budget appear in balance when it really is not.
 
Onus on Middle Class
 But if the policy makers are serious about spending no more than the revenues the Government brings in each year, the middle class would have to pay for it. It would probably mean that working American families earning, say, $30,000 or $35,000 a year and struggling to make ends meet would have to give up an additional 5 percent or more of their income each year in higher taxes and reduced Government benefits they receive.
Still, a balanced budget would not necessarily have all the Draconian effects that Clinton Administration officials have suggested.
It would not have to mean, for instance, that Social Security and Medicare benefits would be reduced by more than $1,000 for each retiree. Or that the Federal Bureau of Investigation would lose 2,000 agents. Or that 26 percent fewer research grants at the National Institutes of Health would be issued. Or that burial in national cemeteries would be denied 14,000 veterans a year. Or that 600,000 more military and civilian jobs would be lost at the Defense Department.
Nor would it have to mean that New York State would be hit with $14 billion to $16 billion a year in higher taxes and reduced services or that Connecticut would be hit with up to $3.4 billion and New Jersey with up to $7.1 billion.
 
Selective Cuts
 Those estimates by various Cabinet members last week were based on the notion that taxes would be raised and spending cut evenly across the board to reach the $600 billion in total deficit reduction that would be needed over the next seven years to bring the budget into balance. Presumably, the President and Congress could be more selective than that.
But while the Administration officials may have engaged in hyperbole in their specifics, their point is on the mark. There is no way to balance the budget without enacting measures that would be enormously unappealing politically -- so unpopular, in fact, that they could cost the politicians who support them their jobs.
The most credible plan put forward to balance the budget by the beginning of the next decade was described by Peter G. Peterson in his new book, "Facing Up: How to Rescue the Economy from Crushing Debt and Restore the American Dream" (Simon & Schuster, 1993).
Mr. Peterson, who has become something of a public scold on the evils of a budget deficit, was Secretary of Commerce in the Nixon Administration. He is now an investment banker in New York and president of the Concord Coalition, a group that lobbies to reduce the deficit.
 
Test of Affluence
 He would subject all Federal benefits, including Social Security, to what he calls an affluence test. The higher one's income, the less one receives. Only retirees with incomes below $35,000 a year would be spared.
Among other proposals, Mr. Peterson would also raise the retirement age to 68 from 65, substantially increase the out-of-pocket share of medical expenses the elderly pay under Medicare, require income taxes to be paid on a portion of Medicare benefits, reduce military spending and sharply cut aid to farmers.
And there would be big new taxes under his plan: a 50-cents-a-gallon increase in the gasoline tax and a 5 percent national tax on retail sales. He would raise billions in new revenue by limiting the tax deductibility of mortgage interest and employer-paid health insurance premiums.
These measures would mean that on average, families with incomes above $20,000 a year would have their incomes cut by 4 percent or 5 percent because of higher taxes or lost Government benefits. Mr. Peterson calculates that the average loss to a family with an income between $30,000 and $40,000 would be $1,817.
 
Well-Off and Elderly
 The elderly, perhaps the single most powerful lobbying force in the country, would be hit hardest. Mr. Peterson writes, "If one group (the nonpoor elderly) bears a somewhat disproportionate share of the sacrifice in my plan, it's because they now receive a vastly disproportionate share of our public largess."
Such a policy might be political suicide for those who voted for it. But every realistic plan for balancing the budget involves sweeping new taxes and deep cuts in sacred cows like Social Security and Medicare.
Politicians who want a balanced budget do not have to accept Mr. Peterson's new taxes, but if they reject them, they must have a better idea for picking up the $204 billion Mr. Peterson's taxes would raise in 2001. And they may object to trims in Social Security and Medicare. But where else would they get deficit reductions worth nearly $90 billion a year by the turn of the century?
This is why Ronald Reagan and George Bush, both of whom advocated a Constitutional amendment to balance the budget, never said what specific steps they would take to reach the goal. It is also the reason no member of this Congress has said how he or she would achieve a balanced budget. The ways to get there from here are impossible for an elected politician to fathom.
 
Will Nature Cooperate?
 The fact is, a Constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget is like an amendment guaranteeing that the catastrophe caused by the flood of the Mississippi River last summer will never recur. Perhaps billions of dollars should be spent to make sure the levees hold the next time the river rises. Perhaps thousands of families should be relocated from the flood plain. Absent specific solutions like that, a Constitutional amendment would be meaningless.
The balanced budget amendment's sponsors say it would put pressure on the Government to find ways to bring its accounts into balance.
But Mr. Peterson is ambivalent about that argument. "Its great virtue would be its symbolism," Mr. Peterson writes. "But we must be aware that in that very symbolism there is also a danger. It might persuade us to think we have solved our problem and thus divert our attention from the real business at hand: making choices."

HEADLINE: Albany Tries Putting Minds Over Other Matters;
With New Slogan, New York Attempts to Sell Itself as the Home of Intelligent Workers

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
It won't replace "I love New York," that's for sure.
But from the people who brought you New York's venerable tourist slogan, here's a new one meant to appeal to business: "I.Q.NY: A State of Minds." 
 Get it? Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday unveiled the twist on the state's famous "I<heart>NY" logo as part of an initial $3 million advertisting campaign to trumpet what government officials see as one of New York's greatest economic virtues: its intellectual resources and many knowledgeable workers.
"In this business, if you don't blow your own horn, there's no music," Governor Cuomo said at a breakfast meeting at the New York Hilton in midtown Manhattan.
Many states, particularly in the South and West, have long marketed themselves as good places to do business. Much of their effort was aimed at luring companies from New York and other states in the Northeast, which have often suffered from an anti-business reputation because of higher taxes, costly regulations and an aging infrastructure.
Now New York, battered by a recession and job losses worse in this region than in most other parts of the country, is trying to fight back. Following in the footsteps of Connecticut and Massachusetts in particular, New York will tout itself to business executives in national newspapers and magazines and on television and radio spots that will mostly be broadcast in the New York region. "New York State is pro-actively pro-business, and we want everyone to know it," said Vincent Tese, the state's Director of Economic Development. "It's a smart place to set up shop."
The campaign, the first of its kind for New York, is sponsored by the Alliance for a New New York, an association created last year by 11 major public utilities and the state government to attract new business to New York and convince companies already in the state to stay.
The campaign is scheduled to get under way on March 7 around New York City and on March 21 elsewhere in the state. National advertising will also begin next month, and some international advertising is planned. Companies that respond to the ads will be told about an array of economic development programs run by the state and its utilities.
The utilities are putting up most of the money to kick off the campaign, which could cost as much as $5 million a year over the next few years.
 
Smug Responses?
 State officials in Hartford and Trenton, long at odds with Albany in the intra-regional struggle for jobs, tweaked New York for jumping on the pro-business bandwagon after them.
"I get a kick out of this," said Alan Steinberg, the new Assistant Commissioner for Economic Development in New Jersey, which is now thinking about ways to follow up on Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's statement in her inaugural address that the state is "open for business."
"Governor Cuomo is now singing our song that state government should look at business as a friend, not an enemy to be taxed and regulated to death," Mr. Steinberg said.
After Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. took office more than three years ago in Connecticut, the state began its first campaign to overcome an image as hostile to business with the slogan, "The New Connecticut: Jobs Are Our First Order of Business." Now Hartford is phasing that logo out, replacing it with a more recent business drive underwritten by its utilities and the state government: "Connecticut: The State That Thinks Like a Business."
"We like to think we've been ahead of other states in the region," said Joseph M. Cohen, spokesman for Connecticut's Department of Economic Development. To bolster its claim, he said, the state cut sales taxes, pared several business taxes and took steps to reduce red tape and ease workers compensation expenses.
 
A Swedish Start
 The "I.Q.NY" slogan and the campaign built around it were created by Anderson & Lembke, an advertising firm that originated in Sweden, first set up shop in the United States in Stamford, Conn., and then moved its American headquarters to New York City. "They proved themselves in Triple A ball," Governor Cuomo said. "Now they've come to the major leagues."
It does not take a genius to figure out that the heart of the marketing campaign is the not-so-subtle suggestion that New York attracts many of the best brains in the country. And it probably does not hurt that the campaign employs a little flattery of companies already here in its approach. "Even the dumbest person wants to think of himself as smart," the Governor said.
There is evidence, though, to back up the campaign's theme. Workers in New York are, on average, almost 20 percent more productive than the national average, according to state officials, who say that New Yorkers are typically better educated and more involved in cutting-edge business activities than employees elsewhere.

HEADLINE: MARKET PLACE;
Stocks Fall On Fears of Rate Rise

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS 

 BODY:
The growing conviction that interest rates in the United States will continue to rise pushed world stock markets down yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 51.78 points, or 1.3 percent, to close at 3,839.90.
In Europe, the slides were steeper. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index in London fell 2.23 percent, or 74.4 points, to 3,267.5, its biggest one-day drop in 16 months. Stocks also fell more than 2 percent in Sweden and Switzerland. 
 On the Paris Bourse, the CAC 40 index fell 1.94 percent, or 43.71 points, to 2,208.29, while in Germany the Dax index fell 1.76, or 37.38 points, to 2,090.29.
"It's mostly interest rates," said William Lord, a trader at UBS Securities, referring to recent jumps in both long-term and short-term interest rates in the United States. "That's where all the volatility is coming from."
 
More Rate Rises Expected

 
 Since the Federal Reserve raised its short-term interest rate target to 3.25 percent from 3.00 percent Feb. 4, long-term rates have jumped four-tenths of a percentage point. These increases, along with the expectation that the Fed will soon raise short-term rates again, is unnerving the bond market here and, in turn, the stock market. The Standard & Poor's 500 index and the Nasdaq combined index suffered declines similar to the Dow's fall.
And European investors worry that a sharp downturn in the American markets would have a ripple effect there.
In Europe, traders said, disappointment that short-term interest rates are not falling faster there made the stock market declines much sharper.
Michael Metz, market strategist for Oppenheimer & Company, said he saw far broader problems. "There's a worldwide meltdown in the bond markets of leveraged positions," he said. "And remember that most of the money that came into the stock market was searching for yield."
 
'It's Ominous'

 
 That meant, Mr. Metz said, that the higher yields now in the bond market could draw money out of equities and "give the stock market a real problem."
Mr. Metz also noted that the Commodity Research Bureau's index of commodities prices rose 91 cents yesterday and that the outlook for oil prices was higher, "both negative developments for the stock markets." "It's ominous," he concluded.
A day after the failure of the largest attempted merger in history, the $33 billion deal between the Bell Atlantic Corporation and Tele-Communications Inc., the aftershock barely made the trading Richter scale. While shares of cable companies and their suppliers slipped, those of telephone companies were mixed, and no broad impact was discernible, traders said.
After the Commerce Department reported that durable goods orders rose 3.7 percent in January, largely because of aircraft orders, bond yields began to climb. The yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond climbed to 6.74 percent, from 6.65 percent at Wednesday's close.
As rates rose, the Dow began to slide, and by noon was off more than 40 points. In the next 100 minutes it regained nearly 30 points, then zigzagged downward for the balance of afternoon. At 3:33 P.M., the Dow was off 50 points, and the New York Stock Exchange imposed a "collar," putting the brakes on index arbitrage trading to contain volatility.
Dragging down the Dow were Caterpillar, which fell 2, to 108 5/8; General Electric, also down 2 to 105 3/8; Allied Signal, down 1 3/8, to 77, and General Motors, down 7/8, to 59. In fact, only three of the 30 industrials avoided a loss yesterday.
Other big losers were Royal Dutch Petroleum, down 3 3/4, to 103 1/2; Motorola, down 2 7/8, to 103, and CNA Financial, the big insurer, which ended down 5 3/4, at 72 1/4, after it was announced that it would be dropped from the S.& P. 500 to make way for Keycorp.
 The S.& P. 500 ended at 464.26, down 6.43 points, or 1.37 percent, while the Nasdaq combined index was down 1.23 percent, or 9.67 points, to 779.44.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange reached 342.9 million shares, up from 309.9 million on Wednesday and 270.9 million on Tuesday. Declining issues outnumbered advancing stocks by a 4-to-1 ratio.
One conspicuous exception was Bell Atlantic, whose shares rose 1 3/4, to 54 1/2, with 1.9 million shares changing hands, a day after it called off its planned merger with Tele-Communications and Liberty Media.
 
Debris From a Wrecked Merger

 
 By contrast, Tele-Communications, left to face growing concern in Congress and the Federal Communications Commission about cable television, saw its class A shares fall 1 7/8, to 22 3/8, in the day's heaviest Nasdaq trading. Liberty Media's class A shares fell just 5/8, to 22 1/2, but its preferred shares tumbled 16 1/2, to 75.
Shares of Cablevision Systems, another cable television company, fell 5 1/4, to 62 1/4, on the American Stock Exchange. General Instrument, which makes cable television equipment, plunged 6 1/8 in heavy trading, to 44 5/8, after Tele-Communications said it would cut its spending. More than 4.5 million shares were traded, 10 times the stock's average daily volume. Cowen & Company also lowered its rating of General Instrument shares to "hold" from "strong buy."
Shares of Scientific-Atlanta, which also makes set-top cable boxes, fell 2 3/8, to 26.
Oracle Systems was another casualty of the failed merger. Shares of the company, which is creating the software that will be used to store movies and distribute them over phone and cable lines as video-on-demand services, fell 1 1/4, to 32 1/4.
In a generally weak technology sector, one winner was Novell, which makes networking software for personal computers, whose shares rose 1, to 24 5/8, after the company reported better-than-expected fiscal first-quarter earnings and several analysts raised their ratings on the stock.
But Microsoft's shares slid 1 1/8, to 79 7/8, a day after it lost a patent infringement case and was ordered to pay a $120 million judgment to Stac Electronics. Stac's shares soared 2 1/8, or 48.6 percent, to 6 1/2, in heavy Nasdaq trading.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Interest Rates Surge on Pace of Economic Gain

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Interest rates surged again yesterday as traders and investors continued to worry about the steady pace of economic growth and inflation. But the Federal Reserve tried to play down their concerns.
Long-term interest rates jumped to an eight-month high, with the yield on the 30-year bond finishing at 6.73 percent. Shorter-term rates also shot higher, with the yield on the three-year note at 5.07 percent, its highest since December 1992. 
 "Bond investors are growing a little concerned, while the Government is off saying there's nothing to worry about," said Roger W. Marshall, president and managing director of the Riggs Investment Management Corporation in Washington. "More and more, investors are coming around to realize that the last quarter-point increase by the Fed was a token gesture and nothing to make any real impact on the economy."
In an effort to cut off a jump in inflation before it began, the Federal Reserve raised its target for short-term interest rates to 3.25 percent from 3 percent on Feb. 4. But rather than reassuring traders and investors, the move seemed to create new concern about inflation, and long-term interest rates have jumped almost half a percentage point since then.
The Commerce Department report yesterday that orders for long-lasting manufactured goods increased 3.7 percent in January, the sixth straight advance, did not help calm inflation concerns because it signaled that the economy is still growing at a steady pace that could eventually push prices higher. [Page D2.]
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, apparently did not have a soothing impact, either. He repeated his recent assertions that there was no near-term threat of a jump in inflation.
In an appearance before the Senate Banking Committee, Mr. Greenspan was asked if it was true that he saw no significant inflationary pressures in the economy. "That is correct," he replied.
By late in the day the Treasury 30-year bond was trading at a price of 9327/32 , down 11/32 , to yield 6.73 percent, up from 6.64 percent on Wednesday. This is the second time in a week that the yield on the 30-year bond has jumped this much in one day.
"For a pre-emptive strike, which one correlates with a stronger move, it was a wimp gesture," said Barbara L. Kenworthy, a portfolio manager for taxable fixed-income funds for the Dreyfus Corporation, of the Fed's quarter-point increase in short-term interest rates. "Had the Fed raised rates earlier and to a greater extent, we would not be where we are today," she said.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Securities, said the market's unraveling yesterday began with the release of the durable-goods report. He said the 3.7 percent increase in orders might have appeared stronger than it really was.
"However, the trend was up and I expect it will continue up," he said. Some traders viewed the increase as resulting entirely from the volatile sectors of transportation, up 23.9 percent, and defense, up 25.3 percent. And they said the odds were low that the durable goods report would be a reason for another jump in short-term interest rates by the Fed.
 
'Grizzly Running Amok'
 By the time that yesterday's five-year Treasury note auction was priced, the market had stabilized somewhat. But Mr. Fine said that it appeared that bond dealers were not able to entice enough investors into buying at the auction, so selling resumed in the afternoon. "It was like a grizzly running amok," Mr. Fine said.
The five-year note at auction was priced to yield 5.61 percent, or 51 basis points higher than at the last auction, another sign of how much the interest-rate environment has changed in only a month. In late when-issued trading, dealers had lowered the price and raised the yield to 5.65 percent to attract more buyers. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Mr. Marshall of Riggs noted that Mr. Greenspan was not alone in trying to reassure the bond market on inflation. He said Robert D. McTeer, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, was also trying to calm the waters, saying long-term interest rates were likely to come back down and that the bond market overreacted to the tightening and will reverse itself.
Mrs. Kenworthy of Dreyfus said she thought the selloff may have gone too far. "This may afford some investors a buying opportunity," she said.
MMS International, an economic analysis firm, said the Fed continued to stress the proactive nature of its current policy tact, "and we expect this message to eventually be driven home with the bond market, such that the last interest hike will ultimately be appreciated by the long end of the market."

HEADLINE: Durable Goods Increase, But Effect Is in Doubt

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
In a report less robust than it appeared at first glance, orders for long-lasting manufactured goods increased 3.7 percent in January, the biggest of six straight advances, Commerce Department figures showed today.
But while the rise surpassed expectations, analysts noted that the strength was highly concentrated in civilian and military aircraft, which involve long lead times in development and production, and that orders for durable goods were up just three-tenths of 1 percent when the transportation industry was excluded. 
 "There is no reason to think the economy is accelerating further," said David Orr, chief economist for the First Union National Bank in Charlotte, N.C. The Commerce Department report showed manufacturing to be firm, but not likely to reignite inflation, he added.
Today's report was presumably welcomed by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who in House testimony on Tuesday made an unusually specific reference to a coming economic indicator.
"Anecdotal evidence does indicate continued underlying strength in manufacturers' new orders and production," Mr. Greenspan told a banking subcommittee, "but we will have a better reading on new orders on Thursday."
Still, many traders and investors interpreted today's durable goods report as another sign that economic growth continued to move ahead at a strong pace. This contributed to a another drop in bond prices, pushing up interest rates.
 
Increase in Jobless Claims
 Separately, the Labor Department reported that first-time claims for unemployment benefits rose by 25,000 last week, to 385,000, increasing the four-week moving average to 378,000. This was the seventh increase in the latest eight weeks and brought the average to its highest level since October 1992.
Analysts had expected a modest decline in claims last week but cautioned that these statistics were subject to unusually big gyrations because of the California earthquake and the severe weather elsewhere.
Still, some analysts suspected the job market might be sagging again after a few months of clear recovery. Pointing to the deteriorating trend in benefits claims so far this year, Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, said economic growth depends heavily on gains in productivity and that "labor market conditions remain sluggish."
The bright side, at least to the Federal Reserve, is that upward pressure on wages should remain minimal, Mr. Straszheim added.
And while orders for durable goods advanced in January, shipments fell for the first time since July, the Commerce Department found. Bad weather was a factor in this decline of four-tenths of 1 percent and also in a five-tenths of 1 percent rise in unfilled orders, the first such increase since February 1993.
New orders for aircraft and, to a much lesser extent, motor vehicles drove transportation orders up last month $5 billion, or 13.9 percent, to a level almost one-third above that of January 1993, the report showed. And orders for electronics and electrical equipment increased $1.4 billion, or 6.5 percent. But orders for industrial machinery and equipment slipped 2.6 percent, the first decline since June, and primary metals eased two-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Insistently Optimistic
 Nonetheless, analysts remained generally optimistic about the economy. "When you get six straight months in the same direction, it's telling you something," said James W. Coons, economist at the Huntington National Bank in Columbus, Ohio, referring to the often-gyrating orders report. "The fact that orders moved up yet again is very encouraging."
But Mr. Coons said that bond traders might be worrying as much about tensions with Japan as about an overheating economy, the fear being that a reduction in the Japanese surplus means a reduction in dollars available to buy American securities.
Overall orders for durable goods in capital-goods industries surged 8.5 percent last month, but without military products, this gain was cut to 5.9 percent, the report showed. And when aircraft and parts were also removed, the increase was transformed into a 6.7 percent decline.
Orders for nonmilitary capital goods other than aircraft are a widely followed indicator because it shows how much companies are investing in new facilities, a process that helps sustain economic momentum in the short run, and by raising capacity, tends to keep a lid on inflation.
Total orders for durable goods last month were $147.87 billion, a 3.7 percent increase that followed gains of 2.1 percent and 2.2 percent in December and November, respectively.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Brazil's Market Boom Is Not for Faint-Hearted

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 24

 BODY:
After Brazil's stock markets more than doubled last year, analysts warned investors to proceed with caution in 1994.
So much for the experts. 
 The stock exchange in Sao Paulo, Brazil's biggest, kept climbing and is up 55 percent since Jan. 1, making it one of the world's hottest markets this year. Now the Sao Paulo and Rio exchanges are Latin America's fastest-growing stock markets, attracting foreign investment at the rate of $1 million an hour.
Cheap stocks, an American passion for emerging markets and a recovery for Latin America's largest economy are making Brazil's markets boom.
 
 
'Significant Earnings'
 From an anemic volume of $16 million in daily trading three years ago, the Sao Paulo exchange now has daily trading volumes averaging $350 million. In the same three-year span, Telebras, the state-controlled telephone company and the exchange's most heavily traded stock, has appreciated 1,500 percent in dollar terms. "In the short term, this could be a bubble that comes down," said Wayne A. Perkins, vice president for equity investment at Chemical Bank's affiliate here, Banco Norchem S.A. "But in the medium and long term, Brazil can't fight world history. There will be significant earnings coming out of this country in a few years."
Not for the faint-hearted, however. Brazilian markets are notorious for their volatility. Over the last five years, Brazil's roller-coaster markets have suffered 50 percent drops on four occasions, said Stephen Rose, president of Stephen Rose & Partners, a London brokerage firm specializing in Brazil's markets.
One news weekly, Manchete, reflecting widespread distrust among local investors, said, "Stock Markets: At the moment of decision, all caution is too little."
Indeed, stocks could skid this fall, experts say, when portfolio managers often sell to take year-end profits. Markets may also get the jitters if political polls strongly favor Luis Inacio Lula da Silva, a Socialist labor leader, in Brazil's October presidential election.
Still, many analysts interviewed this week predicted continued growth. Latin America's other major markets have maintained their levels since the growth spurts of the early 1990's. In Brazil, many analysts believe that the current run-up is for real.
"The market could grow another 100 percent in 1994," said Roberto Serwaczak, director of sales and trading in Sao Paulo for Baring Securities do Brasil. Of Brazil's nine exchanges, Sao Paulo accounts for 85 percent of trades, while Rio lags behind with 12 percent.
The fashion for emerging markets has put Brazil, with an economy 50 percent larger than Mexico's, firmly in the sights of overseas portfolio managers.
"The Brazilian market is the cheapest in Latin America," said Tamzin Hobday, director of Latin American research for Baring Securities Inc. in New York. "Last year, we saw a lot of money going to Southeast Asia. This year, we should see a lot of that money going into Latin America."
Based on Baring's analysis of the ratio of stock market prices to the book value of the shares, Brazilian equities average a bargain basement 0.8. Elsewhere in Latin America, by contrast, countries that have already undergone stock market booms have ratios that are much more pricey: 4.5 for Chile and Peru, 3.4 for Argentina and 3.1 for Mexico.
Growth stocks for 1994 could include Telebras; Marco Polo, a bus manufacturer, and private steel companies like Usiminas and Acesita. Because Brazilian banks usually profit handsomely from high inflation, which Brazil has had in spades, analysts recommend buying Banco National, Bradesco and Itau. Last year, Brazil's inflation rate was a stunning 2,500 percent.
Only four years after opening Brazil's markets to foreign investors, about 1,000 foreign mutual funds invest here, estimated Alvaro Augusto Vidigal, president of the Sao Paulo Stock Exchange. For American investors, popular funds include the Brazil Fund, and the Brazilian Equities Fund, both of which hit their 52-week highs this month and are trading at double or better than their prices a year ago.
Foreign investors, overwhelmingly American, are encouraged by the general direction of Brazil, a capitalist behemoth with an economy larger than Russia's.
Despite a recent radical cut in import tariffs to an average of 14 percent, Brazilian industry has proved to be agile and competitive. Brazil's imports surged 25 percent last year, to $26 billion. Nevertheless, an increasingly efficient export sector gave Brazil a $13 billion trade surplus.
Over all, Brazil's economy grew by 5 percent, the highest since 1986. Industrial productivity in Sao Paulo grew by 6 percent, and foreign car makers announced plans to invest $1 billion a year through 1997. Brazilian businessmen formed almost half a million new companies last year, 15 percent over the 1992 level.
"Brazil's problem is not the private sector," Mr. Vidigal of the Sao Paulo exchange said. "Brazil's problem is the public sector."
A modest privatization program is picking away at a huge state sector. This year, the Government is to auction off 32 midsized companies, largely petrochemical producers. With no company expected to sell for over $100 million, the list leaves untouched the three sacred cows of Brazil's state sector -- Telebras; Petrobras, the state oil company, and Electrobras, the state electric company. In March, Congress is to start reviewing Brazil's constitution, a process which could lead to the privatization of these state monopolies.
Brazil's small investors hold only $1.2 billion in local mutual funds -- 1 percent of the $120 billion held nationally in savings accounts. Because of this lack of liquidity, the huge presence of foreign money could moderate future downswings.
"It would be very difficult for domestic savings to absorb the foreign investments," said Daniel Dantas, managing director of Banco Icatu, a private investment bank here. "So, in fact, the aggregate of foreign investment is making a long-term comittment to Brazil, even if the individual portfolio managers do not have that intention."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alvaro Augusto Vidigal, left, president of the rapidly growing Sao Paulo Stock Exchange, estimated that about 1,000 foreign mutual funds invest there. He stood with traders on the floor of the exchange. (John Maier Jr. for The New York Times)
 
Graph: "Bullish in Brazil" shows Sao Paulo's Bovespa index in U.S. dollars.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Drops Sharply; Gold Loses $1.30 an Ounce

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar dropped sharply yesterday, hurt by a selloff on Wall Street and fresh indications that the Clinton Administration wants the dollar to weaken against the Japanese yen.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 104.95 yen, down from 105.65 yen on Wednesday. 
 Gold prices also declined. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for April delivery lost $1.30 an ounce to settle at $377.60.
Currency analysts said the dollar had initially advanced after the Commerce Department said orders for goods lasting three or more years had surged in January.
But foreign exchange traders began selling the dollar when the Federal Reserve failed to nudge up interest rates in response to the data on durable goods, contrary to expectations. Higher rates make dollar-denominated investments worth more.
Dollar selling intensified as investors moved out of stocks and bonds because they continued to be worried about inflation, despite reassurances by the Fed.
"The lower stock and bond markets contributed to the selling pressure we saw in the dollar during the day," said John Nelson, director of foreign exchange for the New York branch of Barclays Bank P.L.C.
Others ascribed some of the dollar's weakness to remarks by Treasury Secretary Lloyd M. Bentsen before a meeting of finance ministers from the richest industrial nations in Frankfurt this weekend.
 
News Reports Denied
 Mr. Bentsen denied Japanese news reports that the United States wanted an exchange rate of 110 yen to the dollar, about 5 yen higher than its current level. He also said he would meet separately with his Japanese counterpart, Hirohisa Fujii, but gave no indication of any new policy initiatives.
Talks between Washington and Tokyo on reducing Japan's trade surplus collapsed earlier this month. After that, the dollar had weakened against the yen, as traders feared Washington would seek to depress the dollar's value against the yen to reduce the imbalance. That would make Japanese goods more expensive in the United States.

HEADLINE: U.S. Had January Surplus

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
The Government took in $15.61 billion more than it spent in January, the Treasury Department said on Wednesday.
The surplus in January was not as large as in January 1993, when there was a $29.82 billion surplus. But it was a sharp reversal from December's deficit of $8.25 billion. 
 In the first four months of the 1994 fiscal year, which will end on Sept. 30, the total deficit has fallen by 16 percent, to a total of $76.44 billion, from $90.65 billion in the comparable four months of the 1993 fiscal year.
One factor that helped January's numbers was a speed-up of payments scheduled for Jan. 1 to members of the military and to some Social Security recipients. The payments were made in December instead of January, which had the effect of keeping January's spending down.
The Clinton Administration estimated on Feb. 7 that the total deficit would fall in the current fiscal year to $234.8 billion from $254.7 billion last year.
In January, the Resolution Trust Corporation, which was set up to oversee the bailout of ailing savings and loan institutions, took in $74 million by selling off assets of savings and loans it had taken over. That contrasted with spending of $2.47 billion by the agency in December.
Interest payments on the public debt cost the Government $17.9 billion in January. But that was down from $52.71 billion it paid in December and from the $18.1 billion paid in January 1993.

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
Major Discontent

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
The Conservative Party has been in power in Britain for nearly 15 years now, and it is showing the inevitable signs of that long a hold on office: weariness, stumbling, public disaffection. Many feel about Prime Minister John Major and his Government what Oliver Cromwell said to the Rump Parliament in 1653:
"You have sat here too long for any good you have done. Depart, I say, and let us have done with you. In the name of God, go!" 
 In a poll last month, more than two-thirds of those asked said they were dissatisfied with Mr. Major. Only about 15 percent thought the Government was doing a good job.
A particularly grim sign for Mr. Major is the contemptuous tone of pro-Conservative newspapers. The weightiest of Rupert Murdoch's, The Sunday Times, said this week that the Major Government "singularly lacks the country's confidence."
What Mr. Major hoped would be a winning new political slogan, "Back to Basics," has become a public joke. It suggested a return to moral values, but over the last two months a series of Tory members of Parliament, some in the Government, have been caught out in sex scandals.
That may be regarded as bad luck. But the Government has legislative troubles that are a matter not of luck but of ineptitude.
A tough-sounding crime bill should have been popular, since crime is a worrying issue here as in the United States. But it was drafted to centralize police powers in political hands, and that outraged the police. Key clauses were thrown out by the usually compliant House of Lords.
Conservatives pride themselves as being the low-tax party, but tax rates are now actually above the levels in the last Labor Government. A further jump in April will have the average family paying $35 a week more than a year earlier: a savage increase.
The country is just inching its way painfully out of a long recession. Unemployment remains high. In the 15 years of Tory Government, Britain has had the lowest economic growth of any of the industrialized countries.
Then there's foreign policy. Mr. Major and his Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, have been the leading opponents in Europe of intervention against Serbian aggression. A one-time Conservative Minister of Defense, Sir John Nott, published a bitter attack on the Government's foreign policy in The Evening Standard the other day under the headline "The Weak Man of Europe."
With all the battering he has taken at home, Mr. Major must be grateful for the red-carpet treatment he is about to get from President Clinton on a visit to Washington. On Monday night he will sleep in the White House: the first British prime minister to do so since Winston Churchill. Earlier that day he will fly on Air Force One with the President to Pittsburgh, where his grandfather lived.
Some here see Mr. Clinton's gestures as a sign that the President now understands the value of the Anglo-American "special relationship." But that has long been in the category of myth. Mr. Clinton likely wants to soothe ill feeling over the recent grant of an American visa to Gerry Adams of Sinn Fein.
The political realities to which Mr. Major will return include a series of elections over the next few months: for local governments, for seats in the European Parliament and a by-election for a traditionally Conservative seat in the House of Commons. In all, the prospects are gloomy for the Tories.
The Prime Minister can nevertheless soldier on, and almost surely will. He won the last election against the odds, after the sudden party dumping of Margaret Thatcher and his choice as her successor, and friends say he has faith that he can do it again.
The Labor Party might do something silly enough to blight its long-awaited recovery. Labor and the third party, the Liberal Democrats, might get in each other's way. Mr. Major projects a personal decency and reasonableness. But still, time has its claims. A disaffected Conservative here said:
"The only thing that matters after all these years is a change of government. That applies anywhere in the world."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Let's Make a Start on Environmental Justice With Brooklyn

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am pleased that "Environmental Justice" (editorial, Feb. 11) praises President Clinton for asking Federal agencies to insure that their environmental programs do not inflict disproportionate environmental harm on the poor or minorities. Unfortunately, you do not support environmental justice in New York City. 
 The city is in the last stages of obtaining permit approval for construction of the Brooklyn Navy Yard incinerator in my assembly district, a project that you have wholeheartedly supported. Time after time, I have expressed my outrage over the environmental injustices placed upon my low-income, multiethnic community. The Greenpoint, Williamsburg and Fort Greene area, which I represent, is subjected to more environmental health hazards than any other area in the city.
There is a myriad of manufacturing corporations in my community, which pour noxious fumes into the air. It is the home of the largest number of garbage transfer stations in the city, as well as a radioactive waste holding company called Radiac. Daily, my constituents are subjected to the stench of the Newtown Creek sewage treatment facility, along with pollutants emanating from the Greenpoint incinerator.
It seems to me that the Greenpoint, Williamsburg and Fort Greene communities are a perfect case study to justify the need for the new Clinton environmental policy.
I commend President Clinton for addressing this problem, which has been going on far too long in communities all across the country. The color of skin or economic status of a community should play no role in determining the site of an environmental facility.
To preserve the future of this great country it is essential that all localities, regardless of their race or economic class, begin to carry a fair share of their environmental responsibilities.
 
JOSEPH R. LENTOL
State Assemblyman, 50th Dist.
Albany, Feb. 14, 1994

HEADLINE: North Korea Agrees to Some U.N. Nuclear Inspections

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 26

 BODY:
The tense international standoff over North Korea's suspected covert nuclear weapons program eased tonight when the North Korean Government reached an agreement with the United States that will allow United Nations inspectors to visit some of the North's nuclear installations.
As part of the agreement, the United States and North Korea have also agreed to hold a third round of high level diplomatic talks in Geneva starting on March 31. The talks could lead to inspections of North Korea's most secret nuclear installations in return for steps integrating North Korea into the world community and diplomatic recognition from Washington. 
 The United States representative at the talks, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Tom C. Hubbard, said: "We have reached agreement on arrangements which will enable International Atomic Energy Agency inspections to begin on March 1. Our agreement involves understandings on other issues such as the date for the next round of talks between the United States and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea."
During the last year or so, North Korea has been caught in a growing confrontation with the atomic energy agency as well as with the United States after the Vienna-based agency said it suspected that North Korea was building an atomic bomb. The agency asked to visit secret nuclear sites that North Korea has never declared, even though the North, as a signatory of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, is required to open all its nuclear installations to inspection.
Under an emerging compromise a few weeks ago, North Korea was to allow agency representatives to resume normal inspections of seven nuclear sites that fall under the terms of the treaty. Such access was to have paved the way for a third round of talks between United States and North Korea during which Washington intended to offer North Korea trade and other advantages, including possible recognition, in return for ending its secret nuclear program.
But the deal went sour at the last moment when North Korea refused to grant entry visas to inspectors. The agency responded by warning that if its inspectors did not get visas by Monday it would report to the United Nations Security Council that North Korea had breached its obligations under the treaty, opening the door to possible trade sanctions.
After tonight's talks, North Korea's United Nations representative, Pak Gil Yon, said the inspectors' visas were being granted "as we speak."
He said North Korea and the United States had agreed to take "four simultaneous steps" to ease the crisis on March 1.
On that day, he said, the United States will announce that it intends to suspend its annual joint military exercises with South Korea's forces, which are known as Team Spirit.
 
Exchange of Special Envoys
 At the same time the nuclear inspections are to start and will be completed within a time span North Korea and the agency have agreed to.
Meanwhile, working level contacts will resume between North and South Korea on an exchange of special envoys. Finally, North Korea and the United States will announce their intention to begin the third round of talks on March 31 to resolve outstanding issues.
At that time, the United States has indictated that it will help North Korea integrate into the international economy, giving it new opportunities for trade and aid, and hold out the possibility of diplomatic recognition.
But in return North Korea must agree to inspection of all its nuclear installations, including waste disposal sites it has never declared. American negotiators say such a move would effectively end any hopes North Korea may have of becoming a nuclear power.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Economy
Some of the nation's most powerful bankers pledged to support the Federal Reserve in a dispute with the Treasury Department over a plan to centralize bank regulation. The Clinton Administration wants to create a Federal Banking Commission that would absorb most of the regulatory roles of the Fed, the F.D.I.C. and the Treasury. But the bankers endorsed the Fed's plan, which calls for it to take over the bank supervision role of the F.D.I.C. [Page 39.]
 
Cigarettes may be subject to regulation, the F.D.A. suggested, saying there was mounting evidence that cigarettes are sold to satisfy an addiction. [1.]

 
Markets
Big global investors have taken hits recently because of a rise in U.S. interest rates and the collapse of trade talks between Japan and the United States. One of the biggest hits was taken by George Soros. The financier, famous for his successful investments in currencies, gold and real estate, lost $600 million in a single day's trading, betting the wrong way on the direction of the yen. [39.]
 
A big mutual fund had to withdraw a $1.1 billion public offering because of an incorrect chart in the offering's prospectus. Stock prices, meanwhile, were mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped, but broader indexes gained. [40.]
 
Market watchers were stopped cold as their Bloomberg Business News monitors ground to temporary halt, overwhelmed by subscribers trying to read a single news brief: Nancy Kerrigan finished second in the women's figure-skating competition. [41.]
 
Treasury prices bounced back a bit, and a jittery market was calmer after a week of rising interest rates. [48.]
 
The dollar fell against most major currencies amid wariness before a meeting of the Group of Seven. Gold prices rose. [47.]
 
Lumber prices declined as demand for building materials was smothered by snow. Crude oil prices retreated. [47.]
 
The total number of shares sold short in Nasdaq trading rose to record levels in the month that ended on Feb. 8. [51.]
 
 
Companies
Bell Atlantic's loss of a merger deal may be A.T.& T.'s gain. A merger of Bell Atlantic and Tele-Communications would have created a company with lines running past nearly 40 percent of all American homes. The emerging marketplace for interactive services needs such a company with the power to combine disparate telephone and cable television networks, and only A.T.& T. appears to possess that kind of technological might. [39.]
 
Hearst decided it would keep its book division, which includes William Morrow and Avon Books, after months of negotiations on a sale. Putnam Berkley Group had been seen as the likely buyer. [39.]
 
America West's board has endorsed a $220 million bid from an investment group led by the chairman of Continental Airlines. The interest in America West, which is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy, shows a renewed confidence in formerly troubled airlines.[41.]
 
Woolworth said it would report a loss for the fourth quarter, surprising investors. The retailer also said it would take a larger charge than originally estimated in the sale of a Canadian unit. [41.]
 
Westinghouse will acquire the radar and electronic surveillance unit of United Technologies for an undisclosed price. [41.]
 
 
Your Money
Owning a house may be the American dream, but renting one makes more sense for many people. [37.]
 
A private hedge fund is one vehicle that allows investors to make money in falling markets as well as rising markets. [37.]
 
Errors in a a brokerage account can happen, often because of human failing or a computer glitch. But correcting errors requires a quick response and detailed records. [37.]
 
Some mortgage lenders are willing to help borrowers with flexible terms and assistance when there is a disaster like the California earthquake. Others are not so accommodating. [38.]
