HEADLINE: U.S. Asks U.N. to Condemn Sudan on Bombings

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
Alarmed that the refugee and food crisis in the Sudan could grow to rival the suffering in Somalia, the United States is pressing the United Nations Security Council to condemn the Sudan's Islamic fundamentalist Government for bombing Christian towns in the south of the country.
Administration officials say the ground and air offensive ordered by the Sudanese Government has put two million people in the south at risk of famine by forcing people to flee their farms and refugee camps and by thwarting food distribution efforts by relief groups. 
 If international condemnation of the offensive fails to get the Government to desist, American officials warn that they might then seek economic sanctions, perhaps an oil embargo or the discontinuation of international lending. In light of the difficulties the American military encountered in restoring order to Somalia, including the death of 18 soldiers in October, American officials say they have ruled out sending troops to the Sudan.
A draft text of the statement the United States is circulating at the United Nations states that the Security Council is "gravely concerned" that the military offensive "has increased the suffering of Sudanese people" and "seriously undermined the international relief effort."
France, Britain and Russia support the statement, American officials said, adding that China is hesitating to support it because of its traditional reluctance to see countries criticized over their internal affairs.
American officials say the Sudanese Government has taken advantage of the dry season to escalate the civil war and to try to wipe out rebel strongholds in the largely Christian and animist south of the country.
According to Administration estimates, the recent offensive has caused the displacement of 200,000 people within the Sudan, which comes on top of the almost 400,000 Sudanese refugees who have already fled to neighboring countries.
The Clinton Administration, pushed by Anthony Lake, the national security adviser, who is a longtime student of African affairs, is trying to train the spotlight on the Sudan, in part to get relief groups and donors to combat the famine there.
But in seeking to focus attention on the Sudan, an effort that will undoubtedly encourage television news programs to run images of starving Sudanese children, the Administration runs the risk of later being accused of not doing enough to stop the crisis.
The problems in the Sudan place the Clinton Administration between two conflicting impulses. On one hand, officials see the United States as a big-hearted superpower that has a responsibility to help bring peace and reduce hunger. But on the other hand, officials do not want to send troops to a distant land where they see no vital national interests at stake.
"There is no thought being given by the U.S. or anyone else in the international community to introducing troops," a senior Administration official said. "They would meet systematic, armed opposition. Instead, our strategy is to increase international pressure on the Government of Sudan, which is not our favorite government, in any case."
Last August, the United States put the Sudan on the list of nations that sponsor terrorism.
As a result of a severe drought and a failed harvest in the southeast, hunger was already going to be a problem this year, but with the military offensive, American officials fear that the hunger crisis could be worse than the famine in 1988, when about 280,000 people died.

HEADLINE: Rose Law Firm, Arkansas Power, Slips as It Steps Onto a Bigger Stage

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
With Hillary Rodham Clinton in the White House and three other partners taking influential jobs in the Clinton Administration, the Rose Law Firm of Little Rock, Ark., seemed to be on the verge of national prominence a year ago.
But things quickly went awry. The Rose firm, which made itself a dominant power in its home state, is now suffering under the unforgiving glare of publicity. 
 Vincent W. Foster Jr., one of the partners who moved to Washington, serving as a top White House lawyer, committed suicide. A coveted spot on the national scene has failed to materialize. And last month, an independent counsel opened an office in Little Rock to investigate accusations of fraud and conflicts of interest that uncomfortably keep leading back to the converted Y.W.C.A. building that is the Rose headquarters.
Instead of basking in the glory of its ties to Bill and Hillary Clinton's White House, the firm has had to hire its own lawyers to defend itself and cope with the counsel's requests for confidential files. He has ordered the firm not to shred any documents related to the Whitewater Development Company real estate venture. The Clintons were partners in Whitewater with the proprietor of a failed Arkansas savings institution. The independent counsel is investigating whether the institution, Madison Guaranty Savings and Loan Association, improperly funneled money into Whitewater or into Mr. Clinton's 1984 re-election campaign when he was Governor of Arkansas.
The Republicans on the Senate Banking Committee made the Rose firm the target of their scorn during a hearing on Thursday on savings institutions, saying the firm improperly used its connections throughout the 1980's. They denounced as a whitewash a Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation report clearing Rose of a conflict of interest in a case involving Madison Guaranty.
This morning, the chairman of the F.D.I.C ordered the conflict investigation reopened.
The turmoil and the independent counsel's request for client files has made some Rose lawyers apprehensive that they may lose some business, although so far there is no indication of defections from a list that includes most of the state's biggest companies, like Stephens Inc., one of the largest investment banks in the United States, and the Worthen Banking Corporation, the largest banking company in the state, Tyson Foods, one of the world's largest poultry companies and Walmart, the country's biggest retailer.
"It's been a roller coaster ride with its ups and its downs," Herbert C. Rule 3d, a senior partner who has been at Rose for 30 years, said in an interview in Little Rock recently. "It'll pass. It won't be like a kidney stone passing. It will just sort of drift away."
Even if that happens, the brush with power will have left some lasting wounds. After Mr. Foster killed himself in July, the firm delayed its plans to open a small office in the capital until October. "We lost our stomach for the whole idea of Washington," said Allen W. Bird 2d, the partner who opened the office.
 
Pedigree
White Shoe Firm Grew in the 80's
 The Rose firm bills itself as the oldest legal establishment west of the Mississippi, tracing its history to 1820. It gets its name from a founder of the American Bar Association, U. M. Rose, who joined the firm at the end of the Civil War.
Among Arkansas firms, Rose is viewed as the whitest of the white shoes. It is dominated by white men, most of whom came from privileged families in the state and graduated from one of the two accredited law schools in the state. Only a handful of women, and no blacks, have been made partners. Law professors at the University of Arkansas at Little Rock say Rose is among the most sought-after employers by the state's top law students.
Until the mid-1970's, Rose was little more than a loose confederation of a small group of lawyers.
But it changed direction largely because of C. Joseph Giroir Jr., the first full-time securities lawyer in Little Rock, who joined Rose after doing corporate-finance work at the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington. With his help, the firm quadrupled in size as its list of clients, a Who's Who of the Arkansas corporate elite, grew during the explosive economic growth in the 1980's.
By the early 1990's, according to Federal filings, the top partners at the firm were billing clients as much as $185 an hour, among the highest rates in the state, though considerably lower than the top rates of the large firms in bigger cities.
While Mr. Giroir forged one set of connections, another set began to grow with the hiring of the firm's first woman lawyer, Mrs. Clinton. She joined the firm as an associate in January 1977, about the time her husband was being sworn in as State Attorney General.
She became a partner at the age of 32, in 1979, just as her husband was being inaugurated as the nation's youngest governor.
 
Little Trial Work
 Although Mrs. Clinton was described as a trial lawyer in some news accounts both before and during the Presidential campaign, many former colleagues cannot remember any cases she tried, and court reporters in Little Rock say she appeared in court infrequently, perhaps as seldom as once every two or three years.
She was the primary wage earner for the family, since Mr. Clinton's salary as Governor was $35,000. But income tax returns and interviews with other lawyers indicate that she was among the lower-paid partners for much of her time at the firm, in large part because the pay scale was based on how many hours a lawyer billed and the clients the lawyer brought in. Her income did eventually grow, however. She made $203,172 in 1992, the year she left the firm.
Since she was also Arkansas's First Lady, Mrs. Clinton in effect held two jobs, spending considerable time away from Rose. And she would occasionally take leaves from the firm when Mr. Clinton was involved in tough races.
But Mrs. Clinton lent prestige to the firm's letterhead and served as director of several of Rose's biggest clients, including Walmart and TCBY, the large yogurt-franchise company. In a 1992 interview, William H. Kennedy 3d, the head of the firm's executive committee, said she was a leading "rainmaker," the term for a partner who drums up clients for a firm.
Mrs. Clinton was also among the most important state figures involved in the selection of judges. Lawyers, judges and former aides to Mr. Clinton in Arkansas say she played a crucial role in deciding who would fill the unexpired terms of judges, dealing directly with candidates for the jobs. Although state judges are elected, the governor makes appointments to complete terms of those who resign or retire. These appointees, given an advantage by incumbency, are often then elected to the bench.
 
Regulatory Work
 One of the firm's biggest attractions was its ability to help clients navigate the rocky regulatory shoals of state government. When, for instance, Stephens wanted to enter new finance businesses that required Federal or state approval, it was Rose lawyers they turned to. When Tyson wanted tax breaks or had potential environmental problems, it was Rose lawyers who lobbied the state legislature or regulators.
For large companies outside of Arkansas, like General Motors and the Prudential Insurance Company of America, Rose was the firm they turned to when they had local matters to attend to.
At its peak, Rose represented several Arkansas government and quasi-government institutions as well, including the Little Rock Airport Commission and the Public Service Commission. Partners at Rose say that to avoid any suggestion of a conflict of interest, Mrs. Clinton's compensation excluded any profits from municipal and state clients.
 
Accusations
Conflict Questions Occasionally Raised
 Along with the Rose firm's pre-eminence have come accusations that the firm on occasion has been involved in conflicts of interest. Many of the questions involve one of the firm's smaller clients, Madison Guaranty, which has become a central focus of the Whitewater investigation. Madison was controlled by James B. McDougal. In 1978, the Clintons joined Mr. McDougal and his wife, Susan, in buying the Whitewater land, a 230-acre vacation home development along the White River in northern Arkansas.
The independent counsel, Robert B. Fiske Jr., is studying whether Madison improperly put money into Whitewater to prop it up, or funneled money through Whitewater into Mr. Clinton's gubernatorial campaigns.
The Madison connection has provided fodder for critics who contend that the Rose firm looked the other way when it came to potential conflicts of interest. For one thing, they say, Mrs. Clinton represented her own business partner before state officials appointed by her husband. Other accusations center on work Rose did after Madison failed, when Rose represented the Government in a suit against Madison's auditors.
Mrs. Clinton's press secretary, Lisa Caputo, said accusations that Mrs. Clinton was in a conflict over her representing Madison were unfair and politically motivated.
"It's yet another attempt to pile on Hillary," Ms. Caputo said. "It reminds me of the Republican convention of 1992, when the Republicans tried to attack Bill Clinton's wife."
The issue of possible conflicts has also arisen in other savings and loan cases handled by Rose lawyers.
In January 1988, the firm and its insurer paid $3 million to settle conflict accusations raised by Federal regulators in connection with the failure of First South Savings and Loan, the largest savings institution to collapse when it was seized in 1986.
 
Firm Switches Sides
 In another instance, a former savings and loan executive in Arkansas has asserted that the firm had a conflict after it represented him and his family in many matters. The executive, Royce Barrett, said Rose switched sides in December 1985 and represented the Government in taking the savings association away from the Barrett family. Mr. Barrett charges that it was improper for the firm to side against his family once it had handled confidential matters that could be involved in the Government's lawsuit.
"They drew our wills, they knew our assets, they helped set up our trusts," Mr. Barrett said, adding that they had also set up the savings association's holding company. "I felt like it was a conflict of interest."
Mr. Rule of the Rose firm disputed Mr. Barrett's account.
"There is not any conflict, and there never was any suggestion of a conflict," he said, declining to elaborate.
In another episode, lawyers criticized Mr. Clinton's selection of a judge in a case involving the Rose law firm. The Governor appoints special Supreme Court justices in cases in which any justice steps aside because of potential conflicts. That occurred when a lawsuit against Alcoa came before the Supreme Court.
A closely divided Court overturned a $1.1 million judgment won by a man who accused the company of negligence after he suffered a serious injury. The opinion was written by a special justice who had been selected by Mr. Clinton. Alcoa, it turned out was represented by Rose, although the firm says Mrs. Clinton was not involved in the case.
Still, Ted Boswell, the plaintiff's lawyer and a prominent lawyer in Arkansas, charged in court papers that Mrs. Clinton did assist in the Alcoa defense.
Lawyers for the Rose law firm denied that Mrs. Clinton was involved in the case or had influenced the selection of the special justice.
Ms. Caputo, the First Lady's spokeswoman, said the accusation of a conflict was outrageous.
"There was no evidence to support the claim, and the court shot it down," Ms. Caputo said.
 
Prospects
Tough Atmosphere To Attract Clients
 In the months after the four ex-partners went to Washington, representatives of several foreign governments and Pentagon contractors traveled west to Little Rock, hoping to capitalize on the Rose firm's bright new connections.
The mood today is far different. Lawyers at the firm say the last few weeks have been as tumultuous as 1988, when Mr. Giroir left the firm after several lawsuits over his business dealings. Now, many of the firm's senior partners are finding themselves distracted from their work.
"This atmosphere undoubtedly makes it difficult for them to build their practice," said W. Jackson Williams Jr., a partner at Little Rock's Williams & Anderson, which over the years has been on both the same and opposite sides as Rose lawyers. "All the publicity can't be terribly helpful."
Only a few years ago, the Rose Law Firm was looking forward to a large expansion. It built a large addition to its headquarters and planned to double its size to nearly 100 lawyers. Now, some partners at the firm say that projected growth may have been overly optimistic.
To finance the new construction, the firm took out a large loan, which now accounts for more than $3.9 million of the nearly $6 million that the firm and its partners have borrowed from the Worthen Bank of Little Rock.
The firm continues to comb its records for material that has been sought by Mr. Fiske. The latest order issued to the firm by Mr. Fiske about preserving documents was prompted by an article in The Washington Times quoting an unidentified employee who claimed to have seen business records that relate to the Clintons' real estate interests being shredded this month.
Ronald M. Clark, the firm's administrative partner, said those records were not shredded this month, although other unrelated material was destroyed and may have been the source of confusion.
Mr. Clark said the Rose Law firm began a policy of shredding confidential client material in 1992, as the law firm was become the focus of more attention because of Mr. Clinton's campaign.
"Every firm in America destroys sensitive material," he said. "There is absolutely nothing wrong with that."
 
 
 
THE FOUR WHO CAME TO WASHINGTON
 They were the four closest partners at Rose, working on cases, socializing at the same country clubs and participating in the same charitable and political efforts. Together, they came to Washington to take the some of the most powerful positions in Government.
 
Hillary Rodham Clinton
She arrived at the firm in 1977 after teaching for two years at the University of Arkansas in Fayetteville, and became a partner two years later. While at Rose, she served on several corporate boards and state task forces.
 
Vincent W. Foster Jr., deceased.
In Little Rock: Courtly and widely respected at Rose among partners and associates, he was Mrs. Clinton's closest confidant. He graduated at the top of his class at the University of Arkansas School of Law and was top scorer on the state bar. He was one of the firm's top litigators. His wife, Lisa, taught Chelsea Clinton how to swim.
 
In Washington: Mr. Foster, who became a deputy White House counsel, continued to handle personal financial matters for the Clintons. He committed suicide in July 1993 and an independent counsel is now looking into the circumstances of his death.
 
Webster L. Hubbell, Associate Attorney General
In Little Rock: A former college linebacker drafted to the Chicago Bears, he never made it to the pros because of a knee injury. At the firm he was the top administrative partner in the 1980's and the chairman of the conflicts committee. Mr. Clinton appointed him briefly to serve as chief justice of the Arkansas Supreme Court and he also was the mayor of Little Rock.
 
In Washington: Since he arrived at the Justice Department in the first days of the Clinton Administration, he has been the subject of regular criticism by Republicans who say he is the behind-the scenes-conduit for improper White House influence. He remains a regular golfing companion of Mr. Clinton.
 
William H. Kennedy 3d, Associate White House Counsel
In Little Rock: The firm's top administrative partner in the late 1980's and 90's, he was known the firm to be no-nonsense and at times tough. He came to Rose after working as a counsel for Senate Appropriations Committee in the 1977 and at the firm, handled securities and corporate matters. He owns an Italian restaurant in Little Rock.
 
In Washington: A few weeks before Mr. Foster's death, Mr. Kennedy was rebuked in an internal White House report over his role in calling in the Federal Bureau of Investigation to investigate the staff of the White House travel office.

HEADLINE: In Response to Spy Case, U.S. Expels Diplomat Russians Refused to Recall

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
The United States expelled a senior Russian diplomat today after Moscow refused to withdraw him in atonement for its possible role in employing a Central Intelligence Agency officer who was arrested on espionage charges this week.
The diplomat, Aleksandr Lyskenko, whom American officials described as the top officer of the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service here, was given seven days to leave the country. 
 Mr. Lyskenko, the first Russian to be expelled by the United States since 1986, was said by the State Department to have been "in a position to be responsible" for the activities of the intelligence agency official, Aldrich H. Ames, and his wife, Maria del Rosario Casas Ames, who was also arrested.
Hours before today's announcement, President Clinton said the United States had been "crystal clear" in demanding that Russia make voluntary amends or face American action. In a formal statement from the White House, however, he also urged that Congress maintain a generous flow of aid to Russia.
Trying to calm the uproar that the case and other recent Russian actions have provoked, Mr. Clinton first summoned Congressional leaders to warn that he would resist calls for the United States to retaliate by slowing or halting the $2.5 billion in aid to Russia.
"Support of the United States for reform in Russia does not flow from a sense of charity or blind faith," Mr. Clinton said in the news conference later. "Our policy is based on our clear American interests clearly pursued."
 
Russians Note 'Factions'
 The Russian Government nevertheless expressed concern that the Ames case could lead to adverse "political consequences." A statement from its Foreign Ministry suggested that Washington should have shared its suspicions about the spy case with Moscow before making them public, and warned that factions in both countries "are not interested in the friendship of the two major powers."
With the evidence of Mr. Ames's spying provoking a powerful response in Congress, and coming on top of other signs of Russia's commitment to a newly assertive foreign policy, the Administration's handling of diplomatic dimensions of the case has displayed a distinct aversion to punitive action.
Rather than moving immediately to expel Mr. Lyskenko, who was known by American authorities to be Russia's station chief for the successor agency to the K.G.B., the Administration spent the three days after the arrest of the Ameses pursuing a policy that Mr. Clinton described today as giving the Russians time to "take whatever action they wanted to take."
Only after Russia showed no sign of taking the steps recommended by United States diplomats and by a special C.I.A. delegation that traveled to Moscow, was Mr. Lyskenko's expulsion announced today.
The State Department spokesman who disclosed the expulsion, Michael McCurry, said the United States did not rule out further action, but his warning was softened by Mr. Clinton's call on Congress to maintain a "steadiness of purpose" in reaching out to Russia.
The President's remarks at the White House provided the clearest view yet of his Administration's perspective on a week in which the Russian Government has left little doubt about its determination to maintain an independent role in the world.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, and others have argued that the United States should, at least for now, withdraw its hand of friendship to Russia because of that country's new bid for an equal role in the Balkans, and because of the accusations that it has maintained a spying operation here.
 
Not a 'Straight Line'
 But today, Mr. Clinton said it would be a mistake for the United States to judge Russia too harshly.
"What I think is naive in this whole element is the suggestion that we should have ever believed for a moment that every event and every speech made by every Russian politician in every election of every Russian parliament would somehow be in a constant straight line toward a goal that we wanted to predetermine," the President said.
Despite the recent setbacks, Mr. Clinton said, it was still in the interest of the United States to work with Russia to lower the nuclear threshold, promote democracy and a market economy and forge a partnership in international diplomacy. He also expressed some frustration at those who seemed to expect that Russia must either be ally or adversary.
"This is not black and white," he said. "This is gray."
In seeking Russia's help in quieting this week's furor, American officials said the United States had been explicit in identifying Mr. Lyskenko as the diplomat Moscow should agree to withdraw. As the Washington station chief for the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service, known by its Russian acronym as S.V.R.R., Mr. Lyskenko had abided by an informal agreement between the two countries and identified himself to his American counterparts.
They said a C.I.A. delegation that made a hasty trip to Moscow on Thursday had also asked Russian intelligence officials to identify formally, though not to withdraw, three other intelligence officers now in the United States, including the Washington station chief for the Russian Military Intelligence Service, or G.R.U., and the S.V.R.R. residents in New York and San Francisco.
 
Matching the Numbers
 In addition, they said, the C.I.A. delegation had asked Moscow to abide by a previous commitment to reduce the number of intelligence officers in the United States to the same level maintained by American intelligence services in Russia. But they said Russian officials had given no sign that they would agree even on the minimal demand of Mr. Lyskenko's withdrawal.
At his news conference, Mr. Clinton said he had avoided abrupt action on the advice of his national security advisers. But the main purpose of his public comments, scheduled only an hour in advance, was to inject a note of calm into a debate that White House officials said they feared had grown too alarmist.
The United States is scheduled to deliver $2.5 billion in aid to Russia this year, and the Administration is asking Congress to approve an additional $900 million for next year. In the last week alone, however, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia has raised some American unease by dispatching 400 Russian peacekeeping troops to Sarajevo without warning, by asserting a leading Russian role in the former Yugoslavia and by warning Russia's neighbors not to join NATO.

HEADLINE: WEST BANK MASSACRE: Diplomacy;
Clinton Calls Peace Talks From Cairo to Washington

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
Hours after he awakened to news of the massacre at a mosque in the West Bank, President Clinton today asked negotiators for Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization to move their Cairo peace talks to Washington. They immediately agreed.
Mr. Clinton and other American officials said they feared that the attack, carried out by an American emigre who sprayed the historic mosque with gunfire during morning prayers, would derail the peace negotiations that were revived in September on the South Lawn of the White House. 
 "Extremists on both sides are determined to drag Arabs and Israelis back into the darkness of unending conflict and bloodshed," Mr. Clinton said at a news conference at the White House where he explained his decision to intervene in the talks for the first time. "We must prevent them from extinguishing the hopes and the visions and the aspirations of ordinary people for a life of peaceful existence."
Secretary of State Warren Christopher telephoned Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel once and Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the P.L.O., twice today.
 
Condolences to Arafat
 State Department officials said Mr. Christopher called Mr. Arafat shortly after 7 A.M. to express condolences on behalf of the United States. Two hours later, he interrupted a meeting at the White House to speak to Mr. Rabin and Mr. Arafat in turn and invite them to move the talks to Washington.
Mr. Christopher also spoke to Foreign Minister Amr Moussa of Egypt, who until now has acted as a host for the bilateral talks.
The offer appeared to serve the needs of everyone involved. For Mr. Clinton, it was a quick, relatively easy and concrete gesture to demonstrate American concern and willingness to take action. American officials said Mr. Rabin and Mr. Arafat had said they appreciated the urgency of the matter and the need to keep their citizens calm and immediately made arrangements for the new round of talks, which could begin as soon as next week.
Mr. Clinton's call signaled an abrupt shift in the arms-length policy the United States had adopted in the months since Mr. Rabin and Mr. Arafat left Washington to flesh out the terms of their historic agreement in September.
 
Trying to Avoid Intervention
 The State Department has stayed almost entirely out of the negotiations, and Mr. Clinton said today that he still believed that the two sides must "freely agree" without undue international intervention.
But a senior Administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity said today's events rendered mere expressions of shock and sympathy inadequate. "There was a general concern that this event could swamp the progress that had been made," the official said.
Mr. Arafat and Mr. Rabin initialed an agreement two weeks ago that removed many of the obstacles that have delayed carrying out the accord, which would grant Palestinians limited self-rule in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank town of Jericho. In a breakthrough, both sides agreed to the terms of control of the border between Gaza and Egypt and between Jericho and Jordan.
Negotiators have been meeting in Paris to work out the economic details of the agreement while the political details have been discussed during talks in Cairo and in Taba, Egypt.
 
Progess in Talks Cited
 "They've made enormous progress in the talks they've had to date," said Michael McCurry, the State Department spokesman. "And I think the purpose in convening here in Washington is to accelerate that process."
American officials who began hashing out a response to the Hebron killings said today that the agreement had restored a sense of optimism about the negotiations that the United States wants to maintain in the face of today's setback. Mr. Clinton said he expected the two sides to remain "in continuous session" until progress is made.
Israeli officials said the negotiating team headed by Maj. Gen. Amnon Shahak would leave for Washington Monday, the Associated Press reported.
"I am hoping," Mr. Clinton said, "that statesmanship of the leaders in the region and the attention that this will bring to the terrible problem will not only defuse what could become a much worse round of killings and counterattacks, but will actually be used to thwart the purpose of the murder and to reinvigorate the peace process."
 
Israeli Envoy Endorses Effort
 Mr. Clinton's effort to hold together the fragile peace effort was endorsed by the Israeli Ambassador to Washington, Itamar Rabinovitch.
"This was an act meant to derail the peace process," he said at a news conference. "It only reinforces our determination not only to keep to the peace process but to expedite it and to accelerate it."
Even as American officials sought to present a tempered response to the day's events, Arab-interest organizations echoed Mr. Arafat's calls for more direct American intervention aimed at disarming Israeli settlers.
Mr. McCurry would not confirm what actions the Israeli Government might take to tighten security, but said the United States would support such actions. "We applaud them, and we will certainly be following their consideration of those issues in the coming days," he said.
 
Warning to Travelers
 The State Department warned American citizens against traveling to East Jerusalem, the West Bank and Gaza and advised Americans in the Middle East and Europe to "exercise special caution."
Mr. Clinton said his actions today were intended to "send a signal to the peoples in the region to not overreact to this horrible act."
He left no doubt that American officials believe that today's attack was intended to derail the peace talks.
"It can be no coincidence that the murderer struck during the holy month of Ramadan and chose a site sacred to Muslims and to Jews," he said. "His likely purpose was to ruin the historic reconciliation now under way between the Palestinians and the Israelis."

HEADLINE: A Chancellor Encounters Opposition and Support

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

 BODY:
A president of one college of the City University of New York has asked other presidents of the 21-campus system to sign a letter of support for Chancellor W. Ann Reynolds, who has been criticized this week for spending too much time out of town.
At least eight presidents had signed the letter by yesterday afternoon. It said criticism by some trustees and others of her travel was distracting from what some of the presidents viewed as her important initiatives for the university's future. 
 "Chancellor Reynolds, with her staff, in consultation and close coordination with the president, administrators, faculty bodies and students, is devising a vision for the years ahead while managing the nation's third largest university system in a difficult economy," the letter says.
The letter, addressed to the CUNY Board of Trustees, was distributed two days after an article in The New York Times quoted the presidents of five CUNY colleges as saying Dr. Reynolds's involvement on five corporate boards and other outside activities might have accounted for some of the difficulties she faced in gaining acceptance for her proposed academic streamlining. They said they believed the chancellor did not spend enough time cultivating ties to each campus.
 
'It's a Witch Hunt'
 Yesterday, some of the presidents, who did not want to be identified for fear of retribution, said the letter was tantamount to a loyalty oath, and said they thought it was part of a pattern by the chancellor to try to identify those who disagree with her and her policies.
"It's a witch hunt," said one president. "Some people believe she is trying to find the dissenters."
But Jay Hershenson, the vice chancellor for university relations, said neither his office nor that of the chancellor was involved in writing or distributing the letter.
"Our presidents are independent and any matters that they wish to take up individually or collectively is entirely up to them," he said yesterday.
The letter was distributed by Baruch College President Matthew Goldstein, who told several other presidents that he thought the chancellor needed their support, the presidents said. Dr. Goldstein did not return telephone calls left at his office or his residence.
 
'Outside' Affairs Questioned
 This week, two trustees questioned whether the chancellor was violating the board's two-day-a-month limit on "outside consultation and professional activities."
Dr. Reynolds serves on the boards of the Maytag Corp., Humana Inc., Abbott Laboratories, American Electric Power and Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp. She has said she intends to resign from the American Electric board in April. Together, the boards paid her $140,000 last year, the chancellor said.
The chancellor said her service on the boards helps CUNY by giving it a higher national profile. She earns $158,000 a year from CUNY, although she said she donated $6,000 of her salary back to a CUNY scholarship fund.
Service on the boards and its committees, and her participation in several professional organizations, like the Society for Gynecological Investigation, take her out of town several times a month.
On Tuesday the CUNY board unanimously adopted a resolution asking that the chancellor and other top officials disclose how much money they earn outside of CUNY, and to detail to them how much time they spend on the outside activities.
On Thursday and Friday, Dr. Goldstein began distributing the letter at a meeting of the executive council of presidents, which was attended by some of the presidents, some of them said.
Addressed to the trustees, the letter says in part that "personnel policies must be scrupulously followed." But it went on to say that "recent news reports serve our students poorly."
It also said "so much attention of late is directed to these matters that the public and the media may have forgotten" CUNY's accomplishments.
"As independent thinkers, we may not all agree on some of her initiatives," the letter said. "But we support her leadership."

HEADLINE: A $600 Million Miscalculation

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
With world financial markets roiled by developments including a rise in American interest rates and the breakdown of trade talks between Washington and Tokyo, some of the world's biggest and savviest investors have been taken down a notch or two. Among them is one of the biggest and savviest of all, the financier George Soros.
Mr. Soros, 63, who has developed a reputation as an investment seer for his successful bets on currencies, gold and real estate, suffered a $600 million loss on Feb. 14, the first full day of trading after trade talks between the United States and Japan collapsed. His mistake was that he bet the wrong way on the direction of the Japanese yen's value relative to the dollar, his spokesman said today. 
 Other investors have taken big hits this month, particularly those who owned European bonds, which have suddenly tumbled in value. But few have publicly owned up to their losses other than Mr. Soros, who basked in the positive glow of financial victory a year and a half ago when he bet correctly on a big fall in the British pound and stunned the currency markets with a $1 billion profit.
 
Quantum Group Loses 5%
 The loss, which stemmed primarily from speculation on the Japanese yen, erased nearly 5 percent of the $12 billion of assets held by Mr. Soros's Quantum Group, an intensely private collection of investment funds that are registered overseas and closed to American individuals and institutions. The losses, which occurred in six trading and real estate investment funds, ended a remarkable winning streak for Mr. Soros, of New York.
Mr. Soros's opinions have been so respected that his public predictions about currency movements have become self-fulfilling in several instances, even though he devotes most of his time to running his charitable foundation. Through the foundation, he has directed some $300 million to philanthropic activities, mostly in Eastern Europe.
Much of the responsibility for strategy and day-to-day trading is in the hands of Stanley Druckenmiller, Mr. Soros's No. 2 man. It was in an interview with The Times of London, published Thursday, that Mr. Druckenmiller first confirmed the $600 million loss that had been rumored.
Mr. Druckenmiller and the Soros organization said they decided to talk about the loss because the amounts mentioned in rumors had varied widely.
Mr. Soros had been trading on a belief that the yen would continue to fall in value against the dollar, a strategy that generally proved correct. But he was caught unexpectedly in the fallout from the breakdown of trade talks between Japan and the United States on Friday, Feb. 11. When markets reopened the following Monday, the yen, which had been falling, suddenly surged as traders concluded that the United States would seek to push up the yen as a way to narrow the American trade deficit with Japan.
The Japanese currency closed in New York that day at 102.20 yen to the dollar, a change of nearly 5 percent from its close the previous Friday of 107.18 yen to the dollar. A stronger yen makes imports from Japan more expensive in the United States.
 "Mr. Soros is kept sufficiently informed of what's going on that Mr. Soros would say the buck stops here," said the spokesman, who insisted on anonymity.
The spokesman said that the Quantum funds had been performing well otherwise, and that their value was down only 2.7 percent since Jan. 1. Last year, the Quantum Fund, the group's flagship trading fund, rose 65 to 70 percent, the spokesman said.
Mr. Soros's spokesman said that on Feb. 14 the Quantum funds had a short position of $8 billion worth of yen. That means that $8 billion of yen had been borrowed and sold on the assumption that the value would decline against the dollar and that Mr. Soros's traders could buy back yen later on a lower price and return the currency to the lender. But Quantum was forced to sell yen as the currency jumped sharply in value, contributing to the huge loss.
Mr. Soros is by no means the only investor to have been hammered by unsettled financial markets in recent weeks.
With the Federal Reserve shifting course and raising short-term interest rates, many investors who had been focusing on the likelihood of continued rate declines and bond-market strength in Europe suffered large losses as they were caught flat-footed by a selloff in bonds.
Mr. Soros has long been among the most successful and sophisticated traders in the financial markets, but his reputation reached new heights in September 1992 as Europe's system of semifixed exchange rates tottered near collapse.
Mr. Soros bet heavily that the British pound would come under so much speculative pressure that it would be devalued. His bet proved absolutely correct, and on what is known in London as "Black Wednesday," Sept. 16, 1992, and the days following, he reaped a $1 billion profit as the pound was forced out of Europe's exchange rate system.

HEADLINE: Mutual Fund Is Forced To Withdraw Offering

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Billion-dollar public sales of stocks are supposed to go off without a hitch. But yesterday, one of the nation's biggest mutual funds had to withdraw a $1.1 billion public offering, and the New York Stock Exchange suspended trading of the shares, after an incorrect chart in the offering's prospectus was discovered.
The embarrassed investment adviser to the fund is Alliance Capital Management, which has $115 billion of client money under management. It said the prospectus for its new Global Privatization Fund contained a chart that exaggerated the performance of 22 former government enterprises that had been converted to ownership by private investors. 
 The global fund plans to invest in such European, Latin American and Asian ventures, which are known as privatizations. Shares in the fund had traded since Feb. 18.
 
'Doesn't Go Up as Much'
 In a corrected chart now being reviewed by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the performance line "goes up, it just doesn't go up as much," Linda A. Finnerty, a spokeswoman for Alliance Capital, said. Instead of a 170 percent rise in market value over five years, "it's more in the 100 percent range," she said.
Ms. Finnerty declined to say who exactly made the error. Asked if the mistake was made by a college intern with a calculator, Ms. Finnerty replied, "Oh no, it was analysts and portfolio managers at Alliance."
Few, if any, investors objected when informed of the incorrect chart, she said. Alliance was confident that the sold-out 74.5 million shares at $15 each would again sell out, she added, once the new prospectus is cleared by the S.E.C.
Alliance hopes to market the global fund again within the next few days and perhaps as early as Monday.
 
Stocks Are Mixed
 The stock market put in a mixed performance in relatively light trading, following a depressed session on Thursday. Traders are still stymied about what to do in a climate of rising interest rates and befuddlement about inflation, which so far is not in evidence.
The Dow Jones industrial average was down 1.12 points, to 3,838.78, but the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 1.81 points, to 466.07. The Nasdaq composite index rose 4.34 points, to 783.78.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.82 point, to 258.57, on volume of 273.7 million shares. Advancing stocks outnumbered declining stocks by 1,169 to 963. The American Stock Exchange market value index gained 1.87 points, to 467.45.
The Dow Jones industrials may have been out of synchronization with the broader market because the Dow is heavily weighted with economically sensitive stocks. Indeed, three such stocks -- Chevron, General Motors and Caterpillar -- nudged the Dow into the minus column. Chevron declined 1 1/2, to 85 3/4; Caterpillar fell 7/8, to 107 3/4, and General Motors dropped 3/4, to 58 1/4.
But the S.& P. 500 could have been nudged into the plus column by just two stocks. Tele-Communications, which broke off merger talks with Bell Atlantic earlier in the week, advanced 1 1/2, to 23 7/8, as securities analysts continued to praise the prospects of the cable television industry, despite negative rulings by the Government. BellSouth, the largest regional Bell, could be a source of joint-venture money for Tele-Communications, according to analysts. BellSouth rose 1 3/8, to 55 5/8.
In Tokyo yesterday, Japanese stocks ended a strong week with a modest gain. The Nikkei index of 225 issues edged up 37.90 points, to 19,803.38. For the week, the Nikkei gained 843.78 points.

HEADLINE: Farrell Is Named Chairman Of Ways and Means Panel

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 25

 BODY:
Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver today appointed Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., a longtime legislator who heads the Democratic Party in Manhattan, as chairman of the powerful Ways and Means Committee.
Mr. Farrell, who has represented Harlem and Washington Heights since 1975, is the first black legislator to hold the position, which is the highest-ranking committee chairmanship in the Assembly and one of the top negotiators for passing the $62 billion New York State budget. 
 In filling the position, Mr. Silver cemented the new leadership in the Democratic-led Assembly, which had been in flux since the death of Speaker Saul Weprin on Feb. 11. Until Mr. Weprin's death, Mr. Silver was the chairman of Ways and Means. Mr. Weprin also held the post before he was named Speaker three years ago.
"He brings 20 years of experience in the Legislature," Mr. Silver said of Mr. Farrell, who is known as Denny. "He brings the gift of gab."
"I'm not unmindful of the fact that Denny is an African-American," Mr. Silver said. "I think it is a good message to send that the three leading committee appointments are a woman, an African-American and an Italian male. It shows the diversity of the conference."
 
Top Priority: On-Time Budget
 Helene Weinstein, Democrat of Brooklyn, is chairwoman of the Judiciary Committee, and Joseph R. Lentol, also a Democrat of Brooklyn, heads the Codes Committee.
Mr. Farrell, who is 62, has led the Assembly Banking Committee since 1979. He said his first priority is to pass the budget, which is perenially late, by the April 1 deadline.
"Every time we run late it costs us money and it costs us respect," he said. "I want people to know we are on the road to recovery, and one of the best signs is an on-time budget."
Mr. Farrell, who wears a gray ponytail and is often seen cruising in his red Chevrolet convertible, brushed aside questions about whether he had aspirations to become Speaker. "I haven't even found the men's room at Ways and Means," he said.
 
Won't Resign Other Position
 Despite criticism from governmental monitoring groups, he said he would not resign his position as chairman of the Manhattan Democratic Party, nor had Mr. Silver asked him to do so.
"From the practical standpoint of concentration of power, we wouldn't want that much power in the hands of one Assembly member, even someone with Mr. Farrell's integrity," said Andrew Greenblatt, executive director of Common Cause.
While the Ways and Means chairman is nominally in charge of reviewing the Governor's budget and negotiating it into final form with the Republican-led Senate, the major decisions are reserved for the Speaker.
Mr. Farrell's chief competitor for the job was Assemblywoman Eileen C. Dugan, a Democrat from Brooklyn who like Mr. Farrell played an important role in Mr. Silver's rise to Speaker. Mr. Silver today expanded her powers as chairwoman of the Assembly Committee for Commerce, Industry and Economic Development.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. yesterday after being named chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off Amid Wariness Before Meeting of Group of 7

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against most leading currencies yesterday amid hints that German interest rates might remain high and the possibility of further strength in the Japanese yen after this weekend's Group of Seven meeting.
Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for April delivery was up $2.20, to $379.80 an ounce. 
 Currency traders said they were nervous about this weekend's meeting of finance ministers from seven industrialized countries. The session is expected to focus on developments in Russia, although there have been reports that currencies will be discussed. Traders said the continued lack of progress on American-Japanese trade disputes could weigh on the dollar.
The market's perception is that "the U.S. is prepared to continue to let the dollar slide," said Hillel Waxman, chief foreign exchange dealer at Bank Leumi Trust Company.
In late New York trading, the dollar slipped to 104.85 yen, from 104.90 yen on Thursday.
The dollar has sunk against the yen since bilateral trade talks broke down two weeks ago. Many traders believe the Clinton Administration supports a strong yen as a way of pressing the Japanese Government to make trade concessions. A strong yen can hurt Japanese exports, since it makes them more expensive abroad.
Mr. Waxman said the German mark got some support from a German newspaper report predicting higher-than-expected growth in the money supply, a source of inflation. Such a situation would probably mean that the German Government would keep interest rates high, to choke off inflation. High interest rates usually strengthen a currency.
Technical factors also influenced trading, with the dollar's drop below 1.71 German marks setting off pre-arranged orders to sell the dollar, traders said. The dollar fell under 1.72, another crucial point, a day earlier. But the dollar recovered some ground by yesterday afternoon, as bargain hunters bought. It ended at 1.7105 marks, down from 1.7170 marks on Thursday.
The British pound rose in New York to $1.4885 from $1.4865.

HEADLINE: Confidence Index Declines

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index for February fell to 93.2 from 94.3 in January, people with access to the survey said yesterday.
The preliminary February index, released two weeks ago, was 92.9. 
 The index is based on a monthly survey of households around the country. The base number is 100, set in 1966. As the monthly reading drops further below 100, consumers are becoming more pessimistic about the economy.
Since 1966, the record high for the sentiment index is 101, set in March 1984. The record low is 51.7, set in April 1980.
The report by the university also included its February index of consumer expectations, which measures how people feel about the future. The index was 83.5, down from 86.4 in January. The early reading was 82.9.
The expectations index is used by the Commerce Department as one of the 11 components of its chief forecasting gauge, the index of leading economic indicators.
The February index of current economic conditions was 108.3, up from 106.6 in January. The early reading was 108.4.

HEADLINE: Cherished Goals Give Way to Hard Facts

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
The sluggish real estate market in many parts of the country has prompted some house hunters to wonder whether renting may be a better deal financially than the long-cherished and heavily promoted American Dream of home ownership.
For many people, especially those who hold onto their houses for more than seven years, buying makes more economic sense. Besides building equity, there are myriad tax advantages, like the deductions for mortgage interest and property taxes, or the rollover of a gain if the seller buys a more expensive house. 
 But putting aside pride of ownership and the tradition of social stability, renting may make more sense than buying. That is especially the case if a tenant lives in the house for fewer than five years, invests the down payment and obtains a rate of return that is significantly higher than the appreciation of a comparable house and pays less to rent monthly than he would after taxes to buy.
Three years ago, Irene A. Wrenner, a technology coordinator, decided to rent a two-bedroom house in Ridgewood, N.J., for $1,213 a month instead of buying a slightly larger house in the same area for $230,000. She and her husband, Kevin, an electrical engineer, calculated that the monthly costs of ownership, after taxes, would be $1,900. "We refused to ignore the bottom line," she said.
If they had bought the house and now had to sell, the Wrenners figured they would have lost part of their down payment and spent thousands of dollars more in mortgage payments, fees and other costs. By renting, investing their down payment and saving the difference between the rent and the monthly cost of owning, they saved thousands of dollars.
"Our money is also liquid and that pleases us a lot," Ms. Wrenner said.
Ted C. Jones, chief economist with the Real Estate Center at Texas A& M University, said the time spent in a house is important because during the first few years, there is usually no buildup of equity because most payments during the first few years do not substantially reduce the principal of a loan.
Mr. Jones also said the tax savings of the mortgage interest deduction were exaggerated, given today's rates and the increases in the standard income tax deduction. Further, there may be little appreciation in the value of a house during the first few years. He said not only had sale prices stagnated in many places in the low-inflation 90's, but also most houses automatically declined in value by 6 percent, the standard amount paid to a broker, at the sale.
"If you're going to be in your home three years or less, then rent," he said. "Buying for three years just produces a lot of grief and expenses and the illusion of equity."
Mr. Jones said house buyers stayed in their houses for about the length of the average marriage: seven years. "The longer you are going to be in your house, the longer it is going to make sense to buy," he said.
The length of residency aside, the rest of the equation for figuring whether renting or buying provides the most savings is more complex and weighs numerous factors like maintenance expenses, fees, tax savings, gain on the down payment, appreciation and costs of renting.
There are several books and software programs that can help with the computations. Last year, Mitchell A. Levy, a financial analyst in Cupertino, Calif., published the book "Home Ownership: The American Myth" and a software package that creates spreadsheets to show people whether they should buy or rent.
"If you are going to buy a house, have the right reasons, emotionally or financially," he said. "Don't just jump on the bandwagon because everyone else is doing it or because your family and friends say you have to."
The Real Estate Center at Texas A& M sells similar software. "A lot of people will be surprised in that they will come out richer renting than if they buy," Mr. Jones said.
Marc Eisenson, who publishes a financial newsletter, The Banker's Secret Bulletin, in Elizaville, N.Y., said location was an important factor. He said renting usually made the most sense in places like Southern California, where the cost of buying a house was unusually high and the costs of renting comparable housing were low. Buying, he said, generally made more sense in places like the South and the Midwest where sale prices and rents were low.
Mr. Levy said regardless of location, renters usually fared better than buyers only if the monthly after-tax costs of owning were higher, which was not always the case in today's era of low interest rates. For example, renting a one-bedroom, rent-controlled apartment in Manhattan for $600 a month may be more economical than buying the similar apartment for $150,000. But if the same apartment rented at the market rate of $1,600 a month, buying would be better, providing that the owner kept the apartment long enough.
As for the Wrenners, they are in the fourth year of renting and are aware that the longer they stay the more likely it is they will lose the advantages of renting. "We are looking at it year by year," Ms. Wrenner said.
But, she added, there were intangible benefits to renting. "There is a flexibility," she said, pointing out that corporate layoffs had become pandemic in the Northeast. "We also like not having to plow the snow out of our driveway or having to fix a water leak in the ceiling," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Irene and Kevin Wrenner bucked tradition by renting this house in Ridgewood, N.J., and putting their money into other investments. (Julio A. Ibarra Jr. for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Studies on Immigrants Prove They'd Rather Give Than Receive

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Donald L. Huddle says that a column by Anthony Lewis and an article of mine are "clearly wrong" in saying that (a) immigrants do not increase native unemployment, and (b) they put more money into the public coffers in taxes than they take out in welfare and public services (letter, Jan. 26). Not so. 
 Concerning unemployment: In the Wall Street Journal article that Mr. Huddle mentions, I quoted verbatim the conclusions of the only six reputable studies (plus my own) on the subject. All conclude that immigration does not displace natives from jobs. None of the authors of those studies have asserted that the quotation was improper, to my knowledge. In that article I also explained why Mr. Huddle's own writing on the subject -- the only one that dissents from the scholarly consensus -- is entirely without validity. (Mr. Huddle's writings are analyzed at length in my 1989 book, "The Economic Effects of Immigration.")
Concerning the fiscal costs and benefits of immigration: Mr. Huddle notes my calculation that on average both immigrants and natives put more into the public coffers than they take out in individual public services. He claims that my calculation that immigrants are net contributors must therefore be wrong because both cannot be true.
But it is not the absolute net contribution of immigrants (whose calculation, like that of natives, inevitably leaves out some nonindividual governmental expenditures) that is the basis of my conclusion. Rather, the conclusion rests on the fact that the net contribution of immigrants is relatively high compared with that of natives; immigrants make greater net contributions largely because they arrive when they are young and strong, rather than at ages when people collect old-age benefits.
Both unemployment and welfare in connection with immigration are hot and important topics. They are also difficult for the layperson to sort out based on Op-Ed articles and letters to the editor. To clarify the matter, I invite Mr. Huddle to bring his work and mine -- and others, as appropriate -- before a "science court" of economists chosen by, say, the American Economic Association. The person whose work is found less valid would be bound to pay the court's expenses.
 
JULIAN L. SIMON
College Park, Md., Feb. 15, 1994

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Inside The System

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN 

 BODY:
Yvette hasn't changed much since the last time I saw her. She's still working on her weight; she's still warm and optimistic, signs her letters "Fondly," with a big curly F.
It was hot and muggy, that day three years ago, and Yvette was telling me then that a job was right around the corner. And that's what she tells me now, as the snow turns smoke-gray outside the narrow, barred window of her living room, nearly five years after she first went on welfare. 
 Bashing women like Yvette Bell is an American sport almost as popular as baseball, with politicians signing on as captains of the team. But before the President, the governors and the mayors talk about welfare reform, they had better be honest about the truth: that reforming welfare is about the monumental tasks of reforming housing, the economy, child care, health care and schools as well.
Take Yvette, who worked for the phone company for years. She lost her job when she lost her home, and she lost her home because she moved out, she says, when she got tired of her husband messing up her face with his fist. She went into "the system," she calls it, and when she calls it that she makes it sound like the dark fun house at the public policy fair.
When I first met her, in Brooklyn in 1991, she had gotten an apartment and was looking for a job. She made jokes about the crackheads in the hallways. She made jokes about her secondhand clothes, and how when she was working she used to give her own clothes away to the indigent, and now, whatta ya know, she was the indigent herself.
But she stopped laughing. The crackheads took over the top floor of the city-owned building in which she lived with her three daughters. "The police running in and out, the crackheads running in and out, all hours," she says now. "I had to be with the kids all the time. I couldn't even think of going to work when I knew the girls would come home from school and all that was going on."
In October, the fear of who or what might come crashing through her door, the screams and yells and footfalls and shots, got to be too much. "I didn't want to come back into the shelter system," she said, "but I left that place with just what I had on my back."
Two days at a city office sleeping in a chair with a 3-year-old on her lap, several weeks in a transitional shelter. Now Yvette lives in a dark but clean one-bedroom apartment in a building in the Bronx called Seneca House, where 74 families stay until they can find housing elsewhere.
It has as much security as some prisons, with a big clanging metal gate, closed-circuit monitors, guards. Yvette loves that. It's to keep the world out, not to keep her in, and after the crackheads she would just as soon the world took its business elsewhere.
She pores over The Chief, the city civil service newspaper. She took the test for mental hygiene therapy aide and passed. She took the test for a job at the Human Resources administration, and passed that, too. She's just waiting to be called back, waiting for a permanent apartment, to find day care for the baby, to shut off Sally Jesse and Montel Williams and get back into the loop. Outside her building, the out-of-work men shovel snow for a little extra cash.
"You get lazy doing nothing," she says sadly, six months shy of her 40th birthday. Still, she figures she's better off than others who live around her. There's a 14-year-old in one of the apartments who already has two children.
Responsibility, the talking heads yammer about women like Yvette Bell. But responsibilities are slippery things, depending on who's talking about them. Is it more responsible for a poor woman who gets pregnant to have an abortion or a baby? Is it more responsible to care for your kids yourself, or to leave them in iffy situations while you work to support them? Is it irresponsible that Yvette stayed home with her kids when her building was lousy with drugs and violence?
When the President had his economic summit, he invited all sorts of business people to sit around a big table. When Hillary Rodham Clinton was cooking up a health care plan, she put together a panel of people from the industry. And anyone who truly wants welfare reform has this responsibility: to get together a group of women who are in the system and ask them what keeps them there. The answers are complicated; the experts are poor. Yvette'll give them the story, unless, of course, she's found that job by then.

HEADLINE: Q & A;
Investing in Futures

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane 

 BODY:

Q. What is a managed futures fund?
 
SHELLY STEINBERG,
Manhattan
 
A. Futures are an investment vehicle. They include not only commodities like grains and meats, but also markets for interest rates, currencies and stock indexes. Many people without the skill, time or emotional discipline to trade in these volatile markets invest instead in managed futures funds, sometimes called commodity funds or pools.
Managed futures funds, which operate similarly to mutual funds, use professional commodity trading advisers to make buying and selling decisions. Minimum investments in these funds are typically lower than they are for purchases of individual futures contracts. Some funds may use more than one adviser for diverse points of view. 
 "The returns of managed futures are generally not correlated to the returns of the stock and bond markets, an attribute which can assist in dampening the fluctuations of the overall portfolio," said Jane E. Martin, executive director of the Managed Futures Association. "In addition, managed futures offer entrance to global markets not otherwise easily accessed."
 
457 Plan Distributions
 
Q. I work for city government and have retirement money invested in a tax-deferred annuity -- a 457 plan. How long after retirement can one leave funds in this account before a distribution must be taken?
 
GLEN H. SHANE,
The Bronx
 
A. Like 401(k) plans in the private sector and 403(b) plans for teachers, 457 plans let government employees tap the assets after they reach age 59 1/2 without paying a penalty of 10 percent for early withdrawal. Plan participants generally have the flexibility to keep funds in the plan until they reach age 70 1/2.
If the money is not needed -- and you are comfortable with the plan's investment performance -- you can achieve further tax-deferred growth by leaving it in the plan.
 "While the general rule on minimum withdrawals from a Section 457 plan is that they must begin by April 1 of the year following the participant's attaining age 70 1/2, certain government employers have tighter restrictions, such as requiring withdrawals to begin by age 65," said Kurt Cerulli of Cerulli Associates, a financial services consulting firm in Boston. "The specifics of your plan should be checked."
 
When Municipals Are Taxed
 
Q. Do you lose the triple tax-free advantage of municipal bonds if they are sold before maturity?
 
FRANK GRIBBON,
Manhattan
 
A. Any interest you receive from your municipal bond investment is tax-free. But if you sell a municipal bond at a profit before it matures, you incur a capital gain and must pay a capital gains tax. For a long-term capital gain -- on an investment held at least a year -- the top tax rate is 28 percent.
 "Investors may also be subject to capital gains if they sell before maturity, bonds issued at a discount, such as zero-coupon bonds," said Heather Ruth, president of the Public Securities Association. "The discount is the difference between the issue price of the bond and its par value."

HEADLINE: Bond Markets Buoyed by Bargain Hunting

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
After a stormy week that saw interest rates surge, a still jittery market managed to find itself on firm footing yesterday.
Buyers, looking for value after a number of sharp selloffs had depressed prices, emerged in sufficient numbers to give the market a much-needed lift, traders said 
 The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond rose 8/32 yesterday. The long bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.71 percent, from 6.73 percent on Thursday.
"Today I saw less liquidation and some bottom-fishing by investors looking for value," Peter Hirsch, managing director and head of the government trading desk at Salomon Brothers, said. For the first time all week, he added, he saw buying close to the level of selling.
 
Consumer Sentiment
 Bond prices traded mostly higher throughout the session, with the exception of a slight downturn in the morning after reports of a survey by the University of Michigan showing that although its consumer sentiment index fell to 93.2 in February from 94.3 in January, the number was above the preliminary February index, 92.9, released two weeks ago, and thus raised inflation fears.
Comments by a Federal Reserve governor also caused bond prices to slip at one point. The governor, Susan M. Phillips, said she was reasonably pleased with inflation and called the recent bond selloff a bit surprising.
Investors, however, were less fearful yesterday after buyers were lured back, and the market firmed. But with the prospect of bear markets in both bonds and stocks, traders are worried that large speculative investors like hedge funds will start to sell again and move money overseas.
 
March Tightening Possible
 If the Fed tightens credit again, it might wait until the next Federal Open Market Committee meeting on March 22.
Some analysts, however, said it could do so next week, when the market will have three big economic reports to digest: a revision to the gross domestic product numbers, the National Association of Purchasing Management Index and the monthly employment report.
All are important indicators for the economy, but Mr. Hirsch of Salomon Brothers said, "The market will only be focused on anything with a price component."
The price component of the purchasing management report should be of particular interest to the market, since it rose sharply in January.
Other reports due next week -- new home sales, for example -- will probably not be watched so closely, because of the severe winter weather.
Mr. Hirsch said if a tightening were to come next week, it would be after the purchasing managers' report on Tuesday and before the employment report is released on Friday. "It would give the Fed a free ride for a couple days," he said.

HEADLINE: MORTGAGES;
Loan Assistance Varies For Borrowers in Crisis

BYLINE: By Andrea Adelson 

 BODY:
AS Californians with earthquake-damaged homes recently discovered, all mortgages are not the same. Some lenders are willing to provide flexible terms and other assistance when disaster strikes. Some are not.
 For example, Home Savings of America, the nation's largest savings institution, plans to make interest-free loans to 200 borrowers who have badly damaged houses and no other assets, with no payments until the houses are sold. For borrowers needing a brief respite, Home Savings will stretch out their loans. Along with good publicity, the move is intended to avert bigger losses in foreclosure. 
 Banks and savings and loan associations say their structures allow them to be more accommodating than mortgage banks. But mortgage banks, which make loans and do not take deposits, call such portrayals unfair.
 The debate within the mortgage industry is not new and is based on what institutions do with their loans.
Banks and savings and loans typically keep some loans, especially those with adjustable interest rates, in their portfolios. Mortgage bankers, whose rates are often slightly lower than those of other lenders, typically sell their loans to investors. The institutions that hold loans argue that they can more easily revise the terms in case of hardship or bend to meet a borrower in the first place.
"Because we hold the loans, we can make the decisions and move," said Charles R. Rinehart, chief executive of Home Savings.
 "That's something the public should wake up to," said Mario J. Antoci, chairman and chief executive of American Savings Bank in Stockton, Calif.
Peter and Susan Klamkin found a distinction when they shopped for a mortgage for their first house. The Klamkins had a blemished credit history because it took them a while to pay medical bills for treating their daughter's rare metabolic illness, and many lenders turned them away. "Rates became secondary," Mr. Klamkin said. "We shopped for anyone who would listen to our story."
Loan officials at Shawmut Bank in Hartford listened. The Klamkins got a loan of $147,500 to buy a house in Longmeadow, Mass., last summer.
Mortgage bank executives say they also make exceptions and renegotiate loans for borrowers in a cash squeeze. But because they sell their loans, they must abide by strict underwriting rules and relief plans stipulated by the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, which package the loans for investors. Even if these two groups grant temporary relief, the mortgage bank is obligated to continue payments.
"Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac aren't doing the lenders any favors," said Warren Lasko, executive vice president of the Mortgage Bankers Association, referring to commonly used names of the Federal mortgage groups. "They're putting the burden entirely on the lender's back."
Albert Lequang, the national policy administrator for Freddie Mac, could not recall an instance when the agency had agreed to rework a borrower's loan terms other than to pay it off. "Investors don't look kindly on that," he said.
Arranging work-out terms is more difficult with a mortgage bank, said Thomas H. Boone, managing director of the Countrywide Funding Corporation in Pasadena, Calif., the country's largest mortgage lender. "But it can be done, and we do it every day."
Typically, forbearance from Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac means delinquencies are not reported to credit bureaus, late charges are dropped and borrowers are given a 60- or 90-day indulgence period, after which they must establish a plan to repay arrears within a year. Such relaxed rules benefited many victims of Hurricane Andrew and the Midwest floods.
Babette Heimbuch, president of First Federal Bank in Santa Monica, Calif., said: "The programs Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac offer are pretty much useless when your house is destroyed."
Of course, not all traditional lenders give customers more leeway than Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. For hurricane victims, Barnett Banks of Florida stuck with the agencies' guidelines.
