SECTION: Section 6; Page 50; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 2861 words

HEADLINE: The Pequots

BYLINE: By Francis X. Clines; Francis X. Clines is a reporter and columnist for The Times.

 BODY:
They really are palefaces under the neon lights, all these senior citizens and tourists playing the slot machines, blackjack tables and big-payoff bingo games at the Wisconsin Oneida tribe's casino. The casino booms around the clock in the reservation woods near the luck-hungry bettors of Green Bay. Rick Hill, with shoulder-length hair and a patient, earthen-hued outlook on life, reigns there, counting the wondrously gross receipts with the dedicated eye his ancestors once applied to tracking redcoats for George Washington.
Hailing good fortune's arrival on the rundown reservation, Hill first supplies its historical context -- genocidal defeats and the transcontinental retreat of his people, 27 broken treaties and six million lost acres in New York State alone. Only then, against the bleeping and bonging of fortune's reversal, does he comment on Oneida casino revenues, which have risen to more than $375 million a year: "Compared to the previous 170 years, it's not a lot of money, and there are still third-world conditions on most reservations." 
 A few hours later Hill stands before a dozen graduates at the Oneida elementary school, run on casino profits. "Don't hold back," he tells them. And no wonder. Their reservation, like scores of others, is resurgent. "With the community you've got all the resources you need. We'll back you up," he promises. After an elder says a tribal prayer, the young American Indians march off toward the future, their higher-education expenses already guaranteed by the gamblers just down the road.
The Oneidas are but one of more than 100 tribes across the country working to resurrect themselves with gambling after the long spiral of bad dealings with the white man. And they are not the richest. This turn of luck has come about since 1988, when Congress, prompted by the Supreme Court's bolstering of tribal sovereignty, adopted the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act. Out of that law, which requires states to negotiate compacts with tribes, 170 casinos and high-stakes bingo halls have taken root. Where so recently there was utter destitution, the more fortunate tribes have created a $1.5 billion economy in which revenues have been doubling annually.
"Our day in the sun is arriving," Hill says of his tribe's new life of full employment and new schools, roads, sewers and houses -- the Indian version of a postwar Levittown.
"It's been wonderful. I never had these opportunities before in my life," says Pat Metoxen, who for years did odd jobs in Green Bay for $6.50 an hour. He has become an Oneida pit boss at $15 an hour, joining 2,500 other tribe members who work in the casino. Metoxen has a new house, a new car, and he says his three children "will probably need master's degrees in business, at the rate the tribe is progressing."
Law degrees wouldn't hurt either. Tribal gambling powers and sovereignty have come under increasing legal challenges from dumbfounded state officials crying foul at the Indians' success. The critical juncture for the gaming sachems is to come later this year, when Congress considers amending the act -- a familiar, frightening possibility for tribal leaders, who recall how countless compacts were written then disregarded in Washington.
"We've had 200 years of that process," says Timothy Wapato, executive director of the National Indian Gaming Association. The association has 96 member tribes and can afford an impressive lobbying presence in Washington. In recent months the tribes have been negotiating with state officials, searching for a peaceful common position to present to Congress in the growing conflict over tribal sovereignty and states' prerogatives.
In the face of Supreme Court backing of the tribes' sovereign rights, some experienced officials of the Las Vegas and Atlantic City gambling industry have begun cooperating and looking for a management interest in tribal casinos. Others, like Donald Trump, the owner of three casinos in Atlantic City, see their hegemony threatened. Trump is suing. He contends that his rights are being violated by what he calls a "very limited class of citizens."
"The Indians are only a sovereign nation when it comes to gambling," Trump argues, dismissing the nationhood precedent that tribes say was long abused by Washington to negotiate them into retreat. "Most people think casino gambling will be what alcohol was to the Indians of past generations," Trump says. "I have seen these Indians, and you have more Indian blood than they have."
As if measuring some tabloid-mache Custer, Hill smiles when he hears what Trump has to say. He dismisses Trump as a chronically bankrupt entrepreneur who talks a good game of competition until he's been bested. "Another white man has come to take even the measly beads left," Hill declares, matching Trump movie cliche for cliche.
For the lobbying effort, the 96 tribes of the National Indian Gaming Association elected Hill, a 41-year-old gaming tyro who emphasizes tribal culture, as chairman. His style is more Native American than that of his predecessor, Charles C. Keechi, a button-down executive and former chairman of the Delaware nation in Oklahoma. Hill's victory by a 3-to-1 margin last spring was a tribute to his skills in the art of Indian politics, inherited from his father, and to his success at investing casino profits in tribal welfare.
At the gambling tables, the palefaces seem indifferent to Trump's sudden sense of curtailed citizenship and Hill's recapitulation of the Great White Father's perfidy. "I don't know what I'd do with my days if it wasn't for the casino," a grandmotherly gambler says as her fellow retirees cluster vigilantly at Oneida's morning mega-bingo session.
To anyone who ever rooted for the underdog in tribal America's sad saga, the rise of Indian casinos is as heartening as it is amazing. "It's the return of the white buffalo," says Matt Connor of Gaming & Wagering Business International magazine, invoking the rare American bison, a traditional sign of renewed providence. W. Bruce Turner, a gaming company stock analyst with Salomon Brothers, assesses the Indian's gaming business less romantically -- "capable of 200 percent growth over the next several years." He finds their ability to adapt to gambling "nothing short of overwhelming."
A decade ago, the tribes had zero gross product and 70 percent unemployment. Now there are 70 major tribal casinos with table games and slot machines in 19 states. And dozens more are planned. A premise of the 1988 gaming act was that the reservations needed to be freed from patronizing restrictions that prevented them from amassing economic development capital. The result: they now generate, manage and reinvest betting profits that this year will approach $2 billion, over 3 percent of the nation's legal betting take.
"ISN'T THAT WHAT AMERICA IS SUPPOSED TO BE ABOUT?" ASKS IRVING Wizenfeld, an enthusiastic regular at the furiously busy Foxwoods Resort Casino in Ledyard, Conn. Created by the once nearly extinct Mashantucket Pequot tribe, Foxwoods is unique even in these tribal boom times. In only two years, it has become the single most profitable casino in the Western Hemisphere, raking in an estimated $600 million a year in profits.
A two-and-a-half hour drive from Manhattan, Foxwoods offers "wampum" betting cards, cocktail waitresses in skimpy fringed and beaded tunics, and more than 3,000 slot machines. More than 15,000 gamblers show up every day, on weekends as many as 35,000. The gleaming 24-hour casino is the talk of the country's $30-billion-a-year industry -- a subject of both envy and fear.
Foxwoods was created almost single-handedly by Chairman Richard (Skip) Hayward, a reclusive, canny pathfinder. He cut a bold profit-sharing deal with the State of Connecticut that will eventually allow him to have 4,600 slot machines, more than any other casino on the East Coast. He also took care to hire as his chief executive officer G. Michael Brown, the former director of New Jersey's Division of Gaming Enforcement; Brown built his reputation as a prosecutor who forced Atlantic City casinos to steer clear of underworld ties.
Working in desolate woods, Hayward first had to rebuild his own withered tribe by searching out members from the post-Colonial diaspora, some of them lost in the urban underclass. Twenty years ago, the Mashuntucket Pequot reservation had fewer than a dozen residents; Hayward authenticated more than 200 others and campaigned to get them Federal recognition, the key to sovereignty and legalized gambling. All now profit in well-paid jobs, guaranteed educations and health insurance. The tribe has also hired an archeologist to disinter its history and stock the new museum.
"This is truly a case of the last becoming first," exults Tom Tureen, the lawyer who was lead counsel in the land claim fight that established Pequot sovereignty. "There has never been anything to approach this as a means of providing capital to Indians."
To protect the Foxwoods bonanza from corruption threats, Brown, the chief executive, has used his Atlantic City experience to ease back from the absolute sovereignty so dear to other tribes and has instead invited on-site cooperation with state and Federal law enforcement experts, and exchanges of gambling intelligence with Las Vegas and Atlantic City networks.
Federal law concerning Indians is rooted in respect for sovereignty and defers to state-tribal compacts for regulatory procedures. But Washington insists on professional accounting standards to head off sweetheart deals that could siphon funds from tribal welfare programs. The Pequots run a consultant service for other tribes, stressing the need for high-level security, strict controls in the movement of money and experienced management.
"We've found a predictable mix," notes Brown in reference to studies of two other casinos. "One was excellently run; the other was so lax in controls that it could easily fall victim to illicit dealings." He says the main threat to Indian gaming is not underworld infiltration as much as "bad business deals in a risky area, just as with junk bonds."
The tribes might eventually end up with 250 or more casinos of various sizes, if the Federal gaming law is not radically crimped. The Indians' good fortune has helped spur an even larger boom in legalized gambling off the reservation. And it's not just the Indians who are getting richer; areas surrounding the reservations are profiting too.
Gov. Lowell Weicker of Connecticut has agreed that Foxwoods may add slot machines, in a clever monopoly compact worked out under the Federal act by Hayward. The tribe provides the state at least $100 million a year, so long as competitive slot operations, the main engines of gambling profit, are not authorized in other Connecticut cities now agitating for their own action. Last year, as casino revenues rocketed, Hayward defended his golden monopoly by giving the state an additional $13 million in budget help.
In Minnesota, cooperation between reservation and Statehouse has put 11 tribes in control of 17 high-stakes bingo and gambling casinos that constitute an annual industry with betting in excess of $650 million and a $116 million payroll. Seventy-three percent of the casino workers are non-Indians, hired as unemployment on the reservation dropped toward zero. Minnesota found that in casino regions the economy grew twice as fast as in other areas and that welfare dependency fell 3 percent in casino counties while it was rising 15 percent elsewhere.
Hill says he believes that their new wealth has firmed the tribes' resolve to face up to the gaming act challenge. "Economics gives us more political power," he says.
The main opposition comes from the National Governors' Association, which has been negotiating tentatively with the tribes to find common ground for a proposal that might head off the riskier unknowns of unlacing the gaming act. The tribes' staunchest support comes from Senator Daniel Inouye of Hawaii, the chairman of the Senate Committee on Indian Affairs, who says court decisions demand that the act be amended this year.
The governors resent Indian independence of state control and freedom from taxes. But their problem is that court interpretations upholding Indian sovereignty limit their options. They want to avoid the theoretical possibility that financially pressed cities might, under land-trust arrangements, donate part of their downtown areas to Indians to set up casinos. In California -- a critical battleground because it supplies Las Vegas with one-third of its gamblers -- the state has balked at Federally mandated negotiations with tribes, forcing the issue into the courts.
The Indians know that critics are just waiting for a corruption scandal to bolster a wholesale gutting of the gaming act. Rick Hill, bemused at white society's tolerance of its own savings and loan scandal, stresses a Justice Department finding that tribal management has thus far proved more than a match for underworld intriguers.
"There has not been a widespread or successful effort by organized crime to infiltrate Indian gaming operations," the Justice Department concluded. That was two years ago; some tribes have since begun creating their own Vegas-like anticorruption networks. They also are emphasizing management training, something critics believe is needed to deal with intratribal rivalries and charges of executive profiteering.
This emphasis is clear in the security room at the Mystic Lake Casino, run by the Shakopee Sioux outside Minneapolis. A wall of television screens faces a 24-hour control desk where monitors run a high-speed taping system of closeup surveillance, custom-designed by industry experts to zoom in, from multiple angles, on the fingertips of gamblers and all money-handling employees. Discretion is considered counterproductive: when a worker is caught skimming or a gambler is taped tampering with the floor games, the tribe's policy is to make a dramatic on-the-spot arrest.
Success has brought some discord. Since losing his post as head of the National Indian Gaming Association last year, Charles Keechi of the Oklahoma Delawares has been warning that the casino issue may degenerate into a struggle among tribes. "I'm afraid it's the casino haves fighting it out with the have-nots," he says, speaking now as chairman of Natives of the Americas, a two-continent tribal economic organization.
There has been no move toward an intertribal sharing of profits. Most tribes pool their revenues for reservation development; some pay shared dividends to members, who keep details to themselves. Hill denies that the tribes with casinos would insulate themselves at the expense of weaker brethren in dealings with Congress.
At least 30 more tribes in 19 states are now trying to develop their own casinos. But in a universe of more than 300 Federally recognized tribes totalling 1.9 million people, the reservations of two-thirds of them seem less than fortunate, deliberately set far from tourist crossroads by treaty. Others are rebuffed at the statehouse.
The Indians are only part of a legalized gambling industry sweeping the nation in the recession-heavy years. Riverboat casinos now ply the Mississippi and Gulf Coast, with proposals to spread northeastward. And in the rush for revenues, bogus "boats" are being rushed into trenches like frontier settlements. Keeping up with the tribes is a selling point.
THE HEART OF the Indians' problem with unexpected success lies, as ever, in Washington. Hill and the other tribal leaders are wary of what may develop there. They have put their trust in Senator Inouye and Senator John McCain of Arizona, vice chairman of the committee on Indian affairs, who, under pressure from the governors and state attorneys general, have been trying to mediate the casino fight quietly by calling private conferences and serving, in effect, as diplomats among competing nations. Senator Inouye insists he has obtained reassurances from the governors' association that the states do not wish to attack the tribes' sovereignty or economic resurrection; rather, they would work out a better compact process of mutual profit.
Rick Hill expresses watchful faith in the "Inouye process." But characteristically he declines to hold his tongue in denouncing proposed gaming law amendments from Atlantic City and Las Vegas legislators as a "Trump Act" retrenchment of Indian sovereignty. "The civil war may be over for some, but not in Indian country," he says in the flat tone of determination the tribal chiefs sought to project when they chose him for the looming Congressional fight.
For this contest, Tom Tureen, the lawyer who helped create fresh Indian legend from gambling luck, counsels the greatest vigilance.
"History shows that any time Indians have anything of value, there's been people on the non-Indian side ready to take it away. Look at the Black Hills," he says, recalling how the Sioux were forced to move there by Washington, then illegally routed anew when whites discovered gold. "Look at the United States itself."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 46; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 2646 words

HEADLINE: The Native -- and Not So Native -- American Way;
The Apaches

BYLINE: By Erik Eckholm; Erik Eckholm is a project editor for The New York Times.

 BODY:
Arough camp is set up on the outskirts of Whiteriver, halfway up the White Mountains of Arizona and just below the point where terra cotta bluffs and junipers give way to the country's largest stand of Ponderosa pine.
Men chop wood and come and go in pickups. Dozens of women tend large fires, preparing food for the opening rituals of a nine-day celebration of a girl's puberty. Some bake bread and tortillas on open coals, fry steak or simmer a traditional corn brew; others, in the un-self-conscious blend of old and new so common among White Mountain Apaches, roll dough around hot dogs to bake on the fire or pack soda and beer into ice chests. Two medicine-men-in-training, college bound in the fall, stretch inner tubing over metal bowls to make drums. 
 In the printed invitation sent to scores of relatives and friends, Harlan and Caroline Hill Sr., the girl's grandparents, and Steve and Sharon Anderson, her parents, "cordially invite" guests to 12-year-old Shannon's "sacred Sunrise Dance." In this, the primary celebration of Apache identity, girls are temporarily transformed into Changing Woman, a powerful figure in the Apache creation myth. The coming-of-age ritual involves more time, effort and money, in relation to income, than the most elaborate coming-out party or bas mitzvah. Twenty-five years ago, only a few ceremonies were performed each year. Last spring and summer, there was at least one every weekend.
What is striking about this surge in tradition is that it has occurred over the same quarter-century that the White Mountain tribe has aggressively pursued economic opportunities. The tribe of 11,000, which inhabits 1.6 million spectacular acres in eastern Arizona known officially as the Fort Apache Reservation, has yet to abolish the poverty so prevalent among Native Americans. But it runs the largest lumber mill in the Southwest, a major ski resort, a new casino and other ventures that provide more than 1,000 jobs and demonstrate the tribe's ability to manage its affairs to a degree unusual in Indian country. Whiteriver, the tribal headquarters, bustles with plans and events, a virtual rush hour on its main road. Chasing the dollar, far from destroying tradition, has in many ways helped strengthen it. Despite Western education and Christian missionaries, television and rap music, this is one of the country's more intact reservations, a place where the lilting Apache language remains vital.
WHEN I FIRST VISITED THE RESERVATION AS A CHILD IN 1959, PAYING a daily fee for the chance to catch trout in its lakes and streams, many Apaches still lived in wickiups, conical dirt-floored dwellings made of poles covered with branches and grass. A large sawmill owned by an outside company cut logs from tribal forests under rules set by the Bureau of Indian Affairs. Today, nobody lives in a wickiup. The tribe runs its own sawmill, sells no uncut logs to outsiders and sets the rules that keep the forest more intact.
White Mountain storytellers have added new legends to their myths of the ancients -- tales of the 1960's and how the Indians took control of their own affairs. And no one enjoys telling them more than Ronnie Lupe, who has been tribal chairman for 20 of the last 28 years and is a dominant figure in White Mountain development. "The B.I.A. called all the shots," Lupe says, gesturing with practiced indignation as he recalls his first days in office in 1966. "They even opened my mail!" A Korean War veteran whose father had once been tribal chairman, Lupe (pronounced LOO-pee) was elected to the top post at the age of 36. As he sits at his desk, dressed in his standard jeans and cowboy shirt, Lupe laughs, remembering the reaction of local B.I.A. officials to his first solo trip to Washington to meet with Federal agencies.
"They were so mad," Lupe recalls. "They asked: 'Where did you stay? Who did you talk to?' I said, 'None of your business.' " The unending struggle to define tribal sovereignty has become part of Lupe's political persona, which he underscores by hanging a painting of the defiant Geronimo outside his office.
This assertion of independence was not so welcome then, though it is now encouraged by Federal law. Until the recent spread of casinos, few of the country's 300 reservations had managed it -- and even many tribes now profiting from gambling have essentially let outsiders run things. A Harvard advisory team that has provided development advice to many tribes says the White Mountain tribe is one of the most successful in managing its future. "We find a pattern," says Joseph P. Kalt, an economist and a director of the Harvard group. "A charismatic leader aggressively pushes the B.I.A. into the background. You see a growth in civic pride, a sense that the tribe is finally doing something." Keith H. Basso, an anthropologist and linguist at the University of New Mexico, identified two traits Lupe and members of his elected Tribal Council share with the most effective Indian leaders: they are rooted in their language and culture and are not afraid to deal aggressively with non-Indians and Government officials to advance tribal interests.
I met with Lupe last June, in between his trips to Phoenix to lobby for the right to open a casino. As we spoke, he broke off to take a call from the tribe's lawyer in Washington, who was pursuing water disputes and a suit against the Government for past mismanagement of tribal lands, then again for a call from his white economic planner down the hall. Out in the waiting room, people were seeking help with personal crises or bureaucratic tangles. Part corporate executive and part small-town mayor, Lupe spends much of his free time at community functions. His wife was out at the camp, helping the Hill family bake bread.
Despite his achievements, Lupe faces a hard-fought tribal election every four years -- the next one in April -- and his life has the air of a perpetual campaign. Last summer, he was already on the offensive. As I listened with an interpreter to his regular radio address, given in cadenced Apache, an occasional English word jumped out -- "hypocrite," "racism," "sovereignty." Lupe offered a ringing defense of his economic strategy, described his battles with the state and slipped a stiletto into his chief political rival, the director of the tribe's fish and game department, whose wife is a Navajo: "You can marry anyone you want to," said Lupe. "But I married a tribal member and she is always out there, helping people."
HISTORY GAVE THE WHITE MOUNTAIN APACHES SOME advantages. Like other Apaches, they raised fierce warriors who augmented food supplies by raiding other tribes and later Mexicans and Americans in astonishing feats of stealth and desert travel. But geographic isolation held down the extent of their conflict with the American military. Choosing accommodation as their survival strategy, the White Mountain group provided many of the scouts who helped the cavalry track down renegades like Geronimo in the 1870's and 1880's. The main high school is named after Alchesay, who won the Medal of Honor for his exploits and was a pre-eminent tribal leader early this century. The legacy stirs ambivalent feelings: Lupe tells me he does not consider "those who wore the blue coat" to be heroes.
Accommodation paid off. Apart from a brief relocation, the White Mountain tribe was allowed to stay on its ancestral lands. Other Apache groups, some mutually hostile, were uprooted and packed together in the San Carlos Reservation, in a more barren region just south of the White Mountains. The San Carlos Reservation was subjected to harsh military rule and to this day is plagued by crippling factional disputes and a sorry economic record.
The rugged range that once protected the White Mountain people became their chief source of wealth. By far the major industry is the Fort Apache Timber Company, which operates a sawmill that employs more than 300 Apaches at wages averaging $8.50 an hour. Another hundred work for logging contractors. In 1993, the sawmill had revenues of some $40 million and paid the tribe about $10 million in timber fees. The Sunrise ski resort provides work for another 200 Apaches, and when snows are good turns revenues of $6 million and profits of more than $1 million. Other smaller enterprises together net only a few hundred thousand dollars, but include the country's best elk hunting; hunters wait years to pay $11,000 for a guided trip. There is also a tribal liquor store, run reluctantly, on the theory that it is safer for drinkers to buy liquor nearby than to make the 45-minute drive to resort towns outside the reservation.
"Apache Aerospace" proclaims the big sign on a building in Whiteriver. It seems preposterous, especially when you get inside and find 15 employees cutting and sewing insulation at $7 to $10 an hour. It seems less so after talking to Marilyn Endfield, an M.B.A. who has just stepped down as chairwoman of the company and is studying public policy at Harvard. In the 1980's, trading on the Apache name, the tribe persuaded McDonnell Douglas Aerospace to form a joint venture to supply sewn parts for the Army's Apache attack helicopter. Endfield stepped up the technology and hiring at Apache Aerospace, starting with light sheet-metal work, gaskets and seals. The company, she says, "gets people to feel good about being Apache."
Not everyone is so directed. In some ways, Kenny Clawson resembles alienated teen-agers anywhere. A husky 18-year-old with hair to his shoulders, he spends his days hanging out at the tribal newspaper office, which he finds more interesting than the days of drinking and pot smoking that led him to drop out of high school, as nearly half all reservation students do. Many teen-agers are enamored of rap music and its stars and some are even gang wannabes. But Kenny says he finds rap "too slow." His passion is heavy metal music, the morbid and frenetic kind known as death metal. His ambition is to form the first all-Apache death-metal band. Kenny lives with his parents and younger brother in a trailer that has seen better days, above the postcard tableau of Cedar Creek, 20 miles from Whiteriver. His father works at the sawmill, but Kenny sees no prospects for himself there.
Still, this is neither white suburbia nor the inner city, and each evening he joins his parents and relatives for a game of volleyball at the high school. He prefers to speak Apache and urges his young cousin to do the same: "We are Apache! Why are we speaking English?"
That attitude is a measure of the tribe's strength, but Kenny's experience also reflects its woes. There are still nearly twice as many potential workers as paying jobs on the reservation. Half the population receives welfare or food stamps, alcoholism is rampant and the median per capita income is $3,805 a year.
And because of the Apache tradition of sharing with relatives, those with jobs do not live on a scale dramatically different from those without. A few White Mountain families, including the chairman, live in ranch-style houses, but most inhabit nondescript wood or cinder-block tract houses built with Federal money; some live in shacks or trailers that lack running water. Few have telephones, though nearly everyone seems to have a television.
Approximately half of the families belong to Christian churches. Lutherans came first, in 1893, only seven years after Geronimo's surrender, followed by other Protestants and then Roman Catholics. But the most popular in recent years have been aggressive evangelical and "miracle" churches. Lupe says he is not a Christian but is tolerant; his father, who died last year, had joined the evangelicals. And while some preachers campaign against tribal rituals, the Catholic priest embraces them as another route to God. Many Apaches say the church has brought welcome structure into their lives and, overall, religious conflict seems less pressing than one would expect: Apaches seem to blend beliefs as they find them useful.
The unending quest for income and jobs has led the White Mountain Apaches to ride the gambling wave. Two months ago, the tribe opened its first casino, at Hon-dah on a highway traveled by tourists near the northern edge of the reservation. It employs more than 75 tribe members and is projected to yield profits of about $1 million this year and $3 to $4 million in subsequent years. The casino's remote location and competition from other tribes, never mind Las Vegas, may limit revenues. Still, tribal planners envisage a bigger take as gaming becomes the focus of a year-round, family-oriented "destination" resort.
Even with a lift from gambling, the tribal council may be shouldering an impossible burden. Population growth of more than 3 percent a year is comparable to third-world rates. Half the tribe is 18 or younger, but no one wants to talk about family planning -- not surprising among people who were the target of policies of extermination within historical memory.
With a virtual absence of entrepreneurship -- not even small family shops -- the economy suffers the rigidity of a miniature socialist state. Lupe says he would like to see more individual enterprise, but tradition works against it: the pressure on working people to share earnings makes it hard to accumulate capital.
Tradition also works against finding employment off the reservation; most Apaches are extremely reluctant to live far from from their families and land. They say of themselves, only half joking, that Apaches get homesick even before they leave on a trip and sometimes talk themselves out of going at all.
THE APACHE BALANCING ACT IS EVERYWHERE VISIBLE AT THE camp where the Hill family prepares for the Sunrise. Though it is still a minority that can pull it off, many parents are ambitious for their daughters. The girl at the center of events, Shannon Pusher (she has the surname of her mother's ex-husband), who entered eighth grade this fall, seems a bit bewildered. I ask why she is doing it; some girls refuse. "I don't know," she says. Then, "My parents told me they wanted to have one since I was 4 years old."
As the women prepare the feast, a cluster of staggering men grab a drum and chant loudly, jamming Apache-style. Even as the rite begins, one dons a sombrero and keeps yelling "amigos." But the drunken rowdies are just shrugged off. Apaches assume that people are doing the best they can; harsh thoughts could force cancellation of the ceremony.
With noon's approach, the women put on their finest camp dresses, the men colorful shirts. A procession forms, led by the girl, her best friend and parents, followed by drumming, chanting spiritual leaders and the rest of the relatives. They set off in a rhythmic shuffle for the camp of the girl's godparents a quarter-mile away for more drumming, dancing and speechmaking. The girl and her family present a feast and gifts to the godparents. They are not related; another purpose of the ceremony is to make a lasting bond between extended families to strengthen the tribe. Over the course of the week, the two families will sleep in makeshift wickiups and the medicine man and his helpers will perform sacred rites.
Early the next Saturday, Shannon dresses in fine buckskin and before a crowd of friends and relatives begins a five-hour ritual in which she is transformed into Changing Woman, temporarily able to cure the sick and bring rain to thirsty crops. On Monday, the ceremonies completed, her family breaks camp and Shannon goes home to ride her mountain bike and play country and rap music on her new stereo. The ceremony has endowed her with longevity, strength, prosperity and a generous temperament. Her family has cemented ties with another. Her community has again been blessed with the protective goodness of Changing Woman.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
The Suburban Connection

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
"IF you build it, they will come," the philosophy expressed in "Field of Dreams," could serve as a history of Westchester County Airport. Still using its "temporary" post-World War II quarters, and without any effort to lure new airlines or passengers, the airport has seen traffic increase, by fits and starts, almost fivefold since 1982.
"If you unbuild it, they will still come" would also work as a motto, because the long-awaited replacement of the Quonset hut terminal has begun, along with construction of a much-disputed parking garage, making life for the airport's passengers nearly impossible. Yet the passenger figure for 1993 showed a rise from 1992, in contrast with the other suburban airports and New York's three big ones. 
 Westchester Airport is usually considered to be in White Plains, although it is actually in Harrison, along the Connecticut line, off Interstate 684. The two other major suburban airports are state-owned Stewart International, near Newburgh in Orange County, N.Y., off Interstates 87 and 84, and MacArthur Airport, off Interstate 485 in Ronkonkoma, L.I. The latter airport is usually known as Islip, for the town that owns it.
These airports follow the general patterns of air travel, and were hurt by the Gulf war and the recession, but they are thriving by providing travelers from the suburbs with a way to avoid highway traffic in the metropolitan area, and giving people from out of town a fast way to reach the Hamptons, Connecticut and upstate New York. Islip's passenger totals have bumped up and down between 1982 and 1993 but show a more than fourfold rise during this period. Stewart got its first scheduled flight in April 1990, and its passenger traffic, according to its spokeswoman, Judy Lekoski-Eurich, has risen steadily except for last year's notch down.
Passenger traffic can be counted two ways. Enplanements is the number of passengers who take off from the airport; total passengers, the number that enplanes and debarks. MacArthur enplaned 587,278 passengers in 1993, as opposed to 604,710 in 1992 -- a 3 percent drop. Stewart enplaned 370,659 passengers in 1993 and 403,351 in 1992, an 8 percent decrease. Westchester County enplaned 474,728 passengers in 1993, a 24 percent increase from 1992's 382,270. Responding to the observation that this was a big jump for a Quonset hut, Ingrid Meyer, who works for the airport administration, said, "Yes, and you feel it every Friday afternoon."
Of course, these numbers could be shrugged off by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Figures for 1993 are not complete but are expected to be down somewhat from 1992, when the total for Kennedy , La Guardia and Newark was 35.8 million enplanements. The 1993 total for the three suburban airports was 1.4 million.
 
The Snowbird Special
 Increasingly, suburban airports are offering direct flights to more distant places, particularly warm-weather areas, where suburban residents may have second homes or relatives.
Stewart, designated SWF, has 36 outbound flights for February, not all of them daily, and the majority to big hubs, where they link to other flights: American to Chicago and Raleigh-Durham (N.C.); Delta to Atlanta; Trans World Express to Kennedy; United Express to Newark, Dulles in Washington and Boston; USAir to Pittsburgh, and USAir Express to Philadelphia, Syracuse (N.Y.) and Buffalo.
For February, Westchester, designated HPN, has 80 outbound flights on eight airlines: American to Chicago; Carnival to Fort Lauderdale (Fla.); Delta to Boston and Philadelphia; Northwest to Detroit and Minneapolis; United to Chicago and New Haven; United Express to Dulles in Washington, Rochester (N.Y.) and Buffalo; USAir to Pittsburgh; USAir commuter lines to Baltimore-Washington, Binghamton (N.Y.), Boston, Burlington (Vt.), Philadelphia, Poughkeepsie (N.Y.), Syracuse (N.Y.) and Washington National.
Islip, designated ISL, lists its February activity as: American to Chicago and Raleigh-Durham (N.C.); Carnival to Fort Lauderdale, Tampa and West Palm Beach, Fla.; Continental Express to Newark; Delta Connection to Albany and Boston; Northwest Airlink to Boston; United Express to Dulles in Washington, and USAir to Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, Washington National, Syracuse (N.Y.), Baltimore-Washington, Albany, Orlando and Fort Lauderdale (Fla.) and Boston.
Alfred Werner, the manager, says about 70 flights, not all operating daily, arrive at the airport and a roughly equal number depart.
Carnival, a five-year-old airline owned by Micky Arison, the chairman of Carnival Cruise Lines, operates out of Westchester and Islip and is the only one of the start-up airlines to use the suburbs. Max Buck, the marketing director, said the line began nonstop service from Islip to Fort Lauderdale in 1992 because the success that now-defunct Northeast and then Eastern had on this route meant demand was there. The line now has four daily flights from Islip: two to Fort Lauderdale and one each to Tampa and West Palm Beach. In spring, the schedule to Fort Lauderdale will drop to 10 trips a week from Islip.
Mr. Buck said other small airlines may not be trying the suburbs because new aircraft are required to meet noise limitations. Carnival uses new 737-400's.
The airline won in an auction for a takeoff and landing slot at Westchester, Mr. Buck said, and on Dec. 3 began offering an 8:25 A.M. flight to Fort Lauderdale from there daily except Saturday.
 
Terminal Amenities
 The airports offer the usual conveniences: food service, car-rental counters, motels nearby, taxi lines or special phones to call them. They also have places to sit, although in the case of Westchester, there are only about 20 seats. The parking situation, including fees, varies at the airports, although it is generally cheaper to park than at the Port Authority airports.
Stewart, with 10,000 state-owned acres, has abundant long-term and short-term lots, including spaces for the disabled. Fees range from $6 to $8 a day. The lots are managed by Apcoa. For parking information: (914) 567-0276.
Islip has 1,200 parking places that cost $6 a day, also operated by Apcoa, but Mr. Werner said these fill up on major holidays. Parking information for Islip residents: (516) 467-3210. Non-Islip residents: (516) 467-2468.
Westchester is difficult. The garage, recently a wall of snow-shrouded forms for poured concrete, is expected to be usable by August, but, as different plots of ground are ripped up, the parking concessionaire's employees must snake the autos into the sparse long-term spots.
"We have 300 spots to park on the airport grounds, more or less, depending on the day, compared with 1,200 before construction began," said the airport manager, Joel Russell. Mr. Russell said that valet parking off the airport property more than made up the difference. A fee for the valet service, depending on the length of stay, is added to the on-airport parking fee of $7.50 a day; off-airport parking is $12 for the first day and $8 a day after that. For parking information: (914) 946-3846.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S THE WORLD'S PRIORITY TASK?

 BODY:
By presenting apparently contradicting views on the subject of world population growth, it appears that there exist just two diametrically opposed camps: the demographers and the feminist groups. 
 Family planning is a complex issue, one that overlaps many issues, from the environment and economic development to gender equality and the rights of children. It is particularly important, in light of the coming International Conference on Population and Development in Cairo, to emphasize that family planning is not a zero-sum game, in which a woman's right to choose is mutually exclusive to efforts to curb global population growth rates.

HEADLINE: Q and A

 BODY:

Forcing a Board To Hold a Meeting
 
Q. I live in a co-op that has had serious financial problems with the original sponsor that resulted in an auction sale of his shares in the co-op. During this time the co-op board never kept the owners informed of what was happening. The board does meet on a monthly basis, but the shareholders are not invited. Further, there has not been an annual meeting of shareholders in almost two years. Simply put, the shareholders have no idea what is going on in our building. 
 Is there anything we can do to force the board to have an annual meeting? And can shareholders be barred from attending monthly meetings? . . . Kathleen Carr Rickwood, Manhattan
 
A. According to Michael Finder, a Manhattan lawyer, there is no legal basis to force a board to have open meetings, and most co-op boards have closed meetings, particularly because there are certain legal and financial matters that are more appropriately discussed in a closed meeting.
Mr. Finder added that boards were required to hold annual shareholders' meetings and that if they did not the appropriate action would be to petition the board to hold the meeting and, upon its failure to do so, take the members to court, which can compel to board to hold the meetings.
 
The Right to Sublet A Co-op Apartment
 
Q. Can a co-op apartment board refuse to let an owner sublet his apartment even when it means the owner will be forced to sell at a loss of roughly 40 percent of what he paid for the apartment? . . . B. Swanstrom, Springfield, N.J.
 
A. According to Benjamin D. Lambert, a lawyer in Woodbridge, N.J., virtually all proprietary leases for co-ops provide that boards can refuse to let an owner sublet an apartment, regardless of the potential loss the owner may suffer. "The economic consequence to an owner doesn't really factor into the situation, as a legal matter," he said.
There are, of course, many buildings whose proprietary leases or boards of directors have established more permissive rules regarding subletting. Mr. Lambert suggested that you have your attorney review the building's proprietary lease and by-laws and examine any published building policies to determine whether there is any legal recourse.
Mr. Lambert added, however, that in New Jersey such restrictions were in peril. Last year, in fact, the State Legislature almost approved a bill that would have prohibited co-op boards, condo boards and homeowners' associations from barring or unreasonably restricting rentals regardless of what the underlying documents state. He said that the bill had been drafted in response to the difficult economic times and the belief that many property owners in these communities were being punished. He added, though, that such legislation would be undoing deed restrictions.
"One of the major issues that was raised was that you have a number of communities with restrictions, and people bought into those communities with the expectation that they would be owner-occupied," he said.
The bill, Mr. Lambert said, has already been reintroduced for the current legislative session in Trenton.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
The Quest for Shops Below Bushwick El

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
ASIDE from the fact that the J train still chugs along on elevated tracks above his shop, Ben Stewart hardly recognizes the Broadway he knew when he moved his offset-printing business to the Bushwick section of Brooklyn 19 years ago.
He arrived two years before the Great Blackout of 1977. The blackout set off a spree of looting and fires with effects upon Broadway's commercial life that linger to this day. Many small businesses withdrew from the district, never to return. 
 "It used to be so beautiful -- people came to shop on weekends," said Mr. Stewart. "After the blackout everyone moved out."
Not everyone. Not Pat Adipietro for one. Mr. Adipietro opened Krown's, a housewares and floor-covering business, on the corner of Broadway and Gates Avenue 44 years ago. Then, in 1986, the business moved and expanded, after buying a city-owned building at 1325 Broadway between Linden and Grove Streets. Now Mr. Adipietro has retired and his son Anthony, 35, runs the business in 7,000 square feet of well-stocked space. "We need more stores here," he said.
Stanley Henry also had a hardware store. Two years ago Mr. Henry bought city property -- 27,000 square feet on Broadway at Halsey Street -- with a view to expanding into the building-supplies business. He broke ground but foundered on a familiar rock -- no reasonably priced mortgage financing.
Late last year he found a funding source in the Community Capital Bank, a three-year-old Brooklyn-based, state-chartered commercial bank that specializes in loans to small businesses and nonprofit corporations in low- to moderate-income communities. It committed to a construction loan and permanent financing that will speed development to a conclusion late this year. There will be a 13,000-square-foot store plus on-site parking and storage space.
But the largest commercial project on Broadway since the blackout is about to get under way on five blocks mostly cleared along the northeast side of the street between Gates Avenue and Cornelia Street.
This one is will be an early test of a broad effort by the New York City Economic Development Corporation to generate retail development along commercial strips close to concentrations of recently completed city-assisted residential construction.
The successful respondent to a city request for developer proposals for the sites was the Broadway Bushwick Builders Corporation, a group with Jeffrey Stern and Daniel B. Gerard as development partners and Alex Goldin as the construction partner. They will build a total of 43,500 square feet of stores in two phases, with extensive on-site parking. Its cost is estimated at $5.5 million.
The first phase, already financed, will consist of 13 stores with a total of 21,000 gross square feet of space, plus parking, on two large sites between Palmetto and Woodbine Streets and Woodbine and Madison Streets.
The second phase will bring additional stores to land between Gates Avenue and Palmetto Street and between Madison Street and Putnam Avenue. The fifth site, between Putnam Avenue and Cornelia Street, will be reserved for parking to fulfill zoning requirements.
The first phase has a financing commitment from the Community Preservation Corporation, a consortium of banks whose usual role is as a construction and permanent lender to moderate-income multifamily housing. The project also has been helped by a second mortgage of $184,000 from the Economic Development Corporation and a $721,000 city grant. The State of New York Mortgage Agency has committed to insure the permanent mortgage, which will be sold to the New York City Police Pension Fund.
"SECURITY is important," said Mr. Goldin, the construction partner, in describing the project. The structures will have a precast concrete wall system, and roll-up metal gates will protect the fronts at night. Mr. Goldin, a 40-year-old investment builder who was a civil engineer in Russia before immigrating to the United States, is the principal in Century Building Associates, in Bush Terminal, Brooklyn. He has completed seven residential projects under the city's Vacant Building Program.
Other sites for the Economic Development Corporation retail development program have been chosen on Rockaway Avenue in Brownsville and Memorial Avenue in Coney Island. In the Bronx, sites have been selected on Southern Boulevard in Crotona Park East, on Third Avenue in East Tremont and in the Mott Haven section.
The Broadway stores are coming in the wake of a city housing program that has generated 3,000 new or rehabilitated units in Bushwick. The total includes 104 newly built two-family houses, with 68 more in construction and many more to come.
Eventually there will be about 800 new units in these houses, each owner having one rental apartment. Many more new two-family houses fill several blocks near the store sites on the Bedford-Stuyvesant side of Broadway, a community dividing line.
One residential project just beginning in Bushwick will put attached two-family houses on 40 lots immediately behind the new Broadway stores. The midblock sites are off Gates Avenue, Palmetto Street and Woodbine Street. The Bluestone Organization of Queens is the builder and Herbert H. Warman of Great Neck is the architect. Houses will sell for $126,700; the owner will have one rental tenant.
Build enough new housing and eventually an incoming population will support retail development, the theory goes. Bushwick has certainly "come back" residentially, with substantial financial effort from New York City and its intermediary with private builders, the New York Housing Partnership. The question is how successful the developers will be in attracting and holding financially strong stores that provide services that complement the commercial establishments already doing business in the area.
The developers have so far signed a discount variety store called Saverama to a 9,700-square-foot space on one block and a laundromat to a small store on another. Other tenant prospects include an eyeglass store, a shoestore, a jeweler, a check-cashing service, a pizzeria, a deli, a Blimpie's food operation and a variety store.
Rents at present are about $14 a square foot per year, the developers said.
The largest store is likely to be on the site near the Gates Avenue subway stop. There the prospects are for a chain clothing store or drug store with discount merchandise, said Jeffrey Stern, a development partner.
Assisting the developers in their relations with community residents and officials is the Ocean Hill-Bushwick-Bedford Stuyvesant Local Development Corporation, which prefers to use the acronym Obusty. It is dedicated to commercial revitalization on the entire mile-and-three-quarter length of Broadway from Myrtle Avenue on the west to the Eastern Parkway Extension on the east.
"We need apparel stores, stationers, a sporting goods store, an electronics store, florists," said Charles Sterling, the executive director. "We need family-style restaurants and more professional services. We don't have a bakery. We need that, too."
BUSHWICK once had two movie houses, an R.K.O. and a Loews. Both closed and nothing replaced them. A year ago, Marlowe's, which carried clothing for men, women and children, closed when the proprietor finally retired, Mr. Sterling said.
But new proprietors are always coming along. Many are Korean.
Michael Kim, a heater manufacturer who arrived from Seoul in 1976 and now operates the C.T.K. fish stores and Key Point toy stores in Bushwick, was encountered a few days ago as he supervised renovations at a vacant store at 1571 Broadway, at the corner of Halsey Street.
"It could become a pizzeria or a laundromat or an ice cream parlor," said Mr. Kim's son-in-law, Myung-Soo Lee, 35, who teaches marketing at Baruch College of the City University.
And at the corner of Broadway and Stuyvesant Avenue, Bang Keun Lee, 72, proudly took a visitor on a tour of the handsomely renovated interior of the long-closed limestone-and-marble edifice that was built for the Prudential Savings Bank in 1905. The Lee family bought it from a private owner three years ago and has been at work on a gut renovation with family members for 10 months.
The building will reopen in April as Brooklyn Steps, a dancing and martial arts school, said Mr. Lee's son, Suk Chan Lee, 40, who will run it. Another son, Yeon Chan Lee, an engineer, is in charge of construction.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
Spate of Building Applications Heartens Greenburgh

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
SO far this year, the Town of Greenburgh in central Westchester County has had a spate of new-building applications, leading town officials to speculate on a possible economic turnaround.
"Every week, somebody's coming in with plans for a new development," said Paul Feiner, the Town Supervisor. "A lot of them are for little projects, but we're moving in the right direction." 
 Like most communities in the county, Greenburgh had been experiencing a steady erosion of building applications since the peak years of the mid-80's, when they averaged 40 a year in the town's unincorporated area alone, according to Stephen Lopez, the Town Planning Commissioner. Most of the commercial development is in the unincorporated area, which is about a third of the 31-acre town.
Applications to the town, which has jurisdiction over building permits only outside its six villages, hit bottom in 1992, with only 15 requests, Mr. Lopez said. "Then we saw our first significant pick-up last year when we reached 20," he said. And this year looks even better.
"We have 9 applications and I expect 10 by the end of this month," Mr. Lopez said last Wednesday. "That's half of what we had in all of last year."
The applications filed this year are for such diverse projects as a small two-lot residential subdivision, a 3,000 square-foot Boston Chicken franchise and an 80,000 square-foot Federal Express distribution warehouse.
Several of the projects filed last year have been approved or are in the later review stages, Mr. Lopez said. One of the largest is the Town Green, a 105-unit rental apartment complex approved for construction on Taxter Road, near the Saw Mill River Parkway.
"It's the first rental project we've had in the town in 33 years," Mr. Feiner said. "And one of the largest residental projects to be built in the two years I've been in office."
Two weeks ago site clearing began on the project, which, when completed, will consist of 12 buildings with 8 units each and one with 9 units. In addition, there will be a clubhouse and leasing office that will face a swimming pool.
The buildings, which will be on 16.9 acres, will be "New England clapboard style," according to Samuel B. Fuller, a vice president of Avalon Properties of New Canaan, Conn., the developer. One- and two-bedroom apartments, all with balconies, will rent for $1,000 to $1,600 a month, Mr. Fuller said. Construction is expected to be completed in 12 months.
Other projects on which construction is expected to begin this year include Ardsley Estates, a 34-unit one-family development to be built just south of the Village of Ardsley; a 160-bed nursing home on Grasslands Road at Stephens Lane and a 40,000-square-foot shopping center on Central Avenue, just south of the Midway Shopping Center.
Many town residents were surprised and upset, Mr. Feiner said, when two two-screen movie theaters on Central Avenue in the hamlet of Hartsdale closed in January. Joanne Parker, a spokeswoman for General Cinema Theaters, a Boston company that managed the theaters, said they had been closed because such small theaters were no longer economically viable.
BUT Mr. Feiner said he had been approached by two movie theater owners who wanted to build multiscreen theaters in the town.
"One of them wants to build a 10-screen theater," Mr. Feiner said. "And another already owns a 2-screen theater and wants to expand it to a 5-screen complex."
One of the reasons Greenburgh has been successful in attracting such business is "because word has gotten out that we have an open climate to the right kind of development," Mr. Lopez said.
"We're willing to work with developers and community groups to create solutions rather than dissension," he explained, adding that the town was "well-positioned in the county."
"We're not overbuilt like some of the more southern parts," he said. "And we're not really rural like the north county. We're accessible to several major population centers, including New York City."
One indication of the lengths the town is willing to go in order to encourage development can be seen in its current negotiations with Ciba Corporation, the Swiss chemical company, which is considering relocating from its 400,000-square-foot American headquarters on a 60-acre campus near Ardsley to one of four sites in Westchester. It is also considering Connecticut.
In an effort to keep the company in Greenburgh, the town has spent the last year working on a deal that would involve Ciba's moving to 400,000 square feet recently vacated by I.B.M. at the Tarrytown Corporate Center, on Route 119 outside the Village of Tarrytown. As part of the proposal, Halpern Enterprises, a Tarrytown developer, would buy Ciba's 12-building Ardsley campus, which would be used for a commercial and residential development, possibly involving 250 units of housing that would include congregate-care homes for the elderly.
Halpern, in turn, would be given the contract to build a 165,000-square-foot laboratory at the site outside Tarrytown. To achieve all this, the sites near Tarrytown and Ardsley would have to be rezoned and Route 9A, which runs outside the current Ciba property, would have to be upgraded.
The town is continuing to work with state and county officals to put the deal together, and Halpern Enterprises has already filed a rezoning application for the Tarrytown Corporate Park.
ERIC JACKSON, a spokesman for Ciba, acknowledged that his company was negotiating with Halpern, but said that it was too soon to say whether there was a deal. "We've been delighted with the town's help and assistance," Mr. Jackson said. "But there are still a number of issues to be worked out."
Mr. Feiner said it was "98 percent certain that Ciba will remain in Greenburgh," adding that "we're very close to making a deal with them."
In November, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo offered Ciba $13.25 million in low-cost loans, grants, tax abatements and other incentives, including $5 million in utility savings from the New York State Power Authority if it stays in Westchester. Ciba is now a Consolidated Edison customer.
But even if the Ciba deal does go through, and the town continues its present rate of attracting building interest, Mr. Lopez does not expect a return to the boom years anytime soon.
"Historically, when there's a pick-up in building applications, there is usually a lag of several years before we see an actual recovery," he said. "Times have changed. We have such an overbuilt office market now. And even though residential sales have been good, there's still a backlog of homes.
"Until we've absorbed most of that, it won't return to a builder's market. But hopefully, for the next few years, we'll continue to see incremental improvement."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Greenburgh officials, from left: Frederick Turner, attorney; Supervisor Paul Feiner, Stephen Lopez, planner. (Lenore L. Davis for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New York Apartment Rents Moving Up

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
BUOYED by a tightening of the market and an improvement in the regional economy, unregulated rents in Manhattan moved upward in 1993, reversing the previous year's downturn, real-estate agents and analysts said.
The increase, many of them said, was especially notable on the Upper West Side, where rental space is at a premium and which is rapidly becoming a magnet neighborhood for those interested in just that -- a neighborhood, and all that the word means. Agents said that Greenwich Village, SoHo and TriBeCa were also booming. 
 Regionally, however, Federal cost-of-living statistics showed the smallest rent rise in a quarter-century for New York, northeastern New Jersey and southern Connecticut. But Brooklyn and Queens showed larger increases in one survey. And in one trendy location, Hoboken, agents said that a tight market had driven rents considerably higher than they were a few years ago, though prices had recently begun to level off.
"Manhattan has changed from a tenants' market to a landlords' market," said Alan Rogers, managing director of Douglas Elliman, a major New York brokerage. "It started at the end of 1992 going into the first six months of 1993, and it happened surprisingly quickly. From an oversupply it became not a shortage but a much more limited supply."
THE change has not created an extreme situation, such as in the mid-80's when prospective tenants would read obituary notices to find vacant apartments and would have to pay money under the table to get a place to live.
But until last year, unregulated rents in New York had dropped about 15 percent since the real-estate recession began in 1988, about half as much as the sale prices of co-ops and condominiums in the same period. And the ball is now in the landlord's court.
"Landlords have stopped giving concessions," Mr. Rogers said. "It hasn't gone all the way over, but it has tipped in the landlord's favor. A market where landlords paid the broker's fee has become one in which tenants do so."
Mr. Rogers said that rents had gone up from 5 percent to 7 percent or more, depending on the location. Inventory has dropped, he said, because many of the apartments on the market have already been rented. Except for some condominium rentals, he said, there was basically no new product, and the improvement in the sales value of co-ops meant that fewer of those apartments were coming on the rental market as sublets. Mr. Rogers said that a smaller factor was the tightening of sublet rules in co-ops.
At the Windsor Court, a 700-unit building at 155 East 31st Street, a one-bedroom unit that rented for $1,525 a month in 1992 brought $1,650 in 1993, an 8 percent rise, Mr. Rogers said. A two-bedroom unit in the building went up from $2,595 in 1992 to $2,730 in 1993, a 5.2 percent increase.
At the Normandie Court at 225 East 95th Street, rents were $1,395 for a one-bedroom in 1992 and $1,465 in 1993, up 4.95 percent. For a two-bedroom, they were $1,840 in 1992 and $1,935 in 1993.
On the West Side, at 30 Lincoln Plaza, a large building near Lincoln Center, a one-bedroom rose from $1,525 in 1992 to $1,675 in 1993, more than 9 percent, and a two-bedroom went up from $2,360 to $2,560.
"What's interesting is that the '93 levels are almost back at the '88 levels," Mr. Rogers said.
Changes in the rent market have little effect on residents of the city's estimated 1.3 million rent-stabilized or -controlled apartments, which make up about 70 percent of the 1.9 million apartments in the city. Unregulated apartments include those in buildings with fewer than six units and those built since 1973 without tax abatements.
The Feathered Nest, a major New York rental agency, said in its annual report, which is based on a survey of 8,959 apartments -- both regulated and market-rate -- that apartment rents in the borough had increased by an average of 5.6 percent in 1993. East Side rents went up 5.9 percent and those on the West Side rose a whopping 10.6 percent, the survey said. A year ago, the Feathered Nest survey reported that rents in 1992 either declined or stayed the same for all types of apartments.
Rents for studio apartments, the report said, increased by 5.6 percent, one-bedrooms 6.7 percent, two-bedrooms 4.1 percent and three-bedrooms 3.6 percent. The average rent of a one-bedroom was $1,550 in 1993, and $1,475 in both 1992 and 1991. A two-bedroom in 1993 was $2,350 a month, compared with $2,275 in 1992 and the same $2,350 in 1991. For a three-bedroom, it was $3,800 in 1993, $3,600 in 1992 and $3,650 in 1991. A studio was $1,025 last year, $950 in 1992 and 1993, $3,600 in 1992 and $3,650 in 1991. A studio was $1,025 in 1991. A studio was $1,025 last year, $950 in 1992 and $1,025 in 1991.
Nancy Packes, president of the Feathered Nest, said that one reason for the rent increases was a more than 40 percent decline in the number of available apartments between 1990 and 1993: 17,498 listings in 1990, versus the 8,959 last year.
ANOTHER index of the market is the number of showings that a prospective tenant goes on and the number of apartments the tenant sees now as against 1992, Ms. Packes said.
"These days, when people rent through us we show them an average of five apartments over two showings," Ms. Packes said. "In 1992, it was 15 apartments and five showings."
Among the reasons for the turnaround, she said, are the fact that there has been very little new construction since 1988, "and that, combined with a low-interest rate environment, has helped the co-op sale market to improve and take the supply out of the rental market."
In addition, she said, corporations are beginning again to relocate employees in New York. "Three out of five of our customers are corporate relocations," she said.
The resurgence of the West Side, she said, is attributable in part to the fact that the West Side is much smaller than the East Side and has fewer apartments available -- only about one-third the number on the East Side.
"But a key reason," she said, "is that people are seeking a more neighborhood-like environment, which the West Side represents and which the East Side doesn't have. The East Side is not a neighborhood."
Clark Halstead, managing partner of the Halstead Property Company, also said that the Upper West Side had seen the largest and most consistent rent increases. "There's a perception that people like the West Side," Mr. Halstead said. "They say it's more fun, more vibrant, that it has more texture. It's not as homogeneous as the East Side. Access to parks generally is better. And people feel that transportation, with its two major subway lines, is also better."
In addition, he said, the West Side is relatively small, "while the East Side just goes on and on forever."
Mr. Halstead and Brian Edwards, the head of his rental division, said that also because of the desirability of neighborhood feeling, and because of their proximity to a re-emergent Wall Street, Greenwich Village, SoHo and TriBeCa were also hot properties.
"We don't have statistics to back this up yet, but the downtown rental market has been extremely strong," Mr. Edwards said, "specifically in SoHo and TriBeCa. The prices we see lofts being rented for are really quite impressive." And the renters, he said, "are the young Wall Street people who are making those large salaries and high bonuses."
Ms. Packes said Greenwich Village "is as hot as it could possibly be." Mr. Halstead and Mr. Edwards said that the largest increases they had seen in the last six months were in the rents for units at the upper end of the market.
"The larger units, from 4 1/2 to 7 rooms, have seen increases anywhere from 7 to 15 percent," Mr. Edwards said.
Their survey of 800 apartments on the West Side, for example, showed that two-bedroom apartments with a dining room or a convertible third bedroom in a prewar doorman building now rented for from $2,900 to $3,400 a month, compared with from $2,600 to $3,000 last August. In a postwar doorman building, the figures are $2,600 to $3,100 now, against $2,400 to $2,900 in August.
One-bedroom apartments in prewar doorman buildings on the West Side that were $1,400 to $2,000 last August are now $1,550 to $2,100.
ON the East Side, based on a sampling of 1,000 apartments, their survey found that standard prewar two-bedroom apartments in doorman buildings were $2,300 to $3,000 last August and had gone up to from $2,500 to $3,300. Two-bedrooms in postwar doorman buildings that were $2,200 to $2,500 last summer are now $2,300 to $2,700.
On the lower end of the market, though, Mr. Edwards said, "the increases are more gentle, not as dramatic." And some East Side figures had even fallen: The top studio price in a modern high-rise had slipped from $1,600 to $1,525 in the same period. Similarly, the top rent for a modern high-rise one-bedroom on the East Side was down from $2,100 to $1,900.
But Mr. Halstead said that in general, rents on the very smallest apartments were also moving up. "The number of small units in Manhattan far exceeds the number of large ones," he said, "but so does the demand."
Entry-level employees are coming into New York in larger numbers, he said, taking new jobs and "soaking up the apartments," a big change from the situation three years ago in which people were losing jobs and moving out of Manhattan.
Statistics are tricky things, of course, and often depend on what's being counted; another survey, while agreeing with the general direction of rents, reported different findings for the Upper West Side.
A survey of 900 rental units by the National Cooperative Bank showed that the average rent per room in the New York area -- which in the report includes Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and Westchester -- had increased 8.2 percent in 1993, a sharp change from the 6.3 percent decrease the report had shown in 1992.
"The rental market, after the softening in 1992, appears to have stabilized once again," said Grace A. Huebscher, the bank's corporate vice president.
The report saw an increase of 14.6 percent in Lower Manhattan, after a 14.8 percent drop in 1992; 14.5 percent in midtown, after a 9 percent rise in 1992, and 2.8 percent on the Upper East Side, after a 2.7 percent decrease the previous year. But contrary to the other surveys, it said that rents per room on the Upper West Side had decreased 5.5 percent in 1993, compounding a 4.2 percent drop in '92.
"But our report is based on transactions we were doing in the marketplace that year, and the decrease could have been due to our concentrating on a part of the Upper West Side that was weaker," Ms. Huebscher said.
The Cooperative Bank also found in its survey that rents involving its transactions in Brooklyn and Queens had gone up by 8.9 percent last year, after rising 7.5 percent in 1992.
In northeast Queens, Steven Meyer, an owner-broker at Bay-Benjamin Real Estate in Bay Terrace, said that rents have "basically been stable."
"I wouldn't say they've gone down," Mr. Meyer said. "I would say they've been stable and consistent."
But Mr. Meyer, whose area includes Bayside, Bay Terrace, Douglaston, Little Neck, Flushing and Auburndale, said that in luxury buildings, rents in top-of-the-line apartments have in some cases gone up.
CONCERNS about the economy have made some people skeptical about buying, he said, and "sometimes in a luxury building we find we have people waiting in line to get a specific type of apartment."
Available rentals, he said, include condominium and some co-op units, rent-stabilized buildings and apartments in two-family houses. A one-bedroom apartment in a two-family house "could be as low as $650 and as high as $800," he said, while a three-bedroom, two-bath duplex in a two-family would be about $1,200 a month.
At the Bay Club, a 1,037-unit, two-building luxury condominium off 23d Avenue and Corporal Kennedy Boulevard in Bayside, rents have gone up from 5 to 10 percent in the last year, Mr. Meyer said. A two-bedroom apartment at the Bay Club, which has an indoor health club, indoor pool, racquetball courts and gym, goes for from $1,600 to as much as $2,300 or $2,400, he said.
"A lot depends on the demand at a particular time," Mr. Meyer said. "If the inventory is low, prices will go up for that month. But if three or four apartments come on the market at the same time and compete against each other, prices could be a little bit lower."
Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, said that 1993 had seen the smallest increase in rents in a little more than a quarter century on the Consumer Price Index for New York, northeastern New Jersey and southern Connecticut.
The increase, 2.1 percent, was the smallest since 1966, Mr. Ehrenhalt said, adding that in the late 1980's it had been as high as 7 percent.
"It reflects both a weakness in the New York region's economy and a weakness in the rental market," he said. "There is a great deal of resistance to rent increases." He added that he could not provide statistics broken down for specific parts of the region.
The increase, he said, had been 3.4 percent in 1992, 2.8 percent in 1991, 4.1 percent in 1990 and 7 percent in 1989.
In popular sections of the region, however, such as Hoboken, with its proximity to Manhattan, its gentrification, its PATH trains and the Hoboken Ferry to the World Financial Center and Wall Street, rents have gone up.
"There's a housing shortage, pure and simple, and people want to live in Hoboken," said Deno Bogdanos, a broker with Corporate Realty in Hoboken. "People equate Hoboken in desirability with Battery Park City and Brooklyn Heights and Fort Lee. If I have a halfway decent apartment, it's rented in about two days."
Mr. Bogdanos said one-bedroom apartments were renting for from $900 to $1,200 and two-bedrooms for from $1,300 to $1,700, compared with $700 to $900 for a one-bedroom and $1,000 to $1,300 for a two-bedroom three or four years ago.
"There are always apartments that come in a little bit lower," he said, "but about 85 percent of the apartments rent in that price range."
The apartment situation, he said, was in sharp contrast to the sales market, which had "dipped 15 to 20 percent" in price and about 50 percent in volume in recent years.
PEOPLE who were still making good salaries but were holding off buying in an uncertain market were willing to pay "top dollar" for the rental they wanted, he said.
He added, however, that rents had begun to level off about six months ago, because the prices were "all the market will bear."
A major reason for the apartment shortage, he said, was a sewer moratorium that New Jersey placed on Hoboken a few years ago. The moratorium provided that sewage quantity could not be increased on any given parcel of property and essentially prevented the building of any new housing. The moratorium, he said, was lifted a few weeks ago, "but it's too soon to say if there will be any new construction -- though I'm sure there will be."
Stephen Misyak, a sales agent with Wide World Realty in Hoboken, said he thought the lifting of the moratorium would lead to "a little more development."
Rents, Mr. Misyak said, were currently about $650 to $700 for "a shabby one-bedroom or studio, going as high as $1,400." Two-bedroom apartments, he said, began at $900 and went up to about $2,200.
"You can find cheaper apartments on the west side of town," he said, "which is considered not as desirable, scenic or aesthetically pleasing as the east side." In addition, he said, "rents increase as the proximity to the PATH station increases; people love to be able to hop off the train from Manhattan and walk four or five blocks to their home."
A two-bedroom apartment with hardwood floors, an eat-in kitchen, central heating, air-conditioning and an alarm system that goes for $1,450 on the east side of town might be had for as low as $950 on the west side, he said.
Mr. Bogdanos said he thought rents in Hoboken would continue to level off because as the economy improved people were coming back into the market to purchase homes. "The traditional sales market is returning," he said.
But in Manhattan, Mr. Rogers of Douglas Elliman said he thought the 1993 trend of rent rises would continue throughout 1994, taking the market to where it was before the post-1988 dip.
"I see prices going up 5 to 10 percent this year, to the level rents were in 1988, or just above," he said. "Things are going to stay tipped in the landlord's favor."
