HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Beethoven: Quartets and Symphonies

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHERMAN 

 BODY:
WORKS by Beethoven are in abundance this week starting at 8 P.M. on Tuesday when the Tokyo Quartet advances its complete string quartet cycle with the fifth of six scheduled recitals at Sprague Memorial Hall in New Haven. On tap this time: Opus 127, and the First Razoumovsky, Opus 59, No. 1.
Three days later and down the street at Woolsey Hall, the Philharmonia Orchestra of Yale welcomes two other university ensembles, the Glee Club and the Camerata, for an 8 P.M. Friday performance of the Ninth Symphony. Tiffany Jackson, Jane Dutton, Matthew Polenzani and Bruce Baumer are the vocal soloists, with Gunther Herbig, music director of the Toronto Symphony, on the podium. The number for reservations for these Yale events is 432-4158. 
 Beethoven's Eighth opens the 8 P.M. Saturday concert of the Farmington Valley Symphony at First Church of Christ Congregational, although the the group's conductor, John Eells, heads on from there to three works of our own century and country, Aaron Copland's "Ceremonial Fanfare" and "Billy the Kid" plus, with Ron Krentzman as clarinet soloist, the "Dance Concerto" by the Hartt faculty composer Stephen Gryc (677-1321 or 651-9962). And Beethoven's C Major Piano Quartet will be on the program, along with chamber music of Brahms, Mozart and Mahler, when Musicians from Marlboro play at 8 P.M. Saturday in the Stamford Jewish Center (322-7900).
The Berlin Chamber Orchestra has included Jorgensen Auditorium in Storrs on its American tour list, its 8 P.M. Wednesday program ranging from Five Pieces for Strings by Corelli and Bach's "Art of Fugue" to a pair of 20th-century Russian masterworks, Stravinsky's "Apollon Musagete" and Shostakovich's Chamber Symphony in C Minor (486-4226).
The Waterbury Symphony, continuing its music director search, welcomes Philip Greenberg to the podium for its 8:15 P.M. concert on Saturday at the Fine Arts Center. The young maestro, currently music director of the Savannah Symphony, has chosen to start the program with a novelty, the Festival Overture by the Hartford native Dudley Buck. The composition is based on "The Star Spangled Banner" (which, in 1877, was years away from becoming the National Anthem). Thereafter, the program contains more standard repertory: Paganini's Violin Concerto No. 1, with 15-year-old Elizabeth Zeltser the guest soloist, and Mendelssohn's Symphony No. 5 (574-4283).
At 8:30 P.M. Saturday, an all-American evening begins at Klein Memorial Auditorium, with the guest conductor Dorian Wilson leading the Greater Bridgeport Symphony in Copland's "Appalachian Spring" and Gershwin's "American in Paris," while the Connecticut-based Elite Syncopation, a quintet named for one of Scott Joplin's most famous rags and devoted to performances of vintage American popular music, contributes additional splashes of ragtime and early jazz favorites by Joplin, Jelly Roll Morton and Duke Ellington, among others (576-0263).
For 20 years, the South Congregational Choir, under its music director Richard Donohue, has developed intriguing programs of music for Lent and Easter, not only for presentation at its home church in Hartford, but for interested audiences in other communities. More than just choral concerts, these events also involve poetry readings, songs, instrumental pieces and even a certain amount of audience participation. The works this year are typically far-ranging in stylistic content, from a Psalm by Orlando di Lasso to the Kyrie and Sanctus sections of Vaughan Williams's Mass in G Minor to a Bach sarabande for solo cello. The program will be given on three successive Sunday afternoons at 4: next week in Second Congregational Church of Manchester (649-2863), on March 13 at St. Francis of Assisi in Torrington (482-5571) and in Hartford on March 20 (249-8627).
A very different sort of vocal attraction will be on the boards at 3 and 7 P.M. next Sunday at the Garde Arts Center in New London. It's a touring production of the multiple award-winning musical that kept Broadway audiences applauding for more than six years, Joe Darion and Mitch Leigh's "Man of La Mancha" (444-7373).
"Recession and all, we're back for our fourth season of Chamber Music Brunch at Zenny's," the cellist who founded and directs the Sunday recitals at the restaurant in Storrs, Warren Lash, said, "the beauty and intimacy of the room, the gourmet food, and incomparable music played by internationally renowned artists create an ambiance rarely matched at chamber music events." The edibles will be served next Sunday morning at 11:30, followed by music for the soul via the string quintets of Mozart and Brahms, played by Mr. Lash with the violinists Theodore Arm and Ida Kavafian, and the violists Steven Ansell and Steven Tenenbom (429-7510).
The Wilton Candlelight Series, with 45 years of presentations under its belt, concludes its season at 4 next Sunday afternoon, with the Emerson String Quartet doing the musical honors in the Congregational Church with Haydn, Schubert, Webern and Shostakovich (762-9353).
And while in a few months, it'll be time to talk about the 12th annual Connecticut Early Music Festival, next Sunday also closes the circle on the Festival's first winter cycle, the "Soirees Musicales" at Lyman Allyn Art Museum in New London. The Tomasini Quartet -- the violinists Carol Lieberman and Julie Levin, the violist Barbara Wright and the cellist Myron Lutzke will appear at the final 4:30 and 7:30 P.M. recitals. The players will use period instruments to perform more Haydn and Schubert, plus a quartet by their namesake Italian composer (444-2419).

HEADLINE: Secession Is the Talk of Rowayton

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
A VISITOR to Rowayton could understandably think of it as a picturesque coastal New England town. It has, after all, a post office, a fire station, a cemetery, a school, a library, banks, churches, restaurants, a variety of stores, its own beaches, even a Civil War cannon. Not to mention a scenic waterfront, complete with marina, boatyards and a ship chandlery.
Indeed, most of its residents perceive Rowayton as a separate community, a place with a special cachet and charm about it. "There's always been a certain distintiveness about Rowayton; it's a special place," said Burton Shatz, a longtime resident and president of the Rowayton Civic Association. 
 Distinctive, yes, and most of its inhabitants, asked where they live, are bound to say "Rowayton." This is, however, hardly a separate entity. Rowayton, in fact, is a village within the City of Norwalk. As some longtime residents like to point out, a writer once dubbed it "the Athens of South Norwalk."
But now a group of Rowaytonites, angered over a recent city revaluation which they contend will disproportionately raise their property taxes starting July 1, is trying to establish a permanent identity by seceding from Norwalk. The idea is to either become an independent municipality or affiliate with Darien on the west bank of the Five Mile River.
"Everyone I've talked to is in favor of secession," said Edward F. Ryle Jr., the leader of the secessionist movement.
About 40 miles to the east, an even larger group has been actively working towards secession from New Haven. The group, formally known as the East Shore Secession Organization, includes residents of the Fair Haven, Morris Cove and Annex sections along New Haven's shoreline. As in Rowayton, taxes have been the main impetus in a secessionist movement which began more than a year ago.
In both cases, secession is an extreme longshot, according to state legislators and other officials -- and even some of the secessionist proponents.
"There's no mechanism in the State Constitution or in any state statutes that would permit secession," said State Representative Reginald Jones of Darien, a Republican who also represents Rowayton. "So the state legislature would have to enact legislation permitting groups to appeal to the state to secede. And given the temper of the times -- when regionalism is becoming increasigly popular -- I don't think the legislature is going to allow secession." If Rowayton does pursue that route, however, "it would be easier to affiliate with Darien then set up their own town," he added.
But despite a long and close link between Rowayton and Darien -- indeed, it has been said that many Rowaytonites feel more closely attuned to Darien than to Norwalk -- Darien does not seem prepared to roll out the red carpet for the would-be secessionists.
"There's a good bond beween Darien and Rowayton, but I truly believe there would not be a favorable response from the town to any proposed affiliation with Rowayton," said Henry Sanders, the Darien First Selectman. "Our schools are already overflowing and it would be hard to add additional services. So it would be a very hard sell."
It would also, no doubt, be a very hard sell to the rest of the city of Norwalk, which would stand to lose a huge amount of tax money from one of its most affluent sections. "First, there probably would have to be a referendum on the issue in Rowayton and then one for the entire city," Donald F. Reid, the Norwalk Corporation Counsel, said. "Then, assuming passage, there would have to be a special act of the legislature for the secession appeal."
State Senator Robert Genuario of Norwalk, who represents all of Norwalk and two-thirds of Darien, said he thought the secession movement has "no chance."
"Secession of affluent areas like Rowayton would further isolate poor sections of cities and aggravate the existing problem wherein cities pay higher property taxes than suburbs," Mr. Genuario, a Republican, said. "The secession movement doesn't go to the root of the problem, which is the overall property tax structure in the state, which has to be examined."
Another Norwalk legislator, Councilman Rollo J. Giannini, a Republican whose district includes Rowayton, described the secession movement as "a little bit extreme." "I can understand their frustrations over the reassessment," he explained. "Something went wrong there on the taxes. I can't see property values going up so high during a recession."
Mr. Ryle, a salesman for Ring's End Lumber Inc. in Darien as well as leader of the Rowayton secession move, said he thought that assessments in Rowayton would double, compared with far lesser increases in most of the city once the new mill rate is set, probably next month.
"It's extremely unfair," he said. "We're sending the City of Norwalk about $7 million a year in taxes and getting back beween $3 and $4 million in services. And I'm willing to bet that if we look at the Grand List, Rowayton alone would compare with about a quarter of the towns in Connecticut. Yet we don't have any representation from Rowayton in the City Council. The city just doesn't take us seriously."
Mr. Ryle and Mr. Shatz have been around long enough to remember when Rowayton had perhaps as many summer residents as it did year-round people. Many of its homes are former summer cottages which from the 1930's to the 1950's attracted such celebrities as the actresses Madeline Carroll and Betsy Palmer, as well as Don Wilson, the announcer on the Jack Benny radio and television programs, and writers including A.C. Spectorsky, the author of "The Exurbanites."
Year-round residents have included the late actor Horace McMahon, a native of Norwalk, and Andy Rooney, the writer and television personality, who has lived in Rowayton for four decades.
 
The Arrival of Commerce
 At the end of World War II, Rowayton had a year-round population of about 2,500. But by the 1980's, that population had doubled, and it remains at about 5,000. Commercial development also increased as a number of office buildings were constructed on the river side of Rowayton Avenue, the business heart of the community.
"Most people in Rowayton were against that development, and we said so, but the city ignored us," Mr. Ryle said. "We've had virtually no self-determination."
Besides its own identity, Rowayton, also has its own budget. Usually about a half-million dollars is raised annually through taxes to maintain the fire station, which is staffed by unpaid volunteers, and pay for library and beach expenses, street lighting and some other services. "Rowayton's always been slightly different, although there's no doubt that a lot of the people feel that they're a part of Norwalk," Mr. Shatz, an architect, said. "But it's changed a bit, and the average age of homeowners nowadays is younger. There are also more houses valued at more than a million dollars than there used to be."
No one seems able to recall when a section of a town or city was able to secede in Connecticut. The last time part of one town became a separate entity was in 1921 when the eastern part of Orange became the town of West Haven. "But that appears to have been mutually agreed upon,' said Peter Bartucca, the manager of Records and Legislative Services for the Secretary of the State's Office in Hartford. "And, prior to that, the last time it happened was when Ansonia split from Derby in 1889. But apparently there was no animosity in either case."
About 20 years ago, a group in Georgetown, a village that takes in parts of Ridgefield, Wilton, Redding and Weston, tried to establish a separate municipality, but was rebuffed in the General Assembly.
"We got George Guidera, who was then a state representative and is now the First Selectman of Weston, to introduce a bill in the Legislature that would have set up an enabling act allowing us to secede," Jerry Edwards, who lives in the Georgetown section of Wilton and who led the drive, recalled. "But all the powers-that-be in the four towns got together and applied pressure, and the bill died in committee."
Now, as then, Georgetown, like Rowayton, has most of the amenities of a town -- post office, fire station, school and so on, as do a number of other villages in the state such as Southport, an affluent coastal enclave in Fairfield.
"Many years ago, when a new town was formed in the State, it often was because of a church," Robert Nye, the Town Clerk of Waterford, and a historian, said. "For example, Waterford was a part of New London until 1801 when it decided to go on its own. That was mainly because most of the residents of Waterford were Baptists and they had a Baptist church in the area where they lived. By contrast, in New London almost everyone was affiliated with the Congregational Church. But even back then, taxes were a factor, and the people in Waterford, being a considerable distance from the heart of New London, felt they weren't getting their tax money's worth. For instance, if there was a fire in Waterford, there was no way the New London Fire Department could get out there in time to put it out."
 
Three Tries for Secession
But even at that, it took three attempts -- in 1795, 1797 and 1801 -- before secession was accomplished, Mr. Nye pointed out. Then, he added, in 1836 sections of Lyme and Waterford in effect seceded and merged to form the town of East Lyme.
But secession supporters in Rowayton and New Haven face an even more difficult battle. "Coming out for secession is a great vehicle for venting frustrations," said Matthew Naclerio, a Democratic alderman whose constituency includes some of the secessionst supporters on New Haven's east shore. "People see their taxes go up and services decrease, and they think that leaving the city may be the answer. But it flies in the face of regionalism, which is the trend throughout the country. So I think the secessionists are going in the wrong direction."
But despite all of the obstacles, the Rowayton group seems undaunted. "We've had enough, and we think secession is feasible," Mr. Ryle said. "We're not planning on giving up."

HEADLINE: A SENSE OF PLACE

BYLINE: By Glenn Collins 

 BODY:
MEMO TO: Hollywood
FROM: New Jersey 
 Congratulations!
Your brilliantly conceived strategy to prevent New Jersey residents from seeing the finest new films in the state's movie theaters has never been more successful!
Because of your calculated distribution decisions, in the last few months, more movie-starved New Jersey residents have been unable to see more desperately sought-after new movies than ever before.
Time to take a bow, Hollywood! It can't have been easy to deny so many movies to so many people.
Oh yes: You know the names of the movies. You kept them away from us for weeks after their opening, limiting their distribution in New Jersey while more supposedly "sophisticated, prestigious" audiences could see them across the country: "Schindler's List," "In the Name of the Father," "Philadelphia," "Short Cuts," "Six Degrees of Separation,' "Farewell My Concubine" and "The Snapper," to name just a few. O.K., not all of these films were made in Tinseltown. But since your distributors control so much movie booking these days, you can understand why we blame you, Hollywood!
To be sure, your deep-thinking marketing plan to keep Garden Staters out of their movie theaters seems really strange. After all, as anyone who lives in New Jersey knows very well, there are clusters of highly discerning filmgoers all over the state. We watch "Entertainment Tonight" and "At the Movies" and subscribe to Premiere. We follow Siskel and Ebert as it moves from channel to channel to channel.
In fact, Hollywood, thanks to your considerable marketing efforts, most New Jersey folk are bombarded by all of the media that assault the citizens of New York City and Philadelphia with dozens of newspaper, television and radio reviews of the latest movies -- as well as ads, commercials and feature stories about these films' stars and directors.
As a result, we talk to our friends about forthcoming films over dinner, and debate their watchability with colleagues at the water cooler. Indeed, this is exactly what your marketing strategists intended, Hollywood: New Jersey moviegoers are primed to see the best new films. We have a large amount of disposable income that we put aside for moviegoing, and we're eager to spend it.
And then what happens? Someone asks the inevitable question about the hot new movie: "Have you seen it?" Which is followed by the unavoidable New Jersey response: "It's not playing anywhere near me." Or: "Yes, I drove 50 miles to see it at a theater on the highway." Or: "Yes. I saw it in New York."
Hollywood, we want to see the hot movies now, not next spring. But what's playing in the plexes? "Terminator IX," "Splash and Splatter VII," "The Obnoxious Undead II," "Rap 2 Kill," "Fatal Screenplay" and "The Happy Hobbit Family." In short, a glut of mass-market films that can be seen in any multiplex in any mall in the country. But we couldn't even go to "Schindler's List" when we really wanted to see it. It's a rarity to have quick access to the quality films that reviewers have labelled "every intelligent person's must-see."
We admit it. We thought: shame on you, Hollywood. You know that there are highly sophisticated audiences in the state for quality new films. You have seen the lines going around the block for the increasing number of sneak previews you've been holding throughout New Jersey to boost new releases. You know that specialized films, like "The Piano," "The Remains of the Day" and "Shadowlands" can do wonderfully well in the right theaters in New Jersey.
So what's the excuse for keeping these winners from us for weeks or even months? "Platforming" -- that's the movie-industry response. It's a delayed distribution plan, Hollywood's version of the time-release capsule. The idea is that some films need time to reach a level of high public awareness. This strategy was used in marketing "The Crying Game" to good effect.
But we've wondered: why not more platform locations in New Jersey? We're not sophisticated or prestigious enough? And furthermore, why is it necessary to delay and delay the release of so many films that we're so desperate to see? Not just the Yugoslavian clog-dancing movie, but also films with such wide appeal as "Schindler's List" and "In the Name of the Father" (breathes there a woman in the state who did not want to see Daniel Day-Lewis in this role after the initial reviews appeared)?
The whole point of marketing is to build anticipation to a fever pitch: then you sell folks the product at the peak of interest. But with new films, again and again, the frenzy of the initial attention is met with delay and missed opportunity.
Therefore, many films have been torpedoed by the time-delay strategy. After the thrill of Hollywood hype is over, and the impulse to see a hot new film has faded, and no one is talking about it at the office. So, all too many moviegoers say: "Wait until it comes out on cable." Or: "I'll wait for the videotape."
Thus, a ton of movie-theater tickets go unsold.
Oh, sure: distributors have pointed to the failure of some special-interest films, and some foreign films that didn't do well at all when they played in the Garden State. But how many of them failed because they came to New Jersey movie theaters weeks, or months, after all the reviews and the buzz?
And so: For the longest time, New Jersey was resentful. Residents thought: this film-rationing is a grave injustice, the basest kind of discrimination against the Garden State. And for the longest time we wondered: how could the film-bookers be so stupid? How could they so misjudge New Jersey residents' level of sophistication? How could they be so ignorant of the mass population shifts of the last decade that have seen so many art-house-loving families from New York City move to New Jersey suburbs?
Finally we realized, of course, that no one could be that stupid, even movie-industry decision makers. That the distributors were crazy like the proverbial fox. That in fact, the whole distribution pattern was intended: all part of a benign conspiracy.
We can surmise that in a back room on a back lot somewhere in Tinseltown, the great entertainment conglomerates of Hollywood must have banded together to make a courageous and generous gesture: they agreed to sacrifice a large portion of profits from moviegoers in the state of New Jersey. What selflessness! It was a magnanimous decision to (1) favor the cable and video industries of the Garden State, (2) support the economies of New York and Pennsylvania, and (3) further family togetherness.
As hard as this is to believe, it must be true. Can you think of any other far-fetched explanation that might account for such an absurd situation?
Consider: More and more New Jersey residents, unable to see the hot new movies, are giving up. They're renting video tapes, or dialing up pay-per-view. Thus, they're giving a vital boost to these important sectors of the New Jersey economy.
Consider: More and more New Jersey film-lovers, impatient with the endless wait for new films, are driving to New York City for their must-see movies (or traveling to Philadelphia, if they live in southern New Jersey). Thus they are giving a much-needed boost to the movie-theater economy in neighboring states.
Consider: More and more New Jersey movie buffs, unable to see the films they want amid the glut of shock thrillers and action movies, are staying home. Clearly this is strong evidence for Hollywood's selfless strategy to support family values and to promote the concept of spending quality time with one's children.
And now, as we anticipate next month's Oscar frenzy, we will also be telling ourselves that it's all in a good cause. Really.
Hollywood, we are in awe of your humanitarianism.
We are trying to feel more grateful.
P.S.: Oh. But have you seen . . .?

HEADLINE: Public Invited To Forum on Anti-Semitism

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON 

 BODY:
THE Westchester Psychoanalytic Society, which does not often open its educational meetings to the public, is making an exception next month.
On March 7 the society, a group of 60 psychiatrists, will join with the Psychiatric Society of Westchester in presenting "Anti-Semitism: A Historic, Theological and Psychodynamic Exploration." The free meeting will take place at 8:15 P.M. in the main auditorium of New York Hospital-Westchester Division in White Plains. 
 A panel consisting of Dr. Norman Weiss of Scarsdale, Dr. Harold P. Blum of Roslyn, L.I., and the Rev. Robert S. MacLennan, the former senior minister of the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale, will examine the phenomenon of anti-Semitism as it has evolved from pre-Christian times to the present. In addition, there will be an exhibition of historic anti-Semitic medals, postcards and other items from the collection of William Stern of Scarsdale.
Dr. Weiss, secretary of the Psychoanalytic Society, said he had the idea for the meeting soon after receiving his master's degree in Jewish studies last May from Columbia University. He said he would present a history of the perceptions and fantasies about Jews and show how these perceptions increasingly became dehumanized. For example, he said, a Jew was said to lose his "foetor Judaicus," or Jewish odor, immediately after converting to Christianity.
 
Medieval Perceptions
 "The medieval stories about a stench contributed to stories of the Jew as a demon," Dr. Weiss said. "It was not a leap to see a Jew as vermin, not human."
Dr. MacLennan, a specialist in early Christian anti-Jewish literature, will examine the sources of anti-Judaism and anti-Semitism in second-century writings and will also discuss, Dr. Weiss said, the tendency of some contemporary Christian scholars to "invent the Jews they write about."
Dr. MacLennan now lives in Princeton, where he serves as a consultant and works on independent projects.
In his talk, Dr. Blum will explore the psychodynamics of anti-Semitism, discussing the link between the Jews as "Christ-killer, anti-Christ and historic scapegoat" with an emphasis on the Medieval perception of the Jews as Devil. Dr. Weiss said Dr. Blum would also discuss "the significance of the Jew as a devalued, despised, all bad narcissistic object," which he said was the view that led to the Holocaust.
 
Defying Explanation
 Mr. Stern, who owns Multigon Industries in Mount Vernon, a manufacturer of diagnostic ultrasound equipment, said he met Dr. Weiss through their common interest in collecting ancient Jewish and Roman coins. He said some of the German and Austrian medals he will show at the meeting are engraved with caricatures of Jews wasting corn during years of famine or being hanged as villains. The medals, which date from the 17th century, are also inscribed with texts accusing Jews of evil deeds.
In addition to anti-Semitic postcards printed in France during the Dreyfus trial, the anti-Jewish tract of Martin Luther and other material, the exhibition will include "notgeld," or illegitimate money printed in Austria and Germany after World War I. Mr. Stern said the pictures on these bills depicted "virulently anti-Semitic" scenes.
Dr. Weiss said the meeting will deal with the history of anti-Semitism rather than trying to explain it. The subject "cannot be understood," he said.
"People have tried to understand it economically and sociologically," he added, "but it has gone on for centuries and continues to flourish today in countries where Jews hardly exist any longer.
"If anyone leaves the room with an understanding of anti-Judaism or anti-Semitism, we on the panel will have made a mistake." ROBERTA HERSHENSON

HEADLINE: YOUR TAXES;
Higher Rates Sting the Wealthy

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
WHETHER you consider it soaking the rich or sharing the burden, the tax law of 1993 is taking a much bigger bite out of the wealthy.
The top tax rung has risen to almost 40 percent, the highest level since passage of the 1986 overhaul. Although people with high incomes will be hit the hardest in April, others will pay more as well. Various provisions of the law affect Social Security recipients and upper-middle-income families, among others. 
 While the number of people affected appears to be larger than has been asserted by the Clinton Administration, probably fewer people will be hit than think they will be. According to a Gallup poll of 1,003 adults in August, 28 percent said they expected to pay "a lot more" taxes, and 47 percent expected to pay "a little more."
With the filing deadline just weeks away, the wealthy, at least, are expressing little surprise, but considerable chagrin, as they contemplate the checks they will soon write, accountants say.
"Now they are facing the realization that they have a substantial tax liability due in April," said David M. Bradt Jr., a partner in charge of the individual services practice at Arthur Andersen & Company.
While the top bracket for 1993 has jumped to 36 percent from 31 percent -- a 10 percent surcharge brings the rate to 39.6 on taxable income of more than $250,000 -- little of the additional tax has been paid in advance because withholding tables were not adjusted until this year.
The law, called the Revenue Reconciliation Act of 1993, does provide for spreading the increase over three years without interest. But the wealthy may find little comfort in this peace offer by the Administration, considering that the increase in many cases will amount to tens of thousands of dollars.
"To say they're not surprised is not the same thing as to say they are happy," said Clint Stretch, director of tax legislative affairs at the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche.
Although the Clinton Administration asserts that fewer than 2 percent of taxpayers will be in the new brackets, which kick in at $115,000 of taxable income for single filers and at $140,000 for joint filers, some people suspect the proportion is significantly higher, perhaps two or three times the official estimate.
The Administration's figure, said William Dunkelberg, dean of the business school at Temple University, is based on a count taken when the economy was at a low point, meaning the number of big earners was lower. "You get a lot of income volatility up in those ranges," Mr. Dunkelberg said.
The tax hit will be heaviest in the Northeast, where high-income earners are concentrated. According to a tabulation by Deloitte & Touche, Connecticut's share of returns with adjusted gross incomes of more than $200,000 was nearly twice the national average in 1991. The District of Columbia, New Jersey and New York ranked just behind Connecticut.
The new law, not surprisingly, also adds complexity, forcing more people to make computations for the alternative minimum tax, which has been raised from a flat 24 percent to graduated rates of 26 percent and 28 percent. Connecticut, which finished phasing in a state income tax in 1992, added its own alternative minimum tax last year.
One executive feeling the effects of the Federal Government's decision to reverse the principles of its 1986 tax code overhaul -- lower rates, but fewer items exempted from taxation -- is George J. Wile, head of the Planet Products Corporation, a Cincinnati maker of packaging machinery.
"It's raised my taxes enormously," Mr. Wile said. His tax bracket rose in one swoop to 39.6 percent from 31 percent, costing him $50,000 to $60,000 a year.
And for 1994 the 1.45 percent Medicare tax will be applied to all his earned income, not just to the first $135,000, as it was in 1993.
But Mr. Wile, who kept an eye on the tax legislation and, of course, has professional advisers, was not shocked when he learned of his liability.
Those least aware of the cut-off points tend to be of less exalted means, particularly households with two people who earn respectable incomes. With 75 percent of Americans expecting to have been caught by last year's legislation, some will get a pleasant surprise this tax season.
"A lot of people were expecting to be hit who either are not feeling any impact at all or not as much as they expected," said Doris Cook Ross, a principal in Ross, Langan & McKendree, a firm in the prosperous Washington suburb of McLean, Va. She estimated that 40 percent of her firm's clients, whose income is generally $100,000 to $500,000, are getting better news than they expected.
M. Randy Wright, a Texas accountant, paid close attention to the tax law that was enacted in August and responded promptly. Within weeks, he and his wife, director of corporate finance for Southwest Airlines, decided against paying a contractor an estimated $5,000 to paint their suburban ranch house.
"We canceled with him and did it ourselves," said Mr. Wright, who is head of the tax department in the Dallas office of Grant Thornton. "That was a pretty good way to recoup" the extra tax bite, he added.
While the higher tax rates are retroactive to the the beginning of 1993, many other changes in last year's law, like the removal of the cap for Medicare tax, take effect this year.
William J. Caldwell, associate tax partner in the Rockville, Md., office Bond Beebe, points to a large pocket of distress among one lower-income group: Social Security recipients. In 1993, no more than 50 percent of Social Security benefits could be taxed, but some recipients will have 85 percent of their benefits taxed in 1994.
"That really caught them off guard," Mr. Caldwell said. "They had seen this as a tax on the wealthy." Many retired people complain that their income has already dwindled in recent years as interest rates on investments have declined.
Also in 1994, deductions for club dues disappear, deductions for business meals and entertainment drop to 50 percent from 80 percent, moving and travel deductions are less generous, charitable deductions need stronger documentation, the withholding rate on bonuses jumps to 28 percent from 20 percent and the amount of compensation on which contributions to qualified retirement plans can be made is slashed to $150,000 from $235,840.
Yet there are a few bright spots in the law -- provided that taxpayers are willing to file amended returns for 1992 to claim breaks that have been restored. The most notable are for gifts of appreciated personal property, a 25 percent deduction for health insurance by the self-employed and tax-free treatment of education expenses paid by employers.
The real griping from the wealthy about the tax increase may come from people who choose to pay in three installments. They will find themselves paying 1993 taxes in 1995 and in (can you believe it?) the Presidential election year of 1996.
"There are going to be people paying 1993 taxes in 1996, when it will be still fresh in their minds," said Benjamin D. Patton, president of Patton & Erskine, a small accounting firm in northern Virginia.
Almost as inevitable as taxes is gallows humor by taxpayers. This year, country clubs and other haunts of the rich will no doubt echo with two questions: Which President raised taxes before he was inaugurated? And, if there can be a retroactive tax increase, why can't there be retroactive elections?
Both questions will undoubtedly be answered with a snort of derision about President Clinton, who, as Candidate Clinton, promised to cut taxes.

HEADLINE: Mission to Moscow: Preaching the Gospel of Business

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
"WE use mystery guests," Edward L. Roth, a successful motel operator and practicing Mennonite from Archbold, Ohio, population 3,440, said in explaining his motel business to an advice-hungry audience of Russian business people.
The Russian translator, searching for a word to convey that "mystery guests" are people whom Mr. Roth hires to check up on motel employees, finally settled on "inspectors." 
 But in the audience, Irina V. Korsovskaya, a manager of the Veli Ross travel company in Moscow, knew better. "Spies," she murmured to her neighbor. For the first time in Mr. Roth's peppy speech, "How to Put People Before Profits," she smiled approvingly.
Usually, it is American businessmen who pride themselves on bottom-line realism and Russians who are viewed as impractical romantics.
But at a five-day seminar for would-be entrepreneurs in Russia's fledgling hospitality industry, which was sponsored by Mennonite Economic Development Associates, a nonprofit organization that tries to assist small businesses in the developing world, there was an entirely different kind of cultural clash. Last Monday, the seminar's opening day, the Westerners spoke of bringing God and courtesy into the workplace. The 45 Russians feverishly exchanged business cards and fax numbers.
"To be honest, I am not so interested in the lectures," whispered Nikolai V. Ognev, deputy general director of the Kroppy Company tourist bureau in Moscow. "I came here to make contacts."
Almost every week, there is some kind of business seminar going on in Moscow. And on any day, the finer hotels like the Metropole are filled with Western consultants who flock to the former Soviet Union, many on all-expenses-paid ego trips, courtesy of any number of well-meaning foundations. There are as many missionaries roaming across Russia; some 1,000 have come seeking to make converts over the last three years.
But it is less common to find Western businessmen in Russia trying to serve God and mammon at once.
"This is a mission for us," explained Randy Troyer, a Mennonite businessman who manages the Amish Kitchen Restaurant in Wilmot, Ohio. He, like the six other Canadians and Americans, and unlike so many Western consultants, paid his own way to the sober, frills-free seminar, which was held in a vast, gloomy ballroom of the 10,000-room Ismailovo Hotel in northeast Moscow. There are slot machines in the lobby and no Gideon Bibles in the rooms.
The Mennonites, like the Amish, are a branch of the Anabaptists, and they have a 200-year history in Russia. Long persecuted by the Communists, fewer than 15,000 remain, scattered in remote farming settlements in Siberia and Kazakhstan. Many North American Mennonites have Russian ancestors. "We don't expect to receive anything," Mr. Troyer said. "We want to help these people by sharing our knowledge."
THE Russians, who paid $90 to participate, were owners or managers of small new businesses, mostly in Moscow. But Tatyana A. Khramova, managing director of the Kanikuly travel agency in Tomsk, rode a train for three days from Siberia to attend.
And while many practical sessions were scheduled on subjects like how to run a bed and breakfast and the dos and don'ts of franchising, one lesson all of the panelists were determined to share was that money alone cannot buy happiness.
"How many friends did you lose after you gained your first million?" is how Dr. Aleksandr S. Zaichenko put it. Dr. Zaichenko is president of the Moscow-based Association of Christians in Business in Russia, co-sponsor of the seminar.
A former economics adviser to Mikhail S. Gorbachev during perestroika (he was secretly baptized in his bathtub in the 1970's), Dr. Zaichenko is also the founder of Moscow's Club for Fair and Ethical Business. He conceded that membership there was select, given the sometimes fast and loose ethics ruling Russian business today. "We try to find a moral approach to business," he explained wryly. "But that is not the way it is working here actually."
Most Moscow restaurants, for example, do not exactly live up to the principles set by Mr. Troyer's Amish Kitchen. Mr. Troyer had planned to speak on how to run a restaurant effectively at the Friday session, but didn't bring notes on protection money, cash skimming and bribes.
Restaurants here are the absolute symbol of corruption in our society," Dr. Zaichenko said, adding that criminal gangs controlled most restaurants in urban Russia. "They are horrible, evil, full of nouveaux riches," he said. "I try to avoid going to them."
There were other areas of confusion. Thrainn Kristjansson of Winnipeg, Manitoba, runs three theme restaurants. The fluent, BBC-accented Russian translator ran into difficulty explaining the mock-medieval theme of Mr. Kristjansson's Round Table restaurant, pronouncing it to be a "seminar-oriented" eatery. When Mr. Roth said he offered his motel guests free papers, meaning newspapers, the translator said he gave them free toilet paper.
And when Mr. Roth was asked about how he rebuked bad employees, he recommended a positive approach. "We talk to them discreetly in private, then we try to find something they excel at, like maybe they smile real good." The translator rendered that as, "Maybe the employee smiles too much, and the guests don't like it."
The power of positive thinking did not inspire all of the participants.
"Yes, of course: be polite to customers," Olga V. Kartashova, president of Visit, a tourism agency in Yaroslavl, said. "That is obvious. But for us today, there are so many more important issues -- like obtaining visas, or transport when there is none."
Vernon Wiebe, owner of the Prudent Travel and Tours company in Hillsboro, Kan., swapped shop talk with Russian tour operators over a lunch of meatballs and rice.
Russia, he learned, is not quite like Kansas. "It is hard to know how to talk to them," Mr. Wiebe said. "It's easy for me to say that I started with just a shoebox and built a business." He paused, and added gamely, "It must be possible here too, but they will have to be awfully ingenious and creative."
The Dale Carnegie spirit did not filter down to the staff of the Ismailovo Hotel. Instead, Christopher Shore, the young, fresh-faced Moscow-based representative of the Mennonite organization, received a lesson in how paid hospitality can sometimes falter even in the new Russia. "I just can't believe they don't have a sound system," he exclaimed after politely reasoning with a coolly indifferent hotel manager. "Somebody is not asking the right people." Dr. Zaichenko delicately tried to explain the Russian system. "They just don't care," he said.
But Mr. Shore, a determined young man, went home during the lunch break to fetch his own stereo system. He returned dejected after an unsuccessful search of 10 stores for a microphone. "I was willing to spend $500," he said incredulously. "You'd think someone around here would want to make some money."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vernon Wiebe, who owns a travel agency in Kansas, discussed entrepreneurship with Russian businesswomen at lunch. (Alexei Rogov for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3320 words

HEADLINE: The American Economy, Back on Top

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
DURING the Presidential campaign, Bill Clinton often fretted that the United States economy was fast becoming the world's also-ran. But more and more it looks as if he inherited a winner.
A 3 percent economic growth rate, a gain of two million new jobs in the past year and an inflation rate reminiscent of the 1960's make America the envy of the industrialized world. The amount the average American worker can produce, already the highest in the world, is growing faster than in other wealthy countries, including Japan. The United States has become the world's low-cost provider of many sophisticated products and services, from plastics to software to financial services. And after years of decline, the nation's share of the world export market has been rising. 
 For the most part, these advantages will continue even after countries like Japan and Germany snap out of their recessions. It is the United States, not Japan, that is the master of the next generation of commercially important computer and communications technologies and also of leading-edge services from medicine to movie making. And American managers are not only investing heavily in new equipment, they are also much farther along than those in Europe and Japan in streamlining and re-engineering their companies to make them more competitive. That's one reason that American industries that recently were losers -- like automobiles, machine tools, steel and computer chips -- are back with a vengeance.
The turnaround reflects more than 10 years of sometimes innovative and often wrenching change, driven by recession, deregulation, tougher foreign competition, the threat of takeovers, and, not least, new technology.
The image of the United States as an economic winner, once associated only with apologists for the Reagan era, is catching on. The French newspaper Le Monde and the Japanese newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun have each run long series on the new American competitive threat. Foreign leaders and executives who once lectured Americans on their shortcomings now speak enviously of this country's cleverness in churning out everything from jobs to Jeeps.
While such sentiments may seem more common abroad, there are signs that America's self-esteem is recovering. Some polls show that Americans once again see the United States as an economic giant. Rush Limbaugh, who likes to brag about America's prowess, is one of the most popular radio talk show hosts. By contrast, Bruce Springsteen, the balladeer of dying American factory towns, hasn't had a hit in a couple of years.
"Image and reality have both undergone a remarkable change in the last few years," said Michael Hammer, a business consultant and co-author of the best-seller "Re-engineering the Corporation." "American business -- not just manufacturing -- is again perceived as the world leader."
David Rolley, an international economist at the forecasting firm DRI/McGraw Hill, added: "Everyone thought the U.S. was a basket case, but others turned out to be bigger basket cases. Germany has too many good things, too many vacations. Japan is too much like I.B.M., such a successful model that nobody figured out what to do when it exhausted the model."
None of this is an excuse for giddiness. The gains have come at a high price. Even as the economy created new jobs, tens of millions of people lost their old ones and were forced to pull up stakes, take pay cuts, carve out new careers. The United States is still second best (or third or fourth) in many pursuits. And tomorrow's stars, from Malaysia to Mexico, pose growing challenges for many an American business.
Also, the recovery here and the recessions abroad are bound to highlight American strengths and foreign weaknesses. America's turnaround may look better than it is because reports of the nation's demise were exaggerated to begin with. And, as always, what looks like a lot of improvement to one person looks like too little to another.
Finally, the benefits of economic leadership are mostly psychic. The struggle to make the economic pie bigger and insure that all citizens get a slice is largely a race against oneself, not against other countries. And being the economic leader is no cure for some of the most serious problems American society faces, including crime, inadequate education, the growing isolation of the underclass, the rampant economic insecurity that many middle-class Americans feel, and, for that matter, the malaise that can come with working so hard to do better.
But the changing perception of America is already subtly influencing the way we think. Infatuation with the Japanese or German model of capitalism is becoming less fashionable, and the massive government meddling advocated by so many critics to reverse the nation's supposed decline is less appealing to a lot of people.
For example, despite promises of more government help for so-called strategic industries, the Clinton Administration has not budgeted much money for such an industrial policy. And Washington will probably not lurch toward European-style "managed trade," through which the Government sets targets for how much companies should buy from, and sell to, foreigners -- recent threats to limit Japan's access to the American market notwithstanding. And almost no one expects the big worker-retraining programs proposed during the Presidential campaign to materialize.
In fact, interest is growing in less costly ways to let people roll with the punches -- from getting welfare mothers into jobs to making it easier for workers to change jobs without losing pensions or health coverage.
The climate could still change. A trade war with Japan, while unlikely, is nevertheless a possibility. The Federal Reserve Board could turn a blind eye as the inflation genie slips out of the bottle. There's always the possibility that health care reform, if it happens, will add costs to businesses and therefore stifle job creation. Efforts to protect the people who have suffered in the economic transformation could backfire -- as they have in Europe -- if they take the form of protectionism or laws that make it harder for businesses to shrink payrolls or get out of unprofitable businesses.
But many people, including the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, think that the many recent positive signs, especially the rebound in productivity growth, signal that the United States economy will do even better in the 1990's than in the 1980's. That means, they argue, that more Americans will share in the economy's gains.
 
The Evidence
Glowing Numbers And More to Come
 Some of the evidence of America's impressive economic performance has been around for years but ignored. Most of it is fairly new.
Start with the most basic yardstick of economic health, the growth of productivity, or output per worker. Productivity determines how fast living standards can rise.
The American worker is the most productive in the world by far, producing on average $49,600 in goods and services a year in 1990 -- $5,000 more than German workers, $10,000 more than Japanese counterparts. Moreover, while productivity was growing more quickly abroad than in the United States for most of the 20th century, America has lately been gaining more quickly, as companies here figure out how to provide more and better products and services with new technologies and fewer workers.
Since the start of the economic recovery nearly three years ago, United States productivity has been growing at an annual rate of 2.5 percent, more than twice as fast as the average between 1970 and 1990, and markedly better than elsewhere.
The United States lead is widest in services. Retailing is twice as productive in the United States as in Japan, where laws protect the shopkeeper from the discount chain. The deregulated American telecommunications industry is at least twice as productive as Germany's government monopoly. The fragmented American banking industry is a third more efficient than Germany's banking oligopolies. The American edge in these industries has recently been expanding, not shrinking.
Gains on the factory floor have lately been even more stellar than for the economy over all: Hourly output has been rising nearly 5 percent a year for three years even as it has flattened or fallen in Germany and Japan. The United States lead in manufacturing, which had been shrinking as Germany and Japan caught up or moved ahead in some industries, has lately been widening again.
"You're seeing today the results of actions undertaken in the second half of the 1980's," said Stanley Gault, the chief executive who helped revive the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and Rubbermaid Inc.
THERE are at least two reasons for thinking that the American productivity lead won't evaporate when Germany and Japan recover from their recessions. One is that investment, especially in computers, is booming. The other, more important, reason is that corporate America started the painful task of learning how to make more, more quickly and with fewer resources, earlier than many of its overseas counterparts, especially in Europe.
In a recent Harvard Business Review article, Shintaro Hori, a director of the consulting firm Bain & Company Japan, estimated that Japanese companies will have to shed 15 to 20 percent of their white-collar work forces to match the low overhead in America.
"There are far fewer re-engineering efforts under way in Japanese and German companies compared with the United States," said Mr. Hammer, the consultant, whose firm has trained thousands of American managers to overhaul their companies in the last few years but few from foreign corporations.
Hard evidence is the reward American companies are reaping: Despite the moderate pace of the economic recovery, inflation-adjusted corporate profits are close to an all-time high.
In some smokestack industries -- steel, machine tools and especially cars -- the choice was to raise productivity and quality a lot or cede the field to the competition, as American companies did in consumer electronics. American managers chose the former, lifting productivity in the auto plants, for example, by an average of 10 percent every year during the late 1980's, according to McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm.
Indeed, no sooner did "The Reckoning" -- the book by David Halberstam that focused on Ford and Nissan to tell "the story of Japan's ascent and America's subtle industrial decline" -- appear in 1985 than did Ford begin its comeback and Nissan begin to falter. Ford's market share has since climbed to 25.5 percent of the American market from 21.3 percent, while Nissan, with 5.0 percent today, never improved on the 5.3 percent it held in the mid-1980's.
IN the first half of the 1980's, many American products were not only inferior to, but also pricier than, those offered by other nations. The grossly overvalued dollar -- which made American exports expensive and imports cheap -- was largely to blame. But so were a clutch of bad habits -- from executives' granting fat pay increases to Washington's tolerating too much inflation.
These days, by contrast, American factories ship steel to Seoul, transistors to Tokyo, cars to Cologne and Spandex to Siena (for bicycle pants). America's exports have been rising nearly 9 percent a year since 1985, even faster than Japan's 6.6 percent and Germany's 4.2 percent. Even more telling, the United States' share of exports by industrialized countries, which shrank to nearly 10 percent a decade ago, close to a post-war low, has rebounded to its 1980 level, around 14 percent.
Small wonder. Thanks to the weaker dollar, more moderate wage settlements and gains in efficiency, American production costs have been rising more slowly than those in Europe and Japan: 1.1 percent a year since 1985, compared with 2.5 percent in Europe and 1.7 percent in Japan. BMW of North America Inc. and Mercedes-Benz of North America Inc. are building their new plants in the American South. And, to hold down the price of their new models, Japanese car makers with plants in America are resorting to a strategy considered unthinkable just a few years ago: raising as much as possible the content of locally procured parts, as Honda said it would do this year.
Contrast this with Germany's cost problem. At current exchange rates German manufacturing workers are paid about $26 an hour, $10 more than American and Japanese factory hands. The problem is so serious that Chancellor Helmut Kohl devoted the German equivalent of the State of the Union message last October to the problem of German competitiveness.
"It seems as if there is still nothing more important than thinking about how we can expand our recreation time," he scolded. "If we want to secure Germany's future, we cannot organize our country as if it were one big recreation park."
Making things less expensively isn't enough to captivate a world full of ever more affluent, increasingly sophisticated consumers. That requires a prodigious stream of new ideas and invention. A case in point is the converging world of computing, telecommunications and television.
"We're in the midst of the third industrial revolution," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, "and the United States is leading it."
The European technology industry is in deep trouble, its stagnant revenue, lack of new products and need for billions in government subsidies evident even before the recession. Japan has been a leader in consumer electronics. But, as its retreat in high-definition television shows, that country is still mainly the master of mass-produced components -- flat panel displays, memory chips, fax machines.
Six years ago, the fear was that Japanese dominance would spread to leading-edge technologies. But Japanese electronics giants like the Hitachi Zosen Corporation, the NEC Corporation and the Toshiba Corporation haven't been able to keep up with changing technology and American companies like the Intel Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation are in the lead in virtually all the key ingredients of the business- and personal-computer revolution: software, workstations, laser printers, computer networks and the computers-on-a-chip known as microprocessors.
"Everything important gets invented here," said Charles Ferguson, a Cambridge, Mass., technology consultant who a few years ago was warning darkly of the Japanese threat. The growing demand for sophisticated products will probably play to the strengths of American producers. So might the fact that American consumers are already more familiar with new technology than people abroad. Compared with Japan, for example, the United States has more than three times as many personal computers per worker.
"More Americans are familiar with these technologies and are using them in everyday life," Mr. Steinberg said. "And more American businesses have learned to use the technology to improve productivity."
 
The Reasons
Economic 'Vices' Are Also Virtues
 Are there reasons for the American comeback other than inventiveness, streamlining, re-engineering, the adaptability of workers and managers, lower inflation and interest rates, and a weaker dollar?
Yes, indeed. Often overlooked is that some of this nation's supposed vices -- from a reluctance to protect and regulate industries, to an obsession with short-term profits -- have turned out to be virtues as well. And the much-praised features of Japanese and German capitalism -- from managed trade to lifetime employment -- have proved to have drawbacks.
The fact that American companies are regularly exposed to the toughest competitors on their home turf is a blessing as well as a curse. Detroit was forced to compete head to head with Japanese cars. European auto makers enjoyed far more protection from Japan. For a while, the jobs of tens of thousands of European auto workers and their bosses were safe, but now a huge downsizing is all but inevitable.
Lighter regulation in the United States than in other nations proved bracing for many American service companies because it encouraged competition. American shopkeepers cannot fall back on the kind of zoning laws that shield mom-and-pop stores in Japan from certain death by would-be Wal-Marts. A.T.& T. has been at the forefront of communications technology in large part because of challenges from the likes of MCI Communications Inc. and the Sprint Corporation. United Airlines gives passengers a better price because Southwest Airlines does. Contrast the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and United with their German counterparts, which remain carefully guarded state monopolies, though things are beginning to change.
Even the focus by investors and bankers on last quarter's bottom line may turn out to be less of a handicap than some argue. Impatient institutional investors blew the whistle when profits shrank, as did bank lenders without the cozy ties to corporate boards that exist in countries like Germany and Japan.
And the deep pain of layoffs has produced important gains. To be sure, the dislocation caused by layoffs in one American industry after another since the early 1980's is staggering. In the past decade, estimates Steven Davis, a labor economist at the University of Chicago, 1 in 10 manufacturing jobs -- two million -- vanished every year, even though the net decline in factory jobs over the decade was only about 1 million.
But it is becoming clear that the ability to move workers quickly from one industry to another also has benefits to the economy -- in the form of increased productivity that is essential to raising the standard of living.
For all the layoffs, the fact is that the number of new jobs has far outstripped the number of jobs lost in recent years. The United States economy has added 18 million jobs in the past decade, a net gain of more than 20 percent, including 2 million in the past year. And the unemployment rate has dropped about 1.5 percentage points in the past 18 months, to just over 6 percent. The economies of the European Community, which combined are the same size as the American economy, have added just 7 million jobs in 10 years, a net increase of 7 percent, and have grappled with unemployment rates, now in the double digits, that haven't fallen below 8 percent in a decade.
 
The Dissent
But What About That Trade Deficit?
 Perhaps the most compelling counterargument to the notion that America is doing so well is this: Imports are rising three times faster than exports and the trade deficit, which was shrinking during the late 1980's, is swelling. "How can Japan pay wages that are higher, have productivity that is lower and still sell us $60 billion more than they buy?" asked Lester Thurow, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who is much in favor at the White House by dint of his book "Head to Head: The Coming Battle Among Japan, Europe and America."
But the trade deficit is not a particularly reliable yardstick of the health of an economy for two reasons. The first is that how much countries buy abroad depends on their income as well as the attractiveness of the foreign products, and America's income (in short, its gross domestic product) is rising more rapidly than that of most other nations.
The more subtle reason is that critics of American competitiveness have a habit of focusing on trade figures that capture only goods that are traded internationally, ignoring the service sector. Yet America's economic performance depends far more on service industries, which now employ three out of four American workers.
So America's back in the lead. But that's no excuse to relax. "Things are going to get different again," said Mr. Hammer. "People think the hard work is over, but hard work is going to be a permanent condition."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A.T.&T.'s network-operations center in Bedminster, N.J., an example of American prowess in increasingly important industries. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)(pg. 1)
 
Graphs: "HOW THE U.S. HAS REGAINED WORLD LEADERSHIP"
Just a few years ago, America's descent into second-rate status was a widely accepted fait accompli. No more. Europe and Japan have stumbled while the United States economy is growing, inflation is low and productivity and employment are rising. After more than a decade of painful change and dislocation, many American industries are leaner and nimbler and others have seized the leadership of the sophisticated technologies that are ushering in the information age. HEADLINE: Vital Signs Improve for the Nursing Home Industry

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
AS with virtually all segments of the health care marketplace, change is sweeping through the nation's $70 billion nursing home industry. What is different here, though, is that few in this highly fragmented business are complaining.
People in the business are smiling because, among other things, there is a rising tide of senior citizens to take care of, and there is a stagnant to declining pool of beds in which to put them. Nursing home companies are also successfully competing with hospitals in taking care of patients who are recovering from surgery. 
 Indeed, even as reform is causing dislocation in important components of the health care system, from hospitals to drug companies to physicians, analysts say many nursing home operators, particularly the biggest ones, are in pretty good shape.
"Nursing homes are the only area in health care where there is a shortage," said Peter Sidoti, a health care analyst at the NatWest Securities Corporation in New York. "There are not enough nursing home beds in the country, and demand is growing."
Although other factors are playing a role, the driving force behind the positive outlook for nursing homes is demographic. Millions of Americans are getting old, and advances in medical technology are allowing them to grow older still. By the year 2000, there will be about 35 million Americans age 65 or older, and 40 million by 2010, according to Census Bureau Estimates; that's up from 31.5 million in 1990.
For nursing homes, the critical group is people 85 and older, which happens to be the fastest growing part of the elderly population. By the year 2000, their numbers are projected to swell by 40 percent, and to double by 2010.
According to a recent research report prepared by Todd B. Richter, a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds in New York, and by Mark G. Banta, another health care analyst at the firm, more than half of those over 85 need long-term care.
The other critical part of the equation is where will all these older people go? For the foreseeable future they will compete for a finite number of beds that is not expected to get much bigger. There are more than 15,000 nursing homes in the country, with about 1.6 million beds. On any given day, between 90 and 95 percent of those beds are occupied.
Thus far this decade, the supply of nursing home beds has stabilized, or has even declined slightly, because of state Certificate of Need laws designed to control or reduce the number of nursing home beds. If a nursing home wants to expand, it must apply to the state, showing why there is a need for more beds in its area. Because most nursing home residents are on Medicaid, the government health plan that covers the poor, the state pays a big part of the tab at nursing homes. So as beds increase, so does the state's Medicaid costs. The effect: States don't hand out Certificates of Need like aspirin.
In 1990 alone, nursing home payments represented 38.2 percent of Medicaid expenditures nationwide, according to a report prepared by John F. Hindelong, a principal and health care analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Paying for Medicaid is the second-biggest cost item for state governments, and it is probably the single fastest-growing cost.
In their report, Dean Witter's analysts concluded that since restrictive Certificate of Need laws are in place in most states, "We do not believe the supply situation will change materially for the better over the next several years," possibly not before the turn of the century.
Nursing homes, however, have found a way to profit from the state restrictions. Now the average nursing home derives more than 60 percent of its revenue from Medicaid. But by holding down the number of new beds and effectively putting a lid on Medicaid patients, home operators have greater latitude to "pick and choose who they let in the door," Mr. Sidoti from NatWest Securities said. The ability to pick from a generally more affluent group is boosting profitability.
The search for greater profitability has pushed nursing home operators into direct competition with their big cousins, hospitals, for subacute-care patients. These patients, recovering from cancer, coronary bypass and joint replacement surgery, or from serious accidents, are increasingly receiving post-operative therapy at nursing homes.
"We are branching out into areas that until the 1990's were dominated by hospitals," said Paul Ormond, chairman and chief executive of the Health Care and Retirement Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest nursing home operator. For nursing homes able to afford the $10,000- to $15,000-per-bed investment Dean Witter's analysts estimate is necessary to accommodate subacute and rehabilitation patients, the attractions are clear: Operating margins for treatment of subacute care patients are roughly twice those on custodial geriatric care.
For payers like health maintenance organizations and insurance companies, there is one clear benefit of using nursing homes for subacute care: cost.
"We make a pretty compelling argument to payers about the price reductions we can provide," said Paul Willging, executive vice president of the American Health Care Association, a Washington lobbying group that represents 11,000 subacute residential care nursing homes.
"We are talking about a day of care that is one-half to two-thirds the price of what a day at a hospital costs. And we know we can do it cheaper than that."
In Mr. Hindelong's report on the nursing home industry, the Donaldson Lufkin analyst, citing figures from the 1992 Marion Merrell Dow Long Term Care Digest, notes that in 1991 H.M.O.'s generated an average of 30 percent of revenue at for-profit nursing homes. In 1989 and 1990, the H.M.O. contribution to nursing home revenues was 3 percent and 4 percent, respectively.
"People that run skilled nursing facilities are much more cost conscious than people who run hospitals," said Stewart Bainum, chairman and chief executive of Manor Care Inc., the nation's third-largest and most profitable nursing home chain.
David Vanderwater, chief operating officer at Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, the nation's largest hospital chain, admitted that "historically, hospitals have not been the most economical place for these types of services. But the world is changing. I think hospitals are poised to meet that challenge. And we believe hospitals provide much more flexibility than nursing homes."
In order to meet the challenge, some hospitals are reducing their number of beds and sharply cutting their work force.
Columbia/HCA is nevertheless keeping its options open. Last week, the company and Beverly Enterprises, the nation's largest nursing home company, said they were discussing joint ventures in some cities.
All this change is getting Wall Street's attention. Over the last year, shares in the 16 publicly traded nursing home companies have risen an average of 30 percent to 40 percent, Mr. Richter of Dean Witter said..
"We follow 10 publicly traded companies and have buy recommendations on all of them because we think the long-term fundamentals are superb," Mr. Sidoti of NatWest Securities said. That stated, he does have some particular favorites. He likes the Hillhaven Corporation, the nation's second-largest nursing home operator. And he said the Sun Healthcare Group, which NatWest is advising in its $320 million buyout of the Mediplex Group, has a great future.
"Hillhaven owns its own bricks and mortar, and they have good earnings," he said. "We also think that since National Medical Enterprises owns 35 percent of the stock, Hillhaven is a likely takeover candidate."
Sun Healthcare, meanwhile, "is a company that has been ignored by investors. Right now, it has a market capitalization of $250 million, but only $90 million of that is freely traded."
That will change after the buyout of Mediplex, a subacute care provider, is completed.
"After this deal, the company will have a market capitalization of more than $700 million, and more than $500 million of that will be freely traded," Mr. Sidoti said.
Although the big players are getting all the attention, the industry is still dominated by small entrepreneurs, and more and more of them are beginning to merge. There have been a half dozen nursing home combinations over the last 12 months.
At the moment, the nursing home industry remains widely diversified: The 20 largest chains operate just 18 percent of the homes, but that is expected to change.
"Right now the top 32 players have 21 percent of the beds," Mr. Richter said. "Five years from now, I would expect the top 10 players will have 21 percent of the beds."
Mergers make sense because of the need to work with managed care purveyors," said Carl Sherman, a senior vice president and health care analyst at Dillon Read & Company. "In the next few years, the nursing home industry sees this as being all-important."
Also important for the industry is keeping down labor costs, which represent close to 80 percent of a nursing home's expenses. Wages are under control, but that could change.
"So long as unemployment stays above 6 percent, we in nursing homes will do well," Andrew L. Turner, founding chairman and chief executive of Sun Healthcare, said.
Aside from the mergers, larger nursing home operators, including Manor Care, have also entered into joint-venture arrangements with hospitals, or are contemplating them.
Given the huge size of some hospital chains relative to nursing homes, "hospitals could purchase assets and capabilities from the nursing home industry," Mr. Ormond at Health Care and Retirement said. "But it is more likely they will focus on their segment of the market, and we will focus on ours. There will be ways for the system to enjoy the economics of both."
Mr. Turner of Sun Healthcare disagreed. "In 10 years we will be in the hospital business," he said. "But it will be called something different than that."
 
 
 
SMALL FRY ARE MAKING ACQUISITIONS
 Over the last year the nursing home industry has seen a flurry of mergers and acquisitions. But unlike the 1980's, when big companies spent too much for their acquisitions, the buying and selling in the last 12 months has involved smaller operators doing smaller deals.
 "In the past, if there was acquisition activity, it was big fish swallowing little fish," saisd Andrew L. Turner, chairman and chief executive of Sun Healthcare Group, which in January announced in was buying the Mediplex Group for $320 million.
 "Today, it's the little fish who are getting married," he added. "The five largest companies are not out there."
 Indeed. Here is a list of the five biggest nursing home deals in the last year:
 * Genesis Health Ventures/Meridian Healthcare. Price, $205 million. Combination increases the number of beds at Genesis to more than 10,000. Genesis also agreed to lease an additional seven nursing homes from Meridian, with an option to buy them for $59 million in 10 years.
 * Horizon Healthcare Corporation/Greenert Rehabilitation Group. Price, $350 million. Combination gives Horizon just under 9,000 beds.
 * Sun Healthcare Group Systems/Mediplex Group. Price $320 million. Combination make Sun one of the 10 highest nursing home operations in the country, with more than 13,000 beds.
 * Integrated Health Services/Central Park Lodges. Price $184 million. Combination gives Integrated nearly 5,000 beds. Central Park had been a unit of the Trizec Corporation of Canada.
 * Regency Health Services/Care Enterprises. Prices, $120 million in a stock swap. Combination is giving Regency just over 9,000 beds.
