HEADLINE: Business Diary: February 20-25

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Bell Atlantic and T.C.I. Decide the Future can Wait
Maybe everyone got carried away with this "information highway" idea; maybe things were moving too fast. Because all the fancy talk got slammed into a wall of reality. The Huge Merger planned by Bell Atlantic and Tele-Communications was supposed to set off a fireworks-popping transformation of, well, the world as we know it - cable-television, communications, who-knows-what. But last week, the two compnies said, Never mind: The numbers don't add up. Why did the deal crash? The F.C.C. lowering cable rates played a part, and T.C.I.'s aggreasive manner did clash with staid Bell Atlantic. But more likely it just wasn't time for the cable industry to disappear into some labyrinthine, futuristic world. Now, said one executive, cable "will not be folded into the telephone industry as quickly as people thought." cable stocks, though, looked better before. 

What Should Cable TV Cost?
Even without merger confusion, cable television is a slippery thing. Regulators keep trying to put a fair price tag on it, but the technological sands keep shifting. Last year the F.C.C. moved to bring rates down to competitive levels, but somehow a third of consumers saw their rates rise -- partly because cable companies proved adept at reshuffling the channels in a "basic" package. Last week, the F.C.C. tried again, cutting rates an additional 7 percent -- that, it says, is where true competition would drive them -- and it is trying to close the loopholes. The head of the F.C.C., Reed Hundt, called it "one of the greatest consumer savings" -- when you add it up, it amounts to a couple of dollars a month.
 
Soros Takes a Beating
Well, no one's invincible -- not even George Soros. Mr. Soros has taken on a larger-than-life aura for his prescient, and hugely profitable, bets on the direction of the world's currencies. A year and a half ago, he made $1 billion when he bet that Britain's pound would be devalued in the midst of Europe's exchange-rate turmoil. With such stakes, though, the day had to come when the losses would be just as huge. It has. Last week Mr. Soros said his Quantum Group funds lost $600 million on Feb. 14 in a bad bet on the direction of the yen.
 
Giving In to Cancer at Tenneco
Michael Walsh tried for a year to do two quite formidable -- and quite different -- tasks, but in the end one of them demanded his undivided attention. One task had been to run Tenneco, and he did that spectacularly. In less than three years, he had, by all accounts, whipped the company into shape -- just as he had turned around Union Pacific before that. But in January 1993 he developed brain cancer, and after a year of battling that, while staying on the job, he resigned last week at the age of 51. The stock fell $3.375 over two days, to $54.625, but a more relevant point is that that's still nearly twice what it was shortly after Mr. Walsh took charge.
 
Take That, Microsoft!
Mighty Microsoft, the fearsome competitor, got its wrist slapped last week, but it will take a lot more than that to slow it down. A Federal jury said the company infringed the patent of a small California company called Stac Electronics, which had developed a method for doubling the storage capacity of computer disks. The jury awarded Stac $120 million in damages -- which Microsoft can pay out of its pocket money -- but the bigger question is whether this Goliath will now be a bit more cautious in its dealings with various Davids. And it will surely cause more discussion about whether the patent concept is even relevant to something as complex as software.
 
NASA, Back in the Frying Pan
NASA can't seem to stay out of trouble. Recently it went a long way toward erasing one black mark by patching up the Hubble, but last week it had another headache. Federal prosecutors accused nine people, some of whom work for NASA, of taking part in bribery and kickback schemes at the Johnson Space Center in Texas. Martin Marietta agreed to pay $1 million and to help in the inquiry. What's behind it? One scientist cited NASA's loose, "mom and pop" accounting methods, saying, "It's a lot easier to knock off a mom-and-pop than an armored car."
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Japan Abandons HDTV (Briefly)
In Japan, high-definition television is a topic painfully close to the economic nerve. It's their baby, a rare instance of Japan pioneering a technology. So there was an uproar last week when the Government said it might abandon analog HDTV technology, into which industry had poured billions, in favor of the Americans' digital system. Such an uproar, in fact, that the next day Tokyo said, Well, uh, maybe we'll stick with it after all. A token bit of national honor restored, but the damage was done: Who's going to put more effort into a technology that could be a dead end?
 
Bradley Slams 'Japan-Bashing'
President Clinton's tough talk on trade with Japan is good box office, but -- for the long-term good -- is it the right thing? Some have doubts, and last week they got a key ally in Bill Bradley. "People want to believe," the Democratic senator said, that "somebody is victimizing us." But he wants none of it. Mr. Clinton's saber-rattling is "gratuitous brinkmanship," he said -- "Japan-bashing" for domestic consumption. Threats of a trade war, he said, could undermine efforts at reform in Japan. He will surely be heard, because he's usually a solid Clinton backer.
 
Easing High-Tech Exports
People are nervous about exporting fancy technology. As one arms-control advocate put it, we don't want to "send U.S. pilots again to bomb things our industry has exported." But changes in the world, and in technology, cannot be ignored. And, not least, a chance to increase the nation's trade cannot be ignored -- not by this President anyway. So last week Mr. Clinton proposed an overhaul of export controls to fit the realities of a post-cold-war world, with the aim of easing the sale of machine tools and other high-tech stuff. The move seemed, politically, on target, because the protests matched up well: business wanted more, arms-control groups wanted less.
 
Health Reform: A Fatal Flaw?
In his passion to fix the health care mess, President Clinton faces a built-in, possibly insurmountable problem: though everyone cheers the notion of "universal coverage," many recoil at the idea of the Government running things. One lawmaker called the plan "too bureaucratic, too governmental." In other words, any "government" plan may be doomed. And last week the American Association of Retired Persons declined to support the Clinton plan. That one hurt. The group has 33 million members -- with great interest in health care -- and Mr. Clinton has put a lot of effort into getting its backing.
 
Greenspan Keeps 'em Hopping
Alan Greenspan, whose every utterance is scrutinized by the markets, tried to make something perfectly clear last week. No, the Fed chairman insisted before Congress, inflation is under control. No, there's no reason for long-term interest rates to rise just because he'd nudged short-term rates up. President Clinton liked what he heard, but the markets were of two minds, with stock and bond prices rising on Tuesday, falling on Wednesday and plunging on Thursday before steadying on Friday -- with rates cited as a factor all week.
 
Putting the Hot News on Ice
Instant communications. It practically defines our age. Beepers, pocket phones, mercilessly up-to-the-second scheduling gadgets. But wait -- something very curious happened last week. The big story of the winter -- forget the snow, forget the earthquake, even forget Paramount -- was the duel between Ms. Apple Pie and Ms. Pool Hall. But when the ached-for moment came at last, most people didn't know 'til hours later. They didn't want to know ("Don't ruin it for me!") or blocked out the fact that during prime-time figure skating, it was the dead of night in Norway. CBS kept up the fiction, pounding every drum in reach as it opened its coverage of this great taped drama, now seven hours old.
 
Heading Off That First Puff
Dr. Joycelyn Elders is committed to cutting smoking, and last week, in the 23d Surgeon General's Report on Smoking and Health, she took the battle to a new front. Noting that tobacco companies lose nearly two million customers a year -- they either die or quit -- and must thus constantly recruit new ones, she urged that the focus be on preventing those first puffs. "Young people are the chief source of new customers," she said, calling for a ban on advertising aimed at the young, like the Joe Camel ads. The Tobacco Institute insisted that ads are aimed at adult smokers. "We don't need to target kids, and we don't," a spokesman said. . . . The tobacco industry got another blow on Friday when the F.D.A. ruled that cigarettes could be considered drugs -- and face regulation as such.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
An Emerging Emerging Market

BYLINE: By Edward A. Gargan 

 BODY:
HIDDEN in the Indian Ocean like a verdant dollop dripping from the southern coast of tropical India, Sri Lanka has lingered in geographical and economic obscurity. It is a land that lures European tourists, is fighting a vicious but relatively contained civil war, and has quietly managed to attract interest from foreign investors and financial institutions.
Since the beginning of the year, the Colombo Stock Exchange -- tiny by global standards, to be sure -- has soared. Before last week, it had been outperforming markets in every other country except Brazil. Then, last Wednesday, the Sri Lankan all-shares index hit an all-time high of 1,373.48 and the market became the world's leading gainer for the year. The market has risen more than 350 points in three months. 
 Political stability, which appears to have been enhanced in the wake of the assassination of the former president last May, and the most sustained economic growth in South Asia have made Sri Lanka a lucrative investment with considerable potential, according to many analysts.
"A lot of investors are coming into the market," said Thilan Wijesinghe, the director of research at Asia Stock Brokers Pvt. Ltd., a brokerage in Colombo. "We saw the first Sri Lankan country fund last year," he said in reference to the Regent Sri Lankan Fund Ltd., managed in Hong Kong. "It raised a total of $25.6 million in November, and one reason for the rise in the market was that the fund was investing. And then a lot of retail investors got into the market."
Far freer than the regional markets in India, particularly Bombay's, and in Karachi, the Colombo exchange has prospered in a small, and until now unnoticed, fashion. Gone forever, it seems, are the controls and state ownership that characterized the socialist policies of the 1970's. Foreign investment in manufacturing, once discouraged, is now vigorously wooed; and with a literacy rate approaching 90 percent, Sri Lanka has the most educated workers in South Asia.
Still, the country is tiny and the Colombo exchange has one of the smallest capitalizations of emerging market exchanges in the world, about $3.6 billion, up from $1.8 billion in December. But as Mano Titawella, the manager of research at HDF Securities Pvt. Ltd., a Colombo investment firm, put it, "Daily trading volume is now at $8 million. It's small by any other standard, but in December it was $2 million."
Such tiny turnover leads many analysts to ignore Sri Lanka altogether. "It's an emerging emerging market," said George K. Hersh Jr., a Baring Securities Ltd. analyst in New York.
A few foreign analysts, however, believe that Sri Lanka, if not yet of age, is rapidly warranting attention from investors.
"Our feeling is that the market growth is being generated by a combination of factors," said Nigel Rendell, an emerging market strategist at James Capel & Company, a London brokerage. Among them: "A fairly stable political environment, fairly strong growth -- 6 percent G.D.P. growth is the minimum this year if things hold together. There is also the possibility that if they manage to sort out the war with the Tamils [the ethnically-based, northern rebel movement], growth could be in double digits."
In Colombo, brokers and analysts are confident that there is no way to go but up. Mr. Wijesinghe even believes Sri Lanka's size works to its advantage in the competitive emerging market environment.
"Our smallness in itself proved to be an advantage," he said. "Fund managers might have two, three, four million in the Sri Lankan market. So people leave their money here instead of moving it out, like happened in Bangkok or Kuala Lumpur. And new money was coming in.
"Then, the market took off in February in anticipation of two more country funds coming in, as well as the existing regional funds," he added. "I would reckon that there is $100 million still wanting to come into Sri Lanka. You're seeing a classic case of defying fundamentals."
Mr. Titawella of HDF Securities noted that, "There has been a tremendous infusion of liquidity. What has really held up is the announcement of a regional country fund which invested about $25 million. So the market took off in the later stages of December. Three weeks ago we had something called the Sri Lankan Growth Fund sponsored by Smith Newcourt in Hong Kong. They have the authority to put in $100 million." (There are no Sri Lankan funds currently trading in the United States.)
"The key thing is basically, on a whole, the market is overheated at the moment," said Mr. Titawella. "If you look at December, the market valuation was about 21 times historic earnings. Now we're looking at 31 times historic earnings. Traditionally it's been 14. I'm not comfortable with 31, definitely. I'm looking at a forecast of p/e of about 22, which I think is still high, and I think the market should correct itself in terms of a p/eof about 18."
Still, foreign analysts believe Sri Lanka is moving forward faster than other markets in South Asia. And a general election scheduled for the end of the year is likely to be called early this summer so the program of privatizing Government-owned industries and enterprises can be accelerated.
"From a foreign perspective it looks good," Mr. Rendell of James Capel said. "We like the manufacturing sector. We like the construction sector. The service sector also seems to be growing, and the tourist sector is booming."

HEADLINE: Viewpoints;
Innovation: Medicine's Best Cost-Cutter

BYLINE: By MICHAEL PORTER, ELIZABETH TEISBERG and GREGORY BROWN; Michael Porter and Elizabeth Teisberg are on the faculty of the Harvard Business School. Gregory Brown, a former surgeon, is a vice president of Vector Securities International in Chicago. The three have just completed a three-year study of the economics of health care.

 BODY:
IN his State of the Union Message last month, President Clinton began the final stage of his courageous campaign for health care reform. But neither his proposal nor any of the other leading proposals will yield the desired results. They all fail to recognize the central importance of innovation in reducing health care costs.
The Administration's proposal does try to control costs; it just does it the wrong way. It depends upon simplified paperwork, the greater bargaining power of new purchasing alliances and caps on prices. But costs cannot be reduced enough with these measures, which are essentially ways to deliver today's health care more efficiently. The savings from these efforts are possible and necessary, but the desire to widen access to health care, the growing health needs of an aging population and Americans' demands for the best treatments available will soon overwhelm the gains. 
 As many industries have shown, the only real way to lower costs substantially is through innovation. It was innovation that drove down the price of the average long-distance phone call by more than 50 percent between 1984 and 1992 -- while raising quality as well. And although the first personal computer cost $50,000, innovation has reduced cost so much that, today, a PC that drastically outperforms the original model can easily be purchased for less than $3,000.
Despite these and many other examples of innovation's great cost-reducing power, the Clinton proposal completely neglects this principle, and the competing proposals are not much better. The reformers may assume that the march of technology is impervious to Government regulation, but this is wrong. In 1993, for example, more than $500 million in public and private stock offerings for medical-device and drug firms were canceled because of the threat of price controls.
Or the reformers may regard technology as the cause rather than the cure of high costs. They often dwell, say, on the $1 million cost of a magnetic resonance imaging machine while ignoring the diagnoses doctors can make with it and the expensive exploratory surgery it avoids.
This approach is also mistaken; innovation's savings and other benefits are as substantial in health care as in other industries. New drugs to prevent postsurgical infections can reduce hospital stays as much as 10 days. Gene therapy for illnesses like cystic fibrosis and Parkinson's disease can eliminate years of chronic care costs, while also improving patients' quality of life. New cell therapy techniques can reduce the cost of a bone-marrow transplant as much as $50,000. Similarly, the laparoscope, originally developed for use in gynecology, has reduced the bill for gall bladder surgery to $6,400 from $21,000 and turned a six-day hospital stay into an outpatient procedure.
Drugs and devices are not the only ways to innovate; services can be revolutionized, too. Special head-trauma centers have been shown to lower cost and quicken rehabilitation, for example.
What does all this mean? It means health reform will only work if it spurs innovation.
But, by reducing the rigorous competition that innovation requires, the Administration's proposal discourages this invaluable process. Under the proposal, health care will be overseen by yet another sclerotic Government bureaucracy, the National Health Board. There will be monopolistic regional purchasing alliances, which will trigger the rapid consolidation of payers and providers. These large provider-payer networks will reduce choice and competition among specialty-care providers, while deciding what treatments are covered, for whom and when. With a bias against covering anything new, these powerful entities will replace the diversity and experimentation that have long fueled innovation and maintained this country's leadership in the global pharmaceutical, biotechnology and medical-device industries.
To make matters worse, if prices are tightly controlled under reform, America's flow of innovation will slow to a trickle because the incentives needed for its huge investments will disappear. Schering-Plough spent $100 million for a plant to make alpha interferon when that drug was known only to help a rare cancer. Under price controls such an effort would not be made -- nor the discovery that the drug treats 15 other diseases.
THE Clinton proposal aims to compensate for these risks to innovation by continued Government financing of basic research. But private-sector investment in research and development of drugs and medical technologies dwarfs the budget of the National Institutes of Health, the principal Federal source of research funds. And if we deaden the incentives for private-sector investment, much of the Federal research will never be transformed from science into usable technology.
The challenge that confounds health care reformers is that although the United States has produced a breathtaking rate of advance in innovation, competition appears to have failed on another crucial dimension: cost. Incentives to keep costs down have been so skewed by regulation, insurance practices, limited information about quality and price and the natural price insensitivity of ill patients that the normal economic rules do not apply:
* Prices remain high in the face of excess capacity because, until recently, prices were set to cover full costs rather than meet competition.
* Technologies remain costly even when widely diffused because reimbursement has been based on customary charges, not costs.
* Hospitals and physicians who charge higher prices or fail to provide quality service are not forced out of business because quality is poorly understood and local hospitals have been preserved in spite of inefficiencies and underutilization. Instead, providers and payers compete on proficiency at "gaming" the system by cost-shifting, self-referral, "balance billing" of patients above insurers' agreed rates and creative denial of insurance claims.
In other words, the reformers are addressing a health care system that works well in one way but does not in another. Given this diagnosis, the prescription is a straightforward one. We must realign the skewed cost incentives -- the part that does not work well -- and preserve and protect the incentives for innovation -- the part that does work well.
To do this, reform must accomplish many tasks. It must promote competition by forcing insurers to make their money by finding good, low-cost providers, rather than by avoiding the payment of claims. It must be vigilant in enforcing antitrust laws to avoid overconsolidation of providers into a few powerful networks and Government agencies. It must also preserve choice by guarding against overextension of full-service provider networks; only through choice can the best providers emerge. And reform must permit lower-quality, inefficient providers to fail; only then will they be replaced by better ones.
But the first step in successful reform is to recognize the central importance of innovation. And no leading reform proposal -- not the Clinton plan, the Cooper plan, the Chafee-Dolan plan or the Canadian-style single-payer system -- understands this fact. Instead, they all severely limit choice and competition -- and thus innovation, the only long-term solution to our ills.

HEADLINE: Black Journeys: Many Travelers Along Many Roads

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT 

 BODY:
AS this year's version of the annual nod to black history draws to an end, it's hard to escape how often the well-intentioned focus on forgotten lives, legacies and achievements deteriorates into cliches: a nod to Harriet Tubman, Frederick Douglass and W. E. B. Du Bois, a bow to the Harlem Renaissance and the civil rights movement, then all are forgotten until next February.
Like all things rote, Black History Month misses the nuance and detail of real lives and undercuts the yeasty history of blacks in America. It makes seamless what is rich with curlicues and furbelows. 
 How strange was the antebellum life of Amanda America Dickson, the daughter of a white bachelor from Georgia who left her his fortune?
What moved Bessie Coleman, the young Texas woman who went to France to learn to fly and returned to barnstorm through the American Southwest in the 1920's?
Where are the nameless heros and heroines, the deviants from the flatbed of history, who brought black Americans to where they stand today? Unlike other immigrants, most blacks arrived in this country as slaves. But their history is not a simple list of events from chains to freedom. Like the history of the population at large, it is a history of movement. The circumstances of the movement, however, are often distorted by the laws, habits and racism that have defined their experience.
Patterns of black migration have often overlapped those of whites, particularly when whites were masters. Blacks have generally been drawn in the directions that offered them the most freedom and opportunity. Historically, that meant north and west.
Unlike those of European settlers, blacks' ancestral ties to their homelands were cut. So the Old South was a substitute homeland, the place from which their generations went forth in a fascinating migration, one shaped not only by traditional economic forces but by laws that shackled their hopes long after slavery.
 
The Ebbs and Flows
 Only recently has it been possible, with new data banks like that of the Inter-University Consortium for Political and Social Research, to follow the ebbs and flows of black migration.
For much of the 19th century, black migration was constrained -- legally for slaves, officially and by bigotry for free blacks. Still, there was movement. By 1860, Baltimore had more free blacks than any other city. Though Maryland was a slave state, Quakers had a moderating influence. The free blacks had schools, churches and benevolent societies, according to Dr. Bettye Collier-Thomas, a historian at Temple University.
For five years after the Civil War, the Federal Government provided some protection to the newly freed blacks. But after Reconstruction, Southern states reimposed Jim Crow restrictions. The oppression was so heavy that in 1879 many blacks began an exodus from Louisiana, Mississippi and Texas into Kansas and from North Carolina into Indiana.
The recession of 1890 put a stop to this migration, and Jim Crow laws mired blacks in the places that whites thought they should occupy. Blacks remained on the Plains, though in small numbers scattered through central Kansas, the Oklahoma Territory, West Texas, New Mexico, Arizona and the Dakotas.
By 1920, the Great Migration of peoples, black and white, from the South to the North had started. It began earlier for others, like my maternal grandfather, Harrison Streibling, who after a year at Norfolk Mission College left Staunton, Va., for France and World War I.
On his return, he joined the stream of laborers bound North, heading to the mines of Pennsylvania. He was a miner, steel worker, bricklayer, ice deliver, plasterer, awning installer. He scrabbled through a thicket of jobs on the kind of byways we all traveled as we found our way home.

GRAPHIC: Photos: An early daguerreotype of a slave taken in 1850. (Peabody Museum/Harvard University); Opportunities advertised to emancipated slaves, 1877. (Kansas State Historical Society); Proprietor of a restaurant in New Jersey, 1938. (Art Rothstein/Library of Congress); A family at home in affluent Mitchellville, Md., 1992. (Arthur Grace/Sygma)
 
Chart: "Steps in a March From Bondage Toward Home and Freedom"
 
Africans provided a free, seemingly inexhaustible labor supply that could not escape because its members were easily identified, according to the historian John Hope Franklin's work "From Slavery to Freedom." Once colonists realized this, they began importing slaves, and the vast majority of blacks arrived in the New World from Africa in chains. But not all. Africans accompanied Spanish and French explorers of the New World in the 16th century. An African named Estevanico explored New Mexico and Arizona for the Spanish.

The Civil War ended slavery for blacks, but by the late 1870's, another form of bondage emerged: sharecropping and Jim Crow laws. In some parts of the South, blacks who became known as "exodusters" looked northwest to Kansas to escape slavery's legacy.

The Great Migration to the North started emptying Southern fields shortly before the 1920's. There were boom times for some in the North. Within all-black neighborhoods, entrepreneurs thrived, running restaurants, barber shops, funeral homes and banks.

Segregation began to fall under legal attacks in the 1950's, and the reforms of the Great Society in the 1960's ended most legal -- if not actual -- segregation. Those blacks who were best prepared to take advantage of the new freedom moved from all-black neighborhoods and segregated school systems.

Urban Areas have become home to most Americans, including blacks. As some move to the suburbs, both segregated housing patterns and preference combine to create new black suburbs.

HEADLINE: Group of 7 Says Russia Must Do More to Get Aid

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KRONBERG, Germany, Feb. 26

 BODY:
Finance officials of the seven most powerful industrial nations agreed today that economic aid to Russia could continue as soon as it began credible measures to control inflation and budget deficits, but that Moscow still had much to do, Western officials said.
"We urged them to strengthen their efforts to bring inflation under control," Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said. "We told the Russians that a strong stabilization program is needed to trigger more support from the International Monetary Fund." 
 Finance Minister Theo Waigel of Germany said the Western countries had agreed to work with the Russian authorities on measures to help the population cope with the consequences of economic change -- unemployment from bankrupt state industries as they are sold off or closed down, for instance. But he added that the Russians would have to come up with most of the money for such measures themselves.
Two senior Russian officials, Finance Minister Sergei K. Dubinin and Economics Minister Aleksandr N. Shokhin, said they had pledged to bring monthly inflation down from 22 percent to 7 to 9 percent by the end of this year.
 
I.M.F. Talks Expected
 Mr. Dubinin also said he expected discussions to resume by mid-March between Moscow and the Monetary Fund about a second $1.5 billion loan to help Russia make the transition to a market economy.
Echoing the caution expressed by European officials at the meeting here, Mr. Bentsen said: "I hope they can make that. It will be a difficult target."
For the American delegation here, trade friction between the United States and Japan came close to overshadowing concern about Russia.
"We have continued to urge Japan to live up to its commitment to put in place a substantial and effective program to strengthen domestic demand, to reduce its large trade surplus, to open its markets," Mr. Bentsen said. "That is in the interest of all of Japan's trading partners and in the interest of Japan."
But a senior Treasury official said that "there was no breakthrough of any kind" before the Japanese left this evening.
 
Bentsen Wary on Yen
 Pressed on speculation that the United States would try to encourage the continued increase in the exchange-rate value of the Japanese yen to make Japanese products more expensive on United States and world markets, Mr. Bentsen refused to be drawn. "We believe in the fundamentals dictating exchange rates," he said.
Finance ministers and central bank chiefs of the United States, Germany, Japan, Britain, France, Italy, and Canada , known as the Group of Seven, met in a resort hotel in the hills north of Frankfurt that was built as a castle for the Queen of Prussia. The meeting followed a week of turmoil on international financial markets that has seen long-term interest rates rise steeply and the Japanese yen strengthen considerably against the dollar.
Some of the turmoil was caused by fears of inflation because of unexpectedly strong economic growth in the American economy while most of Europe except for Britain is still mired deep in recession, and some by tensions between the United States and Japan on trade issues.
Mr. Bentsen met his Japanese counterpart, Hirohisa Fujii, in the hotel this morning before the broader discussions began, but he made clear beforehand that he expected no breakthrough.
Originally, Mr. Waigel of Germany convened the gathering so representatives from the seven nations could hear reports from Russian officials about what would happen to plans by President Boris N. Yeltsin to move toward a market economy after the political backlash in last December's elections.
 
Little Money Delivered
 At their summit meeting in Japan last summer, leaders of the Group of Seven promised $28 billion to Russia in grants and loans, mainly through the International Monetary Fund and other international institutions, but made the assistance conditional on Russian steps to bring inflation and government deficit spending under control. Only a small amount of money has actually been delivered.
The fund had provided Russia with $2.5 billion in loans since 1992, but has held back on an additional $1.5 billion as Mr. Yeltsin's commitment to change has seemed to waver.
Before today's meeting, officials made clear that no additional Western assistance was under consideration, but that they would like to give the Russians assurances that previous commitments would be met if Moscow continued reform.
"Our response will be dictated by their behavior," a senior Treasury Department official said.
 
No Effect From Spying Seen
 American officials said they did not expect American assistance to be affected by accusations that a senior Central Intelligence Agency official had been a spy for the Soviet Union and, after its collapse, for the Russian Government.
Mr. Dubinin, Russia's Finance Minister, Mr. Shokhin, the Economics Minister, and the central bank chief, Viktor V. Gerashchenko, repeated earlier pledges by Mr. Yeltsin to keep moving ahead with privatization of state-owned industries and budget reforms, but not so fast as to suddenly throw millions of Russians out of work or into poverty.
Fears that change was proceeding too fast are thought to be the main reason for the strong showing of ultranationalist opponents of Mr. Yeltsin in the December parliamentary elections, when they won around a quarter of the total vote.
The latest Russian budget target is to reduce the deficit this year to about $30 billion, but only with Western aid and agreement to roll over much of the $80 billion foreign debt, and to reduce annual inflation to 400 percent.

HEADLINE: North Korea Grants Nuclear Inspectors Visas

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 26

 BODY:
In another example of the brinkmanship that has characterized the yearlong dispute over its nuclear ambitions, North Korea has avoided a possible trade embargo at the last hour by agreeing to open some of its nuclear installations to international inspectors.
North Korea gave its assent to the inspections late Friday, only hours before the start of a process that could have resulted in a trade blockade against the Communist country. 
 At the center of the dispute is the suspicion that the Government of Kim Il Sung is developing atomic weapons. The North Korean Government had refused to grant visas to inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency for an examination of seven sites. Today Pyongyang relented and granted the visas for the inspectors, who are to begin work Tuesday to determine if nuclear material has been diverted for possible military use.
The seven inspectors will leave Vienna for Pyongyang on Sunday, the agency said in a statement from Vienna.
Hans Blix, the head of the international energy agency, had warned North Korea that he would refer the dispute to the Security Council if the visas were not granted by Monday.
But the agreement reached Friday night does not resolve the Pyongyang Government's continuing refusal to let international inspectors visit two secret nuclear installations. The agency suspects that the two sites would yield evidence that North Korea is trying to build atomic weapons in breach of the pledge it made when it signed the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.
In Washington, President Clinton said he was "encouraged" by North Korea's decision to open the nuclear sites to inspection. The accord was reached after two days of talks between Thomas C. Hubbard, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, and Ho Jung, North Korea's Deputy Representative to the United Nations.
In return, the United States has agreed to suspend annual military exercises with South Korean forces. The United States will also hold a third round of high-level talks with North Korea in Geneva on improving relations, starting March 21.
North and South Korea are meanwhile to begin working-level talks on Tuesday with the goal of exchanging envoys, Administration officials said.
North and South Korea do not have diplomatic relations. The mission of the two envoys will be to put into force an agreement the two Koreas signed last December to forswear dangerous nuclear technologies, like reprocessing and enrichment, which have military applications.
At the conclusion of the talks late Friday, Mr. Hubbard described the accord as "only the first step toward the resolution of the nuclear issue."
"But we are pleased that these needed inspections will in fact begin" on Tuesday, he added.
Administration officials say the agreement means that North Korea has fallen back into step with the basic understanding it reached with the United States last December.
That understanding provided for a new round of high-level talks between the Clinton Administration and the North Korean Government on resolving nuclear issues and improving relations once North Korea had reopened its declared nuclear sites to inspectors and begun a dialogue with the South.
At the round of talks now scheduled to start in Geneva on March 21, the United States will offer to help end North Korea's international isolation by promoting trade and aid links and holding out the prospect of eventual diplomatic recognition for Pyongyang.
But in return, Administration officials say North Korea must allow the energy agency to visit the two secret nuclear sites it wants to inspect, abandon any covert nuclear weapons program it may have started and agree to switch over to technologies in its civil nuclear program that offer less scope for military misuse.
The regular inspections of North Korea's seven declared nuclear sites were broken off by Pyongyang just over a year ago after the International Atomic Energy Agency first found evidence that it was being deceived by North Korea.

HEADLINE: Incinerators Again Testing A New Mayor

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
During his campaign for mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani expressed skepticism about plans for two large incinerators in Brooklyn, saying New York City should focus on recycling instead. But a series of recent actions by the administration has worried opponents of incineration, who say they fear the plans will go forward.
The plans call for a new $450 million incinerator at the Brooklyn Navy Yard to handle 3,000 tons a day and for upgrading an unused, smaller plant in Bensonhurst. They have been promoted by previous administrations as vital to the city's efforts to end its reliance on the overflowing Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island. 
 But local opposition has left the projects mired in court fights, and when Mr. Giuliani met with neighborhood residents during the campaign, he pledged to work to increase recycling to alleviate concerns about both incinerators.
 
Concern Over Developments
 Opponents of the incinerators -- a diverse force that includes the Speaker of the State Assembly as well as community groups -- say they are concerned about these recent developments:
*Mr. Giuliani's decision to seek a state permit that would help clear the way for construction of the Navy Yard incinerator.
*The city's decision to submit a court brief opposing a lawsuit that seeks an environmental impact study for the Bensonhurst incinerator.
*The Mayor's plan to cut $5.7 million from the city's recycling funds.
*Mr. Giuliani's invitation to the City Council to revise its 1989 legislation on mandatory recycling and perhaps scale back its goals. The action follows a ruling last week by the state's highest court ordering the city to meet its own requirement that 25 percent of its waste be recycled.
Among those questioning the Giuliani administration's resolve is Sheldon Silver, the Manhattan Democrat who is the Speaker of the State Assembly. "It certainly does trouble me," he said. "It's clearly a change. It looks like perhaps all they want to do is go forward with incineration."
David N. Dinkins, who called for a moratorium on new incinerators during his 1989 mayoral campaign, nonetheless kept the Navy Yard project on track once he was in office. Officials in the Giuliani administration say they, too, do not want to close the door on the project.
Paul Crotty, the city's Corporation Counsel, said the Mayor regards incineration as a "last hope" that should be preserved only as "an insurance policy" in the event that recycling and other alternatives cannot adequately handle the city's waste problems.
Also, a letter on Friday from Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers to the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, said the administration was actively investigating plans to export wastes to other states.
The merits and perils of incineration as a waste disposal alternative have been debated for years. Proponents portray it as safe and cost-effective, saying it would relieve the city's dependence on the overtaxed Fresh Kills landfill, which is expected to be filled to capacity as early as the next decade. Opponents portray incineration as a health risk, particularly to the very young and the elderly, and assert that its economic appeal has not been established.
The opponents assert that the evidence of its dangers because of harmful pollutants has only been strengthened in the seven years since the city conducted its health-risk assessment for the Brooklyn Navy Yard project.
 
'Wise and Prudent Course'
 But members of Mr. Giuliani's administration said that the Mayor staked out a careful position of flexibility on incineration during the campaign last fall and that he has not altered it.
"We believe it is the wise and prudent course to retain incineration as a last option," said Mr. Crotty, who has advised the Mayor on the issue along with Emily Lloyd, the Sanitation Commissioner, who also served under Mr. Dinkins. "That's the policy the Mayor is going to go along with. Where will we be if in the year 2000 we haven't met recycling goals and our landfill has reached capacity? It's an insurance policy. And that doesn't mean the Mayor has backed off his position at all."
Opponents of the incinerators, while conceding that it is very early in Mr. Giuliani's administration to draw conclusions, have become increasingly suspicious of the Mayor's actions. They point to an Oct. 15 interview with a community newspaper in Brooklyn -- in which the Mayor said he would commit himself "to a massive recycling program so there isn't a need to build a new incinerator" -- and they ask what has happened.
"Follow the administration's reasoning, and you might as well build a nuclear power plant in the middle of Brooklyn just so you have another option," said Mark Green, the city's Public Advocate.
 
Seeking a Reassessment
 Much of the recent criticism of the Mayor's actions has centered on recycling. Mr. Crotty said the administration hoped to persuade the City Council to reassess "what's physically realistic and fundable" and rewrite the 1989 recycling law, perhaps scaling back its targets.
Incinerator opponents accuse the Mayor of trying to maintain the status quo, both with regard to the level of recycling and the building of the incinerator.
"It's disturbing because what his actions of late indicate is that his position is no different from the previous administration on how it is going to handle the waste problem," said Larry Shapiro, a lawyer with the New York Public Interest Research Group. "They are the same tracks going in the same direction toward the same destination."
 
Lawsuits, Votes and Protests
 The course of the debate is a long and complicated one. There have been numerous lawsuits, and as many appeals. Administrations have come and gone, permits have been issued and then revoked, votes have been taken and protests have been staged.
At the moment, the State Department of Environmental Conservation will make the next rulings of consequence. A decision on whether the city, under a plan submitted in the final week of the Dinkins administration, has met the state's pollution requirements for the Navy Yard incinerator is expected on Wednesday. The department is also expected to rule on the city's appeal of a ruling requiring extensive air quality hearings for the Bensonhurst incinerator.
No one -- not opponents, not proponents, not the city's Corporation Counsel -- expects anything but more litigation and more contesting of additional permits to follow. Start of construction of the Navy Yard incinerator before 1996 is considered inconceivable by everyone.
"I think the Mayor is going to go for the incinerator, and that everything else is a snow job," said Rosie Baerga, a leader of the Community Alliance for the Environment in Williamsburg. "O.K., fine. Be that way. But the Hasidim, the Poles, the Italians, the African-Americans, the Hispanics, we are not going to be quiet."
Mr. Silver, the Assembly Speaker, whose Lower East Side district is across the East River from the Brooklyn Navy Yard, cautioned the Mayor against hasty decisions on the matter.
"They appear to be making a decision six or seven weeks into their administration that could affect an awful lot of people," Mr. Silver said. "And that can't be right."

HEADLINE: Business and Universities as Partners

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
More and more college and university presidents, like City University's chancellor, serve as paid members of corporate boards of directors, as American companies seek to build bridges to higher education.
A recent survey of 1,000 heads of colleges and universities showed that about 10 percent reported corporate membership, with many serving on one to three corporations. But the City University chancellor, W. Ann Reynolds, who serves on five (she has said she intends to resign from one in April), faced criticism last week that her outside activities took her out of town too often. 
 Last year, in addition to her salary of $158,000, she earned $140,000 from this work.
Last Tuesday the City University's trustees adopted a resolution requiring the chancellor and other top university officials to make known any income they earned from sources other than their university jobs and to account for the time that they spend on business unrelated to CUNY.
The survey of heads of colleges and universities, by the College and University Personnel Association, an academic service organization, shows that 104 of the 1,000 academic chiefs who responded said they derived at least some income from paid corporate directorships, according to the organization's executive director, Richard C. Creal.
 
'A Definite Trend'
 "There's a definite trend for corporations to seek out academic leaders to serve on their boards," said Tom Ingram, president of the Association of Governing Boards of Universities and Colleges, a nonprofit service organization. "That's because of a great awareness that the future of the economy is tied to higher education and that a variety of partnerships can develop."
Such membership helps both colleges and corporations, according to Robert H. Atwell, president of the American Council on Education, which represents 1,600 colleges and universities.
"They need to be out there in the larger society in order to be effective leaders," he said.
"They can also learn a great deal from such involvement as when we recently brought together 40 C.E.O.'s with an equal number of college and university presidents, and they discussed what can be learned from corporations that have had to reduce their size."
While some institutions, like the City University, limit the outside activities of their presidents or chancellors, it is difficult to set firm guidelines on such activities, Mr. Atwell said. "Some corporations," he said, "ask board members to attend only two or three meetings a year whereas others require a great deal more than that."
 
Questions of Time and Propriety
 But from the corporation's point of view, such service should be limited, according to John Nash, president of the National Association of Corporate Directors, a service organization. "I can't see how an active executive gives the necessary time or commitment to his work in today's environment if he sits on the boards of more than three outside corporations," Mr. Nash said.
And some question the propriety of any corporate membership. The executive director of a Ralph Nader organization, the National Coalition for Universities in the Public Interest, condemns the practice as "an unholy alliance between business and the university because it compromises the integrity of the academic institution."
"What Chancellor Reynolds has done is both normal and improper," said the executive director, Leonard Minsky. "Suppose you have a university laboratory working on a way to control environmental damage and then the president of that university serves on the board of a corporation that is causing that damage. Isn't that a serious conflict of purpose? The search for truth and the search for profit are incompatible."
Among those who choose not to serve on corporate boards are L. Jay Oliva, the president of New York University, and D. Bruce Johnstone, who retired last week as chancellor of the State University of New York. In the past Mr. Johnstone served as a director of Key Bank.
 
From Pensions to Chemicals
 Of those who do serve on corporate boards, Jack Peltason, the president of the University of California, serves on the boards of three corporations engaged in a range of activities, from pensions and insurance to computer hardware.
Randolph W. Bromery, the president of Springfield College, a private four-year school in Massachusetts, serves on five boards: Exxon Corporation, Chemical Banking Corporation, Chemical Bank, the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company and Nynex.
Harold T. Shapiro, the president of Princeton University, is on the board of the Dow Chemical Company.
Dr. Reynolds said she felt a special mission as one of the few women in high academic posts to serve on boards, in part to urge better treatment of women in hiring and promotion, salary and training.
A steadily increasing number of corporate directors are women, although the overall percentage of board seats held by women remains small. According to a study released last fall by Catalyst, a Washington-based nonprofit research and advisory service concerned with women's issues, there were 46 women on the boards of leading American corporations in 1977. Today the number has increased to 500. But of the 11,715 present seats on the boards of top corporations companies, only 721, or 6.2 percent, are occupied by women.
Forty-nine percent of these directors said their professional experience was in the field of education.

HEADLINE: Whitman Seeks Tax Plan Beyond State's Borders

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 24

 BODY:
When the New Jersey Assembly takes up the first round of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposed income-tax cuts on Monday, many members of the Republican majority will support the cuts in the belief that they are following in the footsteps of Republican tax cutters in Massachusetts, Michigan and Delaware.
During her campaign for governor and since her election, Mrs. Whitman repeatedly held up the actions of Republican administrations in those states as examples of how bold tax cuts have begun to pay off with revived economies, just as the Governor believes that her tax cut will help New Jersey. 
Yet the parallels between Governor Whitman's plan and the actions of Governor John Engler of Michigan, Pete du Pont and later John Castle of Delaware, and William Weld of Massachusetts are in many ways tenuous. Only in Delaware were income taxes cut as sharply as Mrs. Whitman is proposing, and they were cut as Delaware's economy was expanding so rapidly that the cuts resulted in no loss of revenue to the state.
New Jersey's economy is still struggling, in contrast, and the 5 percent income-tax cut the Assembly is all but certain to pass on Monday will produce an immediate loss of $200 million in revenue once it is enacted. The State Senate is scheduled to take up the tax cuts on Thursday.
 
A Painful Solution
 In Massachusetts and Michigan, Governors Weld and Engler did what Governor Whitman has so far chosen not to do: endure the political pain of first cutting spending to eliminate looming deficits and then trimming taxes at the margins if at all.
"There is no comparison between what Whitman is proposing for New Jersey and what happened in Michigan and Massachusetts," said Steven Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States at the Rockefeller Institute in Albany.
"Maybe Delaware is an example, because they did cut income taxes," Mr. Gold went on. "But Weld and Engler deserve their anti-tax reputations not because they cut taxes a lot, but because they resisted the forces to raise taxes. What Governor Whitman is doing is a very large actual cut, one that is much larger than anything that has occurred in Massachusetts or Michigan."
 
Lower Taxes, More Growth?
 The available evidence so far casts doubt on Mrs. Whitman's supply-side argument that lower taxes produce economic growth. Michigan is enjoying a moderately strong recovery that may be benefiting from Mr. Engler's initiatives, but Massachusetts, three years after Mr. Weld took office, is still in the doldrums, and the boom that paid for Delaware's tax cuts a decade ago has faded.
Though some New Jersey Republicans often cite the party's successes in Massachusetts, in reality the 5 percent cut in the income-tax rate that Mr. Weld often takes credit for was enacted before he took office but did not take effect until after he was sworn in.
Mr. Weld did repeal a business sales tax that had not yet taken effect, and, along with Governor Engler, he cut inheritance taxes; both governors have also enacted some investment-tax credits, though both states have increased cigarette and liquor taxes.
Delaware's top income-tax rate was reduced over six years from 19.8 percent before the first cuts in 1979, the highest in the country, to 7.7 percent in 1988, which is close to the top rates of Delaware's neighbors.
However, in 1982 Delaware deregulated its banking industry, causing bank holding companies to rush into the state, rebuilding Wilmington's skyline and resulting in such an influx of jobs and investment that income-tax receipts remained constant even as the income-tax rate was cut by nearly two-thirds.
"The tax cuts were certainly helpful to the state economy, but they also came at a time when the national economy was strong and the Delaware economy was doing better than the national," said Michael Ferguson, the state budget director, who was also budget director under former Governor Castle. "But clearly corporations don't want to be in a state that has the highest income-tax rate in the country."
 
Spending Plan to Be Unveiled
 Governor Whitman has said she would reveal her spending plan on March 15. At that time state lawmakers will get their first glimpse at how she plans to absorb the loss of $1.4 billion over three years, which is the estimated price of her promise to reduce the state's income tax by 30 percent over that period. In addition to the cuts, the Governor must also close a projected built-in deficit of more than $1 billion starting July 1.
From the outset, however, lawmakers have worried that the loss of tax revenue will force cuts in state aid to school districts, municipalities, universities and transportation. Those concerns are borne out in Massachusetts, where Governor Weld's budget cuts forced a reduction in state aid to municipalities and schools from $2.88 billion in 1990 to $2.33 billion in 1992, Mr. Weld's first budget. That figure has since increased, to $2.96 billion, while aid to higher education has dropped by a third and tuition at public colleges has doubled.
In Michigan, Governor Engler closed mental hospitals, took 82,000 childless, able-bodied adults off welfare rolls and closed entire state departments to eliminate a $1.8 billion deficit that he inherited. He also made many enemies along the way.
"The first two years were just brutal," said John Truscott, Mr. Engler's spokesman. And State Representative Maxine Berman, a Democrat from Southfield, remains harshly critical.
 
Tax Cut vs. Spending Cut
 "The Governor has not cut taxes; we have cut spending in a very, very painful way," Ms. Berman said. "So if Governor Engler is to be an example of how you cut budgets, then there are going to be many, many people in New Jersey who are going to be in as much difficulty as a lot of people in Michigan are."
Yet Mr. Engler and Mr. Weld are both widely popular in their states, as was Mr. Castle when he left the Delaware governorship in 1992. In the end, Governor Engler said in an interview, voters remember chief executives who make difficult decisions, and he said he had given some advice to the New Jersey Governor.
"I told Christie that she is absolutely on the right track, because she's making the right decisions even if they are tough decisions," Mr. Engler said. "What's important in all this is that these decisions pass the test of time, and I absolutely support her in what she's doing, even if it means that New Jersey will end up being a tougher competitor for Michigan after she gets this done."
The cornerstone of Governor Whitman's tax-cut program has always been her supply-side belief that reducing the tax burden will spur New Jersey's economic growth. Yet in Michigan, Massachusetts and Delaware, the evidence on that front is not clear. Private employment in Michigan grew by 1.7 percent from June 1990 to June of last year, giving it a rank in the middle of the states, at No. 25, in growth over that period.
Governor Engler hastens to take credit for the growth in jobs, and while the giant auto companies account for part of the resurgence, a lot of growth in the state has indeed occurred in small businesses of the kind Mr. Engler hoped to help by avoiding tax increases and providing businesses with incentives to grow.
Mr. Weld's Massachusetts, however, shows scant signs of recovery and ranks 47th nationally to New Jersey's 46th in job creation over the same period. Delaware is doing only slightly better and ranks 34th nationally.

HEADLINE: Rage in a Village in Mexico Where Land Is Life

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: EL CARRIZAL, Mexico

 BODY:
It is a possession so precious that it is hidden deep in the woods. When it is needed an elder member of this communal farm in the state of Chiapas gallops away on a white horse, returning half an hour later with a portfolio. Inside are the yellowed papers the Indian peasants of El Carrizal filed on April 7, 1983, to formally demand possession of the land on which they and their forebears had worked in virtual slavery since the turn of the century.
All over Chiapas there are groups of poor farmers like those in El Carrizal who have had faith in Mexico's singular system of land redistribution but have not obtained what they wanted. Their frustration, anger and feeling of betrayal are held in common by the members of the Zapatista National Liberation Army, which attacked several cities on Jan. 1 and demands, among other things, the land that for them means life. 
 What the 45 Tzeltal Indian families of El Carrizal did in 1983 was a classic Mexican land taking, the kind outlined in the 1910 revolution that pits peons against the powerful ranchers for whom they worked. It also helps explain the current revolt in Chiapas, where Indian demands to own land have been ignored so routinely that resentment has turned to rage.
 
Behind the Anger
 The reasons for such anger are apparent. Almost 11 years after they gathered up their courage and legally claimed their land, the families in El Carrizal still have not received the response guaranteed in Mexico's Constitution. So with the rights they assume are inherent in their treasured 1983 papers, they simply took over the land from its private owner.
They have built 30 houses, two schools, a church and a basketball court. Three times already pistoleros hired by the former owner have tried to destroy the settlement, forcing the people to hide in the mountains. Three times they have come back to start again, clutching their treasured legal papers.
"For a long time now the Government has kept telling us we will get our declaration, but it never happens," said Pablo Gomez Vasquez, a stocky 35-year-old whose parents and grandparents are buried in simple graves, with pine boughs as headstones, on the land for which he is fighting.
As is the way with many Indian communities here, he was designated to relate El Carrizal's history, and no one else would be identified. "The Government says 'Respect the law,' " he said, "but how are we going to respect the law if the law doesn't respect us?"
 
No More Redistribution
 Specifically, the farmers in Chiapas have asked for the repeal of a recent constitutional amendment that effectively ended the land giveaways that started in 1915. In one of the most significant moves of the administration of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, the Government in 1992 gave peasants the right to sell their land, but said no more land would be given away because practically none was left to give. The 28,000 community farms owned by more than three million peasants already occupy more than half of Mexico's arable land.
Furthermore, Government economists said, giving away small, unproductive parcels of land practically guarantees that the poor will remain poor forever. Most peasant farmers do not use any modern technology, not even fertilizers, and do not have access to the capital needed to buy equipment or supplies.
[At the peace talks that have begun in Chiapas, rebel leaders have thrown those arguments back at the officials who made them, claiming that redistribution of the land by itself is not enough. They argue now for productive land and the technology to keep it that way, for roads to get produce to market and for a commitment to make peasant farming worthwhile.]
The heart of the matter remains the land itself. For Indians here, descendants of the Maya people, land is the source of life. Broken Government promises to deliver land are considered sufficient cause for taking up arms.
"When the people saw that their requests were never being respected it created an enormous discontent here," said the Rev. Pablo Romo, a Roman Catholic priest who is director of the Fray Bartolome Center for Human Rights in San Cristobal de las Casas. "This is a fundamental part of the current conflict."
The 1910 revolution promised to break up big haciendas and redistribute the land to landless peasants. But the concept never really took hold in Chiapas because of the state's remoteness and the political strength of the gentry.
 
Peasants Without Land
 "The revolution just didn't happen here," said Ronald B. Nigh, an anthropologist at the Center of Investigations and Advanced Studies in Social Anthropology, a Government research institution in San Cristobal. "What you have is really a prerevolutionary situation where all the best land is in the hands of the ranchers, even though they deny it, and the peasants who work there have no land at all."
But the poor of Chiapas still cling to the belief that someday they will have land. They have filed their petitions with the federal bureaucracy responsible for giving out land, and they have waited. Even today, though the giveaway technically has ended, the Government still has to process thousands of backlogged demands, like the one from El Carrizal.
Three years ago, before the constitutional changes, there were 25,000 unresolved land claims in Mexico. That has been reduced to 3,000, mainly by refusing the claims.
It is generally believed to be too early to tell how the new regulations have affected Mexico. There has not been any great wave of peasants selling their land, nor have the old haciendas returned. But agriculture officials say outside investors have expressed interest in buying or renting the best peasant land, although only a handful of deals have yet been negotiated.
The land on which El Carrizal's residents grow corn, beans and coffee once belonged to a huge ranch called San Rafael, about 40 miles from San Cristobal. Mr. Gomez Vasquez's father and grandfather worked for the same man, Manuel Lievano Dominguez, in conditions close to slavery. They gave three work days a week without pay to cover the rent on a tiny plot of land on which they could grow their own food. The owners took a share of whatever they produced: corn, beans, eggs, sugar cane.
 
The Peasants Organize
 Hearing a rumor in 1983 that the ranch might be sold, the peasants organized themselves with the help of a group called the Emiliano Zapata Campesino Organization. Some people believe that an offshoot of the group was the nucleus for the Zapatista Army.
Over the last 80 years, the process for making land claims has evolved from revolution to bureaucracy. The original solicitation is in some ways the most important legal step.
On a brilliant sunny afternoon, Mr. Gomez Vasquez took the original document from the portfolio and handling it as delicately as a holy book showed a visitor what it said. Just one long sheet of coarse paper, typed in single-space by some public writer, the document is a manifesto of peasant rights.
"If we ask for the rights to this property," it said, "it is because in it we have left on it our lives, working from 5 in the morning until 7 at night; we have enriched our patrons. They do not need their property, while we, we need it to live."
The demand was rejected outright. The community tried again in July 1985, but when a month passed without any answer they decided to simply do what they felt they had the right to do. They stopped working on the ranch and moved to their own spot on a high mountain plateau.
Mr. Gomez Vasquez says, and research by the Fray Bartolome Center for Human Rights confirms, that a series of repressions began then that would continue until the present: late night raids, beatings, unjustified jailings. The community was burned to the ground once, and hired thugs accompanied by police officers stole everything, including every machete.
 
A Shared Struggle
 The people struggled on in fear. That was when they first hid their papers, worried that in another raid all would truly be lost. Their anger grew as their poverty deepened, and they were preparing for another raid on Jan. 1, this time supported by the peasants in a nearby community who strongly support the governing party.
"Thanks to the Zapatistas, that didn't happen," Mr. Gomez Vasquez said. Although they fly white flags of peace atop two poles near their basketball court, which forms a kind of civic square, the men of El Carrizal say they have no fear of the Zapatistas.
"We share the same struggle, the same goals," Mr. Gomez Vasquez said, returning from a visit to the grave of his parents. "Their way is different from our own, but that is not to say that we are against it. It's just that it's different. Someday, who knows, maybe we will join with them."
In the afternoon, after the men return from the fields and the women are busy preparing the evening meal, a kind of assembly occurs at El Carrizal. The men sit on two benches made from tree trunks. These people do not vote in regular elections (it costs 50 cents to take the bus into town and it is just not worth it they say) but here all decisions are made democratically.
This day they discussed the land conflict, again. The Government has offered 272 hectares, or 670 acres, just 20 percent of their request. It has also offered rough land in another part of the state, far from the graves of the ancestors. Both offers have been rejected.
 
'Nobody Has Anything'
 Those who want to speak leave the bench and sit on a rough white rock or stand at the other end of the parallel rows, their hats at their feet.
One old man in a ragged knit shirt placed his hat on the ground. "If the newspapers all say that Mexico is at peace, that everyone now is happy because the fighting is over, they are wrong," he said. "Companions, it is true that in Mexico we are almost all equal. But what is equality here? It is that nobody has anything."
He apologized to his friends for the holes in his pants, and to a visitor for the roughness of his Spanish. "If the Government doesn't give us our land claim, then we'll keep on fighting," he said.
How long will it be before they are forced to do more, perhaps to take up arms?
"The only answer to that," he said, "is that there are no arms here now."
If there were, he said, things would be different.

Pablo Gomez Vasquez held them as he told of the villagers' struggle. (Photographs by Damian Douarganes/Associated Press for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Haitians, Thwarted at Sea, Look for a Back Door

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 26

 BODY:
With the United States Coast Guard still repatriating Haitians picked up in boats trying to flee to Florida, many Haitians are increasingly choosing other routes and methods in their attempt to escape, diplomats and human rights officials say.
With the political repression and economic hardship still severe, many Haitians are determined to leave. Four boatloads of Haitian refugees have been picked up at sea north of Haiti since Feb. 4, the most in a single month since military leaders refused to resign to allow the return of Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. 
 But diplomats and rights officials say the risk of repatriation has led many Haitians to explore alternative routes to flee the Caribbean country. One new trend has been a rise in the number of Haitians trying to reach the Turks and Caicos Islands aboard freighters and sailing vessels.
Sometimes ill-prepared, sometimes carrying false travel and identification papers, those migrants try and pass themselves off as crew members on boats that regularly ply their trade between Haiti and the British-owned islands, diplomats said. If they can get past the United States Coast Guard and reach land, they can try to island-hop up the Bahamas, and embark on regularly scheduled voyages to Florida.
"It's either more widely used, or just discovered," Cmdr. Dave Breuninger of the Coast Guard said of the new route. Reliable estimates of the number of Haitians using that strategy were unavailable.
Anne Fuller, associate director of the National Coalition for Haitian Refugees, said that many Haitians appear to have realized that their chances of making it to Florida from Haiti on wooden boats are far outweighed by the risk of drowning or repatriation.
"I think people are afraid of spending several hundred dollars and losing it all," Ms. Fuller said. "They are afraid of not knowing whether local authorities will put them in jail. Most people know they're not going to get through, so they don't try."
Less than 1,000 boat people have been returned to Haiti since the United States order to forcibly repatriate Haitians went into effect in January 1993, compared with well over 30,000 who were returned in the 16 months following the September 1991 military coup against Father Aristide.
Another alternative increasingly chosen by Haitians seeking to escape is to slip over the border to the Dominican Republic, which shares the island of Hispaniola with Haiti, and find work in sugar-cane fields or make their way to Santo Domingo, the capital.

HEADLINE: Investment Service Reduces Troy's Rating

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TROY, N.Y., Feb. 26

 BODY:
The City of Troy, which continues to struggle with a four-year-old financial crisis, had its credit rating reduced below investment grade on Friday by Moody's Investors Service.
Moody's said it had cut Troy's credit rating from B-aa to B-a, one step below investment grade, in response to what it called the "ongoing deterioration" of the city's finances. 
 Any bonds ranked B-a or below are considered junk bonds. The lower rating means fewer investors will buy Troy's bonds, and the city may have to pay higher interest rates to attract investors to those bonds.
The city, just northeast of Albany, ended the 1993 fiscal year with an estimated general fund deficit of $4.5 million, the company said.
The Interim City Manager, John H. Clinton, whose last day in office was Friday, has warned that the city's deficit could run as high as $17 million by the end of 1994.
The city's failure to budget money to repay a $35.1 million mortgage taken in 1992, high overtime costs for the police and fire departments, a shortfall caused by the shutdown of the city landfill and an overestimate in a past surplus have contributed to Troy's problems, Moody's said.
Utica and Lackawanna are the only two other cities in the state rated B-a by Moody's.
