HEADLINE: Boroughs Squabble Over Building Project

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26

 BODY:
Last summer, Representative Floyd H. Flake managed to slip a stipulation into a Federal appropriations bill to build a new regional headquarters for the Food and Drug Administration -- but only on a parking lot at York College in Jamaica, Queens. Since that just happens to be in his district, he thought he had sealed a good deal for his constituents in one of the city's more depressed areas.
Instead, Mr. Flake's legislative legerdemain -- in alliance with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan -- opened a free-for-all that has tied up approval of the $180 million project altogether. It would be the F.D.A.'s biggest laboratory outside its national headquarters in Maryland, testing bales of food, pharmaceuticals and cosmetics, including samples from the tons of foreign goods that arrive each year at Kennedy International Airport. 
 There are a few catches:
Brooklyn, current home to the F.D.A.'s regional laboratory, claims it was robbed -- in part because it did not have a member on the House Appropriations Committee at the time and did not spot Mr. Flake's move.
Representative Susan Molinari of Staten Island says she would be happy to step into the breach by luring the lab and its 300 jobs to the site of the soon-to-be-closed Navy Homeport there, and even New Jersey has pricked up its ears.
And the City University, which as York College's parent would have to approve any deal, is balking -- over what academic benefits would be gained, and over how to replace the 275 parking spaces that would be lost.
"CUNY has got a bunch of bureaucrats who are trying to negotiate parking spots out of the Federal Government and holding up my project," said the Queens Borough President, Claire Shulman. "This is crazy. I'm going to have a heart attack."
The fight is not quite that simple, but it is a classic example of why getting things done can be so complicated in New York, where local bureaucracies rival the Federal one for complexity, and where more than a dozen members of Congress compete for Federal largess in a geographical area that in most parts of the nation would not have enough people to support a single member.
The tussling has produced a blizzard of snippy letters, and CUNY has hired a distinguished nutrition scientist, Dr. Louis Lasagna, the dean of academic affairs for the Tufts University Medical School in Boston, to review the deal on its behalf.
"There's a great deal of interest in this," said Jay Hershenson, CUNY's vice chancellor for university relations. "It's real clear that CUNY is going through a series of reviews here that indicate that this being taken very seriously."
It seems equally clear that CUNY is doing all it can to hold out for the best deal on a project that it never solicited in the first place and that was basically imposed on it by Mr. Flake. The 175,000-square-foot building -- which under Mr. Flake's legislation would be privately built and leased by the F.D.A. for 20 years at not more that $7.8 million a year -- has not even been designed yet, and construction would not begin for at least two years. The subject is on the university board's agenda for its meeting next month, and Ms. Shulman said the chairman, James P. Murphy, has promised action.
Meanwhile, the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, has seized on the delay to make his own pitch for finding a new site in Brooklyn for the headquarters, which for years has been on Third Avenue along the Brooklyn waterfront in Sunset Park, once a major port of entry for the products it tested.
 
'This Is an Outrage'
 "It's a very sensitive thing with me, because I think this is an outrage," said Mr. Golden, who has long had little to do with Senator Moynihan and is furious at Mr. Flake. "I'd like to know how a member of Queens can introduce a committee resolution, how he can take something away from people in Brooklyn, from a needy, interracial neighborhood. He's not creating jobs in Queens, he's stealing jobs from Brooklyn."
Mr. Moynihan's press secretary, Brian Connolly, said the Senator had not been trying to favor one borough over another, only to replace the agency's outdated and decrepit headquarters. "There was a very impressive proposal prepared by Congressman Flake, and they needed a new place," he said.
Mr. Flake's spokesman, Marshall Mitchell, said the Congressman has long sought to make Jamaica a hub for Federal offices (a local Social Security office is already there) in hopes of spurring economic revitalization, that York has always been a centerpiece of such efforts and that "nobody really pushed hard for it to be in Brooklyn."
 
Battling Boroughs
 Or as Ms. Shulman's counsel, Nicholas G. Garaufis, put it: "It's not like we tried to shanghai this at the last minute; we've been trying to shanghai it for years."
Ms. Shulman said Brooklyn already had many Federal projects, including courthouses and offices.
"The F.D.A. wants to come to Queens, and wants to come to York, and Howie has had a lot of wonderful things in Brooklyn," she said. "He should really keep his cotton-picking hands off my project."
The F.D.A. referred all inquiries about the project to the New York regional office of the General Services Administration, whose spokeswoman, Renee Miscione, would only say, "We're following a Congressional mandate on the project to effect an agreement with York College, and we're trying to do that."
But Ms. Shulman has worried that the F.D.A. would lose patience, and perhaps seek Congressional approval for another site, so she has tried to meet the university's objections one by one. She found an underused municipal parking garage on Archer Avenue, three blocks from the college site, that could lease 200 parking spaces, and has promised to provide city capital budget funds to pave a nearby vacant city lot to create 75 more.
Other questions may be stickier, including how to create still more parking spaces that the university wants, and also how to justify turning over land controlled by the State Dormitory Authority to a Federal agency that would use it for purposes only indirectly related to the academic mission of York College, which has about 7,000 students, many of them older working adults. The college's long-term plan calls for eventually building a student union that could have gone on the proposed F.D.A. site.
 
What About York?
 Under state law, said Mr. Hershenson, the CUNY spokesman, such land must be used for purposes related to the college. At its other labs, including the existing one in Brooklyn, the F.D.A. has various arrangements with academic institutions for student internships and faculty research projects, and presumably would continue them at York. But university officials have expressed concern that the F.D.A.'s applied research would not necessarily jibe with York's science faculty's needs, especially since the college does not even have a graduate school, and that in any case the agency could not devote enough time or equipment to the college to justify surrendering the land.
"The F.D.A. has indicated in writing that it is interested in pursuing such issues, and we have asked for greater specificity," Mr. Hershenson said. "We have to look out for the interests of our students and faculty."
Mr. Golden has raised a host of other objections, including concerns that the Queens site is not properly zoned for laboratory use, though he concedes the Federal Government could probably override that.
But Ms. Shulman said she refuses to entertain defeat.
"We're not going to let that happen," she said. "I mean, we'd be the laughingstock of the universe if we lost it. It's a miracle."

HEADLINE: The Woodstock Nation Meets the 90's;
Warily Revisiting a Cultural Icon, for Peace, Love and Profits

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAUGERTIES, N.Y.

 BODY:
Dick Wrolsen wasn't at the first Woodstock festival 25 years ago. But he said he had seen enough on television to know that its anniversary should not be celebrated this summer, as planned, here in the quiet town where he has lived for all his 61 years.
"You can expect to see urination, defecation and fornication on private property," Mr. Wrolsen, a retired employee of International Business Machines Corporation, said over coffee recently. "For the safety and welfare of the community at large, I believe the festival should not take place." 
 Bubbling up from the music and mud of the first Woodstock festival is a stew of fears, but also dreams, about how the concert's 25th anniversary might affect life in a pair of upstate towns. Not one but two commemorative concerts are scheduled for the weekend of Aug. 12: in Saugerties, an understated Hudson River community about 100 miles north of New York City, and in Bethel, the Catskill resort town that was host to the original. (In 1994, as in 1969, the town of Woodstock itself has lent its name but little else.) The promoters planning the concert in Saugerties have the rights to the world-famous name and envision 250,000 young people camped out for a marathon "Woodstock '94" rock festival on a 400-acre farm on Route 212.
 
'Woodstock' vs. 'Bethel'
 Their rivals have the farm where it really all began, Max Yasgur's in Bethel, about 50 miles southeast of here. But their musical extravaganza, which they hope will draw as many as 80,000 people, must settle for the name "Bethel '94."
Some residents in the two communities agree with Mr. Wrolsen that crowding that many people into such small towns -- Saugerties has a year-round population of 20,000; Bethel, 4,100 -- could lead only to trouble. But others, including Jim Griffis, 56, the Town Supervisor of Saugerties, believe that a concert that once symbolized peace and love has evolved into a powerful engine of economic development -- something that could draw tourists from around the world to an area that has endured economic hard times in recent years. For months, officials in Saugerties and Bethel, as well as on the county and state levels, have been consumed by heated discussions on whether to allow the concerts at all.
So far, the two municipalities have granted the promoters only preliminary approval, pending a host of reviews to determine, among other things, how traffic would be affected, where concertgoers would spend the night and whether the security of residents could be assured.
 
Can They Pull Them Off?
 Still, plans for the two concerts appear further along than past efforts to commemorate the Woodstock anniversary, which ultimately fell flat.
The promoter behind the Saugerties concert is Woodstock Ventures, which staged the original Woodstock concert in Bethel in 1969. Unable to reach agreement with Bethel officials this time around, Michael Lang and his two partners in Woodstock Ventures came to this community about 15 miles northeast of the town of Woodstock.
Mr. Lang, now 49, says the residents of Saugerties should put whatever fears they have to rest. This summer's concert, he said, would bear little resemblance to its 1969 namesake, where more than 350,000 people turned miles of rural roads into an impromptu parking lot and danced in the rain, at times with the aid of drugs, to the sounds of Jimi Hendrix, The Who and Sly and the Family Stone.
For one thing, Mr. Lang said, a private security force of at least 800 would insure that drugs and alcohol would be prohibited. Ticket holders -- who would pay about $100 each for the weekend -- would be shuttled to the site on 800 buses that would originate from at least 14 parking lots around the Hudson Valley. Mr. Lang, who intends the target audience to be between 18 and 27 years old, said he expected most of the attendees would spend the night camping out on the farm.
 
$20 Million Venture
 Mr. Lang declined to comment on which musical acts, if any, he had signed to perform. But he said the venture, which is expected to cost $20 million, was being financially backed by Polygram N.V., a $4 billion entertainment company whose recording artists include U2, Sting and Bon Jovi. There was no immediate indication, however, that any of those performers would appear at Woodstock '94. A Polygram spokeswoman, Patricia Kiel, said the company would not comment on whether it had an agreement with Mr. Lang until after the company's annual results were announced on Feb. 28.
While saying that the concert, if successful, could be very good for the town -- indeed, Saugerties stands to collect $4 per ticket, a potential windfall of $1 million -- Mr. Griffis, the Town Supervisor, said officials were cautiously examining every aspect of Mr. Lang's proposal.
"It's my responsibility," Mr. Griffis said, "to make sure whatever does happen is properly planned and properly carried out and that the people and their property are properly protected."
The concert in Bethel is being promoted by Sid Bernstein, who is credited with first bringing the Beatles to the United States in 1964. Although the Bethel town board, by a 3-to-2 margin, gave preliminary approval to Mr. Bernstein's proposal over the plans of a rival, he has been dogged by allegations that his financial backing for the concert, to cost an estimated $10 million, is shaky.
 
Who's Backing Bernstein?
 At issue is a report prepared by a fraud investigator, at the behest of several residents who live near the Bethel site, contending that one of the backers Mr. Bernstein presented to the town, a Pennsylvania real-estate company, could not be located, while another, a North Carolina cellular-telephone company, denied any involvement in the venture.
Mr. Bernstein said that the corporate names in question had been provided to the town by his partners, not by him, and that he was working to secure major backing from "a world-famous soft-drink company," which he would not name, and from Stephen Friedman, one of the co-producers of the Broadway musical "Annie." Mr. Friedman, a longtime friend of Mr. Bernstein, said such discussions were "very premature."
Thomas J. Bowes, a senior vice president at Prudential Securities in Manhattan whose Bethel home is one-eighth of a mile from the proposed concert site, said that questions about Mr. Bernstein's financial condition have made him wonder how safe his family would be if the event draws the 80,000 people that the promoter hopes for.
"How secure can I feel as a homeowner that the security will be proper and that the whole event will be controlled, rather than just in total disarray?" Mr. Bowes said.
Mr. Bernstein -- who said he had signed the folk singer Richie Havens, an original Woodstock performer, to play at the Bethel concert -- said the townspeople will "have to buy my word" that he can pull it off. At the town's request, Mr. Bernstein's plans are being critiqued by a retired state police major who was involved in planning the 1980 Olympics at Lake Placid.
Allan C. Scott, the Bethel Town Supervisor, who was one of the two council members who voted against Mr. Bernstein's proposal at the meeting last month, said last week that he needed to learn much more about Mr. Bernstein's plans and how they would affect the town of 4,100.
 
'Shock to the System'
 "It's very hard," Mr. Scott said, "to deal with the shock to the system that would come with bringing 80,000 people into a rural community that is not used to having 80,000 people come in for the weekend."
Like other residents in Saugerties and Bethel, Severin Koninkiewicz, an 80-year-old former soldier in the Polish and American armies in World War II, believes it is not too early to ready a battle plan for the concert that would take place across the road from his tiny wood-and-brick house here.
With no intention of venturing outside if a concert takes place, he and his wife, Stephanie, plan to stock up on provisions like veal, frozen vegetables and cranberry juice. And to drown out the loud music, they are planning to have a Woodstock of their own -- a "classical" Woodstock, courtesy of their compact disk player -- that will feature the works of Chopin, Mozart and Beethoven.
"The situation will be no worse than a war, or a storm or the earthquake in California," Mr. Koninkiewicz said.

HEADLINE: Some Gifts to the Neediest Inspired by Donors' Grief

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
A woman from California gave to help very young children in memory of her little boy, who died shortly after birth. A man from Brooklyn gave to help teen-agers who have lost parents after one of his co-workers died and left behind a 16-year-old son.
They are among the hundreds of people who have contributed to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in order to do something very much in keeping with the spirit of the fund itself: to "turn sorrow and pain into positive action," in the words of one contributor. 
 The 82d annual campaign, which ends tomorrow, has received more than 12,000 donations from New York and around the country and from places as far-flung as Tokyo and Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. The gifts were sent for almost as many reasons as there were gifts: to commemorate births and weddings and anniversaries, to remember the dead, to celebrate birthdays and to express gratitude for good luck or business success.
 
In Memory of a Child
 But some, like Christine A. Chorney, a lawyer in San Francisco, contributed to help ease others' pain in the midst of their own, simply because they found that doing so is the best catharsis.
"The enclosed contribution is made in memory of my dearest son, Stephen, who would have been almost a year old if he had lived," wrote Ms. Chorney in a letter accompanying her $75 donation. "Although I am sad that I will not be able to provide for him, I would be happy to know that my contribution was used to help a child, preferably a small one like Stephen would have been. Please use it to buy toys, clothing, medical care or anything else needed or wanted by a child."
Her contribution, like all the others that have been sent since the campaign began on Thanksgiving Day, goes directly to support seven social-service agencies in their efforts to help thousands of New Yorkers who are homeless, disabled, unemployed or mentally ill. Because The Times pays the campaign's administrative costs, every dollar is used for direct services for the most needy.
Keith Charles Edwards of Brooklyn, a photographer who gives to several charities through a payroll deduction at his business, gave $5 to the Neediest Cases Fund this month to transform his own grief over a death in his office.
 
Sending a Boy to Camp
 "My now-deceased co-worker is survived by a 16-year-old son who has benefited from The New York Times Neediest and the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies," Mr. Edwards wrote. "I was moved to learn of this boy's progress in life since he won a scholarship to camp two years in a row thanks to the generosity of good citizens."
The Federation, one of the social-service agencies supported by the fund, provides grants each year for children to attend day and summer camps. In 1992 it also started the Black and Latino Males Initiative, which sends 60 inner-city youths to summer camp in High Falls, N.Y.
Mr. Edwards said he planned to make his contribution to the Federation a tradition. "I can afford to give more and as time progresses, so will my increase," he wrote. "I wish you all Godspeed."

HEADLINE: Hollywood Is Casting; New York Stays Home

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
Seeking Hollywood's glamour and its dollars, representatives of governments around the country are gathering this weekend at a trade show in Los Angeles trying to persuade movie producers to film in their cities and states. But there is a notable absence at the Location Expo.
New York City, with a vacancy at the top of its Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting, is not represented. 
 With the once-vibrant television and movie production business in New York just rebounding from the severe drought of the early 1990's, the absence of a new film commissioner has come to symbolize a crossroads for the industry in New York City and to heighten the anxiety of those who make their living in it.
"I think people are nervous because we're at a critical juncture here because we have New York back on the big screen," said Nick Wollner, a New York film producer who is the East Coast president of the Association of Independent Commercial Producers. "New York is back being an acceptable icon on the big screen, but we need to keep up that momentum."
 
A Test on 2 Fronts
 Mr. Wollner and other industry representatives say the film office needs an experienced production professional to maintain the momentum and that the administration's choice for the office will test Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's statements that he views the industry as fertile ground for economic development.
Randy Mastro, the Mayor's chief of staff, said on Friday that dozens of people had been interviewed for the commissioner's job since a selection committee was appointed nearly three months ago. Interviews are continuing, he said, but it will be at least two more weeks before names of finalists are forwarded to Mr. Giuliani. Mr. Mastro added that the time elapsed was no indication that the administration's interest in the film industry was flagging.
"We consider the film office to be extremely important, the film industry to be extremely important," Mr. Mastro said. "It is a major source of revenue for the city."
 
Sending the Right Message
 Mr. Giuliani made a strong statement supporting the industry last week when he took issue with the Transit Authority for restricting film makers from shooting violent scenes in the subway system.
"This message should be conveyed in the right way: we want people to come to New York and make movies," Mr. Giuliani said. He said he saw film making as a source of jobs and tax revenue for the city as well as a way to promote its image worldwide.
The film commissioner's job is to attract productions to the city and then to act as a guide, clearing the underbrush of red tape and politics that can make filming in New York City an expensive and unpleasant experience. The office has about a dozen employees.
The job has been vacant since Richard Brick left last month. Mr. Brick was hired by the Dinkins administration in November 1992 after the film office had been leaderless for much of that year. He is an independent producer and the former chairman of the graduate film department at Columbia University.
 
A Potential Money-Maker
 A study by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in December indicates that the success of the film office can be lucrative for the city.
The study found that television and movie production in the New York City region brought $3 billion into the economy in direct and indirect spending in 1992 and that 91 percent of the economic activity occurred in the city itself. The productions spent $1.3 billion directly in the city in 1992, the study saids.
This level of activity places New York's production business directly behind California's -- although a distant second -- in terms of employees and payroll.
But New York's position is precarious. With financially pressed cities and states around the nation viewing film production as a lucrative, clean industry, the number of local film commissions grew in the 1980's from 60 to 235, according to the Association of Film Commissioners International.
 
Recovering From a Boycott
 The industry is also struggling to recover from a boycott by major studios in 1990 and 1991 because of contract disputes between the studios and craft unions. The dispute was settled in May 1991.
In December the city's Economic Policy and Marketing Group reported seeing the first signs of recovery. The city's film office issued 113 permits for the filming of feature films in the first 10 months of 1993, an increase of 30 percent from the same period in 1992. And the average cost of major studio features filmed in 1993 was $25 million, or 10 times as much as the budgets for the independent films that were the staple of the city's industry during the boycott.
Jeffrey Hayes, the producer of the television series "Law and Order," said the unions had become more accommodating after the boycott. He also said Mr. Brick's 14-month tenure with the city had made the city friendlier to producers.
"There's never been a more favorable climate for films coming into the city," Mr. Hayes said. "What people are worried about is, they need someone strong in the film office to get the message out."
 
The Right Set of Skills
 Mr. Mastro said there were no finalists for the job so far. He also said there were no plans to downgrade the position from commissioner to office director, as some industry representatives said they feared. The job was raised to commissioner level when Mr. Brick was appointed.
Phil Dixon, the New York producer of four daytime television shows and a member of the committee of New York Production Partnership, the production industry group, said the new commissioner must have both the political skills to sell New York as a filming location and the industry experience to work quickly and effectively to solve the problems of Hollywood producers. He said that combination is particularly important, given the competition from other cities.
"There are many cities around the country that can offer lower costs, just because of their economic structures," Mr. Dixon said. And although film makers are still interested in depicting New York in their movies, technology allows them to go to other cities and, in his words, "fake it" without audiences' knowing.

HEADLINE: Dr. Roy Reierson, 87, A Retired Economist

 BODY:
Dr. Roy L. Reierson, a former executive of and chief economist for Bankers Trust Company in New York City, died on Thursday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. Dr. Reierson, who was 87, lived in Granite Springs, N.Y.
The cause was complications following a fall, said his daughter, Kaari. 
 After a 37-year career with the bank, Dr. Reierson retired in 1971 as a senior vice president who was widely respected on Wall Street for his conservative views on national economic policy. He was regarded as an expert on interest rates, the Federal budget and taxes and often testified before Congressional and banking groups.
At various times Dr. Reierson served as a consultant to the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and undertook special assignments for the Departments of Treasury and Commerce, and the Congressional Joint Economic Committee.
Dr. Reierson graduated from St. Olaf College, and received master's and doctoral degrees from Northwestern University, where he later taught. Later he was a member of the faculty of the New York University Graduate School of Business Administration.
He is survived by his wife, Maria Reierson; two sons, Lars, of London and Kristofer, of Boston, and his daughter, Kaari Reierson of Washington.

HEADLINE: WINTER OLYMPICS;
In Politics And on Ice, Neighbors Are Apart

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GJOVIK, Norway, Feb. 26

 BODY:
The secession was peaceful, voted on and done. The players are friends, former teammates, in many cases, on professional teams back home. But no self-respecting breakaway republic wants to be trounced by the country it used to be part of, Olympic medal or no Olympic medal.
Robert Petrovicky of Slovakia heard of the talk back home in Bratislava. "After we lost to the Russians, they said, 'O.K., forget about a medal; just beat the Czechs.' " 
 Playing in its first Olympic tournament, Slovakia survived its preliminary-round pool, but lost to the Russians in the hockey quarterfinals, then dropped a 7-1 decision for fifth place to the Czech Republic tonight at the Gjovik Olympic Cavern Hall that didn't hurt more, but might sting a little back home.
 
Not Big Deal for Czechs
 To the Czechs, from whom the Slovaks broke away last year, this was no big deal, nothing to brag about. Before the Slovaks split from their former union with Bohemia and Moravia that was Czechoslovakia, the Czechs dominated the national team, averaging 15 of the 20 players chosen. Nine of the 12 teams in the country's professional league, now split like the republics, were from the Czech side. They expected to end up with the better team, having the deeper talent pool.
"A normal game, like we were playing the U.S.," said the Czechs' Otakar Janecky. "I think it was more important to them."
"Yes," Petrovicky said. "It was a historic game."
Since the nation split, the more urban Czech Republic to the north, closer to Germany, has prospered, as it continues to build on the foundation of capitalism begun when Communist rule crumbled five years ago. It hasn't even bothered to change its red, white and blue flag, the white third traditionally representing Slovakia.
The more agrarian south, meanwhile, is struggling economically with independence, to the point where Petrovicky wonders what the point was in the first place.
 
A Vote Against the Split
 He was playing in the United States with the Hartford Whalers when the vote was taken, and called his father to ask what he thought. "I remember him saying, 'We came through Communism together, and we should rebuild together,' " he said. "He voted against the split."
Petrovicky is playing this season for Hartford's minor league team in Springfield, Mass., but returned home before the Olympics to train with the national team. He was astounded by inflation. Milk that once cost two Czech crowns a few years ago was going for 15 or more.
"It's 400, 500 percent," he said. "But the people I talk to from the north, the Czechs, they say the prices there are actually going down. I don't usually care about politics, but this I don't understand."
A victory tonight might have soothed those growing pains for a day, at least. But after Slovakia's Miroslav Satan put a goal on the board at 2 minutes 21 seconds of the first period, the Czechs routed Slovakia's goalie, Eduard Hartmann, for four goals in less than 10 minutes. Before they knew what hit them, the Slovaks were done.
"The Czechs are better," Petrovicky said. "But I think if it was a game for more than fifth place, we would have played better."
 
Alarming the Officials
 Compared to the other teams in this watered-down tournament, the Slovaks have been more like a National Hockey League team in style, if not substance. Led by Peter Stastny, a veteran of many N.H.L. wars with the Quebec Nordiques, the gloves were coming off at a rate that began to alarm Olympic officials. They didn't resort to that tonight at this marvelous facility, literally a building carved into the side of a mountain, a hockey cave.
Petrovicky said playing for fifth place wasn't much to get worked up over. The Czechs' Bedrich Scerban agreed that it was more difficult working up the passion to belt someone you've grown up with in the Czechoslovak junior program.
"I play now in Finland for a professional team, and so when we play against the Finns, it's like playing against my friends," he said. "With the Slovaks, I know many of them, more than half. They're my friends.
"If we had to play for a medal, we play hard. But for fifth place, against your friends, you try to score goals. How hard do you play?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jiri Kucera of the Czech Republic scoring a goal yesterday in the second period out of the reach of Slovakia's goalie, Miroslav Michalek. (Barton Silverman/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
This Brake Stuff Just Won't Stop

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon 

 BODY:
AS we know, February's slop has produced turmoil in the eastern part of the country. It also resulted in a blizzard of questions on antilock brake systems, and the queries resulted in a column on the pros and cons of ABS. And that resulted in more questions and comments and . . . oh, just mush onward.
 
Dear Sir,
May I offer one additional thought on antilock brakes? 
 Before I had ABS, my pumping of the brakes caused my brake lights to flash on and off, alerting the driver behind me to the fact that I was braking on a slippery surface. I could see them back off and reduce the possibility of rear-ending me.
Now that I have ABS, the driver behind me doesn't get the warning of flashing lights. So, I deliberately pump my brakes before I "stand on the pedal" to give him that warning and get him off my tail.
May I suggest that the auto manufacturers change the action of the brake lights so they flash on and off whenever the ABS mechanism engages. That should achieve the same result.
 
STANLEY L. POLLOCK
Chicago
Good idea. Consider it passed on. Incidentally, I remember seeing ads years ago for a gizmo that pulsed the brake lights every time you stepped on the pedal. A similar gadget is available for motorcycles, and it might be adaptable for cars. Check with your friendly neighborhood biker gang (or visit a motorcycle shop.)
 
Plumbing the Paradox
 
Dear Sir,
You said recently that you were "boggled" by a study by the Highway Institute for Traffic Safety in which ABS saved almost nothing in terms of insurance claims. Rather than being boggling, such an outcome is fully consistent with the economic/ psychological concept of "offsetting behavior."
Offsetting behavior occurs frequently, and a good example is when pedestrians walk more carefully on icy sidewalks because the probability of falling is much greater than under dry conditions.
Drivers, too, realize that cars with ABS are safer and, in economic parlance, that the cost of undertaking risky activities is now lower. Consequently, it is reasonable (some would say rational) for drivers to take more risk, either by driving more aggressively or deciding to drive at all in inclement weather. Offsetting behavior explains the paradox of safer ABS-equipped cars but no drop in accident claims.
A paper published recently in the Journal of Policy Analysis and Management by Edward Harper and myself finds that offsetting behavior is a quantitatively important factor in understanding motor vehicle fatalities in the United States. Drivers will not remain passive with the new technology, and the number of skids and other potential accident situations will increase because drivers feel more comfortable in the ABS-equipped cars.
On the other hand, offsetting behavior can have a salutary interaction with regulations. For example, Government standards will lead to lighter cars and, by some accounts, to an increase in fatalities. But the hypothesis suggests that driver behavior will be altered because downsized autos will be driven less aggressively, thus attenuating adverse effects.
Failure to recognize the subtle effects of offsetting behavior may well lead to inaccurate business and policy decisions.
 
ROBERT S. CHIRINKO
Champaign, Ill.
You may be right. In which case, I consider myself unboggled.
 
The Quick-Stop Factor
 
Dear Sir,
As a regular reader, I feel I must write to point out an error which you have made for two consecutive weeks.
One of the most frequent misapprehensions about ABS is that it shortens braking distance, and that is not true. The system functions to prevent wheel lockup, and hence to help the driver keep control in slippery conditions.
There is nothing inherent in an ABS system that shortens braking distances, and that is carefully explained by the manufacturers. I don't mean to be an alarmist, but this misinformation is as potentially harmful as the assumption held by some drivers that it's O.K. not to wear a seat belt if the car has an air bag.
 
CHRIS BEYER
Upper Montclair, N.J.
You are right that by eliminating lockup, ABS allows a driver to steer through a panic stop, and that is an important benefit. But antilock brakes do indeed offer an improvement in stopping distances -- particularly on slippery surfaces -- by radically slowing the wheels while preventing the tires from skidding. I've seen it in action, and the difference is dramatic. It is worth noting, though, that antilocks do not make a driver invincible; they are no substitute for common sense.
 
Honoring the Inventors
 
Dear Sir,
Your column on antilock brakes coincides with the presentation of the 1994 Elmer A. Sperry Award to Hans Jurgen Gerstenmeier, Wolf-Dieter Jonner and Heinz Leiber, who developed the technology for Robert Bosch GmbH of Germany. The award will be presented March 1 at the Society of Automotive Engineers International Congress and Exposition at Cobo Center in Detroit.
Starting with an initial idea advanced in 1936, they worked for more than two decades to design and develop the antilock braking concept for application to motor vehicles.
The Sperry Award is given annually to recognize outstanding contributions to transportation. It was started in 1955 to honor Elmer A. Sperry, an inventor of locomotives, streetcars, an electric automobile and many other transportation systems.
 
STANLEY A. MAST
New York
Time they got a break.
 
The Quick-Stop Factor, Part II
 
Dear Sir,
Your article on antilock braking systems missed one critical point: that on packed snow and particularly on ice, the most important device for decelerating an automobile under control is not the brake pedal but the transmission shift lever.
In the storms of the last fortnight, both my wife in her rear-wheel-drive Crown Victoria and I in my front-wheel-drive Dodge Spirit were able to avoid skids completely by downshifting so that brakes were not needed until speeds had dropped below 5 miles an hour.
The technique of downshifting as a means to maintain control under the worst driving conditions apparently is not taught today, or is considered to be a form of transmission abuse, but it works.
 
PETER WHITTIER
Rockaway, N.J.
 
Downshifting, done properly, can be a useful tool in controlling a car's behavior. But it also can be dangerous, particularly when the road is slick. Shifting to a lower gear slows the driving wheels, suddenly putting them out of sync with the vehicle's speed, and a skid can be the result.
 
Freewheeling Discourse
 
Dear Sir,
I read your useful column with great interest and have an additional suggestion to make. If you are trying to go very slowly downhill in snowy or icy conditions and have a car with an automatic transmission, put the gear in neutral. It is magical the way you keep control because otherwise the transmission's "creep" interferes with braking.
 
SUSAN F.C. WEIL
Mount Kisco, N.Y.
Something must be magically out of whack if "creep" interferes with your braking. The engine itself has a good deal of slowing power in the lower gears. And, in any case, it is not a good idea to relinquish any portion of control by disconnecting the engine from the wheels.

HEADLINE: Reebok, Workers and Third World Economies

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Since their adoption less than two years ago, Reebok's Human Rights Production Standards have forced changes in employment and environmental practices by Reebok's contractors throughout Asia. 
 Where can other responsible corporations look for guidelines "to steer a middle course between moral relativism and moral absolutism?" ("Global Business Must Mind its Morals," Viewpoints, Feb. 13). Increasingly, corporate leaders are turning to the internationally recognized standards articulated by the United Nations' Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the legal instruments that are its progeny. These standards establish basic rights for individuals in all societies and avoid charges of moral imperialism by any one country. They offer practical -- though not binding -- investment, employment and marketing guidance to multinational corporations operating in unfamiliar settings.
 
ELLIOT J. SCHRAGE
New York, Feb. 16
 
The writer teaches a seminar on business and human rights at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business.

HEADLINE: Helping the Neediest

 BODY:
Tomorrow marks the end of the 82d appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Despite hard times, our readers have been generous. More than 12,000 donors gave about $4.5 million.
The money will go to seven private agencies that are dedicated to helping the city's most vulnerable citizens. In this particularly bitter winter, that help has made a crucial difference to many lives. For some it has meant a warm place to sleep, for others a meal. For many children, it has made the difference between an intact family and one splintered by the stresses of economic hardship. 
 The agencies' work does not end with the campaign; they continue to provide services to needy New Yorkers throughout the year. The needs will continue too. In a city strapped for cash as never before, private agencies like those supported by the Neediest Cases Fund will take on more of the burden of meeting basic needs for people who have fallen on desperate times through no fault of their own.
Readers can still help; the fund will accept donations throughout the year. Money given after Monday will be applied to the 83d campaign. As always, contributions will go directly to help people in need. No money is kept to pay for administration or solicitation by agencies the fund supports. All contributions are tax deductible to the extent permitted by law, and any amount is welcome. Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and mailed to P.O. Box 5193, General Post Office, New York, N.Y. 10087.

HEADLINE: Hate Fliers Inflame Mayoral Race in New Orleans

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 26

 BODY:
Even by the standards of a city where politics has long been a brawler's sport, a pair of anonymous anti-black, anti-Semitic fliers that have circulated in the build-up to the March 5 runoff election for mayor have been particularly nasty.
The election pits State Senator Marc Morial, 36, the son of the late Ernest (Dutch) Morial, New Orleans's first black Mayor, against Donald Mintz, a 50-year-old Jewish lawyer with a long history of civic leadership and strong ties to the city's blacks. 
 Perhaps the most bizarre aspect of the fliers incident is the Morial campaign's charge that Mr. Mintz, the front-runner by a narrow margin in recent polls, had campaign workers create and distribute some of the more scurrilous fliers themselves to paint Mr. Mintz as a candidate under siege.
In an interview, Mr. Mintz denied that he or anyone in his campaign had created the fliers. But he conceded that his campaign had mailed copies to thousands of Jews throughout the nation along with a fund-raising letter that characterized the fliers' racist sentiments as an attack on "the stature and security of our community."
 
Help in Raising Money
 The mailing generated more than $200,000 in contributions for Mr. Mintz from outside the city, city investigators said. As of early February, campaign records showed that his campaign had raised about $650,000 in all.
Dr. Lawrence Rubin, executive vice chairman of the National Jewish Relations Advisory Council, a group based in New York, said his group had examined the fliers and, based on their language and content, had concluded that they were probably not the work of hate groups.
"People who received the fund-raising letter called us," Dr. Rubin said, "and we shared with them our reservations and concern, but let them make their own judgment as to how to deal with it."
But for the Morial campaign the conclusion was clear. "Mr. Mintz self-inflicted a racial wound where there was none," said Bob Tucker, the campaign chairman for Mr. Morial, "and he did it to raise funds nationally."
The flier that has attracted the most condemnation is titled "Let's Make Mintz Meat & Molasses." It bears pictures of Mr. Mintz and a man who resembles the South African leader Nelson Mandela and demands, "Stop the Colored/Jew Coalition" and "Say Never to Jungle Apes & Christ Killers."
 
'Unusually Nasty'
 Even in this politically jaded city, many find insinuations that the Mintz campaign produced such fliers too cynical to believe. "It's unusually nasty," said Mary Zervigon, a member of the city's Human Relations Commission. "It has been going on for months, rather than just a few weeks, and there is this idea of the reverse spin of a candidate attacking himself in these fliers in order to gain some advantage."
Already, a main Mintz adviser has been charged with a misdemeanor count accusing him of violating state campaign laws by distributing some of the anonymous fliers this month. And Mr. Mintz suffered another setback on Friday when an investigation by the commission issued a preliminary report saying that at least two of the fliers "originated in the Mintz campaign" and that a campaign aide was responsible for distributing one flier and trying to distribute the other in the New Orleans area.
Still, many in this city of 497,000 insist that no one cares about the fliers. Most people have never seen or read them, said Ed Renwick, director of the Loyola Institute of Politics. He and others said Mr. Mintz was unlikely to lose his nearly solid support among whites, who make up 39 percent of the voters, over charges initiated by the District Attorney, who supports Mr. Morial. But the analysts said Mr. Mintz could lose support among blacks, who are 61 percent of the voters.
 
Fear of Crime
 Silas Lee, a political scientist at Xavier University and a pollster, said voters of both races were desperate about crime and the economy. As a result, he said, older black voters and middle-class black voters, usually loyal to black candidates, were willing to vote for a white candidate perceived as strong and able to make a difference.
Mr. Mintz is widely viewed as a man with ideas and the determination to put them into action. Mr. Morial, despite his relative youth and perceived inexperience, has basked somewhat in the aura of his father's reputation for assertiveness and savvy and is seen as someone familiar with the tribulations of the city's first black Mayor.
Either way, said John Maginnis, editor of the Louisiana Political Review, both candidates are seen as an antidote to years of "laid-back" government under the outgoing Mayor, Sidney Barthelemy, who cannot by law seek a third term and who has remained neutral.
Samuel Dubois Cook, the president of Dillard University here and a political scientist, said both candidates were perceived as agents of change who shared prescriptions for curbing crime and diversifying the city's economy.
As he sat down for lunch recently in the French Quarter, Mr. Mintz talked wistfully of his once-proud city, a place now besieged by crime, 37,000 abandoned private housing units and a decline in jobs and educational opportunities. He envisioned bringing manufacturing jobs to the city and bolstering medical research and training institutions at 10 universities.
 
Gambling on a Casino
 Mr. Mintz also emphasized the importance of not putting too much of the city's future economic hopes on a recently approved casino. He accused past administrations of depending too heavily on the oil and gas money that once flowed into the city.
Mr. Morial sounded remarkably the same as he addressed a rally on Friday night at the Lakewood Country Club in Algiers on the west bank of the Mississippi River. But he also evoked a time when a Morial was in City Hall and things were better. In the racially mixed audience, C. W. Chachere, a white advertising executive, said he had been undecided until a few days ago, when disgust over the fliers had driven him into the Morial camp. He said he did not care whether Mr. Mintz's campaign had actually created them, but he was angry that it had used them to raise money.
"Those fliers scare me," Mr. Chachere said, "and I have come to the conclusion that it's Morial and not Mintz who can use all of the people resources we have in the city."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HUNTS POINT;
Battered but Unbowed, Bronx Seeks Government Aid

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE--PIERRE 

 BODY:
In terms of economic aid for the Bronx, Borough President Fernando Ferrer has no bird in the hand. But he is keeping several irons in the fire.
The Bronx has suffered a number of blows over the last year, ranging from the cancellation of a street and sewer reconstruction project for Hunts Point to the Giuliani administration's decision to drop a new Bronx-based police academy to George Steinbrenner's threats to desert Yankee Stadium. 
 Mr. Ferrer is fighting back, seeking two special government programs. First, he said on Friday that the indications were good that he was winning a running battle to have a stretch of the borough included in the city's application for a Federal "economic empowerment zone."
"It was counterintuitive not to include the South Bronx," Mr. Ferrer said. "We believe the Dinkins administration made a mistake." Areas in the empowerment zone would receive funds for job training, drug treatment and other social services.
The city's application will be filed in June, with a decision likely this summer. But Mr. Ferrer is already moving in another direction, filing an application with the state to have Hunts Point designated an economic development zone.
Hunts Point is one of an estimated 40 cities, villages and neighborhoods in New York State expected to submit such applications by tomorrow, attempting to demonstrate that they are poor enough to be designated economic development zones.
Up to 15 will be named in early June, state officials said, and will share about $1.6 million a year.
Under the program, businesses that move into the distressed zones or expand existing operations there are offered state tax reductions and subsidies to help pay utility bills and construction loans.
"We're ripe for this designation," said John Robert, district manager of Community Board 2. "The Bronx is always getting dumped on."
There is plenty of room to grow in the area, borough officials say. Marie Diven, a spokeswoman for Mr. Ferrer, said there are 163 acres of vacant lots in Hunts Point, of which 70 percent are city-owned.
There have been 19 such zones designated in the state since the program was established in 1986 by the Legislature to help struggling municipalities. New York City has four, including Port Morris, the Bronx; East New York, Brooklyn; South Jamaica, Queens, and East Harlem. GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
12 Women Call For Equality In Business

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
Like many struggling business owners, Sandra Sam has put everything into her restaurant, the Gadabout, on Fifth Avenue at 125th Street. In September, she even sold her home to keep up with her bills.
"That was the only home my children knew, and believe me, they're not happy about this," she said. "Right now I'm at the point that if my business closed, I'd have to go on welfare." 
 It is not the hard work, the risk or the challenge of competition that fuels her fears of the worst. She has seen some men prosper while she suffers, she says, and she feels that, in the midst of a small burst of economic growth in the area, the people in control of Harlem's resources are turning a deaf ear to her and other women.
Ms. Sam is one of 12 women -- all black entrepreneurs in Harlem -- who have joined a decade-long wave that has washed through the country, bringing women together to press community and business leaders to give them access to money and information they say they have been denied.
"I'm not asking for a handout," Ms. Sam said last week. "I have boots and I can pull them up. I just want them not to take my feet or hands away, so I can't do what I need to."
Christine Merser, the founder and executive director of Women Resource Center of New York, said the national burst of women's groups, and an accompanying growth of government programs directed at helping women in business, were responses to the historic problems women face.
Among these obstacles, she said, is that women tend to work in ways that do not establish credit histories, the determining factor in qualifying for a loan. Often, they work for someone else or within a marriage. And Ms. Merser said that of the more than 200 business organizations in her database for New York City, none is in Harlem.
The 12 Harlem women have no name for their group, which began last fall, after Dorothy Pitman Hughes, who runs an office supplies store, began organizing other black women in business. After comparing notes, they began a campaign of letters and phone calls to Representative Charles B. Rangel, who agreed to a meeting. They told him that they felt sidelined by Harlem's power structure, pointing out that none of them were invited to a recent meeting of community leaders with Secretary of Commerce Ronald Brown.
In response, he set up a meeting for them this month with Donald Coggsville, the head of the Harlem Urban Development Corporation. Mr. Coggsville said he would seek their advice in drawing up a proposal for Federal aid under the "empowerment zone" program. Mr. Rangel also told the group that he would set up a meeting with the leaders of several banks that are active in the area.
The women were heartened by Mr. Rangel's attention, Ms. Hughes said, and they say they are hopeful. But the bankers meeting has yet to take place, or even be scheduled.
"If we had a support system, if we could go to banks and get a loan, the whole face of Harlem could change," said Ms. Hughes.
Ms. Hughes said she needs money so she can receive lines of credit from manufacturers. Ms. Sam needs to pay back her loans. Beulah Tuten plans to expand her sign-making business and buy a van so she can deliver her wares.
"We need to build a liaison with the people who manage Harlem," Ms. Hughes said. "If dollars are going to come to Harlem, we want to be part of that. And if we are not part of it, I am definitely going to go to Washington and ask the President to lift the economic embargo against African-American women in Harlem." EMILY M. BERNSTEIN

HEADLINE: Beyond Denial: An 'Eldercare' Primer;
Health-Care Rules Are a Dizzying Maze. It's Terribly Painful to Confront a Parent's Mortality. But Why Wait for a Crisis?

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
CAROL MAURO'S father lived happily and healthily on his own in a Manhattan walk-up apartment until last Father's Day, when, at the age of 82, he fell and broke his hip. That injury, complicated by a heart attack, transformed his life, and the lives of his three daughters as well.
Caught unprepared, Mrs. Mauro says, she and her sisters flailed about in their search for information, "all sort of tripping over each other in trying to be helpful." The months since have been a crash course in the elements of what has come to be called "eldercare" -- the runic regulations of Medicaid and Medicare, the relative benefits of home health care versus life in a nursing home. 
 "We got lulled into forgetting how old he really was," said Mrs. Mauro, who directs training programs for a large insurance company. "You live with a whole lot of denial about what's going to happen to your parents."
Now, her father, John Vitale, a retired postal worker who has lived alone since his wife died in 1981, has health aides helping him around the clock, and Mrs. Mauro and her sisters are paying his not inconsiderable bills.
Their story, experts say, is all too typical. It is the rare adult who begins to grapple ahead of time with the financial, medical and emotional implications of caring for elderly parents. Most of the time, such topics are addressed only in mid-crisis, with decisions made hurriedly and then frequently regretted in hindsight.
All of this, of course, is as simple, and as maddeningly complex, as the relationships and inevitable conflicts between parent and child, brother and sister, husband and wife.
Some parents may feel that to involve their children in highly personal decisions would be to surrender irrevocably to old age. Disagreements frequently erupt over whether parents' money should be used for their care or kept to pass on to their children. And often the need to plan for elderly parents gets pushed aside by the demands of a child's own children or career.
But the biggest hurdle for many is simply facing the fact that parents get old and frail and, ultimately, are gone.
"I just didn't want to think of this person, my mother, who I loved so much and who had always taken care of me, as a helpless person," said Linda Nochlin, a professor of modern art at New York University whose mother died at the age of 80 last month. "It's terribly hard. To say one can be rational about it is simply untrue. No one can really help you confront the notion of your mother's mortality, and then your own mortality, which goes along with it."
Still, while a parent may remain healthy and independent until 65 or 90, "the mortality rate is 100 percent, so it's foolish not to deal with these things," says Louise Fradkin, a founder of Children of Aging Parents, a national support group.
The often staggering financial burden of medical care for the elderly is one of the major factors driving the furious health care debate in Washington. And there is added urgency in the changing demographics of New York. While the total number of people over 65 in the city remained fairly constant between censuses in 1980 and 1990, the number of people 85 and older -- those most likely to need specialized care -- rose 32 percent.
"The average 40-year-old couple has more parents than children," said Barbara B. Lepis, director of the Partnership for Eldercare, an information center run out of the city's Department for the Aging.
The aging of the population and the growing complexity of the situation have given rise to an expanding industry of services for the elderly, and for the children who will care for them, from corporate help to a new species of social worker, the geriatric-care manager, who can navigate much of the eldercare maze for you.
The field is vast and complex. All the more reason to learn the basics now. What follows, then, is a primer in many of the major issues of caring for elderly relatives in a city of extensive and diverse but often poorly publicized services.
 
THE PAPERWORK
 The first step is the paperwork.
An essential, lawyers and advocates for the elderly say, is power of attorney, a document in which a parent designates someone who will be able to perform tasks like paying bills and writing checks. Someone who becomes incapacitated without having assigned power of attorney may end up having decisions made by a state-appointed guardian.
A lawyer usually draws up the document, which must be notarized. Forms are available from any stationery store specializing in legal forms, but experts urge great care; power of attorneyis a highly potent instrument that is easily abused.
Next is the health-care proxy, which allows the person designated to make decisions about medical treatment should a patient not be able to participate in such decisions.
Many lawyers also recommend that parents sign living wills, which state their feelings about the degree to which they should be sustained on life-support if they become terminally ill or recovery otherwise seems unlikely. Though New York, unlike many states, does not have a law regulating the use of living wills, "judges generally uphold them," said Ellen P. Rosenzweig, a director of the Institute of Law and Rights of Older Adults at Hunter College.
Lawyers draft these documents, but for those who want to do it themselves, forms for health-care proxies and living wills are available from an organization called Choice in Dying. A New York health-care proxy is essentially valid only within the state.
Parents should also be encouraged to make, and give their children, lists of their assets and of their monthly income from all sources -- pensions, Social Security, rental property, interest and dividends. The list should include safe-deposit box locations, the names and telephone numbers of lawyers and accountants, the location of a will and other important documents, and any information about funeral arrangements already made.
 
HEALTH-CARE OPTIONS
 The next subject -- one that is considerably more bewildering and emotionally fraught -- is health care. While many parents are in good general physical condition and able to manage their own care, and while most will never need a nursing home, many will need some kind of specialized care at some point.
Simply raising the subject can be painful. Carolyn E. Mayo, compensation manager for American International Group, where Mrs. Mauro also works, checked out home care last year for her parents, Dorothy and Walter Spence, who are 78 and 83 and living in their own house in North Bayshore, L.I., despite failing eyesight and other health problems.
"My mother said to me, 'You know your father doesn't like having strangers in the house,' " she recalled. So Mrs. Mayo continues to commute from her home on Staten Island when they need help.
Often the choice is between nursing homes and home health care, which has grown dramatically of late.
Carl D'Aquino, an interior designer, and his two brothers placed their parents, now 73 and 79, in nursing homes twice within the last six months and Mr. D'Aquino called the decision and the aftermath "probably the most difficult thing I've gone through in my entire life."
"As fine as the home is," he added, "every time I go and visit, it's completely draining. Leaving is so hard."
Many people resist nursing homes on a gut level. When Judith Brickman, a nursing-home specialist with the city's Department for the Aging, tells her clients to free-associate with "nursing home," she says, she frequently gets responses like "sick, institutional, depressing."
"They have an absolutely horrible reputation, but I don't think it's deserved," she said, though she allows that 20 years ago, many nursing homes were indeed bad. Still, the 1990 census found that 46,118 New Yorkers over 65, or 4.8 percent, were in the city's 160 nursing ing homes or in other residential facilities.
The Department for the Aging provides lists of nursing homes as well as advice on how to assess them. And there are safety nets to help protect residents of nursing homes. Federal law requires, and pays for, each home to have an ombudsman to take complaints. Another advocacy option is a group called Friends and Relatives of Institutionalized Aged.
Gaining admission to a nursing home usually requires two evaluations -- the patient review instrument and the patient screen instrument -- to evaluate the need for care.
The most popular alternative to nursing homes is home health care, in which aides with varying levels of nursing training assist elderly people in daily activities, from bathing to taking medicine to going to the grocery store. Many private agencies specialize in placing home health aides, for a fee. Nonprofit agencies like the New York Foundation for Senior Citizens will provide health aides under certain circumstances, using Medicaid or private funds. The city also provides them for needy residents through Medicaid.
Screening a health aide is essential, and people should ask about applicants' training, whether they hold a certificate as a home health aide or nurse's aide, whether they have experience and good references, whether they have had a recent physical examination themselves, and how they might respond in a specific medical emergency. Have the person try out for a few days, and monitor the situation closely.
"Employers should lay the rules down right at the start and make sure the aide understands," said Agnes Mak, who runs the home health aide program at the New York Foundation for Senior Citizens. "They should not make medical decisions. They should communicate with the family. The key is constant supervision."
An alternative that falls between home care and nursing homes is "enriched housing," in which frail elderly people live in apartment buildings where a hot meal is served once a day and other services, from transportation to personal grooming, are arranged. The cost varies, but at one large building in Manhattan it is just under $800 a month. A related alternative is "shared housing," in which roommates are found for elderly people who remain in their homes.
 
PAYING FOR HEALTH CARE
 Except for the wealthy and those who qualify for Medicaid, the Federal insurance program for the poor, paying for medical care poses the thorniest problems, and raises some of the most difficult questions, of all.
Generally speaking, for a healthy person over 65, visits to the doctor are covered by private insurance or by Medicare, the Government's insurance plan for the elderly. When a crisis requires hospitalization, Medicare and private insurance will also cover most of those costs.
But by and large, private insurers and Medicare do not pay for long-term nursing home or in-home care, although Medicare does cover up to 100 days of skilled care following a hospital stay of three days or more. For example, a heart-attack patient can have most of his or her hospital stay paid through Medicare, but someone who develops Alzheimer's disease and deteriorates to the point of needing daily care usually can not.
Another significant cost not covered by Medicare is prescription drugs. Most people pay for them out of pocket or with private insurance.
Both nursing-home care and home care can be tremendously expensive. The average New York City nursing home costs at least $5,000 a month, according to the Department for the Aging, and home health aides typically charge $10 and up an hour, which can quickly be just as costly.
"You find out ultimately that this is going to be more expensive than anybody but Rockefeller can handle," said Barry Herman, an economist whose mother, Fannie, has Alzheimer's disease and entered a nursing home last month.
For younger parents without serious health problems, insurers do offer policies that cover long-term care. Such policies are expensive, and don't always cover every contingency.
Which leaves a huge swath of peo-ple in the middle struggling to be covered for long-term care. Which leads in turn to a common, and often emotionally trying, financial maneuver known as "spending down," which allows someone who starts out relatively well off to be covered by becoming legally indigent. Here is how it works:
In New York, which is more generous than other states because of the high cost of living, the cutoff for Medicaid is $534 in monthly income, with $4,700 in assets.
Spending down can take two forms. The first is actually spending assets to pay for care. Mr. Herman's mother, for instance, is now paying for her nursing home, at a cost of about $7,500 a month. After about six months, he said, her money will be gone and Medicaid will take over.
The other route is what is known as the surplus income program. People who have income that exceeds the official limits for Medicaid can still qualify as long as their medical expenses absorb that surplus. They turn the excess income over to the nursing home or home health-care agency, with Mediciad picking up the difference, Ms. Rosenzweig said.
With a certain amount of planning, however, there are ways to keep money in the family.
Because of a 1988 change in Federal law, the spouse of a nursing-home patient covered by Medicaid is allowed to keep $72,660 in savings and have an income of up to $1,817 a month -- more if need can be proven in court. Homes and other possessions are not counted as assets, as long as the spouse or a disabled child is living in the house.
An elderly person without a spouse can also transfer money to other relatives, and the rules for such transfers can influence the choice between home care and nursing home care.
A patient can transfer unlimited assets to another family member, apply for Medicaid and be approved immediately for home care. The same person choosing to enter a nursing home, however, would have to wait out a penalty period based on the amount of money transferred. For example, a person transferring $100,000 in stock would have to wait roughly 18 months -- the value of the assets divided by $5,400, the average cost of a month in a nursing home.
Until last year, the penalty period was limited to 30 months, but now there is no limit, Ms. Rosenzweig said, adding that there is also a proposal in the State Assembly to apply the penalty period to in-home care.
Perhaps the most difficult thing about getting people to spend down or transfer assets, experts say, is that many find it frightening and humiliating, after a life of hard work
"No matter how much you trust and love your children," says Nora O'Brien, a counseling coordinator with the Partnership for Eldercare, "it's scary to take all your money and give it to someone else."
There are myriad tax considerations that affect the transfer of assets to qualify for Medicaid. Mrs. Brickman urges people to see elder-law specialists for help in planning.
Paying for long-term care is one of the issues dealt with in the various health plans now being debated in Washington.
President Clinton's plan would give states grants to pay for in-home care for people of all ages. The plan proposed by Representative Jim Cooper, a Tennessee Democrat, would eliminate Medicaid altogether and recommend that states pay for long-term care, while the plan offered by Senator John Chaffee, a Rhode Island Republican, would provide tax incentives for people to buy long-term care insurance, which is also part of the President's plan.
 
HELPING THE HELPERS
 Like elder-law specialists, geriatric-care managers are a byproduct of the huge growth in the elderly population. Frequently they are hired by adult children to help convince their parents of the need for care or to fill in for the children when they are out of town or otherwise preoccupied.
Many of them started out as social workers and a few are therapists as well, but all are trained to step into complex family situations and begin to sort them out. They are self-regulated, with no licensing required, although most of them belong to the National Association of Professional Geriatric Care Managers and are licensed in their original occupations.
Their fees are substantial -- $80 to $150 an hour, depending on the task at hand -- and are not covered by health insurance or Medicare.
Leonie Nowitz is one such care manager. She started her business, the Center for Lifelong Growth, in Manhattan, in 1979 and has 20 or so clients at a time. She might accompany one elderly person to the doctor, visit with another, help the children of another sign up for Medicaid or find a reliable home health aide. Sometimes the children, and their parents, live in New York; more often the children live in a faraway state. In that case, having a geriatric-care manager on call can eliminate the need to fly out on the next plane when a parent appears to be ill or having trouble.
"People get very nervous about a bureaucratic system, so they ask me to help them get on Medicaid and help them get into nursing homes when the need arises," Ms. Nowitz said. "It's helpful to have contacts at nursing homes. It can be an old-boy network."
For those who can't afford to hire a geriatric-care manager, public and nonprofit private agencies offer social workers who perform many of the same tasks, although usually with much larger caseloads.
Even considering the cost, clients seem to think geriatric-care managers can be invaluable. A 50-year-old New York City schoolteacher said he hired Ms. Nowitz to take his mother and his uncle to the doctor and find home health aides to care for them, but he also found Ms. Nowitz a reliable shoulder when he tired of hearing both his uncle, now almost 90, and his teen-age children complain that he didn't spend enough time with any of them.
"I talked to her once about my feelings, about having to deal first with my mother and now my uncle who needed care," said the man, who did not want his name used. "She seemed to understand that. I had tried therapy many years ago, and it really didn't work. I didn't think they understood me. This time, someone really seemed to have my emotions down pat."
He seems to have reached his own kind of peace with the problems of caring for elderly relatives. These days, he said, he keeps an old black-and-white photograph of himself as a toddler, dressed in a snowsuit and cradled in his uncle's arms, in a dresser drawer.
"He looks so proud," he said. "And now the situation is reversed. Every time I go for my socks in the morning I take a look at it. My uncle was always very good to me, and now I have an obligation to him."
 
One Family's History
 THE CHILD: Carolyn E. Mayo, 44 years old, married, with five children. Lives on Staten Island. Compensaiton manager for American International Group, an insurance company.
 PARENTS: Dorothy and Walter Spence, ages 78 and 83, of North Bayshore, L.I. She is diabetic; he lost a kidney to cance.r Both have eye problems, but are generally healthy.
 THE FINANCES: The Spences get annuity payments from Penn Central Railroad, where he worked, and have private health insurance and Medicare.
 WHAT SHE'S DONE: She knows where the key documents are. Her parents have a burial plot. She researched home care, but her parents rejected it as too expensive and intrusive.
 THE FUTURE: "I now have a list of resources, in the event I have to force my parents to take on these services."
 
 
BARRY HERMAN
 HIS STORY: 50 years old, married, with two children, one in college, the other in high school. Lives in Manhattan. Works as an international economist.
PARENTS: Father died 25 years ago. Mother, Fannie, 81, worked as a bookkeeper. She developed early signs of Alzheimer's in 1992 and lived in a residence for the elderly until last month, when she moved to a Bronx nursing home.
 FINANCES: Mother had assets. Some were transferred to family members; others are being spent to cover he care until she is eligivle for Medicaid, probably inApril. Total cost this year: about $50,000.
 WHAT HE'S DONE: He and his sister have obtained power of attorney and a health-care proxy.
 THE FUTURE: The nursing home is where their mother will stay. "We couldn't have done anything for her that would have been better."
 
 
CARL D'AQUINO
 HIS STORY: 46 year old, self-employed interior designer in Manhattan.
 PARENTS: Josephine andCarl D'Auino Sr., 73 and 79. Father worked as a laborer on the Manhattan Bridge, Mother worked until Carl and his two brother were born. Parents wanted to remain independent in their Brooklyn home but she suffered a serious illness in 1991. They were persuaded to move into a special housing complex for the elderlyin Queens. After a series of accidents on the ice last winter, they entered a nursing home, then another one. Both parents are alert. Mrs. D'Aquino is deaf. Mr. D'Aquino has advanced Parkinson's disease and has had three heart attacks.
 FINANCES: Savings werenot substantial. Both parents applied for and received Medicaid, although a health aide remains on the family payroll to assist Mrs. D'Aquino.
 WHAT HE HAS DONE: Divided responsibilities with his brothers. Carl takes care of housing and the physical environment; Roger does accounting and financial planning; Victor helped hire caregivers. The sons have been given power of attorney and health-care proxy rights.
 THE FUTURE: The issue, Carl D'Auino says, is keeping both parents active and happy.
 
Getting Beyond the Basics
 The issues faced by the elderly and their relatives can be dizzyingly complex. Here are some of the government and private agencies that can provide help, as well as more in-depth information.
* General information: New York City Department for the Aging, (212) 442-1000; New York Foundation for Senior Citizens, (212) 962-7559.

* Help in finding an advocate for a nursing home resident: Friends and Relatives of Institutionalized Aged, (212) 732-4455.
* Nurses who can conduct patient-review-instrument tests to evaluate need for care: Visiting Nurse of New York, (212) 714-9250; Catholic Charities, (212) 371-7000; Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, (212) 764-3878.
* Home health aides: New York Foundation for Senior Citizens, (212) 962-7559; Jewish Home and Hospital for Aged, (212) 870-5000.

* Hospice care: Department for the Aging, (212) 442-1000.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: THE VILLAGES;
MANHATTAN UPDATE

 BODY:

* PENNSYLVANIA STATION: The City Planning Commission has voted 5 to 4, with 2 abstentions, against renewing a Penn Station video arcade's three-year permit.
The arcade, Station Break, also known as Time Out Amusement Arcade, has been attracting mostly young people to its 100 video games for 16 years. Now the owners have 30 days to vacate the site, in the Long Island Rail Road concourse. 
 "We're obviously disappointed with the result, and it's too bad that 40 minority jobs may be lost," said Samuel H. Lindenbaum of the law firm Rosenman & Colin, who represent the arcade. He said the owners, Edison Brothers Mall Entertainment of St. Louis, were "exploring the options."
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which has invested $200 million to renovate the station, led the fight to evict the arcade, which it said was a center for truancy and disorderly conduct.
* 42d STREET: After a public hearing on the proposed 42d Street trolley this month, the City Planning Commission has scheduled a vote for April 11. If approved, the plan would go to the City Council for full review and final vote within 50 days, and then to the Mayor.
The cost of the Light Rail Project, as the plan is formally known, is estimated at $75 million. The trolley, privately owned and operated, would traverse midtown Manhattan at 42d Street. Borough President Ruth W. Messinger has given conditional support to the plan, but community boards in the area oppose it because of the cost and the disruption that would be caused by laying tracks.
 * HARLEM: Spring is around the corner, but the gardens many Harlem residents hoped to see sprouting in some vacant lots may not be.
Under the Dinkins administration, $1.25 million was included in this year's budget to turn a handful of vacant city-owned lots in Harlem and other low-income neighborhoods into gardens. But each site had to go through a lengthy land-use review process, so the funds were never made available. And now, because of the cuts the Giuliani administration listed in its recent budget proposal, the money is no longer available.
Frederic B. Winters, a spokesman for the Department of General Services, said last week that "there is no money in our budget for this project."
Linda Davidoff, the executive director of the Parks Council, which had lobbied for the gardens, said that her group was lobbying for the money to be restored.
"We're hoping that money really won't be extinguished from the budget," she said. "We're caught between two administrations."
