HEADLINE: Japan's Bureaucracy: No Sign It's Losing Any Power

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 26

 BODY:
In the two weeks since Japan and the United States collided over trade policy and began threatening each other with sanctions and counter-sanctions, President Clinton has repeatedly identified the real source of the problem: Japan's entrenched, turf-conscious bureaucrats.
"There's a big fight going on in Japan now," he said the other day, describing a classic struggle between the mandarins who have run Japan's industrial and trade policies for four decades and the reformers, led by Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa, who are fighting to open an economy now choking on overregulation. 
 But Mr. Clinton's description bears little resemblance to the reality of what is happening amid the cramped, battle-gray desks of Tokyo's powerful ministries, where the world's second biggest economy is ruled from some of world's grungiest offices.
Mr. Hosokawa rose to prominence as a bureaucrat-basher, complaining that mayors and governors needed to call Tokyo for approval to move a bus stop. Nonetheless, for two weeks he has said nothing publicly to suggest that his own views differ one iota from the bureaucracy's, especially when it comes to dealing with the angry Americans.
 
U.S. Attack Prompts Defense
 Indeed, if a fierce battle is now under way between Japan's new political leadership and its "permanent government," to use Mr. Clinton's phrase, almost no one here has noticed -- not the beleaguered business sector, not the bureaucrats themselves, not the American Embassy.
Mr. Clinton's attacks have even prompted leaders of the "reform" parties, which in the past have denounced the overconcentration of power in the hands of Japan's unelected elite, to rally to the bureaucrats' defense.
"It doesn't make any sense to condemn the bureaucrats," Ichiro Ozawa, the country's most powerful behind-the-scenes politician, said a few days ago. "If you look at the current situation, the problem is that the U.S. position is not very logical." He then launched into a familiar soliloquy about how the Clinton Administration is trying to manage its trade with Japan.
Noboru Hatakeyama, the former Deputy Minister of International Trade and Industry, who until a few months ago represented all the forces Mr. Clinton was talking about, said: "Maybe Clinton thought this was Russia or South America. There is no struggle here. It is patronizing: 'Poor Mr. Hosokawa, being beaten up by the big evil bureaucracy.' How would Mr. Clinton like it if we went on TV and talked about how he was being manipulated by the evil forces in Congress?"
 
Reputation Tarnished
 Certainly, these are not entirely happy days for the Japanese bureaucracy. Its reputation has been more than a little tarnished: newspapers feasted this week on the chaos that resulted from the public admission by a senior official that Japan had spent billions of dollars backing a technology for broadcasting high-definition television that is already outmoded.
Worse yet, the Prime Minister's trip to Washington, and the subsequent fallout, called into question whether the bureaucrats have lost one of their most valuable skills: placating the Americans.
"The bureaucracy has not yet changed the strategy it used in 12 years of contacts with the Reagan and Bush Administrations," the Yomiuri Shimbun, Japan's largest newspaper, said in an editorial the other day.
But while Japanese love to complain about the power and pettiness of the bureaucrats, they still view them with more than a little pride, as the source of stability that keeps the country running even in times of political upheaval.
That is why the top graduates of the University of Tokyo still vie for positions at the Ministry of Finance or the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, ahead of jobs in the private sector. Where else, they say, could they be given at age 35 so much responsibility, so much respect? And while the demand for computer chips or steel may rise and fall, Japanese always harbor a desire for some central control of the economy, now an integral part of the national culture.
Their reach is such that bureaucrats, rather than elected officials serving as ministers, usually answer questions in Parliament. They draft virtually all the laws, usually wording them in language vague enough to leave maximum discretion in enforcing them. Even judges are trained as bureaucrats, all sent to the same school, and appointed to the bench early in life so that they can be inculcated with the conservative traditions of the courts. Periodically on television, the chairman of a major company is seen being called in by a young bureaucrat for a dressing-down while camera crews record the older man bowing deeply in apology.
 
Wary of Tax Watchdog
 The Finance Ministry also watches over all tax investigations -- a fact that makes most of Japan's politicians, whose fund-raising efforts often live on the far edge of the tax laws, unlikely to challenge them.
But the most important source of the bureaucracy's power is that it has the monopoly on expertise, leaving any prime minister with no alternative source of strategy, especially in the enormously complex world of trade.
Unlike the White House, the prime minister's office has very little staff of its own. There is no real equivalent of the National Security Council, no separate council of economic advisers.
"The staff can barely keep up with routine tasks, let alone take the time to make future-oriented plans for prime ministerial action," Mr. Ozawa wrote in his recent book, "Blueprint for a New Japan."
There are virtually no political appointees at the subcabinet level. Members of Parliament are even more dependent on the bureaucracy for ideas: at most, they have one secretary devoted to policy, while there are several to keep constituents happy or raise money.
 
Commissions Infiltrated
 The result is that there is little contention in the system, apart from feuds between ministries. Mr. Hosokawa, perhaps sensing that he was setting himself up for manipulation, has created a large number of independent commissions to advise him on critical problems, including the deregulation of the economy -- the core issue with the United States. But somehow, bureaucrats or retired senior officials have infiltrated the commissions. The results, some members say, is that the recommendations so far have been tremendously watered-down.
"It was frustrating," said Yotaro Kobayashi, the head of Fuji-Xerox and a leading member of one of the advisory groups. "While we have a new system in place, we have the same people running it. With the politicians in chaos, the bureaucracy is the stopgap."
The American Ambassador here, Walter F. Mondale, describes Japan's bureaucrats in more vivid terms. He compares them to the material on on spacecraft that peels off, layer by layer, as the outside temperature gets hotter and hotter.
"You run in with flamethrowers," he said the other day, "and it just chars a little bit."
Even Mr. Mondale acknowledges his admiration for the skill and intelligence of Japan's bureaucrats; the problem is that their first mission is defending their own institutions. Indeed, even deregulation, the step intended to get the bureaucrats out of the market, has been turned on its head by agencies terrified that their power may be diminished.
 
New Bureaucracy for New Rice
 Not long ago the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, the country's biggest newspaper, reported how the Agriculture Ministry had managed to create a vast new bureaucracy to watch over imports of foreign rice, the biggest single market opening of Mr. Hosokawa's eight-month tenure.
New administrative orders are flying out the door, telling rice millers how to package and label their goods, how to price it, and then where to send it. "It is just like the days when rice was rationed," a bitter-sounding executive commented in the newspaper.
Even men like Akitane Kiuchi, a former Ambassador and recently Mr. Hososkawa's "secret messenger" to Washington, find themselves with some sympathy for Mr. Clinton's complaint.
"The Japanese are, unfortunately, the most conservative people in the world, and perhaps the bureaucrats are the most conservative among the Japanese," Mr. Kiuchi said. "Face it. We are not accustomed to change."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 2, 1994, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about Japan's entrenched bureaucracy misstated the circulation ranking of Nihon Keizai Shimbun, a daily newspaper that described the bureaucracy's handling of the opening of Japan's rice market to imports. It is the fourth-largest Japanese daily; the largest is Yomiuri Shimbun.

HEADLINE: The American Economy, Back on Top

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
DURING the Presidential campaign, Bill Clinton often fretted that the United States economy was fast becoming the world's also-ran. But more and more it looks as if he inherited a winner.
A 3 percent economic growth rate, a gain of two million new jobs in the past year and an inflation rate reminiscent of the 1960's make America the envy of the industrialized world. The amount the average American worker can produce, already the highest in the world, is growing faster than in other wealthy countries, including Japan. The United States has become the world's low-cost provider of many sophisticated products and services, from plastics to software to financial services. And after years of decline, the nation's share of the world export market has been rising. 
 For the most part, these advantages will continue even after countries like Japan and Germany snap out of their recessions. It is the United States, not Japan, that is the master of the next generation of commercially important computer and communications technologies and also of leading-edge services from medicine to movie making. And American managers are not only investing heavily in new equipment, they are also much farther along than those in Europe and Japan in streamlining and re-engineering their companies to make them more competitive. That's one reason that American industries that recently were losers -- like automobiles, machine tools, steel and computer chips -- are back with a vengeance.
The turnaround reflects more than 10 years of sometimes innovative and often wrenching change, driven by recession, deregulation, tougher foreign competition, the threat of takeovers, and, not least, new technology.
The image of the United States as an economic winner, once associated only with apologists for the Reagan era, is catching on. The French newspaper Le Monde and the Japanese newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun have each run long series on the new American competitive threat. Foreign leaders and executives who once lectured Americans on their shortcomings now speak enviously of this country's cleverness in churning out everything from jobs to Jeeps.
While such sentiments may seem more common abroad, there are signs that America's self-esteem is recovering. Some polls show that Americans once again see the United States as an economic giant. Rush Limbaugh, who likes to brag about America's prowess, is one of the most popular radio talk show hosts. By contrast, Bruce Springsteen, the balladeer of dying American factory towns, hasn't had a hit in a couple of years.
"Image and reality have both undergone a remarkable change in the last few years," said Michael Hammer, a business consultant and co-author of the best-seller "Re-engineering the Corporation." "American business -- not just manufacturing -- is again perceived as the world leader."
David Rolley, an international economist at the forecasting firm DRI/McGraw Hill, added: "Everyone thought the U.S. was a basket case, but others turned out to be bigger basket cases. Germany has too many good things, too many vacations. Japan is too much like I.B.M., such a successful model that nobody figured out what to do when it exhausted the model."
None of this is an excuse for giddiness. The gains have come at a high price. Even as the economy created new jobs, tens of millions of people lost their old ones and were forced to pull up stakes, take pay cuts, carve out new careers. The United States is still second best (or third or fourth) in many pursuits. And tomorrow's stars, from Malaysia to Mexico, pose growing challenges for many an American business.
Also, the recovery here and the recessions abroad are bound to highlight American strengths and foreign weaknesses. America's turnaround may look better than it is because reports of the nation's demise were exaggerated to begin with. And, as always, what looks like a lot of improvement to one person looks like too little to another.
Finally, the benefits of economic leadership are mostly psychic. The struggle to make the economic pie bigger and insure that all citizens get a slice is largely a race against oneself, not against other countries. And being the economic leader is no cure for some of the most serious problems American society faces, including crime, inadequate education, the growing isolation of the underclass, the rampant economic insecurity that many middle-class Americans feel, and, for that matter, the malaise that can come with working so hard to do better.
But the changing perception of America is already subtly influencing the way we think. Infatuation with the Japanese or German model of capitalism is becoming less fashionable, and the massive government meddling advocated by so many critics to reverse the nation's supposed decline is less appealing to a lot of people.
For example, despite promises of more government help for so-called strategic industries, the Clinton Administration has not budgeted much money for such an industrial policy. And Washington will probably not lurch toward European-style "managed trade," through which the Government sets targets for how much companies should buy from, and sell to, foreigners -- recent threats to limit Japan's access to the American market notwithstanding. And almost no one expects the big worker-retraining programs proposed during the Presidential campaign to materialize.
In fact, interest is growing in less costly ways to let people roll with the punches -- from getting welfare mothers into jobs to making it easier for workers to change jobs without losing pensions or health coverage.
The climate could still change. A trade war with Japan, while unlikely, is nevertheless a possibility. The Federal Reserve Board could turn a blind eye as the inflation genie slips out of the bottle. There's always the possibility that health care reform, if it happens, will add costs to businesses and therefore stifle job creation. Efforts to protect the people who have suffered in the economic transformation could backfire -- as they have in Europe -- if they take the form of protectionism or laws that make it harder for businesses to shrink payrolls or get out of unprofitable businesses.
But many people, including the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, think that the many recent positive signs, especially the rebound in productivity growth, signal that the United States economy will do even better in the 1990's than in the 1980's. That means, they argue, that more Americans will share in the economy's gains.
 
The Evidence
Glowing Numbers And More to Come
 Some of the evidence of America's impressive economic performance has been around for years but ignored. Most of it is fairly new.
Start with the most basic yardstick of economic health, the growth of productivity, or output per worker. Productivity determines how fast living standards can rise.
The American worker is the most productive in the world by far, producing on average $49,600 in goods and services a year in 1990 -- $5,000 more than German workers, $10,000 more than Japanese counterparts. Moreover, while productivity was growing more quickly abroad than in the United States for most of the 20th century, America has lately been gaining more quickly, as companies here figure out how to provide more and better products and services with new technologies and fewer workers.
Since the start of the economic recovery nearly three years ago, United States productivity has been growing at an annual rate of 2.5 percent, more than twice as fast as the average between 1970 and 1990, and markedly better than elsewhere.
The United States lead is widest in services. Retailing is twice as productive in the United States as in Japan, where laws protect the shopkeeper from the discount chain. The deregulated American telecommunications industry is at least twice as productive as Germany's government monopoly. The fragmented American banking industry is a third more efficient than Germany's banking oligopolies. The American edge in these industries has recently been expanding, not shrinking.
Gains on the factory floor have lately been even more stellar than for the economy over all: Hourly output has been rising nearly 5 percent a year for three years even as it has flattened or fallen in Germany and Japan. The United States lead in manufacturing, which had been shrinking as Germany and Japan caught up or moved ahead in some industries, has lately been widening again.
"You're seeing today the results of actions undertaken in the second half of the 1980's," said Stanley Gault, the chief executive who helped revive the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and Rubbermaid Inc.
THERE are at least two reasons for thinking that the American productivity lead won't evaporate when Germany and Japan recover from their recessions. One is that investment, especially in computers, is booming. The other, more important, reason is that corporate America started the painful task of learning how to make more, more quickly and with fewer resources, earlier than many of its overseas counterparts, especially in Europe.
In a recent Harvard Business Review article, Shintaro Hori, a director of the consulting firm Bain & Company Japan, estimated that Japanese companies will have to shed 15 to 20 percent of their white-collar work forces to match the low overhead in America.
"There are far fewer re-engineering efforts under way in Japanese and German companies compared with the United States," said Mr. Hammer, the consultant, whose firm has trained thousands of American managers to overhaul their companies in the last few years but few from foreign corporations.
Hard evidence is the reward American companies are reaping: Despite the moderate pace of the economic recovery, inflation-adjusted corporate profits are close to an all-time high.
In some smokestack industries -- steel, machine tools and especially cars -- the choice was to raise productivity and quality a lot or cede the field to the competition, as American companies did in consumer electronics. American managers chose the former, lifting productivity in the auto plants, for example, by an average of 10 percent every year during the late 1980's, according to McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm.
Indeed, no sooner did "The Reckoning" -- the book by David Halberstam that focused on Ford and Nissan to tell "the story of Japan's ascent and America's subtle industrial decline" -- appear in 1985 than did Ford begin its comeback and Nissan begin to falter. Ford's market share has since climbed to 25.5 percent of the American market from 21.3 percent, while Nissan, with 5.0 percent today, never improved on the 5.3 percent it held in the mid-1980's.
IN the first half of the 1980's, many American products were not only inferior to, but also pricier than, those offered by other nations. The grossly overvalued dollar -- which made American exports expensive and imports cheap -- was largely to blame. But so were a clutch of bad habits -- from executives' granting fat pay increases to Washington's tolerating too much inflation.
These days, by contrast, American factories ship steel to Seoul, transistors to Tokyo, cars to Cologne and Spandex to Siena (for bicycle pants). America's exports have been rising nearly 9 percent a year since 1985, even faster than Japan's 6.6 percent and Germany's 4.2 percent. Even more telling, the United States' share of exports by industrialized countries, which shrank to nearly 10 percent a decade ago, close to a post-war low, has rebounded to its 1980 level, around 14 percent.
Small wonder. Thanks to the weaker dollar, more moderate wage settlements and gains in efficiency, American production costs have been rising more slowly than those in Europe and Japan: 1.1 percent a year since 1985, compared with 2.5 percent in Europe and 1.7 percent in Japan. BMW of North America Inc. and Mercedes-Benz of North America Inc. are building their new plants in the American South. And, to hold down the price of their new models, Japanese car makers with plants in America are resorting to a strategy considered unthinkable just a few years ago: raising as much as possible the content of locally procured parts, as Honda said it would do this year.
Contrast this with Germany's cost problem. At current exchange rates German manufacturing workers are paid about $26 an hour, $10 more than American and Japanese factory hands. The problem is so serious that Chancellor Helmut Kohl devoted the German equivalent of the State of the Union message last October to the problem of German competitiveness.
"It seems as if there is still nothing more important than thinking about how we can expand our recreation time," he scolded. "If we want to secure Germany's future, we cannot organize our country as if it were one big recreation park."
Making things less expensively isn't enough to captivate a world full of ever more affluent, increasingly sophisticated consumers. That requires a prodigious stream of new ideas and invention. A case in point is the converging world of computing, telecommunications and television.
"We're in the midst of the third industrial revolution," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Company, "and the United States is leading it."
The European technology industry is in deep trouble, its stagnant revenue, lack of new products and need for billions in government subsidies evident even before the recession. Japan has been a leader in consumer electronics. But, as its retreat in high-definition television shows, that country is still mainly the master of mass-produced components -- flat panel displays, memory chips, fax machines.
Six years ago, the fear was that Japanese dominance would spread to leading-edge technologies. But Japanese electronics giants like the Hitachi Zosen Corporation, the NEC Corporation and the Toshiba Corporation haven't been able to keep up with changing technology and American companies like the Intel Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation are in the lead in virtually all the key ingredients of the business- and personal-computer revolution: software, workstations, laser printers, computer networks and the computers-on-a-chip known as microprocessors.
"Everything important gets invented here," said Charles Ferguson, a Cambridge, Mass., technology consultant who a few years ago was warning darkly of the Japanese threat. The growing demand for sophisticated products will probably play to the strengths of American producers. So might the fact that American consumers are already more familiar with new technology than people abroad. Compared with Japan, for example, the United States has more than three times as many personal computers per worker.
"More Americans are familiar with these technologies and are using them in everyday life," Mr. Steinberg said. "And more American businesses have learned to use the technology to improve productivity."
 
The Reasons
Economic 'Vices' Are Also Virtues
 Are there reasons for the American comeback other than inventiveness, streamlining, re-engineering, the adaptability of workers and managers, lower inflation and interest rates, and a weaker dollar?
Yes, indeed. Often overlooked is that some of this nation's supposed vices -- from a reluctance to protect and regulate industries, to an obsession with short-term profits -- have turned out to be virtues as well. And the much-praised features of Japanese and German capitalism -- from managed trade to lifetime employment -- have proved to have drawbacks.
The fact that American companies are regularly exposed to the toughest competitors on their home turf is a blessing as well as a curse. Detroit was forced to compete head to head with Japanese cars. European auto makers enjoyed far more protection from Japan. For a while, the jobs of tens of thousands of European auto workers and their bosses were safe, but now a huge downsizing is all but inevitable.
Lighter regulation in the United States than in other nations proved bracing for many American service companies because it encouraged competition. American shopkeepers cannot fall back on the kind of zoning laws that shield mom-and-pop stores in Japan from certain death by would-be Wal-Marts. A.T.& T. has been at the forefront of communications technology in large part because of challenges from the likes of MCI Communications Inc. and the Sprint Corporation. United Airlines gives passengers a better price because Southwest Airlines does. Contrast the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and United with their German counterparts, which remain carefully guarded state monopolies, though things are beginning to change.
Even the focus by investors and bankers on last quarter's bottom line may turn out to be less of a handicap than some argue. Impatient institutional investors blew the whistle when profits shrank, as did bank lenders without the cozy ties to corporate boards that exist in countries like Germany and Japan.
And the deep pain of layoffs has produced important gains. To be sure, the dislocation caused by layoffs in one American industry after another since the early 1980's is staggering. In the past decade, estimates Steven Davis, a labor economist at the University of Chicago, 1 in 10 manufacturing jobs -- two million -- vanished every year, even though the net decline in factory jobs over the decade was only about 1 million.
But it is becoming clear that the ability to move workers quickly from one industry to another also has benefits to the economy -- in the form of increased productivity that is essential to raising the standard of living.
For all the layoffs, the fact is that the number of new jobs has far outstripped the number of jobs lost in recent years. The United States economy has added 18 million jobs in the past decade, a net gain of more than 20 percent, including 2 million in the past year. And the unemployment rate has dropped about 1.5 percentage points in the past 18 months, to just over 6 percent. The economies of the European Community, which combined are the same size as the American economy, have added just 7 million jobs in 10 years, a net increase of 7 percent, and have grappled with unemployment rates, now in the double digits, that haven't fallen below 8 percent in a decade.
 
The Dissent
But What About That Trade Deficit?
 Perhaps the most compelling counterargument to the notion that America is doing so well is this: Imports are rising three times faster than exports and the trade deficit, which was shrinking during the late 1980's, is swelling. "How can Japan pay wages that are higher, have productivity that is lower and still sell us $60 billion more than they buy?" asked Lester Thurow, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who is much in favor at the White House by dint of his book "Head to Head: The Coming Battle Among Japan, Europe and America."
But the trade deficit is not a particularly reliable yardstick of the health of an economy for two reasons. The first is that how much countries buy abroad depends on their income as well as the attractiveness of the foreign products, and America's income (in short, its gross domestic product) is rising more rapidly than that of most other nations.
The more subtle reason is that critics of American competitiveness have a habit of focusing on trade figures that capture only goods that are traded internationally, ignoring the service sector. Yet America's economic performance depends far more on service industries, which now employ three out of four American workers.
So America's back in the lead. But that's no excuse to relax. "Things are going to get different again," said Mr. Hammer. "People think the hard work is over, but hard work is going to be a permanent condition."

An article last Sunday about the American economy incorrectly characterized the popularity of Bruce Springsteen. Mr. Springsteen has had several successful recordings in recent years, including his current song "Streets of Philadelphia."

Europe and Japan have stumbled while the United States economy is growing, inflation is low and productivity and employment are rising. After more than a decade of painful change and dislocation, many American industries are leaner and nimbler and others have seized the leadership of the sophisticated technologies that are ushering in the information age. HEADLINE: Tax Law, Weather Plague Restaurants

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
WESTCHESTER restaurants are having a bad time," observed M'el Eudes who, with her husband, Henri, owns Auberge Argenteuil, a French restaurant in Hartsdale. "Places are closing left and right. Now the drop in the tax deduction for business meals is the last straw."
What Mrs. Eudes was referring to was the change in the tax deduction for business meals and entertainment, which took effect on Jan. 1 and reduced the tax deduction to 50 percent from 80 percent. 
 But the outlook is not unfavorable for all restaurants. Some are preparing to take advantage of the fact that catered meals on company premises remain fully tax deductible.
 
1989 Saw Beginning of Change
 When the Eudes bought Argenteuil 17 years ago, the deduction was 100 percent. It dropped to 80 percent in 1986. "The economy was strong then," Ms. Eudes recalled. "Companies were booming." But in 1989 things began to change.
"Corporations were among our steady customers," Ms. Eudes said. "Our restaurant is made up of a series of private rooms, which lend themselves nicely for luncheon and dinner meetings. We are a classic French restaurant, and we only use fresh ingredients in the French tradition, and we built up a loyal following. A pharmaceutical house, for instance, would regularly invite groups of doctors for lunch to introduce new products to them."
 
Decline in Corporate Business
 By 1989, however, "a lot of companies began moving out of state, others left the area, and we began to see a fall-off in corporate business," Ms. Eudes said. "Today we are seeing fewer and fewer corporate credit cards."
If the drop in the deduction wasn't bad enough for business, the weather wasn't helping either, Ms. Eudes said. "Since January we have been closed more days than we ever have before in all the 17 years in business." But what especially troubled her about the new ruling was its ripple effect.
"It is going to hurt the people who can least afford it, the restaurant workers," Ms. Eudes said. "They will be out of jobs. We are a small restaurant, and we once employed 30 people. Now we are down to 12."
John Antun, owner of Antun's of Westchester in Elmsford and the former president of both the Westchester Restaurant Association and the New York State Restaurant Association, a trade group, estimates that more than 100,000 jobs will be lost nationally in the restaurant industry.
"Fourteen years ago, it was almost impossible to find waitresses or cooks. Now well-qualified cooks are knocking on my door looking for work. That's how much things have changed."
And it is the restaurants who relied most on the expense-account lunch and dinner, Mr. Antun said, that are especially feeling the pinch.
"Some places have stopped serving lunch entirely," Mr. Antun said. "Restaurants all over the state have been affected. Perceptions are different. Corporations don't want to be seen as extravagant. Corporate clients ask us for banquets and parties that are low-key affairs. What I find interesting is that price is not so much the issue as is the desire not to look lavish."
Henry A. Fondu, one of the owners of Olliver's in White Plains, said that some of his regular customers have already been advised by their employers to cut back on business meals.
"Over the years we have worked up very good relationships with our corporate clients and it is no question that the new ruling will have a negative impact on our lunch and dinner business," Mr. Fondu said. "Companies are not only telling their executives to be more frugal but they are advising them to invite more clients to the company dining room more often."
But so far this year, it is "the weather that has hurt us more than the tax change," Mr. Fondu said. "The snow has been terrible for business."
 
An Essential Business Tool
 One of the things about the deduction for business meals that especially bothers Ms. Eudes is the misconception that the ruling will affect only the rich.
"I can't believe that Congress actually thought this one through," she said. "In addition to the restaurant workers who will be losing their jobs, the tax will hurt middle-income people like traveling salespeople and truck drivers who have to spend money for meals when they are on the road."
And there are those who feel that the business lunch is essential, whatever the penalty.
"Oh, sure, the new ruling will hurt, but the bottom line is that we will have to absorb it as part of the cost of doing business," said Donald R. Levin, president of Levin Public Relations and Marketing in White Plains. "It has its business purposes, and I will continue to take people out for lunch and dinner as much as I feel is necessary."
 
Detrimental Effect Expected
 Mr. Levin, who figured that he takes clients and prospective clients to lunch or dinner several times a week, said that the value of the business lunch is that there are fewer distractions in a restaurant than in an office.
"Just getting away from the telephone is worth it," he said. "There's less pressure and I can get a client's undivided attention. Business luncheons are much more productive than exchanging ideas in an office setting."
Mr. Levin, who favors the restaurants in Stouffer Westchester Hotel, the Rye Town Hilton and Doral Arrowwood, said he spends on the average of $35 for lunch and $50 for dinner for two. "People eat pretty sparingly today, and very few order drinks other than a glass of wine, usually at dinner," he said.
Ralph Serrecchia, manager of Povare Restaurant at Arrowwood, said the new rules would have a detrimental effect on all restaurants.
"I think we are feeling it at dinner more than at lunch, but we will have a better slant on it after we get two normal months of business back to back," he said. "It's hard to judge now how it has affected us so far because the weather has been so bad that business is off anyway."
Yet, Mr. Serrecchia said, the restaurant has stepped up its efforts on special promotions to attract new business. "We are going after local business people who are not necessarily on expense accounts, in addition to local residents," he said.
 
An Opportunity for Some
 And although the drop in deductions angers many of those in the restaurant industry, Mr. Antun said that it might actually benefit modest establishments that have never been on the expense-account circuit.
"Customers will be looking for lower-priced meals," he said, adding that restaurants were also exploring new ways to sell business meals.
"I look upon it as a new market opportunity for restaurants to get into on-site catering," he said. "When meals are delivered to a corporate headquarters or an off-site customer, they are 100 percent deductible as a business expense. We are busy promoting the concept of 'great food to go.' " Arrowwood, Mr. Serrecchia said, is also poised to deliver meals to customers in their offices. "Everything is in place. We expect to start the service shortly."
When she was asked about on-site catering, Ms. Eudes said: "We can't do that. Our master chef can't be in two places at once. We are regrouping in a different way by promoting events such as wedding luncheons and dinners and theme evenings. For example, we recently sent out 300 mailings for a Night in Provence dinner on March 4, which is price-fixed at $45, including wine. In this business you have to do something or you can't make it and you close."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Today we are seeing fewer and fewer corporate credit cards," said M'el Eudes, who, with her husband, Henri, owns Auberge Argenteuil, a French restaurant in Hartsdale. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Connecticut;
Plans Afoot for New Or Expanded Malls

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
AT LEAST a dozen major mall expansions or new malls are being planned across Connecticut, even though retail sales have been flat for five years.
Christopher J. Tennyson, senior vice president of Taubman Inc., said mall developers were looking to the future. His company, based in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., has proposed a 381,000-square-foot expansion of the hugely successful Westfarms Mall, which straddles the West Hartford-Farmington line. The million-square-foot mall has four anchor stores. 
 "Building this will take about two years," Mr. Tennyson said. "If you build only in boom times, you're likely to open in down times. We think things will turn around in the two years it will take us to complete this project."
Taubman is also discussing with New Haven officials the development of an urban mall and is considering a 300,000-square-foot expansion of its 900,000-square-foot Stamford Town Center mall, which would let it add a new anchor store to the three already there, as well as 30 or 40 new shops.
Among other plans is one announced in December by the New York-based Charter Oak Partners for an 80-store, 400,000-square-foot mall on 103 acres in Westbrook, a few miles from where Connecticut Factory Stores is planning a 300,000-square-foot mall on 47 acres in Clinton.
In addition, Homart, based in Chicago, has an option to purchase a site in Waterbury for a new regional mall; Wilmorite, based in Rochester, is considering a site in Plainville and Erichetti Associates has proposed a 925,000-square-foot mall in its hometown of Cheshire, Conn.
All this is happening amid signs that a turnaround may have begun. Connecticut retailers reported 7 to 8 percent increases in Christmas sales over the previous year, said Ronald J. Pugliese, president of the Connecticut Retail Merchants Association, for a third consecutive year of rising sales.
Mr. Pugliese said that Connecticut had long had the highest per capita income in the country and that its unemployment rate was still relatively low. (The unemployment rate as of the end of 1993 was 5.9 percent, compared with more than 7 percent a year earlier; the state estimates that per capita income was $21,321 last year. In 1990, it was $20,189, the highest in the nation, compared with the national average of $14,420.)
Mr. Pugliese said that retailers, looking at those data, were bound to say, "Connecticut is a good place to be, so let's get in there."
Mr. Tennyon, of Taubman, said that "if you look at household income and college education and life style, Connecticut is an extremely attractive market."
John A. Erichetti, president of Erichetti Associates, which has approvals for a 925,000-square-foot mall at the intersections of Routes 691 and 10 in Cheshire, said that his development company was seeing first-hand the revival of Connecticut's economy.
"Our phone is ringing more often, capital is loosening up and investors are coming back into the market looking for deals," Mr. Erichetti said. "I think Connecticut is through the worst of it."
Mr. Erichetti said there was a lot of interest in new retail complexes because store configurations had changed so much in recent years, away from anchor stores and small shops and towards "category killers," such as Toys 'R' Us and Sound Playground, and club-type stores that offer members special discounts. Also, he said, some stores want to improve their location.
William E. Kane Jr., a mall development expert with Edward Heberger and Associates, a real-estate appraisal and consulting concern based in Cheshire, said mall developers wanted to duplicate the success of some relatively new retail projects, such as the Pavilion at Buckland Hills mall in Manchester. They are looking for niches that are unserved or underserved by regional malls, and there are still a few such pockets, such as in the Waterbury area, he said.
THAT is what is behind Homart's proposal for an 850,000-square-foot mall with four anchor stores and 120 smaller shops on 80 acres off Interstate 84 in Waterbury, said Kristine Sandrick, vice president for marketing at Homart. Meriden Center, a mall Homart co-developed, is a 20-minute drive from the Waterbury site, Ms. Sandrick, said, but "we don't have a problem with overlapping that market area" because "the Waterbury market in general is really underserved."
Ms. Sandrick said that Homart, which developed Buckland Hills, was hoping for a similar success in Waterbury. "We feel there are a lot of similarities," she said.
Mr. Kane said he doubted that all the proposals would come to fruition. There are three proposals in Waterbury, for instance, he said, but only one mall would survive "so they fight to see who can get their applications in first, and who can get the anchor tenants signed up first."
"I doubt all three of them would be built," he said, adding that the increase in proposals was ironic, because any mall development might be risky today.
"The department-store industry is going through a real shakeout," he said. "Malls are competing with specialty stores like The Gap and The Limited for clothing, and Sound Playground and Lechmere are taking away the hard-goods market. Stand-alone thrifts like Kmart and Wal-Mart and Bradlee are doing well, so a mall's sales base is eroding."
But some developers are trying to capitalize on the changes in shopping patterns. Jeffrey L. Johnson, a partner in Connecticut Factory Stores, for example, has proposed a 300,000-square-foot mall of factory-outlet stores in Clinton.
"In the entire spectrum of retail development, factory outlets are a real bright spot," Mr. Johnson said. "Sales in factory outlets continue to grow at a pace much quicker than other areas of retail."
He said that he had commitments for more than 60 percent of the space and that if the Charter Oak project in neighboring Clinton was built, rather than hurt his project, it could serve to establish the shoreline towns as a destination for factory-outlet shoppers.
"There are no other significant factory outlet centers in the state of Connecticut," Mr. Johnson said. "And in other areas, factory-outlet shoppers tend to have higher incomes and more education than people who shop in other retail outlets. The demographics in Connecticut are the quintessential factory-outlet shopper."
Other mall development companies are looking to diversify. William L. Grad, general manager of the Crystal Mall in Waterford, owned by New England Development, is seeking approval for two additional developments, each 200,000 to 250,000 square feet. He said one would be for one or two large tenants that did not like malls and the other could be retail-oriented development such as restaurants and movie theaters.
"We know it's a wonderful location based on the nine years we've been in this spot," Mr. Grad said. "The mall has been fully leased the last eight of those years."
Mr. Tennyson said Taubman wanted to expand and renovate its Westfarms and Stamford Town Center malls to make sure they remained among the preeminent retailing complexes in the state.
"One of the reasons you expand and change is to hold onto your franchise," he said.
IN late January the Farmington Zoning Commission approved plans for the $100 million Westfarms Mall expansion after Taubman agreed to direct traffic as much as possible away from residential areas of Farmington. The plans call for 311,000 square feet of retail space and two parking garages in the Farmington portion of the mall. Taubman is awaiting West Hartford's action on the rest of the addition, 70,000 square feet of retail space and a third parking garage.
Kathy Shields, the development director for Homart on the Waterbury mall project, said the company hoped to have it open in mid-1996. Market studies have shown that there are 350,000 people, with an average household income of $49,000, in the towns the mall would draw from, she said, and that they did not have a major mall within a 20- to 30-minute drive.
"'You don't get many clear-cut trade areas like that, that aren't already serviced by a regional mall," she said.

HEADLINE: Better, Brighter Space on a Tight Budget

BYLINE: By VALERIE CRUICE 

 BODY:
IN a tight economy, an architect's job is particularly challenging: How to meet a project's objectives within strict budgetary guidelines -- and still create an exciting design.
Eight firms, having met those challenges, have been recognized by the American Institute of Architects, Connecticut, in its 31st annual design awards competition. 
 The diversity of their projects indicates that creativity is alive and well in the state, whether it be applied to police substations in New Haven or to a biotechnical research center in a cornfield in Mystic or to a vandal-resistant community center for Latino Youth Development in New Haven.
The jurors were Charles Redmon of Cambridge 7 Associates Inc. in Cambridge, Mass.; John M. Clancy of Goddy, Clancy & Associates Inc. in Boston, and Eve Kahn, architectural critic for The Wall Street Journal.
Most of the 62 architects submitting entries indicated that the state was experiencing a brain drain, referring to the loss of corporate and military operations. But, as Linda H. Griffis, program director of the A.I.A. Connecticut put it, "The jurors were delighted to see some low-budget work that was beautifully done."
 
A Center for Latinos
 That the community center for Latino Youth Development Inc. was built at all is a remarkable achievement, according to Charles Beckman Swanson, the New Haven-based architect who brought it in at $70 a square foot. "They had worked out of a former holding jail for a police substation abandoned 25 years ago, but wanted to create a home of their own," he said. "They began to solicit funds and came up with $554,000 in Federal, state and city grants. We spent every penny of it but no more."
A concrete masonry structure, the building houses a game room, tutoring room, counseling facilities and an entire floor devoted to allied outreach programs and offices. It serves as an informational, counseling and cultural resource center.
Even with its tough outer shell, the center is still vulnerable to vandalism -- paint in particular. But an amazing understanding has been reached in the neighborhood.
"The people who operate the building approached the families of known gang members -- the Latino Kings -- and asked them to please save the facility, and they have. It's been up now a year and a half," Mr. Swanson said. "The statement that this building has made to the community is permanence to Latino youth development. It has improved their status."
 
Police Substations
 Another award-winning project executed on "the tightest of budgets," in the jurors' words, is the community-based police substation system for the city of New Haven. Robert Roscow oversaw the project for the Center for Architecture Inc., situated in Wallingford.
"They are really the first of their kind," said Mr. Roscow, referring to the seven structures now present in some of New Haven's most troubled neighborhoods. "The whole concept is you have the policemen on foot assigned to an area -- that gives you a reason for having these substations."
A grant from the state enabled the substations to go up. The architect designed one prototype, suitable for modular construction, from which all could be derived.
"They're very simple little buildings," Mr. Roscow said. "There are no lockups, no booking area, no video cameras at the door. They serve more as an outpost. One side has desks and lockers; on the other side is a meeting room for 30 to 40 people with a kitchen. It's open to different groups in the community."
An added attraction, especially for the local children, is the horse stall prominently situated at the front of each substation to accommodate the mounted patrol. "The horses are bathed, there is hot and cold running water for them, and the kids can pet the horse," he said.
 
Facelift for Schools
 Children and the booming school enrollment were the focus of the winning design of Harold Roth of New Haven, who was charged with the expansion and renovation of two identical elementary schools in Branford.
"We wanted to completely change the image of the schools." Mr. Roth said. "It was done in a way to expand the kind of activity that would enrich the curriculum; a library -- science, music and art facilities. There was no hot lunch program, no place for indoor assemblies."
The Mary Tisko and Mary Murphy schools were both tripled in size, in each case using the original building as the side of a square with an interior courtyard. The new lunch room and library became the front of each school.
 
Battling the Saugatuck
 Fighting to save a historic building from the encroaching waters of the Saugatuck River was challenging enough for Roger Ferris of Southport, but the project nearly drowned because of town zoning.
National Hall, an 1873 Italianate edifice, was originally built as a bank for Westport. "At the time," Mr. Ferris said, "the Saugatuck River was navigable and a port. We have photos that show the large ships right in front of it. The town fathers thought that it would become an important port." The railroads, however, changed all that, he added.
Besides being the town's bank, the building served -- concurrently -- as the town high school, the state police barracks and Town Hall. "This now stands as an odd building, not in keeping with anything else. That's why modern-day regulations didn't fit it very well," Mr. Ferris said.
For the developer to save the building, which was "falling into the Saugatuck River" according to Mr. Ferris, three years were spent in the "regulatory arena and involved 19 local, state and Federal agencies."
Winning designation for the site as a Historic Design District, the architect was able to go ahead with the plan, which called for a 15-suite inn and a restaurant. "The next step was to basically build a new building within the existing shell," Mr. Ferris said. "That whole process included all new steel foundations and rebuilding the cast-iron facade. I liken it to putting one's sock on with one's shoe on."
 
Making a Church Inviting
 Another historic building needed to change with the times, and Steven McAlister of New Hartford did just that for the First Congregational Church in Collinsville, on the National Register of Historic Places.
"My main objective was to allow a contemporary, family, evangelical congregation to use it, without destroying its historical character," explained Mr. McAlister.
The architect said the Greek Revival church was built in 1858 by the Collins family, of the Collins Ax Company (relocated to Asia), and reflected a time when the pulpit was elevated, the choir was out of sight at the back and the feeling was very formal, very Puritan. The church also had an unfinished appearance, indicated by lack of moldings and the use of simple pipe columns.
Mr. McAllister's design for the interior was derived from Greek Revival, and the most dramatic change was the replacement of the pipe columns. "The day the new columns went in, it changed," he said. He also curved the balcony, which was "a weird place to be with no connection to the rest of the church," he said. He raised and canted the pews for a better view of the altar platform, and enlarged the narthex and installed glazed doors in a "conscious attempt to bring the people in the street inside."
 
A Design for Corn
 Creating a strain of corn that is naturally resistant to drought and insects is the charge of scientists who work in the new Discovery Research Center in Mystic. The research facility was designed by a team headed by William H. Grover, of Centerbrook Architects in Stonington.
"This is a biotechnical research center -- we've done quite a few of these," Mr. Grover said. "We had to design laboratories that were relatively inexpensive for a start-up company. It had to be economical, a nice place so they could hire young scientists who wanted to work there, and it had to be a good neighbor to the nursing home next door."
All different kinds of equipment needed to be accommodated, as well as a library, offices, laboratories and greenhouses. "They take things from a single cell and grow a tiny plant to a giant corn plant in a continuous operation," Mr. Grover said. The complex, to blend in with its agricultural location, resembles barns and is surrounded by cornfields.
To house aspiring scientists among other students, Chad Floyd, also of Centerbrook Architects, designed the Academic Center and Honor Housing for the University of Toledo in Ohio.
"It's a 400-bed dorm to house honors students," Mr. Floyd explained. "The idea is that this is an opportunity for those who are really studious to gather in a student atmosphere."
An academic building, yet to be erected, was also designed as part of a master plan. "The look of the building has its roots in the campus itself -- from the academic Gothic style of architecture -- and is similar in hue and value to the buff-colored native limestone on the early traditional buildings on campus," Mr. Floyd said.
Before sitting down to draw, Mr. Floyd had workshop sessions with faculty, students and staff members. "It was clear people longed for some sense of continuity. What we did was to create a new architecture that employs some general Gothic sensitivities but build it with a contemporary sensibility," he said.
The jury noted the project's use of simple materials, the brick pattern at the base, the aluminum roofing and the wonderful chimneys set at an angle to the roofing.
 
A Library for the Light
 The only winning residential project was a library addition described by the jurors as "a plain, brown wrapper with all the icing inside."
"It's a lighthouse, a tower of learning, and kind of a folly," said David Austin, of Austin Patterson Associates in Southport. The three-story library tower was built on an existing foundation, an addition to the original 1820's waterfront tavern, now the home of a Darien family. To reflect the owners' interest in boating, the architect included all kinds of nautical references.
For example, the first-level ceiling beams look as though they are connected to the ribs of a ship. And to gain access to the second and third levels, one has to ascend a single-tread, industrial ladder with spark ling brass railings. The whole structure is tapered to the top, just like a lighthouse, with the third level affording vast views of the river, harbor and Long Island Sound. The floor of the third level is executed in industrial glass blocks, "to bring the light down," said the architect.
An avid sailor himself, Mr. Austin said, "I couldn't resist trying this."

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Study Indian Point 3 Plant

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: BUCHANAN

 BODY:
THREE state lawmakers have begun an inquiry into economic and safety issues at Indian Point 3, the New York Power Authority's nuclear plant here.
Richard L. Brodsky, a State Assemblyman representing parts of Greenburgh, said last week that in the long run, keeping the plant open may not make economic sense, considering the cost of decommissioning the reactor and expenses associated with nuclear waste disposal among other things. 
 The 17-year-old Indian Point 3 was voluntarily shut down a year ago and remains closed, pending work to correct problems identified by the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Last June, after a series of unfavorable evaluations, the 965-megawatt plant was placed on the commission's watch list of the country's most troubled reactors. In July, a performance review by the regulatory body cited inadequate management controls.
 
Safety and Management Also at Issue
 Paul D. Tonko, chairman of the Assembly's Energy Committee and an Assemblyman from the 105th District, which includes Schenectady, has joined Mr. Brodsky in the study of Indian Point 3. Also on the panel is Albert Vann, chairman of the Committee on Corporations, Authorities and Commissions, and an Assemblyman representing the 56th District in Brooklyn.
Mr. Brodsky, chairman of the Assembly's Environmental Conservation Committee, has questioned "the true value" of Indian Point 3, considering the fact that the plant is "down almost 50 percent of the time" and during those periods alternative power must be purchased by the New York Power Authority in order to supply its customers.
In addition to studying the economics of keeping the plant open, the legislative inquiry is focusing on safety issues at the plant and management practices, which the Nuclear Regulatory Commission called deficient.
"The question of safety is something I have been looking at for a long, long time," Mr. Brodsky said. "My point now is that this needs to be thoroughly researched and investigated."
 
A Source of Employment
 James F. X. Steets, communications manager for Indian Point 3, said that the benefits of the plant "have been demonstrated in a $2 billion saving to our customers in New York City and Westchester" since 1976 when the plant opened. The plant's license to operate expires in 2016.
Mr. Steets also said that the plant employs 654 full-time workers and up to 900 part-timers during power failures, which, he said, "has a favorable impact on the local economy in terms of jobs." He also said that most of the management issues had been "addressed and resolved" and that the power authority was looking at a possible reopening of the plant this fall.
But Mr. Brodsky said that Mr. Steets' reassurances notwithstanding, the public had become increasingly worried about the safety and economic issues.
At least one hearing will be scheduled in the spring, and Mr. Steets said the power authority would cooperate by providing whatever information was needed by the legislators.
Mr. Brodsky, however, predicted that the hearing would "be a watershed" and added: "Something very, very major is happening to the policies and politics regarding Indian Point 3. The safety arguments, especially, are becoming more powerful."
Meanwhile, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke's office announced earlier this month that it was mailing an updated booklet, "Planning for Emergencies," to all Westchester residents who live within a 10-mile radius of the Indian Point power plants. Indian Point 2, which is run by Consolidated Edison, is also in this northern Westchester town.
The booklet, published yearly, describes the county's plans to protect residents during emergencies like severe storms, fires, transportation accidents or incidents at the power plants.
 
Report on Radiation Included

 This year's 12-page booklet includes some changes in reception centers, which are predesignated sites for evacuees.
"While chances of a major accident at Indian Point or some other form of large-scale emergency are quite remote, we strongly urge recipients of the booklet to note the changes and read the booklet carefully," Mr. O'Rourke said.
The booklet includes a detailed map of the area and information on sirens and frequencies of radio stations carrying emergency information. It also suggests what children in school, people in hospitals, nursing homes and day-care centers and those with disabilities should do in an emergency.
A report is included on radiation and its effects. The closing paragraph reads as follows: "In more than 30 years, the operation of the Indian Point plants has never caused an injury to a member of the public. Mechanical malfunctions have interrupted operations at times and occasionally have caused small releases of radiation inside the containment building, but have never led to a significant release beyond the plant boundary."
Residents who want a copy of the booklet should call the County Office of Emergency Services at (800) 942-1452.

HEADLINE: Intoxicated With Science

BYLINE: By H. Jack Geiger; H. Jack Geiger is the Logan Professor of Community Medicine at the City University of New York Medical School.

 BODY:

THE YOUNG SCIENTISTS
America's Future and the Winning of the Westinghouse.
By Joseph Berger.
243 pp. Reading, Mass.:
Addison-Wesley Publishing Company. $21.95. 
HOW does one get to be a great scientific researcher and maybe win a Nobel Prize? Practice, practice, practice -- doing research, that is, instead of just memorizing scientific facts and principles. Start early, in a special high school dedicated to turning "youngsters intoxicated with science into scientists." Find a mentor in a real laboratory. Design a full-scale project. Work endless hours, with "impassioned diligence," and love it.
It helps, but is not essential, to come from New York (loaded with such special schools, gifted teachers and research centers); to be the child of an immigrant family accustomed to struggle for whom America is still a frontier; and to have parents who value and foster autonomy, curiosity, initiative and the work ethic.
These are the central messages in "The Young Scientists," in which Joseph Berger, a reporter for The New York Times who covered education from 1987 to 1993, takes what could have been a dry subject and turns it into an account that is at once exhilarating, poignant and deeply troubling.
Mr. Berger uses the annual national Westinghouse Science Talent Search as a vehicle to examine science education in the United States (a nation in which, according to a recent survey for the National Science Foundation, less than half of adults knew that Earth revolved around the sun) and to argue that we desperately need to make more young scientists if the United States is to maintain its economic and technological stature.
Wisely, then, he begins with the places that are doing that job brilliantly: schools like the Bronx High School of Science (which Mr. Berger, a student there more than 30 years ago, remembers fondly), Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan, Midwood High School in Brooklyn and the new statewide science boarding schools, especially the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics ("a Southern-fried Bronx High School of Science with dormitories") in Durham. In each, he takes us into the classrooms, introduces us to inspired teachers who run research courses and guide Westinghouse competitors, and explains the core of the talent search method, which has helped produce 5 Nobelists, 8 recipients of MacArthur Foundation fellowships and 28 members of the National Academy of Sciences.
"In most American science classes," Mr. Berger notes, "students learn scientific concepts and facts that they feed back on tests. They do not learn methods of research, and they do not perform any research." One teacher explains: "How great would it be just getting lectures in basketball? You gotta play the game."
The excitement in "The Young Scientists," and the best reason for reading the book, is in the interviews with the students who have struggled through the year-long Westinghouse project, produced complete, rigorous, publishable and innovative pieces of scientific research, and emerged as national winners. These students are anything but stereotypical nerds; they bubble with energy, combine brilliance with the true grit necessary to think their way past the failures and obstacles that always accompany research, and cherish the curiosity and sense of wonder that really drive science.
These teen-age scientists are not "touched at birth with radiant powers," Mr. Berger reminds us. They are nurtured, and we should be making tens of thousands more of them. "The Young Scientists" shows us how.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nina Felice Tabachnik of New York City explaining her project in the 1972 Westinghouse Science Talent Search. She was the first girl to win the grand prize. (UNITED PRESS INTERNATIONAL)

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Delegates, Alas, Oversimplify Japan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The "failure" of the latest round of United States-Japanese trade talks shows the simplistic and self-centered approach the United States often takes toward its "most important" international partner: unrealistic demands such as numerical targets, failure to obtain agreement or fulfillment, followed by threats to retaliate or a retaliatory action. 
 Watching these spectacles, now too familiar, one wonders if United States negotiators understand the complexity of economic mechanisms and the workings of Japanese society. The overall impression is that the United States is good at working out a conceptual image of, say, Japan; it then takes that image to be reality. When it finds that reality differs from an image so conceived, instead of changing the image, it vents frustration.
Take one Administration official's pronouncement to the effect that Japanese bureaucracy is now the "enemy" of the United States. The economic activities of any country are the result of interactions of a range of factors: industrial productivity, individual corporate strategies, the relationship between corporations and their stockholders, habits and preferences of consumers, regulations, and those who create and implement the regulations, the bureaucrats.
The trade balance is no more than one result of these interactions. It is naive to assume, as the Clinton Administration apparently does, that by reshaping Japan's bureaucracy to its own liking, the United States can eliminate its deficit with Japan.
Only this simplistic, self-centered approach can account for the United States action of bringing in the Japanese foreign minister at the critical stage of framework talks. The obvious assumption was that by going over the heads of bureaucrats, the United States demands on numerical targets would be quickly met.
Most Japanese agree with the Clinton Administration's basic proposition that Japan's social and economic structures themselves must change for imports to increase. This is why Japan has been taking steps to grow out of "a corporate society" by shifting its emphasis from corporations to consumers. The Japanese are also re-examining their regulatory system, even though they have benefited from it for nearly half a century.
There are things that only Japan can do in correcting the imbalance, like reforming its political system, as well as things that only the United States can do, such as reducing its budget deficit. There are also things that cannot necessarily be resolved through negotiations, like the difference in speed in bringing about social change and the different degree of complexity of matters to be changed.
Yet before the talks the Clinton Administration, which turned these disparate elements into a single issue, had made simple assumptions about economic mechanisms and the workings of Japanese society and expressed frustration whenever it found that its assumptions did not conform to reality. In this regard, it was shadowboxing. The danger is that the resulting "failure" could provoke the threat of retaliation or a retaliation itself that would affect the global trade climate. It is hard to imagine that such an approach, which is based on virtual reality, will change economic reality.
 
TOMOHARU WASHIO
Exec. Director, Research & Planning
Japan External Trade Organization
New York, Feb. 15, 1994

HEADLINE: Ticketmaster Depends on Part-Time Workers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Health Care Squeeze" by Bob Herbert (column, Feb. 13) notes that Ticketmaster's part-time workers, according to the collective bargaining agreement negotiated by labor and management, do not receive health insurance benefits. This is a policy driven by economic necessity, one that is inevitably followed by the overwhelming proportion of American companies and accepted by nearly all unions. 
 Mr. Herbert, however, attributes insidious motives to Ticketmaster, parroting a union claim that is now before an impartial arbitrator, where it belongs.
Of course Ticketmaster employs many part-time workers; we could not run our business without them. For example, we need to respond when people call, with large staffs available during peak periods from 9 A.M. to 1 P.M. and from 6 to 10 P.M. Very few people want to work both shifts. Our needs also vary widely from month to month, with demand surging in November and December and plummeting in January.
It is this combination of fluctuating demand and early and late shifts -- operational constants -- that leads us to depend on part-time workers.
We try to accommodate the demands of our employees as much as possible -- but more often than not, it is we who seek people to work extra hours, rather than workers who seek to extend. For example, the employee cited as complaining about reduced hours has told us she cannot work on Fridays, Saturdays or Sundays. Are we manipulating her schedule by respecting her wishes?
These issues will be resolved in arbitration on their merits. The larger problems of extending health care to all -- a program goal we support -- can only be responsibly addressed as part of the national debate on the subject.
 
EUGENE L. COBUZZI
Vice Pres., Ticketmaster-New York
New York, Feb. 16, 1994

HEADLINE: Competing Plan Is Stuck Offstage In Debate Over Better Health Care

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27

 BODY:
If the struggle over health care is a struggle for the soul of the President and his party, Representative Jim Cooper is yanking in one direction and Representative Jim McDermott is pulling in the other.
Mr. Cooper of Tennessee, young tribune of the New Democrats, urges President Clinton to go slow, to turn away from the lure of big government even if it means forsaking the goal of universal coverage. 
 Mr. McDermott, an amiable liberal from Seattle, who was practicing psychiatry while Mr. Cooper was still prepping at Groton, urges the President to stay committed to the goal of universal coverage -- not someday but now -- and to recognize that a straightforward government insurance program like Canada's is the best way.
 
Hot in Washington
 Mr. Cooper is very hot in the capital. Mr. McDermott and his cause -- the less-than-grandly titled single-payer movement -- have been regarded by many as a charming anachronism, the earth shoes of health policy. "Right now, if you read the newspapers, you'd think it was Cooper vs. the President," Mr. McDermott grumbles.
In a meeting at the White House on Wednesday night, Mr. McDermott and some allies served notice that they were still very much in the game.
It is, in fact, easy to underestimate the single-payer influence in the House -- and wrong. Mr. McDermott has 90 Democratic co-sponsors for his health care bill in the House; Mr. Cooper has a total of 57 in both parties. Supporters of a Canadian-style health system are scattered across the Ways and Means Committee, the Education and Labor Committee, the Energy and Commerce Committee, all places where they can make their influence felt as the legislative process begins. They are the Democratic base for health care overhaul, a sturdy counterweight to efforts to push Mr. Clinton to the right.
At the very least, they expect Mr. Clinton to live up to his promise of guaranteeing coverage to all. "It'll be the single payer people in the subcommittees who will keep universal coverage from being phased in over 45 years," said one Democratic strategist on Capitol Hill, a Clinton backer who spoke on condition of anonymity.
In fact, after Mr. McDermott's meeting with the President and his top health advisers this week, the Congressman declared, "I think the President understands that he cannot pass any version of health reform without our votes, and that he is not going to get our votes by simply making more compromises with those who do not share his basic goal of universal health insurance coverage for all Americans."
At best, they hope that the sheer complexity of the Clinton plan -- with its quasi-governmental insurance purchasing pools and its mix of market and regulatory forces -- will drive new supporters into their ranks.
Mr. McDermott said: "I think that ultimately the President will sign a bill that will be quite a bit different from what he produced."
But will it be more like Mr. Cooper's, or more like yours?
"More like us," Mr. McDermott asserts.
 
Many Who Disagree
 There are many who disagree, but on a quiet morning in his office on Capitol Hill, the 57-year-old Congressman seems engaged in something other than political bluffing. He is padding about his office, searching for an account of the practice of bloodletting in Revolutionary America and the role it played in the death of George Washington; he wants to use it in an article he is writing about health care restructuring for the Journal of the American Medical Association.
It is all a matter of faulty and unexamined beliefs, Mr. McDermott explains, with the congenial manner of a shrink-turned-pol: A belief that bloodletting worked, a belief that government does not.
"We have this belief in this country that government can't do anything right," he says. "We've had 12 years of people selling that idea from the White House." That, in turn, leads to a conviction that a single-payer system is "politically not doable," Mr. McDermott argues, a determination that the Clinton Administration made early on.
"They simply said, what will the American people buy? And they said, they won't buy a government program. So they designed their program around public polls, not about what was the best public policy. And I'm willing to argue about that."
 
A Polite Response
 More in sorrow than in anger, the Congressman says, "The President has so much power to shape public opinion, and he's so good at it. I think he could have sold single payer. I really, honestly do."
The Administration responds politely. "Clearly they're a crucial bloc of very committed legislators who have been fighting for health care for a very long time," said George Stephanopoulos, the Presidential adviser. "We're not taking them for granted, we want to work with them, we consider them allies."
There have been many versions of single-payer systems proposed over the years; the main characteristic is that the Government essentially replaces the health insurance companies, doing away with private insurance premiums, raising taxes and using them to pay for medical care. In Mr. McDermott's plan, the Federal Government would define the standard benefit package -- which would include such extensive benefits as long-term nursing home care -- and people would pay for it through a payroll deduction.
Employers would pay 8.4 percent of payroll, small employers 4 percent and employees would pay 2.1 percent of wages or salary. Mr. McDermott argues that most people would end up saving money under this plan, because it would replace what is currently paid to insurance companies -- including huge administrative costs.
 
Hearing the Objections
 Mr. McDermott says he has heard all the objections to a single-payer system: fear of government, fear of vast new taxes, fear of rationing. The rationing issue, he says, is particularly powerful, and, he asserts, particularly unjustified.
"People don't look at what's going on in this system right now, in terms of rationing," Mr. McDermott says. "If you have a hernia operation, you don't get to stay in the hospital overnight. They hand you a bottle of pills and send you home after your surgery. Women have a baby; they get sent home the same day they have the baby.
"That's rationing done by insurance companies, right now in this country, it's happening all the time."
Mr. McDermott has the physician's full measure of disdain for insurance companies. This, in fact, gives much of the power to his arguments: He straddles the divide between those who write health policy and those who live it. He was a psychiatrist for two decades in a variety of settings -- from a private practice to the Seattle/King County Jail to the Foreign Service in Zaire, where he worked with American personnel in sub-Saharan Africa.
Before coming to Congress in 1988, he served 15 years in the Washington State Legislature, where he worked on legislation to provide low-cost insurance to low-income and unemployed people. He was appointed to the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health in 1992.
The single-payer movement is often faulted for its political naivete, and there is some grumbling in the House that Mr. McDermott could be more aggressive and more strategic in pressing his case. He is, in fact, less artful in political positioning than Mr. Cooper.
 
An Excess of Politics
 But Mr. McDermott argues that the Administration suffers from an excess of politics. The recent report by Robert Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, actually did the Administration a favor when it ruled that the Clinton plan was, in fundamental ways, a government program financed by government receipts, Mr. McDermott said.
"He forced them out in the open," Mr. McDermott said. "He said, 'Come on, this thing costs money. Why don't you just admit it, and put it up on the table, and don't try to confuse people about how you're going to get this for free. I mean, that's just baloney, and every American knows it."
In the middle of all this maneuvering, Mr. McDermott said he and other single-payer advocates cling to the President's promise of universal coverage as a fundamental right. Everybody in the health care debate has anecdotes, and as Mr. McDermott sums up:
He was leaving the hospital one night when he was called back to consult in the intensive care unit, where a 45-year-old man who had just had a heart attack was demanding to leave the hospital. "So I went and talked to him, and he said, 'Look, if I stay here at $1,000 a day, if I live, I'm going to be broke, because I don't have insurance. And if I die, my family's going to be broke. So why the hell not get out of here?' "
Mr. McDermott added with a small smile, "He was totally sane. He knew where he was, what was happening to him. He was not the least bit out of touch."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Jim McDermott of Washington, who favors universal health coverage now. (Paul Conklin)(pg. B6)
