HEADLINE: Mexico Mediator Sees Progress, but a Rebel Disagrees

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN CRISTOBAL DE LAS CASAS, Mexico, Feb. 27

 BODY:
Despite indications by the mediator between Government and peasant rebel negotiators that the parties had reached the broad outlines of a settlement, the rebels insisted tonight that the Government had refused to meet their most important demands.
At a news conference this evening in the mustard-colored cathedral where he often says Mass, the mediator, Bishop Samuel Ruiz Garcia of San Cristobal, said the two sides had come to "a significant agreement" that resolved at least 22 of 34 demands presented by the insurgents. 
 But little more than an hour later, the military commander of the rebel Zapatista National Liberation Army, who is known only as Subcommander Marcos, said flatly, "There are no agreements now of any type."
Contradicting both Monsignor Ruiz and a Government official who echoed his report of tentative accords, Marcos said the rebels and President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's peace commissioner for the southern state of Chiapas, Manuel Camacho Solis, had merely presented their different positions.
"There has still not been any negotiation," Marcos said in an interview with foreign reporters. "The Commissioner has heard our demands. We have heard his answers."
It was unclear to what extent the contrasting explanations of what had happened in the first eight days of talks reflected deep or even substantive differences on specific issues.
Marcos seemed to dismiss the Government's responses in part because they were, as he described them, "only promises" that came without guarantees. All parties to the negotiation also said it would soon break up so that Mr. Camacho could lobby for support from colleagues in the Government and rebel delegates could consult with their peasant supporters.
Monsignor Ruiz offered few details of the accords he said had been reached to end a conflict that has taken more than 100 lives, shaken the country's political system and tarnished the public image of Mr. Salinas's administration.
But he said that among the unresolved issues, four or five were "very secondary," while the others were complicated mainly by the difficulties involved in their translation into the four Mayan Indian languages spoken among the 19 Zapatista negotiators.
On the most difficult issue in the talks -- the rebels' demand for broad political changes to assure fair national elections -- Monsignor Ruiz said the two sides had already reached agreement on two non-binding commitments for democratic reform.
The difference in Marcos's account of discussions on that issue was particularly stark.
"What we think is that the Government roundly refuses to accept the discussion of national issues," he said. "The Government has refused to talk about democracy."
He recognized, as he has before, that political reform was a task that goes far beyond the negotiations in San Cristobal. But he added: "If there is no change in the political course, there will not be peace. If that change does not take place, not only will there not be peace, but this country will explode."
Speaking to reporters through the ski mask that has been his only public face, the rebel leader listed eight other main points of conflict. He said they included the rebels' demands for democracy and election-law reforms, changes in the country's legal system and economic policies, and greater protection of Indian rights.
The REPORTS came after two days of intense negotiations in which the talks appeared to have bogged down and the rebel leadership pointedly reiterated its insistence..
The reports came after two days during which the talks seemed to bog down and the rebel leadership pointedly reiterated its insistence that President Salinas either resign in favor of a transitional Government or turn over the supervision of national elections to independent citizens.
"We cannot ignore the interpretation that we are in the most critical part of the accords at this moment," the negotiators said in a joint communique late Saturday night. "We are aware that everything agreed to at the negotiating table and verified in Chiapas has profound repercussions for the future."
The grave tone had contrasted sharply with earlier upbeat announcements of tentative accords for the protection of Indians' civil rights and improvements in areas like housing, health care and education.
It was still not clear what had caused the sharp swings in the tenor of the negotiations.
 
Most Politics Is Local
 Government officials said they had responded generously to the rebels'local demands partly in hopes of persuading them to step back from their insistence on broad changes in the political system.
At a distance from the talks here, the Government and its Institutional Revolutionary Party, which has ruled for 65 years, began to take promised steps to insure fair presidential elections in August. After weeks in which Government supporters resisted opposition pressure for a special session of Congress to draft new election laws, officials said such a session might be called as early as Monday.
Until Saturday, the Zapatistas seemed to have grown more responsive to the Government's argument that it could not bargain over changes in the political system with a small guerrilla force that suddenly declared war against the state on Jan. 1. While making clear that the rebels would not drop their push for political changes, their military commander, Subcommander Marcos, described the talks as too small to accommodate such national issues.
 
Rebels Repeat Demands
 But in a toughly worded communique issued late Saturday, the Zapatistas repeated their demand for sweeping political change.
"Their legitimacy does not come from respect for the will of the majority but its usurpation," the statement said of Mr. Salinas and a group of unidentified state governors whom it accused of having come to power by electoral fraud.
Although the statement seemed to make an oblique threat of resuming the fighting that ended Jan. 10 with a cease-fire, it was understood by some Government officials more as a figurative call to arms.
An official familiar with the talks said the President's negotiator, Manuel Camacho Solis, had offered measures to break the governing party's monopoly on power in Chiapas and to assure Indian communities of a greater role in determining priorities for economic development. But the official said Mr. Camacho had rejected the Zapatistas' call for parallel Indian governments, and would not move from that position.

The Economy
The F.B.I. chief says Americans must be willing to give up a degree of privacy, in exchange for safety and security, in an era of computer communications and digital telephone calls. Louis J. Freeh is defending proposed legislation that would enable law- enforcement agents to gather a wealth of personal information by monitoring citizens' calling patterns and credit-card transactions over the phone network. Critics say the legislation would turn the telephone network into a vast surveillance system. [Page D1.] 
 The Fed is increasingly basing interest-rate decisions on an approach that could be called banker's intuition, having dropped its reliance on money supply figures. HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS:;
A newsletter treats the adventures of Ross Perot
as more than just political entertainment.

BYLINE: By William Glaberson 

 BODY:
ROSS PEROT, according to Micah L. Sifry, may be either the catalyst for an important new social movement or "a dictator in waiting." Either way, Mr. Sifry figures, there ought to be a market for a newsletter ($15 for four issues a year) about the billionaire and his movement.
The result: The Perot Periodical, a quarterly that The Columbia Journalism Review recently called the classiest of a new crop of niche political publications. Others include The Clinton Chronicle, a monthly tantrum against the Commander in Chief, and Stephanopouletter: The Official Newsletter of the George Stephanopoulos Fan Club. 
 Mr. Sifry, whose day job is associate editor of The Nation, the left-tilted weekly, is now working on the third issue of The Perot Periodical. And in case readers don't get the point, the newsletter with the caricature of Mr. Perot as an "albino monkey in a zoo" is not authorized by the former Presidential candidate.
Call it son of The Quayle Quarterly, the irreverent newsletter that passed on to publication heaven when the former Vice President left Washington.
Mr. Sifry, who gave himself the titles of editor and publisher, acknowledges an intellectual debt to The Quayle Quarterly's founders. The Perot Periodical includes some of their brand of satire. But Mr. Sifry says the heart of his effort is to chronicle a movement that is being overlooked by large news organizations. He says Mr. Perot may have been prematurely declared "washed up" by Washington pundits.
Still, Mr. Sifry knows, as Mr. Perot himself seems to, that some of Mr. Perot's attraction is his quirkiness. The "albino monkey" drawing, for example, is part of a regular series by an illustrator, D. B. Johnson, who gamely accepts the invitation offered by Mr. Perot's uniquely descriptive way of expressing himself.
Using quotations from Mr. Perot, Mr. Johnson provides an accompanying image. The recent drawing was inspired by Mr. Perot's explanation, reported in U.S. News & World Report, of his ability to draw crowds: "I'm kind of like an albino monkey in a zoo. People come because they never saw one."
The newsletter's current 16-page issue quotes Mr. Perot as making this comment at a recent rally in Tampa, Fla.: "I am willing to stand up here like a clay pigeon, if you will write your Congressman." Guess what type of bird Mr. Johnson drew?
All the caricatures, of course, are labeled AnthroPEROTmorphics.
But Mr. Sifry has also sounded serious themes.
Reporters for the newsletter have documented what they say could be evidence that "the line between Perotism and right-wing extremism is getting thin." The newsletter also suggested that as many as one-third of the paid leaders in the constantly changing cast at Mr. Perot's organization, United We Stand America, are former military officers.
And it has argued that, rather than losing millions of dollars in running for President in 1992, as reported by many news organizations, Mr. Perot might have made money. It says Mr. Perot's influence helped push Bill Clinton away from early promises of a vigorous economic stimulus program, thus helping to keep interest rates low. The resulting gains in the bond market, it said, were beneficial to Mr. Perot, who is believed to have heavy bond investments. The newsletter concludes, therefore, that he "made a quarter-billion dollars by running for President."
Mr. Sifry, 32, says he is nearly breaking even on his venture, which is aimed at "political junkies" and journalists. He also has what he calls a surprise market among dissident Perot supporters who fret about what some say is a streak of authoritarianism in the organization. The magazine-style newsletter has about 450 mail subscribers, and Mr. Sifry says 4,000 copies have sold briskly at a price of $4 each in bookstores across the country.
At Mr. Perot's Dallas headquarters, however, The Perot Periodical is not a big hit. "It's got a lot of inaccuracies and I guess I don't respect a publication that doesn't report accurately," said Sharon Holman, the spokeswoman for Mr. Perot's organization.
She said the assertion that the organization might be drifting toward the right was false and that it was simply made up of "grass-roots regular Americans." She labeled the assertion that Mr. Perot made a profit because of his run for office "so absurd it's not even worth a comment."
And in response to the newsletter's coverage suggesting that many of the organization's leaders were recruited from the ranks of former military officers, she read a letter from V. B. Corn, its state leader in Ohio. Mr. Corn labeled The Perot Periodical a "tabloid-like" publication and said fewer than 20 percent of the national staff members of United We Stand America had served in the military.
Mr. Sifry said Mr. Perot's movement eludes traditional news organizations precisely because it is nontraditional. But with some polls showing that more than 25 percent of the electorate would consider voting for Mr. Perot for President, Mr. Sifry said, someone ought to pay attention.
"He and the movement," Mr. Sifry said, "ought to be covered as more than a sideshow or a freak show."

HEADLINE: Not Red, but Still a Bear;
Russia, No Longer an Ideological Enemy, Remains a Power With Its Own Interests

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27

 BODY:
The tension between the United States and Russia over the war in Bosnia and Russia's spying in Washington has raised the question in the minds of many: Just what is the relationship between America and Russia today? Allies? Not exactly. Enemies? Not really. Acquaintances? That's not it either.
Across Washington last week, officials, diplomats and lawmakers struggled with that question as Russia has engaged in more and more behavior that seems hostile to American interests. 
 At stake in the answer is everything from $4 billion in American aid to NATO's willingness to accept Moscow into the alliance one day.
 
Optimism Seems to Be Waning
 About all that is clear now is that the optimistic post-cold-war consensus in Washington about a "partnership" between Russia and the United States seems to be crumbling.
Even one of the leading advocates of American assistance to Russia, Senator Richard Lugar, the Indiana Republican, declared today on the NBC News program "Meet the Press": "We have to get over the idea that this is a partnership. This is a tough rivalry, and that is an important distinction to make."
The confusion over America's relationship with Russia grows out of the false assumption that the United States had only one conflict with Moscow during the cold war: the ideological struggle between democracy and Communism.
That was the struggle that received all the attention. But there was another, less obvious conflict, which existed before Russia became Communist in 1917 and still exists today: the natural competition between states -- competition for raw materials, economic wealth and security. With Russia occupying one-seventh of the world's land mass and being the home of 150 million people, it will always be a voracious competitor for resources, whether it is led by a Jefferson or a Yeltsin.
That is why Alexis de Tocqueville wrote in 1835 that history and geography would always make the Russian-American relationship complex: "There are now two great nations in the world which, starting from different points, seem to be advancing toward the same goal: the Russians and the Anglo-Americans."
"America's conquests are made with plowshares, Russia's with the sword," he wrote. "Their point of departure is different and their paths diverse; nevertheless, each seems called by some secret desire of Providence one day to hold in its hands the destinies of half the world."
The nature of the rivalry in the immediate future will depend a great deal on how Russia defines itself. Will Russia define itself as a democracy like Britain or France, and therefore limit its competition with the United States to the economic sphere? Or will it define itself differently?
 
Russia's Three Transitions
 That definition, said Daniel Yergin, an economic historian, will depend on the outcome of three transitions under way in Russia: a transition from Communist dictatorship to democracy, from a planned economy to a free market and from an empire to a nation-state.
All three of these transitions are incomplete, and none is assured of a happy ending -- as events like the release in Moscow on Saturday of hard-liners who plotted the overthrow of President Boris N. Yeltsin only underscore.
"Until two and half months ago," Mr. Yergin said, "there was a complacency in the United States that everything was settled and behind us, and that while Russia was interesting, at times confusing, it didn't really matter much -- it was on autopilot.
"But that American consensus has broken down, and it is now in need of rethinking and re-articulation."
Understanding that Russia is still up for grabs, President Clinton, has begun to try to build a new consensus about relations with Moscow, based on a more hard-headed reading of politics there.
At a news conference on Friday, Mr. Clinton said: "What I think is naive is the suggestion that we should have ever believed for a moment that every event in Russia and every speech made by every Russian politician in every election of every member of Parliament would somehow be in a constant straight line toward a goal that we wanted to predetermine. This is not black and white; this is gray."
 
Helping the Reformers
 Mr. Clinton argued that the United States should continue giving aid to Russia to increase the likelihood that the liberal reformers there would win and therefore be the ones to define the America-Russia relationship.
"It is in our national interests to continue working with Russia, to lower the nuclear threshold, to support the development of Russia as a peaceful democracy," Mr. Clinton said. Virtually all American foreign aid to Russia, he said, goes to grass-roots projects to privatize state-owned businesses and toward building democratic institutions, dismantling nuclear missiles and helping a market economy to take hold in individual cities.
That is precisely the sort of aid that should be continued, he indicated, no matter what happens in Moscow.
But as logical as that view may be, it will not be easy to sustain if the drift toward nationalism, Pan-Slavism and populist economics continues apace in Moscow, or if more Russian spies are uncovered at the C.I.A.
For instance, Senator Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, told reporters on Friday that he agreed that the spying incident involving Aldrich H. Ames should not alone lead to a cutoff of Russian aid. But he added that he and some of his colleagues felt that given what is now happening in the relationship, "Russia aid, at least as it's currently constructed, is in some trouble looking to next year's appropriations bill."
 
Avoiding the Extremes
 That is the kind of drift in sentiment that President Clinton now finds himself fighting. But the question for Mr. Clinton is how understanding he can afford to be of Moscow as Russia goes through the painful process of defining itself as a state.
On one hand, he does not want to drive Moscow to extremes by being too tough, say, by expelling all Russian intelligence agents from Washington. On the other hand, being too tolerant, as he may have been when Russia intervened this month in Sarajevo on behalf of the Serbs, can encourage the worst instincts in Moscow.
President Clinton might be having an easier time selling a gray Russia policy to a public accustomed to decades of black and white if he and his predecessor, George Bush, had been more frank from the beginning about the brutal nature of the competition between Moscow and Washington.
"In 1992, Bush was trying to inflate his accomplishments by overselling to the American public what the end of the cold war meant," said Michael R. Beschloss, a historian of the cold war. "There was little emphasis on the primal forces still at work in Russian politics or the long history it would have to overcome to achieve democracy."
As for President Clinton, he wanted to persuade an American public that was turning inward after the cold war to support more financial aid to Russia, to help the reformers there triumph.
But in fairness to both Presidents, the American people, weary of 40 years of cold war, deeply wanted to believe that with the fall of Communism, the struggle with Russia was over -- that Russia had gone through therapy and was now a new, different, American-like nation.
Those days of illusion are over.

HEADLINE: Business Backs Weicker On Reduction of Taxes

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 25

 BODY:
Business leaders and municipal officials came to the Capitol this week to say they support Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s call for the state to reduce local property taxes, but they disagreed over which taxpayers should benefit.
In a meeting with Mr. Weicker and in testimony before the General Assembly's Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee, business leaders supported his proposal to eliminate the personal-property tax, which towns and cities assess on motor vehicles and business equipment. 
 Businesses pay as much as two-thirds of the $700 million a year raised by the tax.
Mayors and first selectmen, however, urged the committee to focus on property-tax relief for homeowners. While eliminating the personal-property tax on cars would save most families a few hundred dollars a year, they said, the real-property tax on their homes costs them thousands of dollars, with no regard to income.
 
A Means to Competitiveness
 Mr. Weicker is promoting his property-tax relief plan as a way to make Connecticut more competitive and to stimulate its economy. The plan would begin by relieving businesses of the property tax on their computers and other data-processing equipment, at a cost of $56 million.
As employment grows, Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark told the finance committee today at a hearing, more people will pay taxes and so the overall tax burden will lessen.
"While business appears to be the immediate beneficiary of this proposal, the inevitable consequence is a fairer tax burden on everyone," she said.
 
Reaching the Limit
 But the municipal officials said that in many communities, residents were reaching the limit of what they can pay, especially as the increase in housing values over the last decade has shifted the property-tax burden toward homeowners, from business and industry.
In East Hartford, for example, homeowners could see their taxes increase as much as 40 percent because of a reassessment in 1993, even though Pratt & Whitney Aircraft makes up more than one-quarter of the town's tax roll.
In cities, property-tax rates have soared so high that they are forcing out the middle class, leaving behind a population that cannot pay the taxes, said John DeStefano, the Mayor of New Haven.
"As we increase the tax rate, our tax collections are going down," he said.
 
No 'Line in the Sand'
 Lieutenant Governor Groark and Mr. Weicker's budget chief, William J. Cibes, both assured the finance committee that "no line has been drawn in the sand" over details of a plan that the Governor could support -- beyond his insistence on providing relief to businesses.
Legislators, for example, could take the $300 million that eliminating the tax on vehicles would cost and use it to help homeowners, Mr. Cibes said.
But that amount, Mr. Cibes also warned, would not greatly reduce homeowners' taxes, compared with erasing the entire tax on their cars. And, he said, Mr. Weicker's plan held a small windfall for towns and cities: while many collect less than 90 percent of the taxes they levy on vehicles, the state would reimburse them for the full amount, thus increasing their actual revenue.
 
Opposition Expected
 Mr. Weicker's plan faces significant opposition, in part because it favors business, in part because it requires towns and cities to give up a tax they now have control over and then to depend on the state's promise to reimburse them.
In drafting a plan to phase in the elimination of the personal property tax over 10 years, Mr. Cibes relied on projected surpluses of revenue in those years to finance the reimbursements to municipalities.
"Where will the money come from?" asked Representative Robert A. Maddox Jr., a Republican from Bethlehem, citing other grants that the state promised to make but then paid only in part. "It will be there to start with, and then it will vanish."
A member of one coalition of community groups that was formed in 1991 to support Mr. Weicker in his fight for a personal income tax today testified against his property-tax plan, saying it does not provide enough relief for individuals.
A major effect of the income tax, combined with business tax cuts Mr. Weicker also urged for his strategy to help the state's economy, was to shift hundreds of millions of dollars in taxes from businesses to individuals.
 
No Bank for the Family?
 "On the opening day of the legislative session, we heard that the state has become a 'bank' for businesses," said Suzanne Haviland, executive director of the coalition, the Taxpayers Alliance to Serve Connecticut. "But when is the state going to become a bank for the average family? By 1998, we will have given out more than $500 million in corporate tax cuts, tax breaks and more."
Legislators have submitted several alternatives to Mr. Weicker's plan. Most use what are known as circuit-breakers, to set a ceiling on how much property tax a person would pay.
One bill proposed by Senator Martin M. Looney, a Democrat from New Haven, would allow homeowners to subtract from their state income-tax payment any tax on their home exceeding 5 percent of their income. The property-tax ceiling for a couple earning $40,000, then, would be $2,000,
A second bill would limit taxes on a house to 2 percent of its fair-market value. If that same couple's house was worth $100,000, the tax ceiling on it would again be $2,000.
Other bills would allow individuals to subtract anywhere from 20 percent to 100 percent of their property taxes from their income-tax payments. And one bill proposed by Representative Richard T. Mulready, a Democrat from West Hartford and a co-chairman of the finance committee, would raise $300 million for property-tax relief by raising the top income-tax rate to 6 percent, from the current 4.5 percent.
"An encouraging note," Mr. Mulready reassured the mayors today, "is that we're talking about how to do something, not whether to do something."

HEADLINE: Highest U.S. Rights Official Meets With Leading Chinese Dissident

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Feb. 27

 BODY:
The State Department's top human rights official met privately today with China's most prominent dissident in the first such encounter with a Clinton Administration official since the dissident was freed last year after serving 14 1/2 years in prison for advocating democracy.
The official, John Shattuck, an Assistant Secretary of State, agreed to take a message from the dissident, Wei Jingsheng, to President Clinton urging him to maintain economic pressure on Beijing as the best way to win the release of political prisoners. 
 An associate of Mr. Wei's described the meeting in a telephone call, but the United States Embassy had no comment on it. The Chinese authorities have warned Mr. Wei several times that he will be rearrested if he persists in his campaign for human rights and democracy.
Mr. Wei's associate said Mr. Shattuck had requested the meeting to solicit opinions about the condition of political prisoners, the strength of the democracy movement and how the Administration could best exert its influence on China to improve its human rights record. The associate quoted Mr. Shattuck as saying he had taken "strength" from the meeting with Mr. Wei, a former electrician at the Beijing Zoo, who by virtue of his unbending will during years in prison, has emerged as the potential leader of a new democracy movement in China.
Separately today, China acknowledged that the human rights situation in the country "is not completely satisfactory," but in a long commentary carried by the official New China News Agency, Beijing lashed out at the United States for setting itself up as a moral arbiter in the world at a time when crime, drug-related violence and discrimination are "infringing on the human rights of the American people."
Mr. Shattuck is in Beijing for what are expected to be tough negotiations on the "overall, significant progress" in human rights that Mr. Clinton is demanding as a condition for annual renewal of the low-tariff privileges under which China exports tens of billions of dollars of goods to the United States.
Chinese officials are increasingly frustrated by the unwillingness of the Administration to define what it means by significant progress in the categories it has identified, like releasing political and religious prisoners and safeguarding Tibet's cultural heritage.
Former Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger, who met with Chinese officials last week, said in an interview here that the Chinese were afraid that Mr. Clinton, in demanding results, would "move the goal posts" as soon as the Chinese acted in those areas. Mr. Eagleburger also implied that some American diplomats were becoming frustrated at the President's not defining what he means by progress.

HEADLINE: Tool Orders Increase 7.8%

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27

 BODY:
Orders for American-made machine tools rose 7.8 percent in January, continuing the upward trend seen in 1993, an industry trade group said today.
The Association for Manufacturing Technology, based in McLean, Va., said orders for machine tools totaled $356.05 million in January, up from a revised $330.35 million in December. The January orders were more than double the $175.55 million of January 1993. 
 "January orders signal continued reinvestment by the U.S. in manufacturing, which is essential to our long-term economic health," the association's president, Albert W. Moore, said.
Orders for machine tools, which are considered an indicator of future economic activity, ended 1993 at a five-year high and are forecast to increase in 1994 and 1995.
The revival largely stems from renewed strength in manufacturing.

HEADLINE: Dr. Leopold Kohr, 84; Backed Smaller States

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: VIENNA, Feb. 27

 BODY:
Leopold Kohr, an Austrian philosopher and economist who argued that "small is beautiful," died Saturday in Gloucester, England, where he had lived for about a decade, said his biographer, Gerald Lehner. Professor Kohr was 84.
No cause of death was given. 
 Dr. Kohr, who used the pseudonym Hans Kohr, is best known for his studies of national economies, which led him to favor small countries and oppose broad unification projects like the European Union.
The phrase "small is beautiful" is generally associated with the late German economist Fritz Schumacher, who lived in Britain and published a book with that title in the 1970's. But Mr. Schumacher said Dr. Kohr had been his teacher, Mr. Lehner said.
In the mid-1960's, a group of Dr. Kohr's supporters raised money to try to test his theories on Anguilla, a Caribbean island that had declared its independence from Britain. But the project was not supported by the residents.
Leopold Kohr was born in Oberndorf and studied law in Austria and political theory at the London School of Economics. He served as a correspondent in the Spanish Civil War and left Austria in 1938 when it was annexed by Nazi Germany. He taught economics at Rutgers University in New Jersey in the 1940's and 50's.

HEADLINE: Regulators Mute Their Fears Over Derivatives

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Feb. 27

 BODY:
The nation's top financial regulators are having fewer nightmares about a potential crisis from the explosive growth of a new category of financial transactions known as derivatives.
At a three-day conference here sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, which ended on Saturday, about 100 Government officials, academics and financial executives agreed that the complex web of new derivatives transactions, which have a face value of more than $7 trillion, is forcing changes in everything from accounting standards to the training of bank regulators. 
 Gone, though, were the concerns that have plagued some regulators -- that derivatives were making the financial system more vulnerable to a worldwide market meltdown.
In the keynote speech, a Federal Reserve governor, Susan M. Phillips, challenged "the persistence of what appears to be exaggerated fears of the risk of derivatives activities."
"I have concluded," Ms. Phillips said, "that the concerns that have been expressed about derivatives by legislators, regulators, and even senior executives of financial institutions can best be understood as symptoms of broader anxieties about changes in financial markets."
 
Just What Are Derivatives?
 Derivatives are financial agreements whose value varies in relation to -- derives from -- the performance of a financial market. They are in effect side bets, payable in cash, that interest rates, currencies, commodities or stocks will move in a certain direction. For example, a company that buys oil could protect itself from price increases with an option that would pay the company if oil prices rose.
Clifford W. Smith Jr., a finance professor at the University of Rochester, more directly challenged the skeptics and doomsayers on derivatives. "It's hard to get people to get precise about what they mean by systemic risk," he said, alluding to the meltdown fears. "It's clear it's big and sometimes scary, but after that they get fuzzy."
Mr. Smith's comments angered William J. McDonough, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, who had just given a speech that mixed strong support for the growth of derivatives with caution about the potential for their misuse. Mr. McDonough responded that it is the role of a central bank to worry about a possible catastrophe.
Nonetheless, in his speech, Mr. McDonough conceded that regulators' admonitions "have a nagging quality because we have not specified a concrete approach to controlling and managing this risk."
In general, regulators spoke highly of the ability of banks and brokers that deal in derivatives to manage the risks they present. Indeed, Ms. Phillips said the theories and computer systems developed to manage risk in derivatives are improving their other businesses.
The potential for losses from derivatives is, in general, far less than the risks of lending, argued Lewis W. Teel, the BankAmerica Corporation executive in charge of controlling trading risk. "The loan guys in my bank have found a way to lose $7 billion over the last few years lending to developing countries and real estate developers, and they tell me they are credit-risk experts," he said.
A number of participants said the biggest potential problem today is among corporations that use derivatives, most of which have not developed risk-management systems as sophisticated as those used by the major dealers. Recently, the huge German mining conglomerate Metallgesellschaft A.G. lost hundreds of millions of dollars through mistakes in using oil derivatives to hedge part of its refining business.
"We are going to have a U.S. version of Metallgesellschaft," Mr. Teel said, "when a user will blow $1 billion."
 
Call for a Clearinghouse
 Many speakers said that the potential effects of such a major failure could be reduced by the creation of a clearinghouse modeled after those run by the futures exchanges that would guarantee derivatives contracts. Currently, most derivatives are private agreements between two parties, subjecting each to the potential default of the other.
While such an arrangement would be difficult for the more complex derivatives, "we should migrate the plain vanilla stuff to an exchange as quickly as possible," said Maurice R. Greenberg, chairman of the American International Group, the big insurance company that earns 20 percent of its profits from derivatives dealing.

HEADLINE: Bigger Role For Intuition Seen at Fed

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve, having dropped its reliance on the money supply figures that made markets soar or swoon in the 1980's, is increasingly basing interest rate decisions on an approach best summed up as banker's intuition.
When Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, gave his semiannual testimony before Congress on Tuesday, the only section of his written testimony that he did not bother to read aloud concerned money supply measures like the M-2, which represents the total of cash, checking accounts, savings accounts, certificates of deposit of less than $100,000 and several other financial instruments. 
 In a series of interviews last week, top Fed officials said they were putting greater weight on economic indicators ranging from the price of gold and the output of factories to personal anecdotes. They are also paying more attention to human psychology: notably investors' expectations of inflation, an area that has long exasperated economists who use computer models to predict inflation.
 
 
Data With an Attitude
 "I get a feel for what I think is going on based on the information -- not only the anecdotal information in the press and the statistical information assembled and compiled by the staff here, but also from the general tone of the markets," said John P. LaWare, a Fed governor, who added that he also looked at figures on housing starts, employment and bank loans. "I'm probably least sensitive to the money figures because I don't know what they mean anymore."
In looking at so many economic indications at the same time, Fed officials in effect rely on educated hunches of what they should do, rather than following the dictates of computer models or a couple of key indicators.
"Policy has become more intuitive over the last year," David M. Jones, a longtime Fed watcher at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company of New York, said today.
The main reason has to do with the discrepancy between what happens with the money supply and what happens in the economy. That is partly a result of the enormous growth of mutual funds, which are left out of the main money supply measures.
"I came on believing what I had been taught -- and taught as a professor -- which was M-2," said Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Fed governor and former Harvard economics professor. "I don't think I can use it anymore."
In place of money supply figures, he said, "we look at a whole raft of variables -- we ignore nothing and focus on nothing."
To be sure, Fed officials are not flying the economy by the seat of their pants. Like many private economists, some Fed officials start with computer models that assume that various indicators will signal inflation with the same lags as in the past. For example, higher inflation rates have tended to follow increases in the money supply.
But having concluded that such historical patterns are not always valid, Fed officials are revising computer models to fit their assumptions about how the economy works now. They then run the new models to see how the changes affect the models' predictions of future inflation.
Such an approach may seem very orderly. But it all depends on the Fed official's guess of how past statistical relationships have changed, a guess that is based on a lifetime of experience.
 
Monetarists Object
 Many monetarist economists in academia believe that money supply figures remain valuable. They criticize Mr. Greenspan for focusing on a succession of economic indicators in public testimony.
"It's a very dangerous game to play, to drag out whatever indicator is pointing in the right direction," said William Poole, a monetarist at Brown University often cited as a possible future Republican nominee to the Fed.
But Mr. Greenspan appears unmoved. The Fed's monetary policy committee "will continue to monitor the behavior of money supply measures for evidence about underlying economic and financial developments more generally, but it will still have to base its assessments regarding appropriate policy actions on a wide variety of economic indicators," according to Mr. Greenspan's written, but unread, testimony on Tuesday.
The most important consideration for the Fed these days appears to be investors' expectations of inflation, which are reflected to some extent in long-term interest rates and commodity prices.
 
 
The Degree of Slack
 Short-term changes in prices may depend on how much slack is available in the economy to accommodate surges in demand, but over the longer haul, "the rate of price change depends crucially on price expectations, and not on the degree of slack," Mr. Greenspan told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress on Jan. 31.
Long-term interest rates tend to vary with these expectations. And the success of the Fed's interest rate policy, Mr. Greenspan said on Tuesday, should be judged by whether it holds down these long-term rates. The Fed has no direct control over long-term rates but does control short-term rates. In theory, it can pull down long-term rates by pushing up short-term rates.
The Fed pushed up rates for overnight loans between banks by a quarter of a percentage point on Feb. 4. Long-term rates, however, have risen by more than a third of a percentage point since then. This has surprised and dismayed Fed officials. "I had thought that a move by us at that time would be more likely to stabilize or maybe even bring down the long-term rate," Mr. LaWare said.
Mr. Greenspan said on Thursday that the rise in long-term rates did not reflect the Fed's move on short-term rates. Instead, he said, long-term rates rose because of subsequent economic reports that investors misinterpreted as signs that the strong economic growth in the fourth quarter of last year would continue this year and rekindle inflation.
 
 
Gold and Commodity Prices
 Many Wall Street analysts say the Fed now focuses overwhelmingly on prices for gold and other commodities in setting short-term interest rates. Mr. Greenspan seemed to lend strong support for this view on Tuesday, when he told the House Banking Committee that gold prices were "a very good indicator" of future inflation.
But other senior Fed officials say they see little use for gold as an indicator of inflation. "If that's what the chairman believes, that's fine -- it's not my view that gold forms a key or central variable," Mr. Lindsey said.
Mr. Greenspan played down the importance of commodities before the Senate Banking Committee on Thursday.
Susan M. Phillips, another Fed governor and a former chairwoman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, is widely assumed to follow commodity prices closely. But she said she had actually paid less attention to these prices since her appointment in December 1991, although she still described them as important.


GRAPHIC: Here are the economic indicators that the Federal Reserve is now watching in determining when to raise short-term interest rates to fight inflation. Some of the best-known variables and intellectual influences from recent years have fallen out of favor. Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, cited most of these variables in his testimony before a House Banking Committee panel last week.
 
WHAT'S IN
 
Expected inflation, especially as reflected in long term interest rates and commodity prices. Nororiously difficult to measure, expectations of inflation are nonetheless Mr. Greenspan's top target. He tried on Tuesday to talk down these expectations, and long-term bonds with them.
 
Gold prices. When they rise, people may be losing faith in the currency and moving into tangible assets.
 
Capacity utilization. If factories are already operating at full speed, raising output could feed inflation.
 
Real short-term interest rates. Subtract inflation from the interest rate to find the real rate. But the Fed now thinks that Government figures may overstate inflation.
 
Unit labor costs. If wages rise faster than productivity, then these costs increase, feeding inflation.
 
Figures on bank lending and other credit figures.
 
WHAT'S OUT
 
Various categories of the money supply, like the amount of money Americans hold in cash and checking accounts.
 
Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank survey of prices paid by manufacturers for suplies. The Fed thinks it predicts economic activity and new orders, not inflation.
 
The consumer price index. Because data are only available with a lag of nearly three weeks, the index provides too little information about future inflation.
 
(Sources: Federal Reserve officials' testimony before Congress and interviews) (pg. D3)

HEADLINE: A Push for Surveillance Software

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
In the age of computer communications and digital telephone calls, the American people must be willing to give up a degree of personal privacy in exchange for safety and security, the head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.
In an interview on Friday, Louis J. Freeh, the F.B.I. Director, defended proposed legislation that critics say would turn the nation's telephone network into a vast surveillance system. He said taxpayers would be asked to pay up to half a billion dollars to develop and deploy the necessary network software. 
 The Administration wants to impose new technology that would enable law-enforcement agents to gather a wealth of personal information by monitoring citizens' calling patterns and credit card transactions over the telephone network -- and over the two-way cable television networks being planned by cable and phone companies. The system would go well beyond current wiretapping technology, because much of the information could be gleaned without the police or F.B.I. actually having to eavesdrop on specific voice or electronic-mail conversations.
"The costs are high, but you have to do a cost-benefit analysis," said Mr. Freeh, who insisted that fighting terrorists and criminals was the Government's intention -- not playing Big Brother to the citizenry.
 
'A Credible Solution'
 "The damage to the World Trade tower and the economic interests of the country are conservatively estimated at $5 billion," he said, citing last year's bombing of the World Trade Center in Manhattan. "I think the American people will agree that this is a credible solution to the problem we face."
The Administration is trying to line up Congressional support for the legislation, called the Digital Telephony and Communications Privacy Improvement Act of 1994, before having it formally introduced.
Government officials say traditional wiretapping is becoming increasingly difficult because more and more phone calls and data communications are transmitted as streams of digital information -- representing the ones and zeros understood by computers. Thousands of such calls may intermingle on a public-network circuit at any moment. Proponents of the legislation say new software placed on computerized network switching equipment is necessary to help law enforcement sort through this traffic.
But executives of McCaw Cellular Communications, the nation's biggest cellular telephone company, told Mr. Freeh and White House officials at a meeting on Thursday that their newest telephone switches already provide the surveillance capabilities requested in the legislation.
Moreover, privacy advocates say the Government can point to no case in which digital network technology alone has impeded an investigation. And they note that in the World Trade Center case, it was not electronic communications but mundane bungling of vehicle and warehouse rentals that led to arrests.
 
An Electronic Portrait
 Such critics have long warned that in the information age, it is possible to build a detailed model of an individual's behavior, political and sexual preferences, social network and travel itineraries simply by examining telephone-calling patterns and credit card purchases.
Some capabilities were demonstrated when law-enforcement agents pieced together a chronological list of phone calls made by the people accused of plotting and carrying out the attack in January on the figure skater Nancy Kerrigan. But the type of software the Clinton Administration wants to add to the public communications network would make possible much more detailed records of individuals' electronic activities.
"It will be possible to develop a life-size portrait about you as a person," said Jerry Berman, executive director of the Electronic Frontier Foundation, a Washington privacy-rights lobbying group. "This is not just about a phone number."
For the Administration, having taxpayers rather than communications companies pay for the system is meant to dilute industry criticism of the plan, which has met resistance since it was disclosed a few weeks ago. Congressional support is difficult to gauge.
"The bill has some significant problems we need to resolve," said Representative Don Edwards, Democrat of California and chairman of the House Judiciary subcommittee on civil rights. "The profiling and the tracking aspect of the bill is something we are concerned about."
A version of the legislation was first proposed in 1991 by the Bush Administration at the urging of the Justice Department. But unlike that version, the new bill would limit the surveillance to public networks and not include company phone systems -- private branch exchanges, or PBX's -- or private corporate computer networks.
Despite those changes, civil liberties groups and some industry executives say they are concerned that the scope of the new bill would give law- enforcement agencies new access to a vast amount of "transactional," or billing, information related to the setup of a telephone call.
Under current law, obtaining a subpoena to obtain transactional data from the telephone company is easier than getting a wiretap warrant to eavesdrop on actual conversations, which requires a judge to find probable cause that a crime has taken place.
Mr. Freeh met with telephone industry executives at the White House on Thursday and with Congressional leaders on Capitol Hill on Friday in an effort to attract support for the bill. He said in the interview that he was willing to compromise by adding safeguards for transactional information.
"I understand the privacy concern," he said. "My real objective is to get access to the content of telephone calls. With respect to the extraordinary amount of personal information that is generated by this new technology, we would consider some way to block some of that information or raise the standard required to gain access. We're flexible on that."
The F.B.I. Director said new digital communications technologies were making it more difficult for authorities to listen to conversations of suspected criminals who may be using cellular telephones or whose conversations may be carried as data streams in networks of fiber optic cables.
Mr. Freeh said wiretapping had long been one of law enforcement's most effective tools. He cited examples in which it had been used effectively to prevent crimes, including a case in Chicago in which a terrorist was planning to shoot down an airliner with a Stinger missile.
In that instance, Mr. Freeh said, the telephone networks involved were not advanced digital systems, but older analog networks that send voices as electronic patterns mimicking natural sound waves.
But he said there had already been hundreds of cases in which attempted F.B.I. wiretaps had been thwarted by new digital communications technology -- not, he said, because the suspected criminals were necessarily trying to evade detection, but simply because the public-network technology made it difficult for agents to listen.
Last year, a group called the Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility obtained Government documents through a Freedom of Information request indicating that an informal survey of F.B.I. offices in Newark, Philadelphia and Las Vegas, Nev., found no instances in recent years in which F.B.I. agents had encountered any technology-based problems in conducting wiretaps.
Asked about those findings, Mr. Freeh said he was not aware of them.
Several telephone industry executives who met with Mr. Freeh at the White House last week said that they were skeptical whether new legislation was needed and that they were concerned about provisions that would fine telephone companies up to $10,000 a day for failing to comply with the new law.
"This is just new faces giving the same pitch," said one telephone industry vice president who attended the meeting and who had been opposed to the Bush Administration's version of the legislation. He spoke on condition of anonymity.
Executives at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said they did not believe there were significant technological problems that warranted new legislation. They also said they feared that the proposed legislation would undercut the privacy expected by customers.
"Clearly the privacy concern is the biggest concern for A.T.& T.," a spokesman for the company, Herb Linnen, said. He said the company would continue to meet with the White House and Justice Department in an effort to narrow the bill. Industry executives and privacy advocates have also warned about abuses of new surveillance technologies by telephone company insiders and computer vandals.
But the F.B.I. Director said the protections in current analog telephone systems would be adequate to deter most break-ins.
"This is always a threat," Mr. Freeh said. "But it's de minimus if you consider the alternative, which is not giving law-enforcement and intelligence agencies these capabilities."
A White House official said that he believed opponents of the legislation were overreacting and that the law was a good compromise between privacy and law-enforcement needs.
"The authority to gather transactional information already exists; I don't think this expands that authority," said John Podesta, the White House staff secretary. "We're open to talking through the issue with the privacy community."

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
For Giuliani, the Message Is Making It on Your Own

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

 BODY:
Speaking at a junior high school in the bleak streets of Brownsville recently, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani gave a conservative twist to the words of John F. Kennedy to preach self-reliance to the students. They should, he said to an audience of black and Hispanic teen-agers, ask "not what somebody else can do for you but what you can do for yourselves."
And ever since that Brooklyn school visit, Mr. Giuliani has repeatedly used a naive question asked by one girl to build a morality tale of how students have unrealistic expectations of what government can, in fact, do for them. She had asked why there couldn't be scholarships granted irrespective of grades to allow people like her to go away to college. 
 "I thought it would be kind of useful, rather than kind of pandering to her, to get her ready for life," Mr. Giuliani said on WLIB, the black-oriented radio station. "She was a teen-ager already and I said, you know, that other people won't pay for you. I couldn't afford to go away to college when I was your age. I wanted to go away to college. My family couldn't afford it. So I went to college in New York City. I commuted and got a very good education." The Mayor then added that she could go to the City University.
Day after day, as he takes charge of the city and roams the radio dial, Mr. Giuliani has been spelling out his conservative social philosophy, political values and Horatio Alger belief in making it on your own in a harsh world and without a helping hand from government. "Government has a role," he says, but a far less expansive one than has been the norm in New York City.
 
Signature Issues
 Some of these views were clear in the mayoral race when Mr. Giuliani spoke of energizing the private sector and inveighed against crime and the "disorder that is driving this city down."
But once past his signature issues of crime and the economy, Mr. Giuliani was often unrevealing, with a campaign strategy to avoid mistakes and protect a lead. He highlighted endorsements from Democrats and Liberals to soften his Republicanism and ran biographical campaign commercials presenting him as a warm family man.
His one major foray into social policy -- a position paper on the homeless -- brought an outcry by advocacy groups with its call for a 90-day limit on shelter stays for all but the chronically homeless. The controversy forced Mr. Giuliani to be on the defensive, left explaining that he meant the time limit as a spur to government to find better solutions.
Two months into his mayoralty, Mr. Giuliani's reticence is gone. To the contrary, he seems to relish the chance to argue daily with the city's traditional liberal orthodoxy, often waxing his most adamantly conservative when being questioned by openly skeptical commentators on black-oriented radio programs.
 
'A Little Bit Beyond'
 Washing dishes 12 hours a day in a restaurant is "an honorable, decent, terrific thing to do," the Mayor says, and suggests that the squeegee men who wash windshields instead of holding a restaurant job are trying to avoid paying taxes. Of the high unemployment rate for youth, he says "there are also jobs that don't get filled at the same time there's unemployment, so you push yourself a little hard, and you push yourself a little bit beyond, you're going to find a job." Illegal aliens, he has noted, find jobs.
And speaking of the student who wanted government to provide scholarships not tied to grades, Mr. Giuliani said, "you've got to talk to that young lady about realism, not fantasy dreams, because one of the things government does, we can realistically help, we can't provide fantasies."
Philosophically, Mr. Giuliani's views resemble the neo-conservative critique of the welfare state as fostering dependency -- a philosophy embraced by the Reagan Administration, in which Mr. Giuliani served before becoming United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.
 
Help-Wanted Ads
 Democrats, too, starting with President Clinton and his pledge to "end welfare as we know it," inveigh against welfare these days. But there can be a sense of time warp to Mr. Giuliani's comments as if Washington's debate of a decade ago has now come to New York. "In fact, there was just an article in one of the papers on how there were more jobs available in certain areas than people who want to fill them," Mr. Giuliani said last week in an uncanny echo of President Ronald Reagan when he was asked about black unemployment in 1982 and pointed to the help-wanted ads in The Washington Post.
"I made it a point to count the pages of help-wanted ads," Mr. Reagan said at the time. "In this time of great unemployment there were 24 full pages of classified ads of employers looking for employees. What we need is to make more people qualified to go and apply for those jobs."
Those who know Mr. Giuliani call his views long held and heartfelt. And in politics, social policy is often born out of personal experience. When Mayor David N. Dinkins was pushing for a civilian complaint review board to oversee police conduct, he recalled that as a law student managing his father-in-law's liquor store, he was berated as a "nigger" by a police officer in upper Manhattan when he parked his car briefly in a bus stop after midnight to see his father-in-law at a nearby restaurant and assure him that he had deposited the night's receipts.
 
'I've Washed Dishes'
 Mr. Giuliani often harks back to his youth as he delivers his exhortations toward self-reliance. He repeatedly uses his life as the son of a middle-class tavern owner in the Long Island suburbs as a model for the down and out of the inner city, with no sense of dissonance in the comparisons. "I've washed dishes in restaurants," Mr. Giuliani explained in reference to his work in his father's taverns as he said squeegee men should find restaurant jobs.
"I wanted to go away to college and I couldn't afford it, so I went to college in New York City -- I commuted," he recalled as he talked about the student's dream to use college as a route to get out of Brooklyn.
"I didn't own my own textbooks -- I had to borrow them," he said recently, discussing current conditions in city schools.
Democrats concede that Mr. Giuliani is on popular political ground with such aphorisms, but say he is ignoring the harsher realities facing today's young people in the city. "Should we be having a continuing public dialogue about, say, 200 younger black men who should not be squeegeeing us?" asked Mark Green, the city's Public Advocate. "Or a dialogue about the army of 20,000 young minorities who want to work but can't find gainful work?"
It is not yet clear how Mr. Giuliani's views will move beyond oratory, and how extensively he plans to redesign social programs. Last week he named Joan Malin, a veteran of the Dinkins administration to run the city department overseeing the homeless shelters -- a department that Mr. Giuliani said during his campaign should be turned over to nonprofit groups. But he also appointed a former Republican-Conservative candidate for mayor, Diane McGrath-McKechnie, to run the agency that administers the city's anti-poverty grants.
Mr. Giuliani's advisers say they are now looking at a variety of initiatives that could be ready in about a month for moving the city's 1.1 million welfare recipients toward work. "To the extent we can change any policy to encourage self-reliance, we'll do it," said one of the Mayor's senior advisers.
In the case of welfare, the adviser said: "You've got to get training and have jobs, but you can't put all the emphasis on training. You get people a job and you've started them off on the right course."
Explaining his governing philosophy, Mr. Giuliani said last week, "Government has a role, and if we're able to achieve all of the reforms that we want to achieve, government will still have a role, an important one."
But he added: "The fact is if you look broadly in New York City, government has always answered the question of should government do it by answering it yes. What government should have done is occasionally answer it yes and more often answer it no."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Two months into his mayoralty, Rudolph W. Giuliani's reticence in confronting liberal politics is gone and he does not hesitate to spell out his conservative social philosophy and political values at stops throughout the city. He greeted people yesterday in a pizza parlor in Kew Gardens, Queens. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)(pg. B2)

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 541 words

HEADLINE: A Wrongheaded Amendment

 BODY:
When the Senate votes tomorrow on a constitutional amendment, proposed by Senator Paul Simon of Illinois, that would require Congress to balance the Federal budget, the outcome will be close. Such an amendment would be a political mistake. It would allow a mere 40 out of 100 senators and a similar minority in the House to block legislation that would create a deficit. And because the amendment includes no enforcement procedure, it would drag courts where they do not belong -- into routine budget disputes.
Fiddling with the Constitution could be defensible if a mighty public purpose were at stake. But Mr. Simon's amendment, and substitute versions also up for voting, would engrave into the Constitution a standard -- zero deficits -- that makes little economic sense. The deficit, as measured by Congress, takes no account of inflation, no account of growth, no account of recession and no account of the value of public investment. 
 Yes, the Federal deficit over the last 15 years has been too high. When the Government spends more than it taxes, it borrows the balance. Borrowing threatens to siphon money away from businesses that would have used it for plants and equipment. When this happens, the private economy is left less productive -- a blow to our children's living standards.
So Federal borrowing must be contained. But at what level? For several reasons the answer is not necessarily zero. Consider the impact of growth. As incomes rise, individuals can afford to carry more debt. At current growth rates, Congress can run deficits of about $200 billion and still keep the debt growing less quickly than incomes. Or consider the impact of inflation. Inflation eats away at the economic value of government bonds that individuals hold. At current rates of inflation, Congress could run a $100 billion deficit without raising the real value of the debt. The upshot is that $200 billion deficits are fiscally prudent.
But the biggest danger lurking in a balanced budget amendment has to do with the way Congress keeps its books. The Federal budget lumps together ordinary spending (for farm subsidies or administrative salaries) and long-term public investment (for mass transit or scientific research). Forced to cut out hundreds of billions from the deficit, Congress will be driven to eliminate big-ticket investments whose payoffs are far into the future and preserve lower-cost giveaways to politically powerful special interests. At risk will be spending on education, training and infrastructure.
The proposed amendment also poses a threat when the economy turns sour. During downturns, tax revenues fall off, sending the budget into deficit. Under the amendment, Congress would be required to cut spending and raise tax rates -- throwing the economy into a steeper tailspin. The only way out is for three-fifths of each house to suspend the amendment -- a vote that would be nearly impossible to achieve until the economy had slipped badly.
Though the 1993 budget law should keep deficits tame for now, they are expected to soar again by the end of the decade. But the villain is almost entirely health care costs. The answer to that is health care reform, not a destructive constitutional straitjacket.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
A New Ball Game

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
"The road to any solution in Bosnia now runs through Moscow." A senior diplomat here thus summed up the dramatically changed landscape faced by Western governments trying to design an end to the Bosnian conflict.
When Russia intervened two weeks ago, offering a hand to the Serbs, it became an essential player in the diplomatic game -- with President Boris Yeltsin personally involved. That sharply limits what the United States and the Europeans can do on their own. But it also offers an urgent opportunity for Russo-American action. 
 An example of the new restraints on the West is the outlook for further NATO air strike threats, like the one that helped move Serbian guns back from Sarajevo. Their purpose might be to end the Serbian shelling of other Bosnian Government enclaves, to reopen the Tuzla airport or to stop military traffic from Serbia and Croatia.
But now that Russia is involved, can such NATO air action be a serious possibility? NATO members are highly unlikely to want to risk an even more dangerous conflict. And threats that will not be carried out are worse than useless.
The irony is that, in the events of the last two weeks, the Serbs have ended up winners. The Bosnian Government hoped that it was finally getting a protective arm from NATO. But the symbolic protection that Russia has extended to the Serbs is more meaningful.
The changed situation most significantly affects the sine qua non of any overall peace settlement achieved by territorial division of Bosnia: getting the Serbs to withdraw from enough of the territory they have seized -- 70 percent of the country -- to make possible a viable if rump Bosnia.
The United States is now trying to broker a cease-fire between the Muslim-dominated Bosnian forces and the Croats -- and a political plan for a Bosnian-Croatian confederation. Those would be important steps if they actually worked -- though one has to be skeptical that they can after such brutality as the Croatian savaging of Muslim civilians in Mostar.
But if the Bosnian-Croatian plan does succeed, there will still be the terrible problem of the Bosnian Government enclaves in the east and west. No Bosnian state would be viable -- or its borders peaceful -- if some of its territory consisted of islands surrounded by hostile Serbian forces.
Diplomats have hoped that Bosnian Serb leaders would give up enough land to link the Government territories. But how can the Serbs be persuaded to do that if Russia is effectively protecting them from Western pressure?
The answer can now probably lie only in agreement between the Yeltsin Government and the West. And "the West" really means the United States, because Bosnia has shown again how dependent the Europeans are on American leadership.
It is a strange situation. Here is a Russian state in desperate economic and political trouble, its President unable to prevent a grant of amnesty to men who tried to overthrow him. Yet that Russia is in a position to help shape -- or block -- any resolution of the Bosnian conflict.
If there is to be a peace that has a chance of holding, Washington and Moscow have to agree broadly on the terms. Then the United States would have to sell them to the Bosnian Government, Russia to the Serbs.
Such a joint demarche is the new opportunity, and it is a serious one. In the past, Russian diplomats have been cooperative and well informed on the Bosnian situation. President Yeltsin's call for a Moscow conference on Bosnia, which has drawn a lukewarm Western response, might in fact have possibilities.
The risk is that domestic political pressure on Mr. Yeltsin -- from the rise of Slav nationalism -- may now make him lean too far toward the Serbs. But President Clinton would have some negotiating leverage to produce a modestly decent result for the Bosnian victims. Sanctions on Serbia are a powerful lever. And after the C.I.A. mole affair and Congressional anger at Russia, Mr. Yeltsin has reasons to want to look cooperative.
But there will be no chance of success unless President Clinton has a firm policy, knows his objectives and is personally committed to them. More of the wavering that marked his past positions on Bosnia -- the confusion between aggressors and victims, the empty postures -- would be fatal. The President faces a classic, difficult challenge in foreign policy. With attention and commitment, he can meet it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 5; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Delegates, Alas, Oversimplify Japan;
Tell It to the Jobless

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Big Trade Deficit With Japan: Some Think It's No Problem" (front page, Feb. 15) quotes Robert M. Solow of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology defending the proposition that the Japanese "may be giving American exporters a hard time, but the bilateral deficit is not evidence of it." However, neither you nor he explains why the laws of cause and effect are suspended in United States-Japanese trade relations. 
 Gary Saxonhouse of the University of Michigan is quoted stating that we run trade deficits simply because we consume more than we produce so long as foreigners are willing to finance the transactions. Neither you nor he explains why, during a period of constricting employment and declining living standards, our failure to produce domestically more of what we consume -- thereby employing more of our people -- is not troubling. Nor is our growing dependence on financing by foreigners mentioned.
Mr. Solow noted that he ran a "trade deficit" with his barber without ill effects and that his employer also ran a "trade deficit" with him -- buying his services without selling him anything in exchange -- without harm. This analogy is ludicrous.
Mr. Solow does not throw himself out of work when he goes to someone else to have his hair cut in the way Americans have been thrown out of work in many domestic industries while consumers had their hair cut elsewhere, so to speak. It's a wonder M.I.T. and the University of Michigan aren't driven to importing economists from Germany and Japan.
I am a criminal defense lawyer, not an economist, but I wish to reinject into the discussion what strikes me as self-evident: The lack of decent-paying work for our unskilled and semiskilled work force is a major cause of United States crime and social decay.
The bulk of my clientele falls into the chronically unemployed and the newly laid off or chronically underemployed. The gainfully employed mostly do not commit crimes. The remaining, and growing, portion, who are not securely employed or decently paid need solid factory jobs to work their way out of poverty, and those jobs don't exist anymore. Why? Because they've been moved to Taiwan, Singapore and, yes, Japan.
Now we cannot employ all our people at a living wage, and as a result, our nation is suffering a catastrophic decline in living standards with an unraveling of our social fabric. But your writer would have us believe we needn't worry about our $60 billion loss to Japan this year in unreciprocated trade. Do you think the rest of the country, being out of a job, has so lost its mind as to believe such rubbish?
 
PETER A. VANCE
San Diego, Feb. 15, 1994

HEADLINE: MUNICIPAL WORKERS;
Where Giuliani Is Aiming the Knife. . .

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has portrayed New York City's municipal work force as a wasteful, uncontrollable beast that has slowly strangled the economic life of the city.
 Enough! the Mayor declared as he presented his preliminary budget plan in early February, vowing to cut 15,000 jobs over the next year and a half. All that, he insists, without seriously disrupting essential services. (What services are essential remains to be defined.) 
Already, the Mayor has eliminated more than 4,000 positions, largely by not filling openings. By June, he hopes to cut 7,600 more with a severance package of cash and benefits.
 The details of that plan still have to be hammered out in negotiations with the municipal unions, beginning this week. Most of the other job cuts will come through attrition, if everything goes as planned. Otherwise, the Mayor says, layoffs will be needed. STEVEN LEE MYERS
Board of Education -- 88,883 Mr. Giuliani has no direct control, but has proposed a $291 million cut in the city's contribution and pressured the Schools Chancellor to cut nearly 2,500 administrators from the central office.
Police -- 36,824 Mr. Giuliani has proposed no reductions here. He says it would be "crazy" to cut the police force. Fire -- 12,425 No cuts are planned
Sanitation -- 10,937 The Mayor has cut 1,282 positions from Sanitation, and another 250 workers are targets under his severance plan. He says improvements in productivity make the jobs unnecessary.
Corrections -- 13,210 Nearly 1,000 positions have been lost, with severance planned for another 330.
 
Human Resources -- 30,071

 Includes 25,000 employees in Social Services, which administers services for the poor and faces some of the deepest cuts. About 1,000 jobs have been eliminated, and the Mayor hopes to eliminate at least 3,600 more through severance.
Health and Hospitals -- 48,429 The city contributes $278 million to the corporation's $3.2 billion budget, but the Mayor has little direct control over how it is spent. He has pressed the board to eliminate more than 1,100 administrative positions.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 18, 1994, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A chart on Feb. 28 examining New York's municipal work force, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's pro posed cuts in it, mislabeled one entry in a table showing employment per capita in selected categories in the nation's largest cities. The category in which New York has 6.8 workers per 1,000 population is public transit, not transportation.
